column1: Characterization of NiP layers and alternative coating systems as wear and corrosion protection on aluminum alloy castings ¤ Piston rings in exhaust gas turbochargers are currently manufactured from the high-temperature-resistant aluminum alloy EN AW 2618A. However, due to the reasons of wear and corrosion protection, these must be coated additionally in engines with low-pressure exhaust gas recirculation. The used nickel-phosphorus layers have a significant impact on the dynamic load-bearing capacity. The goal of this dissertation is therefore to first reproduce the loads of the piston ring in suitable tests and secondly to create a comparable data basis for various piston ring base materials and coatings. The loads of the piston ring are reproduced here in tensile fatigue tests, various corrosion tests, by cavitation and thermal aging. The investigated base materials are the currently used material EN AW 2618A and an alternative alloy AA 2055. As possible coatings, nickel-phosphorus layers and plasma-chemical aluminum oxide layers are investigated. In the comparison of the two base materials, it shows that the alternative material is superior to the currently used material in terms of dynamic load-bearing capacity and wear resistance. However, corrosion and aging resistance are lower. In the two coating variants, the nickel-phosphorus layers show the best variant in terms of wear and corrosion resistance. However, the lifespan of the layers is lower compared to the plasma-chemical aluminum oxide layers. By adjusting the nickel-phosphorus layers appropriately, the lifespan can be increased to a level significantly higher than that of the plasma-chemical aluminum oxide layers.

Competitor Relationship Management : Description, Explanation and Design of Relationships between Competitors ¤ Theoretical analysis of competition and competitor relationships -- Spectrum of competitive organizational forms -- Performance measurement in competitor relationships -- Competition costs and benefits -- Instruments for designing the relationship between competitors -- Designing the coupling of competitive and non-competitive relationships. . Oliver Neumann develops an innovative and comprehensive approach to cost- and benefit-oriented management of relationships between competitors. The author derives an innovative coordination model for competitor relationships based on existing governance and theory models and models types, structures, and courses of competition costs and benefits for the first time. The presented design approach includes both the perspective of a competitor and the perspective of organizers of competitions. It is shown how the intensity of relationships between competitors can be influenced by means of a configuration, interaction, and infrastructure management. The content Organizational theoretical analysis of competition and competitor relationships Spectrum of competitive organizational forms Performance measurement in competitor relationships Competition costs and benefits Instruments for designing the relationship between competitors Designing the coupling of competitive and non-competitive relationships The target groups Teaching and studying business administration with a focus on organization, strategic management, relationship management, and network management Professionals and executives involved in organized competitions The author Dr. Oliver Neumann graduated with Prof. Dr. Michael Reiss at the Chair of Organization at the University of Stuttgart.

National State Formation, War, and Consolidation of Democracy: Croatia, Serbia, and Montenegro ¤ Similar initial constellations -- Actor theories -- The type of institutionalization -- The influence of external factors -- The emergence of competitive-authoritarianism regimes -- The phase of democracy consolidation Filip Milacic develops mechanisms that reconstruct the causal influence of war on democracy consolidation and shows how national state formation and war have affected the democratization process in the states of Montenegro, Serbia, and Croatia. An investigation of the transformation processes and the hybrid regimes that emerged there, which sees the causes of success and failure in a given mixture of the three factors, has not been done before. This book contributes to the theorization of the connection between national state formation, war, and democracy. The content • Similar initial constellations • Actor theories • The type of institutionalization • The influence of external factors • The emergence of competitive-authoritarianism regimes • The phase of democracy consolidation The target groups • Lecturers and students of political science, history, and sociology • Practitioners in the fields of transitionology, consolidationology, and (east European) history The author Filip Milacic studied political science and east European history at the University of Heidelberg and was a fellow of the Friedrich-Ebert-Foundation at the Humboldt University in political science (supervisor Professor Wolfgang Merkel). He was a research assistant at the University of Montenegro and a columnist for several daily newspapers in Montenegro. He deals with the relationship between identity politics and democratic processes

Numerical and Experimental Investigation of Phase Change Materials for Reducing High Summer Room Temperatures ¤ Modern office architecture with rooms in lightweight construction and large transparent façade elements exacerbates the problem of summer overheating in buildings in conjunction with high internal loads. Phase change materials (PCM: phase change materials) offer an interesting opportunity to reduce summer overheating in buildings without elaborate equipment technology such as air conditioning. The thermal comfort in rooms equipped with a PCM paint can be significantly increased. The work investigates the application possibilities and optimization potential of a PCM paint on an experimental and numerical basis.

Integrated Usage Mining : A Method for Analyzing User Behavior in the Web ¤ How do users use websites? With established procedures, it has not been possible so far to find sufficiently detailed, objective, and representative answers to this. Kai Honsel closes this research gap with a new method: the integration of Web Usage Mining and Eye Tracking. In addition to the theory, the author describes the software-technical implementation and demonstrates the added value and efficiency of the procedure in a large-scale reference study.

Investigations on Structure-Activity Relationships and the Mechanism of Action of Melleolid Antibiotics ¤ Melleolides, secondary metabolites from representatives of the Armillaria genus of Basidiomycetes, possess high bioactivity. The underlying phytotoxic, antifungal, antibacterial, and cytotoxic mechanisms have never been investigated. This work deals with structure-activity relationships and mechanisms of action of selected melleolid antibiotics. The target for antifungal activity was identified using a chemically synthesized probe based on dehydroarmillylorsellinat (DAO) in the model organism A. nidulans. The fungal, eukaryotic elongation factor 2 (EF2) was found to be the target of DAO for antifungal activity and was confirmed by inhibition experiments with various yeasts using the known EF2 inhibitor sordarin as a reference substance. The mechanism of action of DAO could be transferred to further melleolides with a Δ2,4-unsaturated aldehyde in position C1. The assumption of different binding sites in the fungal EF2 protein could be simulated in silico at a model protein of the EF2 from A. nidulans, and thus a putative DAO binding site was identified. DAO interacts with human cells with 5-lipoxygenase, an enzyme of the inflammation cascade. By a Michael addition based on the Δ2,4-unsaturated aldehyde, DAO selectively and irreversibly binds to cysteine 159 (C159) at the entrance of the catalytic center of 5-LO, thereby reducing leukotriene biosynthesis. The observed rapid cytotoxicity of human cancer cells and monocytes is based on another mechanism. The covalent binding of DAO to the head group of phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) causes an induced cell death due to a reduction in cell membrane permeability. Necrotic and apoptotic effects are the consequence. In this work, three completely different mechanisms of action of Δ2,4-unsaturated melleolides could be identified.
Existence and uniqueness of certain automorphisms on K3 surfaces ¤ Supersingular K3 surface, automorphism, Salem number.

Adjoint Navier-Stokes methods for hydrodynamic shape optimisation ¤ To efficiently calculate the sensitivity derivative of hydrodynamic objective functionals with respect to the shape, the adjoint Navier-Stokes equations were derived analytically. Consistent adjoint discretisation schemes were developed term-wise from the primal finite-volume discretisation. The adjoint method, implemented in the framework of a general-purpose pressure-correction based RANS code for unstructured grids, was validated against analytical solutions and verified by means of the direct-differentiation method. The adjoint-based sensitivity derivative was computed to guide a manual re-design of a ship hull to improve the wake field. Moreover, automatic shape-optimisation runs were carried out to reduce the power loss for ducted flows.

Immunelectronmicroscopic Investigations of Lung Development with Epithelial and Mesenchymal Markers in Embryonic Chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) ¤ In the study, structural and functional aspects of the embryonic development of the gas exchange tissue of the avian lung (using the example of the chicken) were investigated. The structural changes and developmental processes occurring during this time were examined using light microscopy on semi-thin sections, transmission electron microscopy on ultra-thin sections, and scanning electron microscopy. The functional relationships were depicted in the transmission electron microscope using immunogold technique with the markers Anti-E-Cadherin, Anti-SOX2, Anti-alpha-smooth muscle actin and Anti-Laminin.

Criminal Compliance in Long-term Care Facilities : Concepts and Strategies for Avoiding Crimes against the Person ¤ Ziel einer verantwortungsbewussten Pflegeheimleitung muss es sein, strafrechtliche Risiken in der Einrichtung erkennen, bewerten und verhüten zu können. Ausgehend vom Recht auf gewaltfreie Pflege und kriminologischen Erklärungsansätzen für Gewaltursachen in Pflegeeinrichtungen dient dieses Werk mit Handbuchcharakter der Pflegepraxis als Diskussionsgrundlage, um die Chancen der Criminal Compliance in der stationären Altenpflege auszuloten. Die Befunde verdeutlichen, dass nicht nur Heimbewohner vor Übergriffen, sondern auch Pflegekräfte vor strafrechtlicher Verfolgung geschützt werden können und müssen. Das Kompendium beschränkt sich dabei bewusst auf Straftaten gegen die Person. Typische Strafbarkeitskonstellationen finden überwiegend unter Auswertung einschlägiger Rechtsprechung Erörterung. Innerbetriebliche Präventions- und Meldesysteme werden ebenso vorgestellt wie nationale und internationale Überwachungsregime, die zu Kontrollbesuchen in Pflegeeinrichtungen ermächtigt sind.

Corner Strength Optimized (Further) Development of a Process for Separating Ultra-Thin Glass ¤ The use of glasses, particularly ultra-thin glasses, is limited in numerous innovative applications due to their brittle fracture behavior. In the present work, a new, production-capable corner strength measurement process for ultra-thin glass samples is described, compared with established strength testing procedures and found to be suitable for use. In the further course of the work, a corner strength optimized notch and fracture process for ultra-thin glass is developed through the construction of new machine components using a large number of tested samples and advanced statistical methods. Furthermore, it is proven that the resulting strength can be predicted using a linear model if a cutting fluid is used. Based on a large number of tested samples, it is then demonstrated that the resulting strength follows a 3-parameter Weibull distribution and therefore has a strength threshold below which the fracture probability is negligible from an engineering perspective. This enables product designers to develop innovative products that are based on a reliably high strength of ultra-thin glass and thus significantly expand the application range of glasses.

The Agglomeration Areas in the Federal Republic of Germany: Development, Re-definition, and Regional Load Analysis ¤ Cliff's Notes: The development of agglomeration areas is of great importance for society and the state. The prerequisite for the development of spatial planning concepts and programs are in-depth knowledge of the causes and development trends of the agglomeration process. These are therefore at the center of the first part of the investigation. Subsequently, an attempt is made to lay the foundations for a multi-level model for evaluating the negative consequences of regional agglomeration processes. This includes a problem-oriented concept for re-defining the agglomeration areas as well as a specific instrumentarium for intraregional load analysis. Both models are checked using test calculations.

Person Identification by Witnesses in Criminal Proceedings: Requirements for the Proper Conduct of Recognition Procedures and Evaluation of the Evidence Value of Identification Performances under Special Consideration of Forensic Psychological and Criminological Aspects ¤ Misidentifications by witnesses account for a significant proportion of the total number of judicial errors in German criminal proceedings. How can misidentifications occur? -- The recognition of a person as a previously perceived perpetrator is subject to an extremely complex cognitive process. The identification performance of witnesses can be impaired by a series of psychologically investigated influencing factors and is extremely error-prone. Nevertheless, person identification by witnesses in criminal proceedings often has a guiding significance. -- Anja Hofmann shows that the inherently error-prone recognition of persons can be made significantly more reliable by observing certain methodological procedures. She demands with emphasis that those responsible give sufficient attention to these forensic psychological and criminological findings and incorporate corresponding methods into police and judicial practice. -- The author not only offers a compact information opportunity, but also makes a contribution to reducing the error sources in person recognition and thus to solving the associated procedural, forensic psychological, and criminological problems.

Evaluation of the utilization of Common Reed (Phragmites australis) for local livelihood, biomass production and wetland restoration in Inner Mongolia, China ¤ Schilf, China, Inner Mongolia, Wetland, Paper, Reed, Renewable Energy, Biomass, Paludiculture, Common reed, paludiculture, wetland, paper, pulp Wetlands are often considered as wastelands as they cannot be used as regular farmlands, for which they are usually drained to turn them into agricultural land. Such a limited perspective on wetlands overlooks the multiple ecosystem services that wetlands provide for humans and nature. Some of those services are the storage and purification of water, provision of food and raw materials, regulation of local climate and using as a habitat. Many of such services are provided by nature for ’free’ and therefore have no monetary value on traditional markets. In the case of China, wetlands cover 8% of the total area but are in a serious threatening situation through there is some success in restoring parts of them in recent years. In the last 50 years more than 20% of Chinese wetlands got lost due to pollution, water diversion and dams, reclamation, drainage and over-exploitation resouces. Water resources and wetlands −especially in North and North-East of China, are under pressure as these are arid or semi-arid regions. Yet, wetlands provide important ecosystem services for aforementioned region and contribute significantly to local livelihood in many ways, for instance the provision of food and raw materials. The aim of this thesis was to make an assessment- in both economic and ecologic terms, of Common Reed (Phragmites australis) at Lake Wuliangsuhai, where reed can be found in large amounts and is locally relevant. Reed was investigated at a case study in Inner Mongolia, China ...

School Policy in Cities with Student Decline: A Governance Analysis at the Example of Leipzig and Timişoara ¤ The Governance Approach as Analytical Perspective -- Historical-political Context of East Germany and Romania -- Dealing with Declining Student Numbers in Leipzig and Timişoara -- Governance Forms in Comparison -- Declining Student Numbers at the Interface of Education and Urban Policy. Anne Walde analyzes political negotiation processes in connection with declining student numbers in cities affected by demographic change and migration. At the example of Leipzig and the Romanian city of Timişoara, she examines the frequently controversially discussed decisions on school closures as well as the collision of opposing interests of parents, schools, politics, and administration. Using the Governance Perspective, the author shows that political decisions depend on the actors and their action possibilities against other actors and how this is presented in concrete terms on site. The Content The Governance Approach as Analytical Perspective Historical-political Context of East Germany and Romania Dealing with Declining Student Numbers in Leipzig and Timişoara Governance Forms in Comparison Declining Student Numbers at the Interface of Education and Urban Policy The Target Groups Researchers, Lecturers, and Students of Education Research, Educational and Political Science, Governance, and Urban Research Responsible in School Network and Urban Planning as well as in Local Politics and in Ministry of Education The Author Anne Walde is a scientific advisor at the Transfer Agency Middle Germany for Municipal Education Management of the German Youth Institute in Leipzig.

The Use of Unusable Random Discoveries for Evidence Purposes in the Investigative Procedure of Criminal Procedure ¤ The study considers the regulations in §§ 161 II 1, 477 II 2 StPO. These regulations only allow the use of accidental discoveries as evidence in an investigation process if the primary investigative measure could hypothetically be disposed of in the new investigation. The key question of this study is to what extent the prohibition on using accidental discovery for evidence influences the use of that information for compulsory measures like searches and pre-trial custody.As far as the accidental information may be considered to substantiate the suspicion of having committed a crime, it is necessary to take into account the higher interference of the compulsory measure with the constitutional rights.

Synthetic studies on Canangone and ß-Chamigrene ¤ The objective of this work was to synthesize the quaternary stereocenter containing spirocycles, (+)-Canangone and ß-Chamigrene. Michael acceptor was prepared in three steps. The Robinson annulation of enamino lactone and Michael acceptor followed by hydrolysis provided the spirolactone. Subsequent deprotection, Luche reduction and oxidation gave (R*,R*) Canangone and (5R*,6S*)-epi-Canangone. Following the same strategy, optically active (+)-Canangone and (-)-Canangone, and their epimers were synthesized. As a second target, the synthesis of ß-Chamigrene was attempted but unfortunately, attempts to synthesize the ß-Chamigrene precursor completely failed.An alternative route was proposed, in which ß-Chamigrene could be synthesized in only four steps. The Diels-Alder reaction of methyl vinyl ketone and isoprene gave acetyl cyclohexene and alkylation of this product using prenyl iodide provided the mono alkylated product but unfortunately, attempts to cyclize it failed completely to give the desired spirocyclic compound.

Titanocenes bridged by azines in the oxidation states II and III ¤ Im Rahmen dieser Doktorarbeit wurden die Reaktivitäten von Titanocenen der Oxidationsstufen II und III gegenüber aromatischen N-Heterozyklen, wie beispielsweise 4,4`-Azobis(pyridin) und 4,4`-Bipyridin untersucht. Als Ausgangsstoffe dienen Titanocen(II)acteylenkomplexe sowie das [Cp2Ti(III)(THF)2][B(Ph)4]. So konnten eine Reihe von ein- und zweikernigen bis hin zu multinuklearen Komplexen isoliert und charakterisiert werden. Im Speziellen führt die Verwendung von permethylierten bzw. tert.-butylsubstituierten Cyclopentadienylliganden am Titanocen(II) in Reaktion mit 4,4`-Azobis(pyridin) zur Bildung von molekularen Quadraten. Des Weiteren kann, als zusätzliches Beispiel, die Bildung eines Koordinationspolymers angeführt werden. Es bildet sich bei der Reaktion von Titanocen(III) mit 4,4`-Bipyridin. Ebenso wurden verschiedene fluoridverbrückte Titanocen(III)verbindungen isoliert und charakterisiert. Die Oxidation erfolgt hierbei durch die Umsetzung Titanocen(II)acetylenkomplexen mit fluoridhaltigen Ammoniumsalzen. <dt.> Within the scope of this thesis the reactivities of titanocenes in the oxidation state II and III with aromatic N-heterocycles like 4,4`-azobis(pyridine) and 4,4`bipyridine has been examined. Titanocene(II)acetylene complexes and the compound [Cp2Ti(III)(THF)2][B(Ph)4] are used as precursors. In such a way, a set of mono- and dinuclear up to multinuclear complexes has been synthesized and characterized. Especially, the reaction of titanocenes with permethylated and tert.-butylsubstituted cyclopentadienylligands with 4,4`-azobis(pyridine) lead to the formation of molecular squares. Furthermore, the formation of a coordination polymer can be alleged as a suplementary example. This polymer is formed through the reaction of titanocene(III) with 4,4`-bipyridine. Likewise, varoius fluorine bridged titanocene(III) complexes are obtained. Here, the oxidation ensues from the oxidation of titanocene(II)acetylene complexes with fluorine containing ammionium salts. <engl.> END

Impact of motif content on dynamic function of complex networks ¤ Network motif; Network analysis; Train transportation; Phase synchronization; Social networks; Motif theory; Null model This pattern of over- and underrepresentation of small subgraphs has become a standard method for characterizing complex networks and evaluating the influence of a mesoscopic organizational level on the function of a network. This work deals with a series of network-based systems with a focus on motifs. Initially, an analytical prediction of motif number and fluctuations is introduced. It is used to predict motif signatures arising from unusual graph properties. We also discuss artifacts that arise from discrepancies between the investigated network and its null model. In a model of social dynamics, we show that successful and unsuccessful agents systematically have different local motif neighborhoods. In co-authorship networks, we find that some are systematically more successful than others. Finally, we deal with the network of train connections. The most important result is a correlation between synchronization and delay propagation. This can be replicated in a simple avalanche model.

Light deflection in the post-linear gravitational field of bounded point-like masses ¤ This work deals with light deflection in the post-linear gravitational field of a system of two bound point masses. It is assumed that both the light source and the observer are located in the infinite in an asymptotically flat space. The equations of light propagation are explicitly integrated up to the order $G2̂/c4̂$. In the work, it is shown that the expression for light deflection calculated in this work agrees with the result of Kopeikin and Schäfer up to their calculated order. The expression for light deflection takes a particularly simple form when the unperturbed light beam propagates perpendicular to the orbital plane of a binary system, whose components have equal mass. The application of the calculated formulas for light deflection to the double pulsar PSR J0737-3039 under the assumption of a shock parameter five times greater than the distance between the components of the binary system shows that the corrections to an Epstein-Shapiro light deflection angle of $10{̂-6}$ arcsec lie between $10{̂-7}$ and $10{̂-8}$ arcsec. The corrections caused by the self-rotation impulses of the components of PSR J0737-3039 lie between $10{̂-8}$ and $10{̂-9}$ arcsec.

Methods of Action in Social Work: Development of an Integrative Model ¤ In this study, a scientifically founded method integration for the field of methods of action in social work is offered. Through the development of an "Integrative Model",

Synthesis and Functionalization of Carbo- and Heterocycles via Photocatalytic Transformations ¤ A catalyst transformation of a Grubbs catalyst to a photoredox catalyst Rutheniumtris-(2,2'-bipyridin) was developed, which was synthetically utilized in a sequential catalysis from a ring-closing metathesis and a 1,2-difunctionalization. Furthermore, the spirooxindole alkaloid Dioxyreserpin was functionalized at various positions and the obtained derivatives were investigated for their biological activity against various cancer cell lines.

Flexibilization of synchronization-defective supply chains: Design of a conceptual data model for logistics application systems exemplified by mechatronic products in the automotive industry ¤ The subject of this work are supply chains of mechatronic products in the automotive industry. In this case, it involves inter-company production structures, which have the task of providing mechatronic primary products, modules, and individual parts of high variety and different technology.

State Understanding and Enterprise Development: A Case Study of Chinese Printing Companies ¤ In this work, a method for a cross-cultural comparative study between China and the West was developed. This method allows for enterprise development in China to be understood from its own historical context, rather than just from a purely theoretical perspective. Since current scientific theories are mostly from Western culture and are connected with value judgments and terms from the Western cultural sphere, they must be considered in the historical context of the Western cultural sphere. In the first part of the work, the Western modern state is used as a research concept, its conditions of origin and its use and manner of use, particularly how it influences economic theory and practice in the West, with the modern state principle playing an important role. The New Institutional Economics serves as a theoretical framework for this work. Through a theoretical extension with the Western modern state understanding, important Western constitutional institutions are analyzed, as they influence the rights and obligations of citizens and the formation of the capitalist enterprise. In the second part of the work, the Chinese state understanding is analyzed – from the traditional „Tianxia“ to the „modern“ state. Using derived criteria, Chinese enterprise development is considered in three temporal cross-sectional phases, how Chinese companies develop from traditional to „modern“. As a case study, Chinese printing companies are used. First, the printing system and its changes in three time phases are considered. In this, the aspects of printing organization, state administration, such as censorship and copyright, as well as teaching material are focused on, which are important for the development of printing companies and represent a system. From a micro perspective, three printing companies are analyzed in the time phases. The result of the work is that conclusions are drawn, e.g. that modernization should be understood as actualization, but not as destruction.

Theoretical Investigation of Monovacancies in SiC Polytypes ¤ Within the framework of density functional theory (DFT), vacancies in group-IV semiconductors are investigated, where the exchange-correlation interaction of electrons is treated both in local density approximation (LDA) and local spin density approximation (LSDA). Structural effects such as atomic relaxations or symmetry-reducing Jahn-Teller distortions are considered on the basis of the Hellmann-Feynman theorem. In this case, ionic interactions are described by non-norm-conserving pseudopotentials. As a basis, plane waves are used. For modeling a single vacancy, the supercell method is applied with cells up to 216 atoms. The semiconductor materials Si, C, and SiC (cubic and hexagonal) are investigated. The results on the influence of vacancies on the atomic and electronic properties of these materials are compared with experimental data and other theoretical investigations.

On the vegetation density of xerothermic grasslands northwest of Halle/ Saale: methods of assessment, structural vegetation types, and the influence of vegetation density on the reproductive potential of xerothermic grassland species: with 25 tables in the text and on 3 supplements ¤ Betr. Untersuchungsraum Gimritzer Porphyrlandschaft zwischemn Lettin, Salzmünde, Mücheln, Lettewitz, Beidersee

Boosting Energy Efficiency in Automotive Manufacturing Factories ¤ Energy consumption in vehicle manufacturing -- Concept for energetic improvement of automobile factories -- Identification of energy-efficient processes -- Selection of measures and potential assessment. Patrick Dehning outlines a comprehensive concept for a continuous energetic improvement process in manufacturing companies in four steps. He makes internal knowledge usable and thus contributes to a reduction of the energy efficiency gap. Within the concept, the author identifies energy-efficient production processes through a statistical comparison on a workgroup level. In the second step, he makes existing ideas and

Localisation and tracking of people using distributed UWB sensors ¤ In many surveillance and rescue scenarios, the localization and tracking of people indoors without cooperation is required. For the detection of objects through walls at short to medium distances, the Ultra-Wideband (UWB) radar technology is promising due to its high temporal resolution and penetration capability. In this work, a process is presented with which people can be localized indoors using UWB sensors. It includes, in addition to the acquisition of measurement data, distance estimates, and the detection of multiple targets, also their location and tracking. Due to the weak reflection of people compared to the rest of the environment, a background subtraction method is used for person recognition first. Then, a constant false alarm rate method is applied for detection and distance estimation of people. For multiple target localization with a UWB sensor, an association method is developed to assign the target distance estimates to the correct targets. In scenarios with multiple targets, it can occur that a target closer to the sensor shades another. A concept for a distributed UWB sensor network is presented, in which the field of view of the system can be expanded by using multiple sensors with different fields of view. A prototype was developed, which enables the tracking of multiple targets in real-time through the fusion of sensor data. Synchronization and cooperation aspects play a particularly important role here. Sensor data can be disturbed by time delay and systematic errors. False measurements and noise in the measurements affect the accuracy of the estimator results. Further insights into the target states can be gained by using temporal information. A multiple target tracking system is developed based on the probability hypothesis density filter, and the differences in system performance are investigated with regard to the information provided by the sensors, i.e., the fusion of location information and the fusion of distance information. The information that a target should be detected when it is not recognized due to shading by other targets in the scenario is described as dynamic coverage probability. The dynamic coverage probability is integrated into the tracking system, which allows fewer sensors to be used while simultaneously improving the performance of the estimator in this scenario. When selecting and developing methods, the requirement for real-time application in unknown scenarios was taken into account. Each aspect of multiple person localization investigated in this work was verified using simulations and measurements in a realistic environment with UWB sensors.

High-Resolution X-Ray Polarimetry ¤ Within the scope of this work, precision polarimetry in the X-ray range was successfully developed and improved. By optimizing the crystal surface treatment and using multiple reflections at a Bragg angle of θB = 45°, the polarization purity of X-ray polarimeters was increased to δ0 = 2.4.10-10 at an energy of 6.5 keV [49]. The best polarization purity was determined with 6-reflection channel cuts. Increasing the number of reflections to 8 in the channel cut did not lead to further improvement of the polarization purity. Possible limitations for the best polarization purity achieved so far were determined to be, on the one hand, multiple scattering and, on the other hand, source divergence. The limitation due to source divergence could be overcome in the future by improvements in X-ray sources (XFEL, ESRF upgrade, Petra III upgrade) as well as by X-ray optics that improve beam divergence. The second limitation of polarization purity, the influence of multiple scattering, is determined by the rocking curve tails. It was found that the rocking curve tails do not correspond to the theoretical course of the dynamic theory. This well-known "Wing problem" was attempted to be solved by using industrially polished quasi-channel cut crystals. A quasi-channel cut polarimeter was developed and successfully tested for the use of silicon wafers. Investigations showed that no change in the rocking curve tails can be achieved by this means. The above-mentioned best value of polarization purity could be confirmed within the measurement error.

Constitutional and EU Law Frameworks for Charging Self-Generation with the EEG Levy ¤ With the EEG levy, the costs of renewable energy expansion were passed on to electricity consumers until 2023. Originally, the levy obligation was tied to electricity supply, so that self-generated electricity was not taken into account. The so-called self-consumption privilege was essentially abolished with the EEG 2014. However, various exceptions led to the fact that a large part of self-consumption quantities remained privileged. The work examines to what extent this patchwork of different regulations is due to the constitutional and EU law frameworks. In addition to a systematic collection of the statutory legal framework, an analysis is carried out to the extent to which constitutional and EU law restricts the legislative scope for state-initiated, but privately designed levy systems.

Kiel in the Weimar Republic : the urban development under the leadership of Willy Hahn ¤ This book deals with an important phase of change in the history of the city of Kiel at the beginning of the 20th century. In the center stands the architect and city building councillor Willy Hahn, who was elected as the first full-time >Technical City Councillor< of the city of Kiel in 1921 and determined the urban development and artistic design of this city for nine years. After the lost First World War, the city of Kiel, which had been oriented solely on armaments production up to then, faced the heavy task of developing an economic reconstruction program on a civilian foundation, which also required new urban development perspectives

D̲sr-s.t - Studies on the Small Temple of Medinet Habu ¤ The subject of the study is a small sanctuary on the west bank of Thebes, erected in the 18th dynasty by Hatshepsut and Thutmose III at the southern end of the Theban necropolis in the cult area of Medinet Habu: The so-called Small Temple of Medinet Habu bore, according to Egyptian sources, the name D̲sr-s.t and was dedicated to the ancient Egyptian god Amun-Re. The temple, largely preserved to this day, is the longest-used cult site in Medinet Habu. It is the oldest cult building for Amun-Re at this location and was significantly expanded by numerous additions from the time of its construction to the Roman imperial period. Medinet Habu and its cult buildings were investigated by the German architect and Egyptologist Uvo Hölscher for the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago in the first three decades of the last century. Following the archaeological fieldwork, a detailed evaluation of the excavation findings emerged, which was published in several volumes in the Oriental Institute Publications of the University of Chicago. Despite the excellently published findings, the Small Temple has never been the subject of a single study since Uvo Hölscher ...

Pharmacokinetics of Betamethasone and Triamcinolone Acetonide after intraarticular Application regarding doping relevance in horses ¤ Betamethasone, Triamcinolone Acetonide, Pharmacokinetics. - The objectives of the present work were the optimization and validation of an HPLC/MS/MS method for the quantitative analysis of betamethasone and triamcinolone acetonide from horse urine and plasma, as well as the determination of pharmacokinetic parameters by conducting studies on the pharmacokinetics after intraarticular administration of various corticosteroids in horses. On the current state of doping analysis, it should be checked whether detection times for the intraarticular application of glucocorticoids can be predicted. The presented analytical method consists of a wet-chemical sample preparation and subsequent analysis by HPLC/MS/MS. The validation was carried out in accordance with the parameters selectivity, linearity, detection limit, quantification limit, precision, accuracy, stability, and recovery. It was shown that the method meets all the set criteria and is therefore suitable. The detection limits are 0.004 ng/ml for betamethasone in urine and plasma. Triamcinolone acetonide can be detected with certainty up to a concentration of 0.008 ng/ml in plasma and 0.010 ng/ml in urine. In test series, betamethasone and triamcinolone acetonide were applied to horses and blood and urine samples were then taken, which were examined for the applied substance. In the first test series, the excretion behavior of betamethasone after intravenous application was investigated. In the further test series...

Change of Refractive Index by Ion Exchange in Structured Glass Components ¤ The material scientific fundamentals for the change of refractive index by ion exchange in a glass (FS21) structured according to a special process (photostructuring) have been created. The reduction of refractive index was favored and investigated in detail. By the subsequent processing of the glass with the technologies photostructuring and change of refractive index by ion exchange, the production of delicate light-conducting glass components is possible. From this, applications in microsystem or precision engineering can be explored. Possible are, for example, grippers and springs with integrated sensor function based on light conduction and the utilization of light conduction for special measurement tasks. - For the ion exchange, a salt melt with a composition of 100 % NaNO3 is used. A cost-effective experimental setup was developed and the process parameters were designed so that the ion exchange can be performed reproducibly and yet can be controlled by changing the ion exchange temperature and duration. - The work deals extensively with the diffusion profiles created by ion exchange in glass FS21 and their dependence on the ion exchange parameters. Theoretically expected relationships between diffusion coefficients and profile depths and ion exchange temperature and duration were found experimentally. In addition, special features in connection with the three ions Li+, Na+ and K+ present in the glass are addressed. - Mechanical compressive stresses due to ion exchange are demonstrated in specially designed ion exchange experiments and are described in more detail by measuring the difference in travel. - The expected change of refractive index is calculated in advance from the diffusion profiles (profiles of chemical composition). The comparison with measured refractive index profiles allows the interpretation of the mechanism of refractive index reduction. Similarly, the formation of refractive index profiles in dependence on ion exchange temperature and duration is also investigated. These results agree with those of the diffusion profiles. - Simple light-guiding elements were produced and in them the parameters light-guiding component cross-section, ion exchange temperature and duration were varied. The light intensity at the exit of these light-guiding elements is characterized with respect to the mentioned parameters and maxima are found. In U-shaped and light-guiding elements, the light-guiding function was demonstrated in principle experiments and thus hints at the possibilities of the geometric diversity of light-guiding components. The work can be a starting point for both application research and glass fundamentals research and contains corresponding proposals.

Investigations on Properties and Development of Formaldehyde-Free Chemical Copper Baths ¤ Chemical copper electrolytes without external current have a great importance in the metallization process in the printed circuit board industry. Almost exclusively formaldehyde-containing electrolytes are used. Despite the well-known environmental and health hazards of formaldehyde, these baths are successful, not least due to the good cost efficiency, the quality of the copper layers, and the simple and reliable handling. However, the increasingly stringent environmental guidelines require new perspectives in the field of chemical copper deposition. Many alternative reducing agents have already been described and investigated for the replacement of formaldehyde. Nevertheless, there is currently no formaldehyde-free chemical copper bath that is successfully used commercially. The reasons for this are mainly the narrow working ranges of the copper electrolytes, the inadequate coverage of the base materials, the incomplete reduction of the copper ions from the complex, and the deposition of very thin copper layers, as no autocatalytic deposition process is present. In addition, disturbing by-products and instabilities in the electrolyte can occur. Some of the alternatives to formaldehyde are also environmentally and health hazardous and are also very cost-intensive. In this work, environmentally friendly reducing agents are presented and checked with regard to their ability to perform autocatalytic copper deposition. A combination and variation of selected complex-forming agents with the respective reducing agents are carried out to investigate their suitability in the process of formaldehyde-free chemical copper deposition. Based on this, individual formaldehyde-free copper baths are developed. Through chemical and electrochemical investigations of both the bath components and during the deposition process, the formaldehyde-free copper electrolytes can be characterized and analyzed. Their mode of action and the properties of the copper layers are compared with formaldehyde-containing copper baths. The reducing agent glyoxylic acid is a suitable alternative for the formaldehyde-free autocatalytic copper deposition process due to its similar chemical properties to formaldehyde. Glyoxylic acid is not only usable with the existing activation methods, but also with many variable electrolyte components. The preferred complex-forming agents are HEDTA and Sorbit. Special electrolyte additives, in particular sodium hypophosphite, which supports the initial phase of copper deposition, enable the optimization of the glyoxylic acid-containing copper electrolytes with regard to the requirements to be achieved (e.g. high deposition rate).

Informiertes Wissen : A Sociology of Knowledge in a Computerized Society ¤ Through the massive use of new media in science and everyday life, knowledge about the correct information acquisition and use is gaining importance compared to knowledge content. At the same time, the use of new technologies changes the knowledge mediated by them. Nina Degele provides a captivating analysis of the societal upheaval triggered by the increasing dissemination of information and communication technologies. At the same time, she shows how knowledge will be managed, changed, and made effective in the future.

Calcium-regulated transcription in plant innate immunity : interplay between CAMTA3 and MAPKs and CDPKs ¤ CAMTA3 was shown to be rapidly phosphorylated after PAMP treatment. It interacts with the PAMP-responsive MAPKs, MPK3 and MPK6, in vivo. Mass spectrometry, following in vitro phosphorylation assays, identified multiple phospho-sites in CAMTA3 that are directly phosphorylated by MAPKs. In vivo, MAPK-mediated phosphorylation results in subcellular re-localization and proteasome-mediated degradation of CAMTA3. In parallel, the PAMP-activated CPK5, also interacts with CAMTA3 in vivo and also causes CAMTA3 phosphorylation at sites distinct from those targeted by MAPKs. However, in vitro phosphorylation assays did not support a direct phosphorylation of CAMTA3 by CPK5. The proposed working model is that at least two major PAMP-activated kinase pathways (i.e. MAPKs and CDPKs) converge on CAMTA3, where phosphorylation induces CAMTA3 subcellular re-localization and degradation. CAMTA3 is released from defense-related gene promoters and expression of downstream defense genes is de-repressed. This supports the negative role of CAMTA3 in plant innate immune pathways and a phosphorylation-dependent control of its function.

The Significance of Estates in Libraries - Illustrated by the Estate of Robert Michel and Ella Bergmann-Michel in the Library of the Sprengel Museum Hannover ¤ Written estates are collected and managed in German libraries in a long tradition. In the present bachelor's thesis, the peculiarity of written estates and the development of estate processing are explained. Initially, definitions of terms, significance, and developments in estate processing are presented to introduce the topic. The question of responsibility for taking over an estate and the related competence dispute is linked to the introductions. Subsequently, acquisition is addressed. The various acquisition methods are presented, and the possible legal problems in acquisition are shown. Estate processing is presented in terms of cancellation, ordering, indexing, and measures for preserving the collection. The topic of written estates is completed with aspects and questions of use. The theoretical treatise is followed by the documentation of the ordering and indexing of the photograph collection from the estate of Robert Michel and Ella Bergmann-Michel, which begins with the presentation of the artist couple and their estate. Then follows the explanation of the practical task in terms of objective, initial situation, preparation, and implementation. The documentation is completed with recommendations for the future processing of the photographs and the entire estate.

Finite element simulation for the cold-joining of high power connectors ¤ In the context of this work, a new method for describing massive copper cold-press contacts is developed. The calculation of press connections according to DIN 7190 is not applicable for the design of massive copper contacts, as high deformation rates and friction stresses occur during the joining process. The new model not only provides shortened and efficient design cycles for new high-performance contacts (HPC), but also deepens the understanding of the joining process and contact properties. After a brief motivation of the topic and an introduction to cold contact technology, the fundamentals of experimental work and simulation methods are worked out in Chapter 3. The challenges in modeling joining processes lie in material description and friction characterization. Therefore, the two topics are presented in two independent chapters, starting from the current state of the art to the validation of the developed methods and models. Chapter 4 deals with material description and includes two new methods for determining the flow properties of copper materials on a component level. The friction behavior in a pressing process is investigated in Chapter 5. A new test stand was set up to determine friction coefficients and describe the occurring wear mechanisms. Material description and friction characterization are closely linked. Therefore, both models were integrated into a finite element (FE) tool to be able to describe the complex interactions. Guidelines are developed and proposed for a precise but with as little effort as possible connected FE description of pressing processes. Based on the FE model, new high-current contacts are developed. The model was successfully validated and its validity impressively demonstrated by comparing the simulated and real properties.

Online Communication of Members of the German Bundestag: Politicians in the New Land ¤ With a complex statistical analysis strategy, Christoph Blank succeeds in explaining the selective political online communication behavior of members of the German Bundestag validly. At the same time, he expands the common member typologies from member sociology with his result. His research instrumentarium and his differentiated findings from a written survey of 208 MPs in 2009 offer themselves as a basis for special follow-up studies. "Self-marketing" is the primary motive of members of the German Bundestag when using digital political communication possibilities. One-way communication predominantly determines their network activities. Interaction and participation offers are offered to citizens rather rarely. The content Effect theses on the relevance of the internet in the parliamentary representation system Examples of political online communication between parliamentarians and citizens Model of influencing factors on the online media usage behavior of members of parliament Member typology in the use of digital communication channels The target groups Lecturers and students of Political Communication, Communication and Media Science, and Politics Science Politicians, communication consultants, politics consultants, campaigners, members of parliament The author Dr. Christoph Blank is Managing Partner of a communications agency and lecturer at the Heinrich-Heine-University Düsseldorf Effect theses on the relevance of the internet in the parliamentary representation system -- Examples of political online communication between parliamentarians and citizens -- Model of influencing factors on the online media usage behavior of members of parliament -- Member typology in the use of digital communication channels

Innovation and Cooperation : Organizing a Regional Network ¤ Cooperation has advanced to become the key concept of regional innovation capacity. But how can cooperation be initiated between regional organizations if they themselves do not recognize a reason for it? Traditional notions of

Band-Displaced Heterostructures for the Utilization of Hot Charge Carriers in Third-Generation Solar Cells ¤ The present work presents results of the experimental examination of the original concept for a hot charge carrier solar cell. The developed solar cell is intended to demonstrate an energy gain through photogenerated hot charge carriers and thus to show a new approach for the further development of more efficient solar cells. Two prototype structures based on Au:Zn/InP/PbSe/ZnO:Al and Ag/ZnTe/PbSe/ZnO:Al were manufactured using cost-effective technology processes. The band displacements and crystal structure in a novel heteroepitaxial ZnTe/PbSe structure were determined and published. The entire band arrangement of the two prototype cells was reconstructed and analyzed. Both prototype cells were characterized using both classical and a novel double-beam measurement method. In the second double heterostructure, a higher yield of hot charge carriers was found and justified. At the second prototype, under natural sunlight and at room temperature, a zero-voltage greater than the bandgap of the absorber was determined. This characteristic behavior for hot charge carrier solar cells was confirmed by further independent measurements. The unusual curves for the second solar cell prototype required a new interpretation of the dynamics of hot charge carriers based on kinetic transport theory and thermoelectricity theory. Both models were considered in terms of the previously known phenomena and presented in the present work.

Social Acceleration in Non-Western Societies: The Case Study of Iran ¤ This dissertation addresses the question of the establishment and development of modern social institutions in so-called non-Western societies. The Iranian society serves as the case study to paradigmatically represent the social, economic, and cultural conditions in a non-Western society. The work relies primarily on a historically-sociological perspective on Iran for empirical support. The theory of social acceleration serves as the theoretical foundation, and it is argued that the various types of functional mechanisms and potential connections of the motors of social acceleration lead to different accelerated social formations or social constellations. A detailed examination of the modes and motors of social acceleration, their functioning, and mutual connections forms the basis for understanding the problem of establishing an accelerating social formation in Iranian society. It is shown that, throughout the 20th century, the three motors of social acceleration in Iranian society consistently struggled with three corresponding problems: 'autocratic modernization measures (the economic motor)', 'uncompleted social differentiation (the structural motor)', and 'the promise of a closed utopian future (the cultural motor)'. END

Optimization of Complex Movement Patterns in Throwing Movements ¤ The maximization of the takeoff speed of the competition equipment and the target precision are of decisive importance for the success in the competition in sports games as well as in the athletic throwing disciplines. Although the training methods have been optimized in recent years, it remains the privilege of a few athletes to set the absolute top in this area. These differences in the quality of movement execution are largely individually determined on the basis of an individually optimally developed movement coordination. Since the classical, program-oriented technical training does not represent the desired solution path, an attempt was made in this volume to develop a system-dynamically oriented, differential training program, which, applied in a meaningful time frame, should bring about an improvement in movement coordination. By means of a processor-oriented research approach, the kinematic and electromyographic features were recorded within a one-year training study, where the system-dynamically oriented method proved to be more effective in contrast to the program-oriented training method

Investigation of Combustion Processes for Natural Gas and Biogas on the Example of Industrial Engines for Agricultural Use ¤ The work deals with a systematic investigation and evaluation of various internal combustion engine combustion processes with regard to the lowest pollutant emissions and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions based on a converted diesel engine for agricultural use. Starting from the stoichiometric energy conversion, the influence of a charge dilution by additional combustion air and exhaust gas recirculation is detailed analyzed. From the partial results, a motor concept is derived, which has significant advantages over the conventional diesel engine.

Hervey Bay - insights from numerical modelling into the hydrodynamics of an Australian subtropical bay ¤ Hervey Bay, a large coastal embayment situated off the central eastern coast of Australia, is a shallow tidal area, close to the continental shelf, that shows features of an inverse estuary, due to the high evaporation (approx. 2 m/year) and low precipitation (less than 1 m/year). Due to the high tidal range (> 3.5 m) the bay is considered as a vertically well-mixed system. Recent field measurements, but also the numerical simulations indicate a nearly persistent mean salinity gradient of 0.5 psu across the bay, with low salinities (35.5 psu) in the open ocean and peak values (> 39.0 psu) in the head water of the bay. The investigation further shows that wind forcing is the main driver for exchange processes within the bay. Due to a long-lasting drying trend along the east coast of Australia and a significant change in local climate, the frequency of hypersaline and inverse conditions has increased. Moreover, the salinity flux out of the bay has increased and the evaporation induced residual circulation has accelerated. <engl.>

Process as Form : Parametrics as Fundamental Functional Principle of Design ¤ The conditions of the digital present no longer allow for designing in rigid schemas and isolated individual considerations. The permanently changing contexts demand a fundamental adaptability of design, which can only be ensured through a holistic consideration of things in their contexts and a design thinking in changes - through parametrics. Fabian Kragenings indicates a paradigm shift, through which designers no longer design the concrete design, but the conditions of design itself: No longer closed products, but connectable processes are now given a form. Design; Process; Parametrics; Artificial Intelligence; Designing; Architecture; Culture

Investigations on Laser Beam Welding with Dynamic Polarization ¤ In the present work, the influence of a fast, spatially and temporally defined change (up to the kHz range) of the polarization state of CO2 laser radiation (Dynamic Polarization DP) on the dynamic processes in the interaction volume during CO2 laser beam welding is investigated. The implementation of this method is based on a special arrangement consisting of an interference laser radiation modulator (ILM-H) and a ? 2 -unit, which enables the generation of a beam with constant total power but temporally variable polarization state. By means of exemplary welding experiments on the materials Ck45, St37 and 22MnB5 (USIBOR) as well as on St37 under application of contrast materials with continuous powers up to about 3 kW, the expected DP effects were experimentally investigated and qualitatively explained by means of model-based assumptions and estimates. The arrangement of the ILM-H in double transmission used in this case is the basic prerequisite for DP, which is not realizable by means of other modulator types (e.g. electro- and acoustooptic modulators). The ILM-H is based on previous ILM models and was further developed in the framework of this work for powers in the multi-kW range. The characterization of the experimental behavior of the ILM-H shows that the beam splitting function for continuous (cw) powers up to 2 kW follows almost the theory of the ideal Fabry-Pérot interferometer.

Investigations on the Variability of Diatom Associations in Waters of Different Trophic Layers, as well as their Impact on Practiced Indication Utilization ¤ The focus of this work was the capture of the variability of diatom species compositions in the presediment of northern German lakes and their impact on the reconstruction of paleoenvironmental variables based on transfer functions. A distinction was made between spatial variability within and between lakes and temporal variability within a lake (seasonal and annual). Based on the results, new models could be developed, which led to a significant improvement in the prediction error of transfer functions.

Ruling through Prevention : A Critical Analysis of Burnout Prevention after Michel Foucault ¤ In view of the global crisis of mental health, it is essential to consider burnout prevention as a government problem and part of a prevention dispositif. From the perspective of governmentality, Jozef Zelinka shows how the prevention of mental disorders is used to secure the neoliberal performance society: subjects are pushed towards self-management by continuous risk pressure and risk calculation. The critical dispositif analysis makes these discursive, everyday practical, and above all material manifestations of prevention visible

Nonlinear dynamics in complex networks and modeling human dynamics ¤ Through large data sets, researchers can investigate the properties of complex systems, e.g. complex networks and human behavior dynamics. A large number of systems are represented as large and complex networks, e.g. the Internet, power grids, economic systems. More and more researchers have a great interest in the dynamics of complex networks. This work consists of the following three parts. The first part is a simple dynamic optimization coupling mechanism, but very effective. Through the mechanism, synchronization in complex networks with and without time delay can be realized, and the ability of synchronization of small-world and scale-free networks can be improved. In the second part, the enhancement of the robustness of scale-free networks in relation to the community structure is discussed. Some reaction patterns and topological communities are uniform. The results show a new aspect of the relationship between functions and network topology of complex networks. In the third part, which plays an important role in complex networks, the behavior dynamics of human communication is investigated through data and model analysis, and a new communication model is developed. With the help of an interaction priority-queue model, the new model can be explained. With the help of the model, many practical interaction systems can be explained, e.g. email and letters (or post). With my investigation, human behavior can be learned anew on the individual and network level. In the fourth part, I can prove that human comment behavior in online social systems, a different type of interaction dynamics of humans is non-Poisson and can be explained by the model. With the help of non-Poisson processes, the personal attraction model can be better understood. The results are helpful for learning the pattern of human behavior in online societies and the development of public opinion not only in virtual societies but also in real societies. At the end, it is about a prognosis of human dynamics and complex networks.

Series Investigation of Meat Ripening and Microbiological Status of Wild Boar Meat and Deer Meat ¤ Wild meat, Cooling, Microbiological Quality. - The quality of wild meat is largely determined by the circumstances during the shooting and care, as well as further by the handling during the entire ripening and storage period up to processing. The current EU food law stipulates that wild bodies of shot game must be cooled to not more than +7 ʿC within a reasonable period of time after shooting. In addition, meat from free-living game may only be brought into circulation if the wild body has been transported to a wild processing plant as soon as possible. In contrast to the previously existing law with precise time specifications, shot game could be stored in the deck at +7 ʿC for up to 9 days and at +1 ʿC for up to 17 days and transported to a wild processing plant, the current legislation lacks a definition of the requirement to be transported as soon as possible, thereby making interpretation more difficult. The present investigation should contribute to the elimination of uncertainties in connection with the interpretation of the new regulations by checking the development of the microflora under consideration of various cooling regimes. For the quality of wild meat, in addition to the microbiological status of freshly shot wild animals, the subsequent ripening processes are of great importance. Both aspects are determined by the post-mortem storage conditions. A good wild cooling should ensure high microbiological safety as well as the formation of...

Biofuel Policy in Germany: On the Discursive Construction of a Multiple Problem Solution ¤ Biofuels in Germany -- Interpretative Policy Analysis -- Discourse Coalitions -- Environmental, Agricultural, and Energy Policy -- Ecological Modernization -- Neoliberalization Biofuels have been promoted as a potential solution for a wide range of problems since the 1980s: from oil dependence to agricultural structural change and climate change. Against the backdrop of the German biofuel policy's sudden and sometimes contradictory course, Thomas Vogelpohl draws the societal construction of biofuels over the past thirty years and their reflection in political decisions discursively. He examines how biofuels have gained and maintained their status as a political solution option in Germany and how this complex social construction process can be understood in the context of historically specific political-institutional and paradigmatic framework conditions. The content Biofuels in Germany Interpretative Policy Analysis Discourse Coalitions Environmental, Agricultural, and Energy Policy Ecological Modernization Neoliberalization The target groups Lecturers and students of political science, sociology, and human geography Interested in biofuels from research and practice The author Dr. Thomas Vogelpohl is a research assistant at the Department of Policy Field Analysis & Environmental Policy at the FernUniversität in Hagen

Occurrence and Avoidance of Pathogenic Clostridia in Biogas Plant Substrates and Residues ¤ In the context of a plant screening, inputs and residues of various biogas plants were tested for the presence of pathogenic Clostridia. Independently of the operation mode and temperature, pathogenic Clostridia could be identified in input and residue samples. The sensitivity of spores of pathogenic Clostridia to high temperatures, depending on various residence times, was also tested in hygiene experiments. Spores of C. sporogenes and C. perfringens survive the standard hygiene temperature of 70 °C for at least ten hours.

Process Evaluation in Logistics: Key Performance Indicator-Based Analysis Methodology for Enhancing Logistics Competence ¤ The knowledge of weaknesses in the company's own logistics is the first step to unlocking new performance potential. In order to use specific logistics knowledge to initiate targeted process improvements, however, structured analyses are necessary that allow for a detailed evaluation of one's own logistics processes in the performance dimensions of time, quality, and cost on various process levels. Christian Büssow develops a multi-stage analysis methodology for continuous evaluation of the company's own logistics systems based on performance indicators. It is supported by partial results and individual instruments such as a logistics reference model with an extensive catalog of around 350 key performance indicators and allows adaptation to one's own framework conditions and objectives. The author presents a prototype of an internet-based application that captures key performance indicators, analyzes logistics processes, and assigns specific content to a knowledge platform for targeted process improvement of identified weaknesses.

Fluids in systems of natural rock composition at ultra-high pressure metamorphic conditions : an experimental approach ¤ This experimental study investigates fluids in natural rock compositions under UHP-metamorphic conditions. UHP fluids are quantified, their chemical composition and distribution on a grain scale are described, as well as conclusions regarding their properties under experimental conditions and their behavior upon cooling are drawn. Microstructures and phase parageneses are characterized in dependence on pressure, temperature, experimental time, water content, and rock type.

A Coffin Only and a Funeral Dress: Death and Dying in the 19th Century; On the Cultural and Devotional History of Catholicism in Southwest Germany ¤ A coffin only and a funeral dress, remains to you of all glory

Heterochromatic Gene Silencing and the Control of Pathogenicity of C. graminicola ¤ Colletotrichum graminicola; Pathogenität; Epigenetik; Heterochromatin; Histone methylation; DNA methylation; Heterochromatin Protein 1 (HP1) The filamentous ascomycete Colletotrichum graminicola is the causative agent of anthracnose leaf spot and stalk rot on corn. Epigenetic regulatory mechanisms for the formation of heterochromatin, such as H3K9 trimethylation (H3K9me3) or DNA methylation, have been poorly understood in this organism. Targeted knockout analyzes of putative histone and DNA methyltransferase genes reveal that these factors play a crucial role in the formation of heterochromatin in C. graminicola. The heterochromatin protein 1 (HP1) acts as an adapter between H3K9me3 and DNA methylation. Furthermore, it has been shown that this heterochromatin protein 1 is essential for the pathogenicity of the fungus. Colletotrichum graminicola; pathogenicity; epigenetic; heterochromatin; histone methylation; DNA methylation; heterochromatin protein 1 (HP1) END

Non-Instantaneous Polarization Dynamics in Dielectrics ¤ Frequenzabhängige Suszeptibilität, Dispersions-Scan-Verfahren, nichtlineare Antwortfunktion. - Frequency-dependent susceptibility, dispersion-scan, nonlinear response function

On the Principle of Business Continuation in Insolvency ¤ Insolvency and Continuation -- Insolvency Law and Insolvency Accounting -- The Continuation Assumption in Insolvency Accounting -- A Heuristic Solution to the Timing Problem -- The Summary of the Results. The evaluation of the principle of business continuation is considered one of the most difficult problem statements in accounting. As a fundamental principle, it has direct consequences for accounting in terms of basis, amount, and presentation. The determination of the point in time from which no longer bilaterally from the continuation principle can be departed is therefore of decisive importance. In addition, it must be examined when a revival of the continuation principle is required. Based on a normative research approach, Stefan Eickes penetrates this problem statement for the case of the insolvent company and shows which problems in particular need to be taken into account in determining the point in time. The Content The design of insolvency accounting under commercial law The distinction between prognosis of continued existence and continuation assumption The consideration of the point in time of the loss of the continuation assumption The consideration of the point in time of the revival of the continuation assumption The target groups Lecturers and students of business administration with a focus on accounting and auditing Practitioners in the field of accounting, auditors, insolvency administrators, and management consultants The author Dr. Stefan Eickes was promoted by Prof. Dr. Michael Olbrich at the Institute for Auditing (IWP) at the University of Saarland.

Complex structures, disorder and low dimensionality - treatment of oxides and semiconductors by a relativistic Korringa-Kohn-Rostoker Green function method ¤ The thesis describes the implementation of the fully-relativistic Korringa-Kohn-Rostoker Green function method within the full-potential approximation. In contrast to previous implementations the single-site scattering problem is obtained by a direct solution of a system of ordinary differential equations. The choice of this approach is motivated from an extensive numerical investigation of the problem. Furthermore, the relativistic KKR method is used to investigate the tuning of band inversion in Pb_xSn_(1-x)Te alloys. Additionally, a scalar relativistic approximation was applied to study the low temperature magnetostructure of PrMnO3 and CaMnO3. With the help of the Mathematica group theory package GTPack single Ho atoms on a Pt(111) surface are investigated within the framework of crystal field theory. Korringa-Kohn-Rostoker Green-Funktionsmethode; Dichtefunktionaltheorie; volles Zellpotential; Telluride; Manganate; Dirac-Gleichung; Streutheorie; Holmium; Kristallfeldtheorie; gewöhnliche Differentialgleichungen

Suspicion Work in Child Protection: A Profession-Oriented Comparative Study ¤ Tobias Franzheld provides an insight into current challenges of the German child protection system. Based on a comparative study, he presents relevant actors and their specific task priorities. Suspicion serves as a hinge to connect sociological reflections of professions, field-specific framework conditions, and professional peculiarities in a methodically controlled form to an integrative concept. The study closes the research gap of professional cross-comparisons and reconstructs interdisciplinary cooperation contexts that exemplify for representatives from medicine, police, and social work in the handling of child welfare endangerments and their new professional work requirements. The content The relationship work from the perspective of sociology of professions Child protection as a field of action and professional challenge Suspicion work at police, doctors, and social work Theoretical and empirical textures of suspicion work Target groups Teachers and students of social work, sociology, and social sciences Social work professionals, medicine, and police as well as sociologically interested individuals The author Tobias Franzheld is a research assistant at the Faculty of Human Sciences at the University of Kassel and coordinator of the DFG project „Knowledge Transfer in Child Protection“ at the universities of Kassel and Jena

The Promise of Mobile Freedom : A Cultural and Technological History of Car Radio, Walkman, and Mobile Phone ¤ Am Beginn des 21. Jahrhunderts fungieren MP3-Player, Handy oder Laptop als stete Begleiter des Menschen. Jedoch fanden bereits zuvor zahlreiche elektronische Geräte als "Portables" ihren mobilen Platz in Transport- und Kleidungstaschen oder direkt am Körper. Ihr ortsunabhängiger Gebrauch veränderte Vorstellungen über privat und öffentlich und Beziehungen zu Körper, Technik und Identität. Anhand der Produktkultur und Aneignungsgeschichte von Kofferradio, Kassettenrekorder, Walkman und Handy analysiert dieser Band die neuen Formen des Technikgebrauchs, des sozialen Miteinanders und der Mobilität und stellt damit die aktuelle Debatte um eine "mobile Revolution" erstmals in eine historische Perspektive.

Application of Adaptive Learning Procedures for the Regulation of Industrial Combustion Processes ¤ In this work, it is shown how adaptive learning process models can contribute to improving process management in large industrial combustion plants. To this end, the essential components of such a combustion process are presented, and it is explained why conventional control procedures (e.g. PID controllers) cannot or only inadequately control parts of this process. Learning models are essentially capable of ensuring better process management. It is also shown which problems standard learning procedures have with real process data. In the main part of the work, three improvement approaches are developed: The influence of noisy data on the learning process. In order to obtain good models despite such data, both noisy points (outliers) are removed from the data set and robust training procedures are used. The adaptation of a learning model to changes in the process over long periods of time. It is shown that adapting the model leads to advantages over a static model. On combustion data, the best results are achieved with the weighted combination of adaptive models in ensembles. The functional safety of the control strategy of a learning model. Learning standard procedures often fail due to the distribution of data in already regulated processes. To avoid such errors, several complementary approaches are developed. Significant is the integration of expert knowledge into the learning process. By comparing with existing data of the plant, knowledge can be specifically integrated for unknown areas and the reliability of learning controllers can be increased. The essential feature of this work compared to other works on learning process models lies in the immediate practical reference to combustion processes. The presented procedures were tested on various waste incineration plants and cement works over several weeks and months. Solutions are shown that enable learning systems to actively control control variables over long periods of time and thus achieve a significant improvement in process management.

Economic Problems of the Oil Conservation Policy in the USA ¤ This economic analysis of the conservation policy of the USA with regard to its oil economy asks: How is a production to be achieved at the lowest possible costs while avoiding overproduction, and how can it be ensured that production and consumption of the limited available and non-renewable reserves occur economically optimal over time?

Cosmopolitanism or Kingdom of God: The Moravian Brethren as a Global Community 1727 - 1857 ¤ Introduction. History beyond the nation-state ; Research status ; Community and society ; Source situation or : the Brüther community's handling of its own history -- Organization. The Brüther community as a pilgrim community ; The establishment of community sites ; Shared life rhythm ; Living for the Kingdom of God ; From charisma to institution : reorganizations after Zinzendorf's death ; Frameworks for global action ; The spread of the Kingdom of God -- Communication. Reports from the Kingdom of God : periodicals as a pietistic form of communication ; Global communication in the Brüther community ; World events in the Kingdom of God ; Further periodicals of the Brüther community -- Memory. The Brüther community as a narrative community ; Autobiographical writing as a social practice ; Autobiographical writing in Pietism ; Life stories in the Brüther community ; The memory of images -- Conclusion -- Overview of the worldwide settlements and mission stations 1727-1857

Conversion of Ethanol to Butanol on Heterogeneous Catalysts ¤ With an annual production of more than 3.6 million tons, n-Butanol (Butanol) is one of the most important commodities worldwide. It is produced on a large scale from propylene using the Oxo-Synthesis. In contrast, ethanol has a production volume of 85 million t/a, produced in the largest fermentation process in the world, cost-effective and available in large quantities. Due to dwindling fossil resources and the additional scarcity of propylene due to shale gas fracking, alternative production methods for butanol are becoming increasingly important. One of these methods is the Guerbet reaction, in which ethanol is condensed to butanol on heterogeneous catalysts. In this work, heterogeneous catalysts were developed for the discontinuous and continuous reaction guidance of the Guerbet reaction from ethanol to butanol.
