For this, hydroxyapatite (HAP), hydrotalcite (HT), magnesium oxide (MgO), and aluminum oxide (Al2O3) were intensively studied in the first place, following the results of screening experiments, under previously established standard conditions. HT (SBuOH=55-68%) and self-made MgO (SBuOH = 72%) achieved promising results. Subsequently, the carrier materials HAP, HT-Mg70, MgO-425°C, and Al2O3 were used to produce metal carrier catalysts, which were then comprehensively tested. The results of the experiments showed that higher yields and butanol selectivities can be achieved with small amounts of a metal compared to the pure carrier materials. Furthermore, the long-term stability of 1% Co/Al2O3 and 10% Ni/Al2O3 in repeated batches and in the Konti reactor was examined, which showed very good results with constant yields and selectivities in the Konti reactor for both catalysts. Consequently, an optimization was carried out with the catalyst systems, which particularly showed the large impact of catalyst reduction on the results of the reaction. Subsequently, the influence of various reaction parameters in the batch and Konti reactors on the reaction was studied to increase the yield and butanol selectivity. In addition, experiments on the mechanism and reaction network of the Guerbet reaction were also carried out, for which various intermediates, by-products, and butanol as educts were used in the batch reactor. The results of the experiments pointed to a multi-stage mechanism of the reaction from ethanol to butanol.

In-situ Measurement and Simulation of Liquid Phase Silicification ¤ Liquid phase infiltration of porous carbon preforms with silicon, commonly referred to as Liquid Silicon Infiltration (LSI), is one of the most economical technologies for the production of carbon fiber reinforced silicon carbide (C/SiC). Despite decades of research, the physical phenomena at the infiltration front are not yet sufficiently understood. Consequently, no mechanistic model exists that would help optimize the production process of C/SiC components. The present work aims to close the research gaps and provide a validated simulation model for process optimization. The work is divided into three parts, where the first part initially deals with the production methods of C/SiC components. Subsequently, the fundamental chemical and physical processes of the reaction of silicon and carbon to silicon carbide are explained. Following the current understanding of the infiltration of porous, carbon fiber reinforced carbon preforms (C/C preforms) with liquid silicon, the state of the art is dealt with the existing infiltration and diffusion models. The second part deals with a newly developed experimental setup for investigating the LSI process. This allows for in-situ observation during the infiltration of a glass carbon slit capillary with silicon. Originally, the experimental setup was intended to validate the recognized infiltration models based on the general capillary theory. However, the experiments showed that the infiltration kinetics fundamentally differs from the behavior predicted by the known infiltration models. Further investigations led to new findings that enabled the development of a mesoscopic model for predicting the actual infiltration behavior. With the infiltration and investigation of porous C/C materials, the application range of the infiltration model is extended to commercial C/C materials. The third and final part deals with the development of a numerical model for simulating the LSI process. For the first time, the reactive infiltration of porous C/C preforms was simulated in three dimensions and the model was validated with in-situ measurements. A newly developed infiltration equation and the introduction of a time-dependent diffusion coefficient led to a good agreement between simulation and measurement results as well as short calculation times even for complex components in industrial scale.

Photooxidation of Water on WO3(001) : a Combined Approach of Periodic Slab Calculations, Embedded Cluster Model, Artificial Intelligence, and Quantum Dynamics ¤ In this dissertation the photooxidation of water to WO3(001) was investigated. First the water splitting cycle was analysed with periodic slab models. From the resulting geometries a W12O36 cluster model could be evaluated, with which a three-dimensional potential surface could be calculated using the CASSCF method in the ground state and charge transfer state. These surfaces were then interpolated with a neural network optimised by a genetic algorithm. Finally, the photochemistry could be analysed in wave packet studies.

Rapidly Crystallizing Glass Rods for Laser Welding Applications ¤ In the field of sensorics, housings made of corundum or sapphire are used because they can withstand high mechanical stresses and can be used in extreme environments. To join these components, sealing materials are necessary that have a linear thermal expansion coefficient adapted to corundum or sapphire (a = 8.4×10-6 K-1) and can be used at temperatures up to 1100 °C. For this purpose, glass rods that crystallize during the joining process are suitable. The temperatures required by conventional joining methods, however, are not suitable for encapsulating temperature-sensitive components, as a short-term, local energy input into the joining zone is required. During a laser joining process, only the joining zone is heated for a short time, and the components are not destroyed. Available crystallizing glass rods still have a high proportion of glass phase after the laser joining process and thus do not achieve the desired operating temperatures of 1100 °C. Therefore, rapidly crystallizing glass rods are considered in this work, which meet the requirements of laser joining. For this purpose, glasses from the systems BaO-TiO2-SiO2 (Glass system A), CaO-Al2O3-SiO2 (Glass system B), and MgO-CaO-Al2O3-SiO2 (Glass system C) were selected, where the SiO2 concentration in systems B and C was kept low (≤ 20 mol%). To determine a suitable temperature-time profile for the laser joining process, the sintering and crystallization behavior was investigated using dynamic differential calorimetry (DSC) and heating microscopy (HSM). Subsequent to this, wetting and joining experiments were carried out using laser beams on various corundum and sapphire capillary tubes. It was shown that glass system A is not suitable for laser joining, as the crystallization rate of the stoichiometric composition is too high and a complete densification of the glass rod is not possible. By increasing the SiO2 content, the sintering behavior of the glass could be significantly improved. However, this increase leads to a decrease in the thermal expansion coefficient, resulting in a strong difference in the linear thermal expansion coefficients of the base material and the glass rod, leading to stress in the joining bond.

Nitrogen household during composting balances, contents, turnover-, and release processes ¤ Some N-compounds have a huge resource potential especially if used in agri- and horticulture culture for fertilization. On the other, N-compounds may also lead to strong negative environmental impacts. In the present book, the N-compounds as well as their behavior and changes during composting are described. On the basis of technical scale investigations N-turn-overs and -releases were determined and N-balances generated. Based on this, universally valid principles and models were formulated considering the depend-ency on influencing factors such as substrate composition, degradation stage, water content, pH-value, tem-perature, and gas composition. The occurring processes - ammonification, nitrification, denitrification, immobilisation - are described and discussed. The results allow the evaluation of composting in the context of the global N-household. They also can be used for the development of innovative processes, e.g. for fertilizer production from biowaste and for N-emissions minimisation strategies.

The Reliability of Notes to the Financial Statements in IFRS: A Theoretical and Empirical Analysis ¤ Appendix from theoretical, normative, and empirical perspectives -- Significance of the audit for the reliability of accounting information -- Importance of the appendix in the annual audit -- Reliability of notes to the financial statements -- Reliability in dependence on the disclosure location. Stefan R. Grabs shows that the reliability is particularly limited by subjective notes to the financial statements in the IFRS financial statements and that the audit in this case can only contribute to an increase to a limited extent. The author first considers the theoretical, normative, and empirical perspectives of the appendix and the audit with a focus on the concept of sufficient audit assurance. Within the framework of his own empirical study, the determinants of the maximum audit assurance of notes to the financial statements are shown, and the effect of the disclosure location (appendix or balance sheet/consolidated income statement) is also analyzed. The content Appendix from theoretical, normative, and empirical perspectives Significance of the audit for the reliability of accounting information Importance of the appendix in the annual audit Reliability of notes to the financial statements Reliability in dependence on the disclosure location The target groups Auditors and executives of standard-setting organizations The author Dr. Stefan R. Grabs completed his doctorate externally with Prof. Dr. Klaus Ruhnke in the field of corporate accounting and auditing at the FACTS Department of the Free University of Berlin.

Chemically Motivated Hubbard Models: Exact Diagonalization, Charge Transfer, and Local Approximation Methods ¤ Abstract: In this work, chemically specific Hubbard models are investigated. These models originate from the field of theoretical solid-state physics, where they serve to describe the electronic structure of strongly correlated solids. The model parameters required for this purpose are obtained directly from ab-initio calculations. For the solution of the electronic structure problem, the exact diagonalization method has been implemented and parallelized. Specifically, an electron-phonon coupling is introduced, symmetries are utilized, and approximation methods are developed. The approximations combine a local description of d-orbitals with a molecular orbital approach for s- and p-orbitals, delivering correlation energies with an error of a few per mille compared to the exact solution at significantly reduced computational time. With these methods, three problems have been investigated. Firstly, the effect of strong electron correlation on charge transfer in the Creutz-Taube cation and related systems is analyzed. For the iron porphyrin, a separate symmetry consideration was carried out, making the system calculable only with exact diagonalization. For one- and multi-cationic iron-sulfur clusters, the formation of local magnetic moments and the singlet-triplet splitting is investigated. In almost all cases, even strong approximations prove superior to a standard method (unrestricted Hartree-Fock and configuration interaction with single excitations).

Direct Synthesis of Doped Silicon-Germanium Alloy Crystals using Spark Plasma Sintering, Nutrient Synthesis, and Single Crystal Growth by Zone Melting ¤ Abstract: The central aspect of this work is the synthesis of doped, polycrystalline Silicon-Germanium alloy crystals (SiGe) using the Spark Plasma Sintering method, to make these available through a fast synthesis process for thermoelectrics. Highly doped SiGe alloy crystals can be used as high-temperature thermoelectrics that generate electrical current from a temperature difference using the Seebeck effect. Polycrystalline powders and samples for application were produced through melting processes with subsequent grinding or through mechanical alloying, where hot pressing was used for compaction. These processes are time-consuming and labor-intensive, whereas Spark Plasma Sintering as a current- and pressure-activated sintering process can have significant advantages on sintering temperature and duration as well as material properties due to the effects of the current. In the framework of this doctoral thesis, doped, polycrystalline Silicon-Germanium samples with 96 at% Si and 4 at% Ge as a cost-effective variant, as well as the composition with 80 at% Si and 20 at% Ge as the most efficient thermoelectric composition were synthesized. Classical elements such as B and P, as well as GaP and a combination of GaP and P were used as dopants. The synthesis of p-type Si0.96Ge0.04 alloy crystals proceeded largely successfully with the used temperature programs, so that comparable ZT values at room temperature could be obtained compared to samples from the literature, produced by arc synthesis. For the n-type material, the doping proved to be more difficult, so that for further syntheses a doping with SiP was pursued. In this way, for the Si0.80Ge0.20 material, carrier concentrations comparable to those of strongly phosphorus-doped samples from the literature could be generated through the small addition of SiP. For the p-type Si0.80Ge0.20 material, further optimization of homogeneity was carried out by determining the optimal synthesis temperature through calibration of the oven. This was necessary, as the temperature set on the SPS oven differs from the temperature in the sintering crucible. Building on the SPS synthesis, the crystallographic part consisted of nutrient synthesis for single crystal growth. This was carried out through direct syntheses un ...

Multivariate hydrometeorological extreme events and their impacts on vegetation : potential methods and applications ¤ Droughts and heatwaves affect our society and vegetation. Especially in the context of climate change, the impacts on vegetation are of particular importance. In the global carbon cycle, terrestrial ecosystems are normally carbon sinks, but can become carbon sources during and after climate extreme events. A crucial aspect here is the role of different plant species and vegetation types at various scales, which influence the impacts on the carbon cycle. Although physiological differences between different plant species suggest different reactions to extreme events, these differences have not been systematically evaluated and fully understood at the global level. Another aspect is that climate extreme events are naturally multivariate. For example, hot air can absorb more water than cold air. Extreme events with significant impacts have been frequent in the past, such as in Europe in 2003, Russia in 2012, or the USA in 2012. This multivariate nature of climate extremes requires a multivariate perspective on these events. So far, single variables are mostly used for the detection of extreme events and no covariation or non-linearity is considered. New generic workflows that consider such multivariate structures must be developed or transferred from other disciplines to provide us with a multivariate perspective on climate extremes. The overarching goal of the dissertation is to improve the recognition and understanding of climate extremes and their impacts on vegetation by enabling a broader multivariate perspective, which complements existing approaches to the detection of extreme events.

Solving regularized total least squares problems based on eigenproblems ¤ BEGIN In the first part of the thesis we review basic knowledge of regularized least squares problems and present a significant acceleration of an existing method for the solution of trust-region problems. In the second part we present the basic theory of total least squares (TLS) problems and give an overview of possible extensions. Regularization of TLS problems by truncation and bidiagonalization approaches are briefly covered. Several approaches for solving the Tikhonov TLS problem based on Newtons method are mentioned, which lead to a converging sequence of linear systems. The emphasis of the thesis is on quadratically constrained TLS (RTLS) problems. Two different iterative concepts for the solution of the first-order condition are analyzed. The first iteration results in a sequence of quadratic problems while the second concept leads to a sequence of linear eigenvalue problems. For a fixed point iteration based on quadratic eigenvalue problems, i.e. the RTLSQEP method, the global convergence to the RTLS solution is proven. With the characterization of the rightmost eigenvalue of the QEPs the RTLS solution can be described via a generalized trust-region problem. The second concept has been studied in detail as well, i.e. the RTLSEVP method. To ensure convergence it was necessary to generalize the function g. The properties of this function have been heavily analyzed, which lead to a deeper understanding of the RTLS solution: It can also be characterized via the solution of a TLS problem. The RTLSQEP and RTLSEVP algorithm for solving the RTLS problem are shown to be very efficient when combined with iterative projection methods in the inner loop. Since a sequence of convergent problems has to be solved it turns out that the Nonlinear Arnoldi method is the method of choice, because it is able to recycle most of the information during the iterative process. The computational complexity of the proposed approaches is kept at the order of matrix-vector multiplications. We give a detailed description of an efficient implementation of the different parts of the algorithms. Two efficient algorithms for evaluating the L-curve at discrete points are presented. Since setting up the L-curve requires solving a sequence of RTLS problems the advantage of the Nonlinear Arnoldi method is even more apparent: Recycling the search space, not only within one RTLS problem but throughout the whole sequence. END

Surface-Active Molecules for the Control of Surface Properties ¤ A fundamental understanding of the self-organization of surface-active molecules at the air-water interface is a necessary prerequisite to achieve a targeted control and application-oriented optimization of interfacial and surface properties. The present dissertation deals with systematic investigations of the surface activity of various amphiphilic substance systems (p-Terphenyl derivatives, 1-Acyl-1,2,4-triazoles) in the form of Langmuir films and Langmuir-Blodgett films, in order to clarify the behavior of surface-active molecules at the air-water interface. In addition to these basic investigations, practical investigations on the control of surface properties are carried out within the framework of an industrial research project on the optimization of nitrogen-sulfur fertilizer granules. In this context, the 1-Acyl-1,2,4-triazoles are used as nitrification inhibitors in a technical application example. surface-active molecules; Langmuir films; Langmuir-Blodgett films; collapse mechanism; Brewster angle microscopy; atomic force microscopy; p-terphenyl derivatives; 1-acyl-1,2,4-triazoles; N/S fertilizer granules; nitrification inhibitor
The Conjecture of the Organism : Probabilistic Thinking and Performance in Late 18th Century ¤ Note International Hölderlin Bibliography: pp. 341-426: Organisation des Aorgischen: Hölderlin's Poetics

Customer-Individual Mass Production: Development, Production Preparation, Change Management ¤ In order to be able to react individually to customer wishes even in series production, special requirements must be placed on development management and production preparation. Taking into account the special challenges of development processes with regard to interdisciplinarity and product complexity, mechatronic systems are used as an example. The book can be used as a guide for action for designing development processes in individualized series production. The methods and tool deployment for the treated examples are described. TOC:Introduction: Is individuality standardizable?.- The competitive strategic orientation as a customer-individual mass producer.- The application field "mechatronic products".- Development of customer-individual mass products.- Preparation of production of customer-individual mass products.- Change management to the customer-individual mass producer.- Summary.- Bibliography.-

Pore water biogeochemistry and trace metal dynamics in deep intertidal flat sediments ¤ Biogeochemical processes were studied in deep pore waters at different locations in the backbarrier area of Spiekeroog Island, Germany. A multilevel in situ pore water sampler was developed, which allows pore water sampling down to 5 m sediment depth. Sulphate, DOC, and nutrients were studied for the identification of organic matter remineralization pathways. Differences in sediment structure and hydrological conditions explain spatial variations in pore water depth profiles of margins compared to central parts of tidal flats as well as of sand and mixed flats. The deep pore water studies illustrate that seasonal variations of sulphate, DOC, and nutrients are not limited to the sediment surface. Seasonal variations of Mn, Fe, Mo, and U are by contrast limited to the upper decimetres of the sediment. Close to the tidal flat margin pore waters originating from some metres depth presumably escape at tidal flat margins at low tide thus representing a source for the ecosystem in the open water column. <engl.> END

Violence in Video Games: Facets of a Pleasure ¤ Grand Theft Auto, Battlefield, Counter-Strike - Violence in video games is repeatedly controversially discussed. But what emotional experiences does the playful handling of virtual violence enable? Through participatory observations in online games and at LAN parties as well as with the help of interview, magazine, and video analyses, Christoph Bareither works out how millions of people can experience something as enjoyable that shocks others. Without resorting to value-laden clichés, the ethnographic study thus makes a decisive contribution to a debate at the intersection of popular culture, politics, and public discourse Grand Theft Auto, Battlefield, Counter-Strike - Violence in video games is repeatedly controversially discussed. But what emotional experiences does the playful handling of virtual violence enable? Through participatory observations in online games and at LAN parties as well as with the help of interview, magazine, and video analyses, Christoph Bareither works out how millions of people can experience something as enjoyable that shocks others. Without resorting to value-laden clichés, the ethnographic study thus makes a decisive contribution to a debate at the intersection of popular culture, politics, and public discourse.

Strolling in ArCAADia : digital architecture visualizations - Analysis of an overlooked image genre ¤ Today, primarily, the communication of large construction projects is carried out through computer-generated architecture visualizations. On a stroll through the digital "ArCAADia", policies for space are observed, which in current urban planning and urban policy as well as architectural planning find their real counterparts.

The Europeanization of Energy and Climate Protection Policy in North Rhine-Westphalia: The Government Period of CDU/FDP from 2005 to 2010 ¤ In the present case study, Simon Wiegand examines the positions, influence strategies, and functions of the state government and state parliamentary groups in North Rhine-Westphalia in the policy process for the

Intervention Scenarios of Dementia Care: A Health Economic Modelling of the Cost- and Benefit Effects of Selected Intervention Concepts ¤ Dementia, Health Economics, Intervention, Modelling, Scenario Dementia is a challenge for many societies, especially in the light of demographic transition processes. This fact requires innovative care strategies. There are some public and academic proposals for dementia interventions, but a health economic study on costs and benefits has been missing, yet. This research paper investigates the economic impact of different intervention scenarios. For this purpose a markov modelling study was conducted that analyses different costs and benefits of interventions taking account of several perspectives (statutory health insurance, statutory care insurance, patients and caregivers) and care settings (home, group living, nursing home). The analyses show that some interventions could be efficient from societal perspective. However, certain interventions lead on to financial transfers between involved payers. The implementation of efficient interventions makes several structural changes in health care financing necessary.

Toxicological and immunological effects of DON and LPS at the intestinal barrier ¤ DON, LPS, Ussing-Chamber-Technique. - The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of DON-containing feed administered in vivo, directly applied DON in vitro, and in vivo intraperitoneally administered LPS on short-circuit currents and tissue conductance in the small intestine of growing pigs. In addition, in vitro measurements of DON transport across the intestinal epithelium were performed and an assessment of the immunological effects of DON and LPS was made by quantifying the stimulation of cytokine secretion in vivo. The study was conducted in two series. In the first series, sections from the duodenum, the middle jejunum, and the ileum of six pigs were used to investigate the in vitro effects of DON in various concentrations on short-circuit currents and tissue conductance of the intestinal epithelium in the presence and absence of alanine and glucose using the Ussing-Chamber-Technique. The results showed that DON in various concentrations affected short-circuit currents and tissue conductance of the intestinal epithelium. In addition, a significant stimulation of cytokine secretion in vivo was observed. In the second series, the in vitro effects of LPS on short-circuit currents and tissue conductance of the intestinal epithelium were investigated. The results showed that LPS in various concentrations affected short-circuit currents and tissue conductance of the intestinal epithelium. In addition, a significant stimulation of cytokine secretion in vivo was observed. The results of this study show that DON and LPS can affect intestinal barrier functions in various concentrations. This has important implications for the evaluation of the safety of feed and the development of strategies to reduce the effects of DON and LPS on the health of pigs.

The PEP-Carboxylase in Poplars: Identification of the PEPC Gene Family and Overexpression in Populus x canescens ¤ Zusammenfassung: Short rotation coppices with fast growing tree species are expected to be planted more widely in the future to meet the growing demand for wood as renewable energy source. However, especially poplar trees are known to emit large amounts of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) like isoprene, which can effect the atmosphere chemistry of the troposphere in a negative way. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase (PEPC) is an anaplerotic enzyme positioned at a metabolic crossing point between C- and N-metabolism of plant cells. It has been discussed that PEPC might also be involved in the regulation of the isoprene emission of plants. Both, the PEPC reaction and isoprene biosynthesis are dependend on the supply of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) as a substrate, which led to the postulation of a competition for cytosolic PEP reserves between both processes. Thus, a stronger expression of PEPC should result in a reduction of isoprene emission and in an increase of amino acid synthesis and other parts of anabolic metabolism. PEPC is encoded by a gene family in plants but so far little is known about PEPC genes in poplar or other tree species. The aim of this study was to fill this gap by using two different approaches. One approach was to identify the PEPC gene family in poplar and to characterise the constituent genes by tissue specific and seasonal gene expression analyses. The other approach was supposed to create transgenic Grey Poplar plants (Populus x canescens) overexpressing a C3-PEPC gene from Flaveria trinervia. Three transgenic lines (13, 23, 25) were selected and investigated in terms of PEPC activity, biomass and gas exchange parameters, water balance, metabolites and isoprene emission. Furthermore, these lines were tested under drought stress conditions. Five PEPC genes were identified in Populus trichocarpa: Pt-PEPC.1, Pt-PEPC.2 and Pt-PEPC.3 represented typical plant type PEPCs, while Pt-PEPC.4 and Pt-PEPC.5 belonged to the so called bacterial type PEPCs. The gene pairs Pt-PEPC.1 and 2 as well as Pt-PEPC.4 and 5 exhibited very high identity rates of over 93 % to each other, while Pt-PEPC.3 grouped independently of both pairs. All essential amino acid residues were highly conserved. The C-terminal region of each gene was cloned and sequenced for Populus x canescens. Based on these sequence information, qPCR primers for gene expression analyses in Populus x cancescens were designed. The genes Pc-PEPC.2 and especially Pc-PEPC.1 were expressed most ...

Calculation of Selected Quality Parameters of Electrical Energy as Planning Basis for Electrical Energy Supply Systems ¤ To ensure conformity in electrical energy supply systems, it is necessary to include electrical energy quality in the planning process of networks and facilities. The quality parameters of electrical energy must be economically determinable by suitable calculation programs. The necessary requirements for such a calculation program, the required mathematical procedures, as well as the modeling of the operating materials of the networks and the consumers are derived and implemented in the SALOMON program system. In addition, methodological guidelines are given that allow for efficient use of the program technology, but also ensure that the accuracy requirements for determining the electrical energy quality parameters are fully met. With three case studies, it is shown how investigations for the evaluation of electrical energy quality should be carried out during the planning of electrical engineering facilities and networks, and how the SALOMON program system can be used appropriately in this context.

Method for Evaluating the Fatigue Strength of Systems Subject to Long-Term Friction Loads ¤ Wear-out failure-prone applications -- Tribological systematics -- Calculation approaches for strength evaluation -- Universal test procedure -- Computational strength proof. The author analyzes wear-out fatigue as a combined tribo-mechanical damage phenomenon and develops a method for strength evaluation of systems subject to long-term friction loads based on this. In doing so, he extends the FKM proof and uses a universal test procedure to determine the required key values, the tribological roughness factors, experimentally depending on the most important system parameters. This achieves a significant improvement in failure prediction compared to the classical approach. Content Wear-out failure-prone applications Tribological systematics Calculation approaches for strength evaluation Universal test procedure Computational strength proof Target groups Lecturers and students of mechanical engineering, automotive technology, aerospace, and materials science Practitioners in automotive and drive technology as well as aerospace The author Jakub Vidner was a scholarship holder and scientific assistant at the Chair of Construction Theory at the Technical University of Chemnitz with research focuses on wear-out fatigue, vibration wear, and adhesion. Since 2013, he has been a product manager for operational strength and vehicle dynamics at a renowned company for measurement technology.

The modern portfolio theory applied to wind farm investments ¤ In a context of research of alternatives to improve investments in renewable energy sources, this work addresses the Modern Portfolio Theory when applied to investments in wind farms. The Modern Portfolio Theory describes how the combination of assets subject to different characteristics of risk x return leads to optimized portfolios of investments. Grounded on the principles of diversification, the theory has been originally developed to assess investments in financial assets. In view of the intrinsic differences between financial assets and a physical asset such as a wind farm, this work investigates the limits of a theory developed to manage risk in securities when applied to wind farm investments. <engl.>

The Orient Journey of Kaiser Wilhelm II. 1898: A Study on German Foreign Policy at the Turn of the 20th Century ¤ Cliff Notes: In the autumn of 1898, Wilhelm II traveled to the Orient. He wanted - as officially announced - to visit the Holy Land as a devout pilgrim and be present at the inauguration of the Jerusalem Redeemer Church. However, the imperial journey to the East was more than a devout pilgrimage. At the Sultan, Wilhelm II advocated for the construction of the Baghdad Railway, as a

Contributions to the Development of a Driver Assistance System for Parking Maneuvers ¤ This contribution documents the further development of the standard parking aid (obstacle warning) to a semi-autonomous (lat. partially self-contained) parking assistant. In this assistance function, tasks are largely automated during parking; however, the driver's involvement is deliberately not dispensed with. Thus, man is not only a user and operator, but also a system component with its own sensors and actuators as an integrated part. The current development of driver assistance systems shows that new functions can only be successfully established if the relationship between man and machine and the required interfaces are taken into account during development. Accordingly, the challenge in system design is to identify the needs of the driver and support him by taking over partial tasks. The process from the idea to the first use of the product prototype in test drives is described. Based on a parking study, the concrete requirements were recorded on the basis of the desired assistance by the drivers as user requirements. This made it possible to concentrate the development work on the driver's needs. In the requirements analysis, the results of a study on parking behavior are discussed, which includes user surveys, observation, and parking statistics. From the functional design, the components (operating principles and solution elements) were derived. The functional design provides for the environment detection using ultrasonic sensors and the position determination by internal vehicle sensors. Two different system designs are discussed: In the first variant, the driver is provided with information via a suitable man-machine interface on how to steer and drive in order to optimally (subjectively easier for the driver) enter the parking space. In the second variant, steering is automatically performed using an electromechanical steering system (Electric Power Steering), and the driver is only responsible for longitudinal guidance. Alternatives for calculating the parking trajectory, experiences in designing the man-machine interface, and lane-following control concepts are presented for the variants. After the implementation of the planned system, it is again up to the drivers to uncover defects and errors in the use of the system and to evaluate the expected acceptance. For this purpose, user tests were carried out with the system prototypes. The results show a high validity due to the high reality factor and the immediate experience. In this targeted approach, therefore, a driver-centered development is spoken of.

Continuous mixing of silica based rubber/filler-composites in twin screw extruder ¤ Manufacturing processes of rubber compounds for tire components significantly affect the performance and quality of tires. One of the standard processes is the mixing of silica with organosilane and rubber in an internal mixer. Due to the chemical reaction between silica and organosilane, the process typically involves several stages and is particularly time-consuming. By using rubber/filler composites (RFC) with silica and continuous mixing process, mixing time and mixing energy can be significantly reduced. This work describes the principles of continuous mixing based on experiments in a twin screw extruder. It investigates the mixing of RFC based on E-SBR/silica/silan, S-SBR/silica/silan, and BR/silica/silan together with cross-linking chemicals. It shows the relationships between process parameters such as screw geometry, dosing construction, screw speed, throughput, and filler content and mixing and vulcanization properties (e.g. filler-filler interaction, tensile strength, and wear). Finally, investigations from mixing experiments in a twin screw extruder in combination with a transfermix extruder and gear pump are presented. The summarized results of this work show that the continuous mixing process is a suitable and advantageous technology for the production of silica-filled rubber compounds and rubber blends. Optimization of screw geometry and process parameters is necessary. Under these conditions, the continuous mixing process can be realized as a one-stage or two-stage process. Rubber compound; continuous mixing; twin screw extruder; transfermix extruder; gear pump; Rubber/Filler-Composites; rubber blend.

Emergent electrodynamics in non-collinear spin textures : [cumulative Dissertation] ¤ Festkörperphysik; Magnetismus; nicht-kollineare Spintextur; Skyrmion; Hall-Effekt; Topologie; Spintronik; elektronischer Transport; Spindynamik; Datenspeicher Solid state physics; Magnetism; Non-collinear spin texture; Skyrmion; Hall effect; Topology; Spintronics; Electronic transport; Spin dynamics; Data storage device This cumulative thesis reports on the theoretical investigation of the coupling of electrons and non-collinear spin textures like magnetic skyrmions – small, whirl-like modulations of the ferromagnetic phase. Using micromagnetic spin dynamics simulations, Monte Carlo simulations and effective equations of motion, an optimization of the skyrmion-based racetrack data storage device is proposed. Here, spin-orbit torques are manipulated to suppress the skyrmion Hall effect. Moreover, the existence of individual biskyrmions, as well as periodic lattices of magnetic bimerons and antiferromagnetic skyrmions are predicted. By utilizing the Berry theory and the Landauer-Büttiker approach, the topological Hall effect of electrons and the magnetoelectric properties of skyrmions are quantified. Furthermore, a purely topologically induced Hall effect of electrons in bimeron crystals and a topological spin Hall effect of electrons in antiferromagnetic skyrmion crystals are predicted. In this cumulative work, the interaction of electrons with non-collinear spin textures, such as magnetic skyrmions – small, whirl-like modulations of the ferromagnetic phase –, is investigated. Using micromagnetic spin dynamics simulations, Monte Carlo simulations and effective equations of motion, an optimization of the skyrmion-based racetrack data storage device is proposed. Furthermore, the existence of individual magnetic biskyrmions, as well as periodic lattices of magnetic bimerons and antiferromagnetic skyrmions are predicted. Moreover, the Berry theory and the Landauer-Büttiker approach allow the quantification of the topological Hall effect of electrons and the magnetoelectric properties in non-collinear spin textures. Furthermore, a purely topologically induced Hall effect for bimerons and the topologically induced equivalent to the spin Hall effect in antiferromagnetic skyrmion crystals are predicted.

Participation in Society: People with Disabilities between Inclusion and Exclusion ¤ Participation in Society leads as a target perspective the entire system of rehabilitation and fundamentally changes the tasks of politics and social services. The book introduces from a sociological perspective the general conditions of inclusion and the risks of exclusion in modern society and concretizes these at the example of the living situation of people with disabilities. On the basis of a detailed analysis and criticism of the welfare state models and concepts for the treatment of their special exclusion risks, new approaches to an effective design of rehabilitation services are shown and discussed

Further characterization of the breeding of the Cftrtm1Unc-Tg(FABPCFTR)1Jaw/J mouse strain, as well as evaluation of an oral inoculation model with Pseudomonas aeruginosa with regard to its suitability for antipseudomonal vaccine studies ¤ Cystic Fibrosis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, nasal vaccination. - Patients with the monogenic inherited disease Cystic Fibrosis often suffer from an infection with the multi-resistant pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa in the advanced stage of their disease. In fact, the Pseudomonas aeruginosa lung infection in CF patients is considered the leading cause of death (PAUL et al. 2001). Consequently, preventing such colonization would be an important step to improve the quality of life and survival of such patients. Therefore, numerous attempts have been made in the past to develop an antipseudomonal vaccine (DORING u. PIER 2008). Since infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is primarily acquired through the nasal-pharyngeal space (KUBESCH et al. 1988), the failure of previous vaccine studies may be explained by the fact that the application of the respective vaccine has always been carried out solely systemically to date, and thus also the antibody response occurred systemically. In the present work, a recombinant OprF-I- vaccine was investigated for its efficacy in the mouse model, which could be applied both directly systemically and mucosally in the form of a nasal gel (BAUMANN et al. 2004). Due to the corrected CF intestinal pathology, mice of the Cftrtm1Unc-Tg(FABPCFTR)1Jaw/J strain were chosen as experimental animals (ZHOU et al. 1994). The oral inoculation model according to Coleman et al (COLEMAN et al. 2003) served as the infection model. Before the actual vaccine study began, the...

Es gibt für mich keine Zitate : Intertextuality in the Poetic Work of Ingeborg Bachmann ¤ Note International Hölderlin Bibliography: pp. 138-148: "Paris" ; pp. 182-184: Nietzsche - Hölderlin; pp. 409-411: "Disturbing Memory" - Hölderlin

Molecular Function of the Voltage-Gated Sodium Channel hNav1.9 ¤ BEGIN The SCN11A gene encodes the voltage-gated sodium channel (NaV-channel) NaV1.9. This channel exhibits the greatest differences in sequence and gating behavior within the NaV-channel family (NaV1.1- NaV1.9). The channel cannot trigger action potentials due to its unique properties. NaV1.9 is expressed in dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons and is associated with the sensitization of tissue during inflammatory processes. An isolated study of heterologously expressed NaV1.9 channels has been impossible in non-neuronal cells so far. However, this is necessary to clarify the relationships between the SCN11A mutation L811P and the disturbed pain perception in patients with congenital analgesia. To this end, domains and hNaV1.9 channels were functionally investigated using electrophysiological methods in neuronal and non-neuronal cells. The C-terminus of NaV1.9 was identified as the trigger for the poor heterologous expression of NaV1.9 and as responsible for the unique NaV1.9 gating behavior. Therefore, a NaV1.9 construct was developed, which can be expressed in non-neuronal cells and used for pharmacological investigation of NaV1.9 channels. It was shown that the mutation L811P significantly increases channel activity and affects the resting membrane potential of DRG neurons. In addition, the other disturbed bodily functions of patients with L811P mutation (gastrointestinal motility, motor function, sweating) suggest an abundant physiological role of the NaV1.9 channel in many tissues and in many physiological processes in humans. Furthermore, NaV1.9 could function as a target molecule in pain therapy. END

Planning and Optimization of Flow Assembly Systems : A Contribution Considering Changing Requirements for Process Reliability, Product Quality, and Flexibility ¤ Originally, the design of assembly systems in the form of flow systems aimed at a consistently high volume of a single product with a high degree of automation. Due to reasons such as continuously increasing customer demands or changes in sales, assembly processes are constantly adapted to the changed conditions. Such requirements have an impact on the structure and design of flow assembly systems. As a result, aspects such as redundancy, buffering, and the integration of quality stations gain importance in planning such systems. New methods are therefore developed to improve the configuration and operation of post-processing loops, converging and diverging, and parallel structures. The developed structures exhibit more advantages in terms of flexibility, redundancy, availability, utilization rate, and buffer capacities compared to conventional structures.

Frugal Innovations : An Examination of the Criteria and the Approach in Product Development ¤ Criteria for defining frugal innovation -- Design of the innovation process -- Procedure for identifying customer needs -- Procedure for concept development. . Timo Weyrauch examines which criteria define a frugal innovation and how frugal innovations can be developed. In the first part of the investigation, three criteria are developed on the basis of a literature review and a qualitative survey to distinguish frugal from non-frugal innovations. In the second part, the innovation and product development process is investigated using action research. The author shows how frugal innovations can be targeted developed with which procedures and methods. The content Criteria for defining frugal innovation Design of the innovation process Procedure for identifying customer needs Procedure for concept development The target groups Lecturers and students of engineering sciences, technology and innovation management, economics and business administration as well as business administration Practitioners from the fields of technology and innovation management, product management, product development and research and development The author Timo Weyrauch is a manager in a strategy consulting firm and was promoted at the Technical University of Hamburg at the Institute for Technology and Innovation Management under Mr. Prof. Dr. Cornelius Herstatt.

Analysis of genotypic differences in biochemical and physiological adjustments to N-deficiency and drought stress in potatoes (Solanum tuberosum L.) with consideration of yield components ¤ This work aimed at comprehensive phenotyping of potato cultivars in response to N-deficiency and drought stress at the morphological, physiological and biochemical level. 17 European potato cultivars were investigated in two years pot trials in a rainout shelter with two N-levels and two water supply regimes. Additionally, a broad in vitro screening was performed to monitor specific traits under different N-levels. Furthermore, out of these two contrasting genotypes were analysed in a proteomic approach to identify proteins associated with genotype specific responses to N-deficiency.

Digital reading : Change and Continuity of a Literary Practice ¤ What is digital reading? How do readers cope with the digital abundance of offers? Individual coping mechanisms often no longer suffice to master this challenge, and the hype around digital media obscures the view of their tradition. Therefore, the development of stable reading strategies and media competence requires a systematic historical and scientific description of the phenomenon. From the synthesis of reading act theory, materiality and media research, as well as practice theory, Franziska Wilke develops a reading typology that illustrates reading digital literature. Her gained insights are not only useful for readers, but also for those who want to become readers.

Implementation of the EU enforcement directive in the Baltic countries : experience in view of the development of protection of intellectual property rights ¤ The work deals with the legal regulations for the protection of intellectual property rights in the Baltic states

Acquisition of Modeling Competences: Empirical Comparison of a Holistic and an Atomistic Approach to Promoting Modeling Competences ¤ The acquisition of mathematical modeling competences is compulsory in Germany since their fixation in the educational standards for students of all school forms and levels. Susanne Brand compares a holistic and a dissecting modeling approach to promote modeling competences empirically within the framework of the intervention project ERMO. Her results show that the effectiveness of the two examined approaches must be considered differently, especially in view of the performance strength and -heterogeneity of learning groups. Content Mathematical Modeling Acquisition of Modeling Competences Modeling activities within the framework of an intervention project Results of the empirical study with regard to model comparisons, the key values of the chosen model, and the development of student competences Target groups Lecturers and students of mathematics education Mathematics teachers and seminar leaders The author Susanne Brand was a research assistant in the field of mathematics education under Prof. Dr. Gabriele Kaiser at the University of Hamburg

Numerical Methods for Nonlinear Mixed-Integer Optimization Problems in Water Management ¤ Abwassermanagement, optimale Steuerung, nichtlineare Optimierung, gemischt-ganzzahliges Modell, nichtlineares Modell. - Wastewater management, optimal control, nonlinear programming, mixed-integer model, nonlinear model

Control in Organizations ¤ How can control in organizations be theoretically appropriately captured? Action theories draw on individual actors and social structures to explain (control) action, while system theory draws on social structures and interaction processes. According to the initial hypothesis of the book, each theory neglects an important aspect of determining social (control) action: action theories neglect the determination by ongoing interaction processes and system theory neglects the determination by the individual actor. It shows that control in organizations is a complex phenomenon that is viewed differently by various theories. This work aims to contribute to clarifying this question.

Work on the Sound Field in ADHD: Pedagogical and Psychodynamic Aspects of Affect Regulation ¤ Begga Hölz-Lindau demonstrates that, using the haptic approach of Heinz Deuser's work on the sound field, affect regulation is achieved in children with ADHD symptoms. She thus shows the positive benefits of this treatment approach for the patients. Interdisciplinary, Hölz-Lindau describes the development of the work on the sound field method and shows its effectiveness in children with ADHD based on her clinical study. She presents the significant improvements in affect regulation in relation to its pedagogical and psychotherapeutic relevance and works out didactic mediation paths as well as first concrete implementation possibilities in practice.

Investigating the feasibility of accelerated drug release testing for intravaginal rings ¤ Wirkstofffreisetzung, accelerated drug release testing, vaginal rings, diffusion, quality control Accelerated drug release tests are essential for quality control (QC) of long acting (non-oral) controlled release formulations. Real-time release experiments are usually required for product development, to understand the mechanism of release and to establish a correlation with in vivo release. Ideally, the accelerated test should maintain the biorelevant aspect of the in vitro method and the mechanism of release should not change under accelerated test conditions. At the same time adequate discriminatory ability is a prerequisite as the accelerated test should be able to discriminate between batches with respect to manufacturing variables that can impact on bioavailability. The objective of this thesis was to develop accelerated drug release tests for intravaginal rings (IVRs) and to gain a mechanistic understanding of the principles that facilitate in vitro drug release under accelerated test conditions. A detailed evaluation of the in vitro release characteristics of the formulations under real-time test conditions was considered as a prerequisite for developing predictive accelerated tests. Two formulations were subject of this study, in which the mechanism of release is primarily governed by drug diffusion. One formulation was the commercially available Nuvaring®, a combined hormonal contraceptive IVR that releases etonogestrel and ethinylestradiol with a constant rate over a duration of 3 weeks. The second formulation was a prototype of an investigational IVR that is ...

Enzym-catalyzed, kinetic Racemate Splitting of α-quaternary β-Oxoesters ¤ Ziel der asymmetrischen Synthese ist die Darstellung optisch aktiver Verbindungen, wobei eine mögliche Herangehensweise die Trennung racemischer Substrate ist. Im Rahmen dieses Dissertationsvorhabens wurde sich für eine kinetische Racemat-spaltung entschieden, bei der als Katalysator ein Enzym für die enantioselektive Verseifung eingesetzt werden sollte. Asymmetric synthesis is aiming at the preparation of optically active compounds. One suitable approach is the resolution of racemic materials. Herein we have chosen a kinetic resolution process using an enzyme as catalyst for an enantioselective saponification which has been successfully applied before by Christoffers et al. on the synthesis of (–)-kjellmanianone.

Foreign Exchange Market Efficiency: An Empirical Investigation of High-Frequency Exchange Rate Reactions to Macroeconomic Publications ¤ The foreign exchange market is considered the most traded, liquid, and technologically advanced financial market worldwide. So, trading in foreign currencies attracts a large number of highly professional market participants who can react to changes in market data in the shortest time possible using modern electronic communication tools. The present monograph focuses on the question of whether this is actually the case in the context of newly published macroeconomic information, by analyzing the ultra-high-frequency reaction of the most important US dollar exchange rates in the second. To this end, a comprehensive presentation of the functioning of the foreign exchange market and the principles of exchange rate formation is first provided. Further content highlights concern the processing of information on financial markets, the concept of market efficiency, and the event study methodology. The results of the empirical investigation complement existing knowledge on news effects on foreign exchange markets and shed light on the incorporation of new information in the second.

Social Work and Systems Theories ¤ System theory is currently a dominant paradigm of the scientific discourse. In the context of Social Work, systems thinking has become known primarily as a counseling concept. Furthermore, the adoption of systemic approaches is also associated with the expectation of a stronger independent profiling of a theory of Social Work. The author examines the various stages of development of system theory and its reception within Social Work and inquires about their applicability on different levels of theory formation of Social Work, from interaction to societal functional determination.
Investigation of Current Displacement in the Stator of Highly Utilized Electrical Machines ¤ Current displacement, Eddy effect, AC resistance

Grammar Knowledge for Spelling Rules? : Three German Spelling Dictionaries Critically Analyzed ¤ Which spelling rules require less grammar knowledge from writers - the old or the reformed ones? Sabine Mayr examines the rule directories of three common old and new German spelling dictionaries (Duden, 20th ed. 1991 and 22nd ed. 2000; Bertelsmann 1999) to find out which grammatical technical terms they assume to be known, where understanding problems lie, and whether or how these can be solved (e.g., which grammar helps). The comparison shows that with the reform, the understanding of the rules has been slightly improved.

Violence in Domestic Relationships: Socioscientific and Evolutionary Biological Positions in the Discourse ¤ Under careful consideration of the respective paradigmatic prerequisites, Ingrid Kaiser presents in this interdisciplinary study for the first time systematic relationships between socioscientific and evolutionary biological approaches to violence in pair relationships and parent-child relationships. Based on the biological-functional theory offers, she discusses the conditions of origin of violence in domestic relationships in an extended theoretical framework and presents new approaches to explaining hitherto contradictory empirical findings. Against this background
Development of a Modular Gesture Control System ¤ Gesture control, motion detection, real-time, modularity

Europe as a Border: An Ethnography of the Border Protection Agency Frontex ¤ With the European Border and Coast Guard Agency Frontex, the European Union has created a uniformed and armed police unit for the first time. Bernd Kasparek presents a detailed analysis of the agency's creation and development. Through a genealogy of the European border and an ethnographic reconstruction of the Schengen crisis, he examines the long project of Europeanizing border protection. At the center is the analysis of changing rationalities that manifest in political and technical programs. It becomes clear that governing the border and migration at the same time means governing Europe. With the European Border and Coast Guard Agency Frontex, the European Union has created a uniformed and armed police unit for the first time. Bernd Kasparek presents a detailed analysis of the agency's creation and development. Through a genealogy of the European border and an ethnographic reconstruction of the Schengen crisis, he examines the long project of Europeanizing border protection. At the center is the analysis of changing rationalities that manifest in political and technical programs. It becomes clear that governing the border and migration at the same time means governing Europe.

Intergenerational Divorce Transmission in Germany : the Search for the "missing link" between Divorce in the Parent Generation and Divorce in the Child Generation ¤ The starting point of the present investigation is the repeatedly replicated finding from the USA, that persons who experienced the divorce of their parents in childhood or youth have a higher divorce risk compared to persons who did not experience this, in comparison. The goal of the present work was to determine whether the as "intergenerational divorce transmission" described connection between divorce in the parent generation and divorce in the child generation is also to be proven in Germany, and - if this were the case - how this connection is to be explained.

Network Management in Trade: Process Innovations in Trade Using RFID Technology as an Example ¤ Introduction -- Introduction -- Challenges in Trade -- Competition through new business forms -- Developments in the trade environment -- Process innovations in trade — Reaction to the pressure for efficiency in trade -- Trade processes as a starting point -- Process innovations in trade to increase efficiency -- Network management in trade — Management of a network for the introduction of a cross-company process innovation -- Network structures — The network as an organizational form for the introduction of a cross-company process innovation in trade -- Control mechanisms — Control of a network for the introduction of a cross-company process innovation in trade. Network management is not only of great importance for companies in the trade sector, but also associated with significant challenges. In particular, when introducing cross-company process innovations such as, for example, RFID technology, management within and by networks plays a central role. Thomas C. Salditt shows a selection of current challenges for the trade sector, which increase the pressure for efficiency on individual traders. Cross-company process innovations such as RFID technology can be used to counter this pressure. Business networks and the management of these networks are a central aspect here. The author places trade processes and process innovations in the context of network relationships and derives concrete recommendations for management in networks from this.

A Design Methodology for Data Warehouses ¤ Recently, data warehouses (DWHs) as a decision support system's core caused a lively interest in research as well as in practice. Decisions based on the DHW and their consequences, respectively, are often far-reaching. Therefore, the underlying database has to fulfill some specific quality criteria. This doctoral thesis proposes a method for designing DWHs which is based on the three level approach. For conceptual modelling the language MML (Multidimensional Modeling Language) is defined. MML features multidimensional as well as object oriented constructs. It is supplemented by the graphical notation mUML, a multidimensional extension of the UML. After the transformation to the logical layer is realised, physical design of the database schema is treated in depth. Furthermore, the prototypical implementation of the concepts is described and the method is evaluated using a real world example.

On the cycle spaces associated to orbits of semi-simple Lie Groups ¤ Let G be a semi-simple Lie group and Q a parabolic subgroup of its complexification GC, then Z = GC/Q is a complex GC-fan manifold. The group G, just like the complexification KC of the maximal compact subgroup of GC, acts on Z with only finitely many orbits. For every G-orbit ' there exists a KC-orbit ·, such that the average ' is not empty and compact. By considering the properties of cycles at the boundary of G-orbits, a definition of the cycle space of any G-orbit was given. By means of Schubert varieties, Schubert cuts and with the help of a certain complementary hypersurface, the complete characterization of all cycle spaces, associated to a G-orbit ', was given. In particular, all cycle spaces, with a few exceptions in the Hermitian case, are equivalent to the region ƯAG. In the exceptional cases, the cycle space is equivalent to the associated restricted region.

Search Engine Optimization and Competition Law ¤ This examination from the perspective of the UWG shows which measures of search engine optimization (SEO) are permissible or impermissible under competition law. The investigation first presents a representation of SEO, as well as its classification in relation to the UWG, and shows fundamental problems of a publicity law consideration of SEO. Subsequently, the author subsumes various SEO case constellations under the UWG provisions. It then follows an engagement with the existing case law on the UWG and SEO. The work provides concrete instructions for the application of publicity law, which is confronted with cases of SEO.

Fermions in curved spacetimes ¤ In this dissertation, we investigate a formulation of Dirac fermions in curved spacetimes that possesses both general coordinate invariance and local spin basis invariance. We illuminate the benefits of the spin basis invariant formulation from a conceptual and practical perspective. Using the spin basis formalism, we construct a field theory for quantized gravity and matter fields and show that the quantization of the metric and matter fields suffices. For field theoretical approaches to quantum gravity, this observation is of particular relevance, as it suggests a purely metric-based quantization scheme, even in the presence of fermions. Therefore, we investigate in the second part of this work the gauge and field parameter dependence of the renormalization group flow in quantum gravity theories. While physical observables are independent of such details of the calculation, one typically needs

Failed Integration Processes after Serving a Juvenile/Prison Sentence from an Identity-Theoretical Perspective ¤ The qualitative study titled „Failed Integration Processes after Serving a Juvenile/Prison Sentence from an Identity-Theoretical Perspective“ aims to utilize identity constructions as a theoretical framework and reference point for social integration processes. The methodological and methodical framework for approaching this subject area is the Grounded Theory Methodology. The analytical focus is on identity constructions of a selected group of inmates who have experienced repeated incarceration and, as a result, exhibit certain characteristic combinations. In particular, negative experience values 'with' society and socialization institutions prompt subjects to open up their own biography and social positioning for a self-referential discourse. In this process, social experiences of disregard are worked through, interpretable as an attempt to establish normalization and affiliation capabilities, which then merge into a functional form of identity work, oriented towards 'Authenticity' (core category), in the institutional context. This form of identity work elevates the refusal to comply with societal integration requirements as a constitutive element of one's individualized identity project. This articulation practice is initially limited to the time of imprisonment. The subjects enter their re-release with the claim to document successful integration; however, the authentic construction logic is no longer suitable to establish expectation security in the course of re-release, in order to realize 'successful' identity work outside the institution, which makes re-incarceration attractive: The 'return' to the prison institution stands in the context of increasing experiences of alienation, which convey to the subjects the progressive exclusion, explicitly in the function of an inclusive disintegration, and can, in addition, counteract a threatening identity damage in a self-image-friendly manner.

Sects in Experiential Reports: Hybridities between Literature and Religion ¤ Cliffnotes: There is a wide variety of literature about ex-sect members. But what is the actual validity of these autobiographical experience reports? Can they be scientifically evaluated? The author exemplarily shows, using Scientology, Jehovah's Witnesses, and Satanism as examples, how a scientifically-oriented and source-critical approach to the works can look like. Both individual experiences and collective sect images and discourses, which form the narrative framework, are taken into account here.

Influence of two progesterone-releasing preparations (PRID®alpha, CIDR®) on the synchronization of recipient animals in the context of an embryo transfer program in cattle ¤ Synchronisation, Progesterone, Embryo transfer. - The aim of this study was to investigate the influence of two progesterone-releasing preparations (PRID alpha Spiral and CIDR Spange) on the endometrium of recipient animals and the influence of the medication duration on the progesterone level, synchronization success, and pregnancy rates after ET. For this purpose, a total of 104 heifers of the German Fleckvieh breed were synchronized at the recipient animal station Brandhof of the Neustadt / Aisch e.V. breeding association. The group allocation was as follows: Group 1A 33 animals (synchronization using PRID Spiral, medication duration 8 days), Group 1B 34 animals (synchronization using CIDR Spange, medication duration 8 days), Group 2A 11 animals (synchronization using PRID, medication duration 9 days) and Group 2B 13 animals (synchronization using CIDR, medication duration 9 days). All animals received a prostaglandin injection 24 hours before the removal of the preparations (Groups 1A and 1B on day 7, Groups 2A and 2B on day 8). Estrus occurred approximately 48 hours (day 10 of the experiment) after removal of the preparations. The animals were then either fertilized with an embryo or an egg and the pregnancy rates were checked after 30 days. The results showed that the synchronization of recipient animals using PRID and CIDR was successful and significantly increased the pregnancy rates after ET. The medication duration had no significant influence on the synchronization success and pregnancy rates. The results of this study can contribute to the optimization of embryo transfer programs in cattle breeding.

Methodical Material and Process Development for Additive Series Production of Automotive Structural Components ¤ The powder bed-based laser beam melting process (LPBF) offers the possibility of creating end-conforming and highly complex metallic structures. In combination with flexible material systems, a variant-rich, load-path-optimized, and lot-independent component production is realizable, which is of particular interest for the automotive industry with a variety of vehicle derivatives and consistent lightweight design concepts. Currently, a widespread dissemination in the body-in-white construction is not yet given. In addition to the frequently limited formability of the materials, the lack of knowledge about the application behavior, in particular with regard to crash and corrosion, is a barrier to innovation in the framework of the extensive release processes of the automotive manufacturers. This work presents a systematic knowledge base for the applicability of existing and novel aluminum alloys for automotive series applications. Furthermore, methodical approaches and recommendations for action are given for the extended series integration of the technology. The content Systematic knowledge base for the applicability of additive manufacturing in automotive body-in-white construction Innovative methods and approaches for the accelerated development of novel material systems Material and process optimization with regard to crash-related loading cases and corrosive application conditions The author Andreas Lutz studied mechanical engineering with a focus on methodical product development and production technology at the University of Ulm and the Technical University of Berlin. He graduated in 2022 under the supervision of Prof. Dr.-Ing. Claus Emmelmann at the Institute for Laser and System Technology (iLAS) of the Technical University of Hamburg. During his doctoral studies, he was employed as a doctoral researcher in the corporate research of Mercedes-Benz AG from 2017 to 2020.

Carsharing and the Society of Tomorrow : An Environmentally Conscious Approach to Automobility? ¤ Based on a quantitative survey of approximately 1,500 young people and young adults from Baden-Württemberg, Sarah Witzke shows a cautious trend regarding the intention to use car-sharing vehicles instead of their own cars in the future. She shows that the ownership of a private vehicle is of great importance for this group. Through a linear regression calculation, central influencing factors regarding the car-sharing intention were identified. In particular, the influence of significant third parties, perceived car-sharing availability, and awareness of the environmentally burdensome effect of motorized individual traffic are thus decisive. The content Problem outline: Sustainable mobility as a challenge of the future Car-sharing – a classic example of shared consumption The youth and the concept of car-sharing Theoretical explanation models for mode choice Quantitative main study: Car-sharing as an alternative to the private car? The target groups Lecturers and students of economics, social sciences, and mobility research Professionals and executives from the automotive industry, car-sharing providers The author Sarah Witzke is employed as a scientific assistant at the Institute for Sustainable Corporate Management at the University of Ulm. In particular, the mobility of young people and young adults, as well as the mobility concept of car-sharing, are at the center of her research.

Methods for learning structured prediction in semantic segmentation of natural images ¤ Automatic segmentation and recognition of semantic classes in natural images is an important open problem of machine vision. In this work, we investigate three possible approaches to recognition: without supervision, with supervision at the image level, and with supervision at the pixel level. This work consists of three parts. In the first part of the work, we propose a clustering algorithm that optimizes a novel, information-theoretic objective function. We show that the presented algorithm has clear advantages over standard procedures from the literature on many different datasets. Clustering is an important component in many applications of machine vision, especially in automatic segmentation. The second part of this work presents a procedure for automatic segmentation and recognition of object classes in natural images, which is able to learn a segmentation model with the help of supervision in the form of class occurrences on images. The third part of the work investigates one of the most widely used approaches to semantic segmentation and object class segmentation, Conditional Random Fields, connected with procedures of structured prediction. We investigate various learning algorithms of structured learning, especially in connection with approximate prediction. We show that it is possible to learn exact structured models for image segmentation despite the presence of circles in the considered neighborhood graphs. With the presented methods, we advance the state of the art on two complex datasets for semantic segmentation, the MSRC-21 dataset of RGB images and the NYU V2 dataset of RGB-D images of indoor scenes. We also present a software library that allows for a comprehensive comparison of the best learning procedures for structured learning to be performed. Our study allows us to characterize the considered algorithms in a range of applications, especially semantic segmentation and object class segmentation.

Palladium-catalyzed Functionalization and Cyclization as well as Acid-Mediated Cyclization of Quinoline Derivatives ¤ The thesis deals with palladium-catalyzed as well as Brønsted acid mediated cylization of quinolines. The indoloquinolines were synthesized via palladium-catalyzed Suzuki-Miyaura-reaction, followed by Buchwald-Hartwig Amination. The syntheses of benzoacridines and benzophenanthridines as well as the benzoindolizinonaphthyridines were carried out via palladium-catalyzed reactions and a following Brønsted acid mediated cyloisomerization. The optical properties were examined by absorption and emission spectroscopy.

From Protease to Peptidase: The Influence of the Oxyanion Hole on Reverse Proteolysis at the Example of Trypsin ¤ The enzymatic ligation of peptide and protein fragments presents a significant challenge. Among other things, suitable biocatalysts are lacking, which exhibit both sufficient interaction with the peptide backbone and catalyze the formation of a peptide bond. Lars Franke investigates the possibility of transferring the excellent ligation properties of Surfactin-Thioesterase II to anionic rat trypsin II, which in turn shows a suitable interaction with the peptide backbone. While the catalytic mechanisms of both enzymes essentially correspond to those of serine esterases, there is a difference in the architecture of the oxyanion hole. Corresponding oxyanion hole mutants of trypsin were generated, their catalytic properties were investigated, and their utility for enzymatic ligation reactions was quantified. As a result, the author was able to generate two trypsin variants that are suitable for peptide ligation and protein modification. The content includes: Anthropogenic protein synthesis Enzymes for enzymatic peptide synthesis Generation and purification of trypsin variants Kinetic parameters of the acyl transfer reaction and protein modification The target groups include researchers and students of biochemistry and enzymology Enzymologists and peptide chemists in industrial research and development The author Lars Franke is active in the development of custom-made enzymes for peptide synthesis and protein modification at the Charles-Tannford-Protein Center in Halle. Anthropogenic protein synthesis -- Enzymes for enzymatic peptide synthesis -- Generation and purification of trypsin variants -- Kinetic parameters of the acyl transfer reaction and protein modification.

Validation of Biomagnetic Procedures at Isotropic and Anisotropic Volume Conduction in a Torso Phantom ¤ In this work, the accuracy and reproducibility of biomagnetic procedures were investigated. Biomagnetic measurements were performed with a vector biomagnetometer on a realistic, complex, partially anisotropic torso phantom. Various detailed computer models could be examined. The reconstruction of a single dipole during simultaneous activity of other dipoles could be successfully performed with a torso phantom. The used RAP-MUSIC algorithm could be successfully validated as a current method for source reconstruction. Circular and spiral-shaped currents were systematically investigated in different manifestations as a possible source for differences in magnetic and electrical data. It could be shown how the circular or spiral shape affects the magnetic flux density and the electrical potentials.

Operational Flexibility Planning Model: A Reference Model for Manufacturing Enterprises in the Photovoltaic Industry ¤ Practice, especially the photovoltaic industry, is confronted with barely predictable demand fluctuations, in short volatility, to which it is necessary to react flexibly. In theory, flexibility research goes back to the beginnings of business administration, and flexibility is now demanded by entire value chains. Nevertheless, there is still a lack in business literature of a theoretically founded, comprehensive, and at the same time practical approach model that offers a guide for systematic flexibility planning. In the present work, such an approach model for systematic operational flexibility planning is developed at the example of the photovoltaic industry, which also represents a reference model for any value-adding production systems.

Operational Regulations in the Railway Noise Protection System: A Critical Inventory of the Administrative Noise Protection Powers in Railway Planning and Railway Hazard Prevention Law ¤ Noise pollution caused by rail traffic is a topic of lasting social, economic, and political relevance. One possibility for reducing this unwanted side effect can be the administrative order of operational regulatory measures – for example, speed or passage restrictions –. The work analyzes the most relevant legal questions in this context under national and European law. The focus is on railway planning. The legal situation outside of specialized planning is also examined. On this basis, further potential reform possibilities are shown.

Microstructural Properties of Quartz as Part of Late-Reactive, Alkali-Sensitive Additives ¤ Between the years 1920 and 1930, there were structural damages to bridges and roads along the California coast, which mainly manifested in a clear cracking. Since then, structural damages have been repeatedly described, whose cause is seen in the reaction of additives containing reactive silica with the pore solution of the concrete.
