This reaction is referred to as the Alkali-Silica Reaction (ASR). Since the first publication by Stanton on the alkali-aggregate reaction on opal-containing additives, hundreds of research works have been conducted on this topic and their results have been published. Despite extensive research for more than 80 years, neither the mechanism of ASR is fully clarified nor is a clear prediction of the threat to buildings or building components with potentially ASR-sensitive additives possible. This is mainly due to the fact that ASR is a reaction that consists of a complex sequence of chemical and physical processes, which can lead to damage to concrete or concrete components and buildings in their entirety. A closed description and treatment of this reaction is not possible as long as no satisfactory knowledge of the sequence of individual steps is available. This requires fundamental investigations of the individual chemical and physical reaction steps as well as a quantitative evaluation of the various influencing factors. In general, there are a wide range of guidelines and standards worldwide that are intended to prevent damage to buildings by ASR. In Germany, the current valid rulebook is the so-called Alkali Guideline of the German Committee for Reinforced Concrete (DAfStb).

Development Systematics of Thermal Management for High-Quality LED Systems ¤ The demand for increasingly powerful LED systems while simultaneously limited space requires increasing demands on thermal management. Not only the lifespan, but also optical properties, such as light flux and color, depend on the LED chip temperature. As a result of a pronounced temperature dependence, the development process of LED systems is very complex. This complexity arises due to the larger number of interconnected elements, which are realized in different disciplines. Due to this fact, there is a need for a cross-disciplinary development process that takes into account the tasks, problems, and requirements of all disciplines. Within the scope of this work, a possible integration of the disciplines relevant to the error-free functionality of thermal management with the engineering approach in product development was specified. The result is a systematics that structures the development process of LED systems and assigns suitable methods and tools of thermal management. The applicability of the development systematics was presented using the design of two demonstrators. In this context, it was shown that the interaction of the various disciplines opens up potential for the design of new products and applications.

Morality as a Bar to Protection: An Investigation into German and European Intellectual Property Law ¤ What is the purpose and relevance of morality exceptions that prevent protection in intellectual property law? Svenja Maria Schenk tackles this question with a comprehensive analysis of the principles of European and German intellectual property law while simultaneously offering guidelines on how to apply the clauses in practice and proposing a new, unitary concept of morality in intellectual property law.Survey of contentsIntroduction A. Problem statementB. Objectives of the work, delimitation of the subject matter and state of researchC. Methodology of the investigation § 1 Purpose of the bar to protection A. Formal design of intellectual property rights and implications for the function of absolute bars to protectionB. Special role of copyrightC. Current state of opinion on the purpose of the bar to protection of morality in the individual areas of industrial property lawD. Statement: Purpose of the bar to protection in the context of the functions of protection § 2 Examination methods and standards A. Narrow interpretation of exceptions?B. Relevant subject matterC. Relevant perspective for evaluationD. Relevant point in time for evaluation § 3 The concept of morality in intellectual property law A. Morality in the European multi-level system: Harmonized (union-)autonomous concept?B. Definition of the concept in the context of intellectual property lawSummary in theses A violation of morality can prevent the acquisition of intellectual property rights. Svenja Maria Schenk undertakes a cross-sectional investigation of corresponding moral and moral-related general clauses in intellectual property law. Based on a comprehensive analysis of the systematics of European and German intellectual property law, she works out the function and special importance of these norms for the appropriateness of the protection systems and the free competition in view of ever new (technological) developments. She deals with existing uncertainties, differences and fields of tension and contributes to the legal security for applicants and legal practitioners through the proposal of concrete application principles for practice. In the following, she submits a new, uniform understanding of the concept of morality in intellectual property law and also addresses the procedural consequences of this proposal.InhaltsübersichtIntroduction A. Problem statementB. Objectives of the work, delimitation of the subject matter and state of researchC. Methodology of the investigation § 1 Purpose of the bar to protection A. Formal design of intellectual property rights and implications for the function of absolute bars to protectionB. Special role of copyrightC. Current state of opinion on the purpose of the bar to protection of morality in the individual areas of industrial property lawD. Statement: Purpose of the bar to protection in the context of the functions of protection § 2 Examination methods and standards A. Narrow interpretation of exceptions?B. Relevant subject matterC. Relevant perspective for evaluationD. Relevant point in time for evaluation § 3 The concept of morality in intellectual property law A. Morality in the European multi-level system: Harmonized (union-)autonomous concept?B. Definition of the concept in the context of intellectual property lawSummary in theses

EasyKit : a development methodology for rapid engineering of miniaturized mechatronic systems ¤ The current development of mechatronic systems is mostly characterized by a sequential design process of electronics, software, and mechanics. At the same time, the domain-specific design often requires development tools in individual fields, which require a high level of expert knowledge and are only partially compatible with each other. The EasyKit development methodology aims to simplify this development process through modularization on the hardware and software level. For this purpose, tools are provided to the user, which have already been infused with extensive expert knowledge, so that he can develop and build the hardware and software for mechatronic systems independently with simple means and basic knowledge. This work describes these tools and the associated technologies. Various possibilities for a solvable connection of electronic components are presented. In addition, a interface concept in the form of an external bus is shown, with which electronic function carriers can be easily stacked on top of each other. Existing templates for the PCB layout and test adapters support this approach. Another major goal of this work is to accelerate and make the development process more economical. For this purpose, a three-stage model has been developed, which enables a simple transition from the functional pattern (Stage 1) to the small series (Stage 2) to the series product (Stage 3). The existing function blocks in hardware and software lead to a rapid construction of first functional patterns. Through the reuse of these function blocks in all three stages, the transition from the functional pattern to the series product can be strongly accelerated. This concept has also been transferred to software. Through a graphical programming interface and available function libraries, programs and executable codes are significantly easier to generate. Two practical examples, a temperature measurement system and a regulated pneumatic cylinder, illustrate the complete design process and show advantages and disadvantages. A cost comparison with the conventional approach highlights the economic benefits of the development methodology.

Novel cationic esters from cellulose and dextran : synthesis, structure analysis and properties ¤ The goal of the work was the synthesis of new water-soluble aminogroup-containing cellulose and dextran carboxylic acid esters under homogeneous reaction conditions. The ring-opening reaction of N-Methyl-2-pyrrolidon (NMP) in the presence of p-Toluensulfonic acid chloride resulted in the chlorides of cellulose-4-[N-methylammonium]butyrate (with average substitution degrees, DS, of 0.31 to 1.04), hydroxyethyl cellulose-4-[N-methylammonium]butyrate (with DS values of 0.28 to 0.98) and dextran-4-[N-methylammonium]butyrate (with DS values between 0.12 and 0.72). Cellulose-4-[N,N,N-trimethylammonium]butyrate chloride could be produced by the reaction of cellulose with (3-Carboxypropyl)trimethylammonium chloride under activation with N,N'-Carbonyldiimidazole. N,N-Dimethylacetamide/LiCl and BMIMCl served as reaction media. High reaction temperatures (up to 100°C) and reaction times (up to 20 h) were necessary to synthesize products with DS values between 0.17 and 0.75.

Combination of Nanofabrication and Nanometrology on a planar Ø100 mm Nanofabrication Machine (NFM-100) ¤ The demand for high-precision positioning for the application of nanofabrication in macroscopic work areas is steadily increasing. Due to a new level of complexity in micro- and nanoelectronic manufacturing, extreme requirements for high-precision nanopositioning over areas up to 100 mm and their combination with high-efficiency nanostructuring processes are necessary. In the last few decades, numerous alternative methods have established themselves in comparison to optical lithography for the generation of nanostructures. For highly accurate nanostructuring and measurement, sharp-based technologies offer a significant advantage compared to other methods. However, the usual movement range of sharp-based systems is usually limited to a few hundred µm². The goal of the present work is to transfer the previously small-scale nanostructuring by a Fowler-Nordheim emission current to wafer sizes up to 4 inches based on an ultra-precise nanopositioning and nanomeasuring platform. Through the unique combination of planar nanopositioning technology with a sharp-based system, the movement ranges can be expanded by a factor of 10^6 to 10^8. The use of active microcantilevers allows for an arbitrary switch between scanning force microscopy and scanning probe lithography modes. After characterizing and optimizing the planar nanofabrication machine, targeted and comprehensive studies of the sharp-based system follow to be able to combine both systems optimally. Subsequently, various experiments are presented through the combination of the systems for large-area scanning, where the demonstration of macroscopic AFM scans up to 100 mm is in focus. Comprehensive studies on nanofabrication over macroscopic areas follow. With this, the successful synergy of the two technologies has been proven. The relationships of reproducibility, precision, and tip wear are intensively investigated. Also, processing length and maximum scanning speeds are analyzed and discussed. To demonstrate the usability of the generated nanostructures with the NFM-100, a possible pattern transfer for the application of further nanofabrication processes such as nanoimprint lithography has been successfully demonstrated.

The spatially distributed modeling of water budget and runoff formation in the Ammer catchment : with 21 tables ¤ From the introduction: In the framework of this work, the water budget of the Ammer catchment shall be modeled under special consideration of the hitherto only insufficiently clarified, spatially distributed runoff formation. In the foreground stands the physical description of the processes involved in the water budget.

The Income and Turnover Tax Law Treatment of Internet Commerce ¤ The development of internet platforms is having an increasing impact on economic life and trade. This also poses challenges for tax law in the demarcation of commercial and entrepreneurial activity. This volume examines the tax law treatment of internet commerce in terms of income and turnover tax law. It analyses case law, tax administration and literature and examines whether alternatives to the present approaches exist. END

Functional Nanoparticles Based on Cellulose ¤ Novel polysaccharide nanoparticles (PS-NP) were developed and their application as sensors was investigated. Hydrophobic dyes were incorporated into PS-NP from cellulose esters during self-assembly. The particle properties of the composite-NP are influenced both by the hydrophobicity of the dyes and by structural interactions. By comparing the two production methods – dialysis and dropwise addition – particle size and the width of the size distribution of the composite-NP were optimized. Carboxyl groups on the particle surface were covalently coupled with antibodies to obtain colored conjugates. The conjugates showed lower detection limits in the lateral flow immunoassay than corresponding reference particles. Furthermore, cellulose esters with active ester groups based on N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS) were synthesized under homogeneous conditions. N,N'-Disuccinimidylcarbonate proved to be an effective reagent. The derivatives could be converted into reactive PS-NP with activated NHS groups on the surface, to which an aminofunctionalized fluorescent dye or enzyme could be covalently immobilized directly and without the usual activation step in aqueous phase. Optimized reaction conditions allow the dye to be bound with high efficiency of up to 90%. For the conversion of 6-maleimidohexanoic acid with cellulose esters, iminium chloride proved to be an effective reagent. During the conversion to particles, a thiol-functionalized dye could be bound to the derivatives via thiol-ene reaction (click chemistry) to obtain fluorescent and reactive PS-NP. The obtained PS derivatives were characterized using elemental analysis, infrared, and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, while the PS-NP were investigated using dynamic light scattering, electron microscopy, and optical spectroscopy.

Synthesis and Characterization of Telechelic Poly(3-hexylthiophenes) ¤ conjugated polymers; organic solar cells; P3HT; end group functionalisation; HPLC-ESI-ToF MS; perylene derivatives The aim of the present dissertation was the synthesis of bivalente poly(3-hexylthiophene)s (P3HT) bearing hydrogen bonding moieties on the end groups. Molecular recognition can be set up between the end group of functionalized P3HT and 3,4:9,10-perylentetracarboxylic acid dimides (PTCDI) via supramolecular interactions. Different reagents has been tested for the functionalization of P3HT with spezific end groups and the products were analysed semiquantitatively using mass spectrometry coupled with liquid chromatography (HPLC-ESI-ToFMS). PTCDI-derivates with thymine, triazine and barbiturate end groups were synthesized and used as electron acceptor materials with complementary hydrogen bonding moities. The characterization of the PTCDI products was accomplished via elemental analysis, ESI-ToFMS and 1H-NMR spectroscopy.

Radiative corrections to the decay of the top quark ¤ The calculation of the NLO electroweak and QCD corrections to the top-quark decay width, including the W-boson decay and off-shell effects is presented. Both the semileptonic and the hadronic decays are considered. The one-cutoff slicing method has been extended to decay processes with more than two charged particles, to deal with soft and collinear divergences. Its generalization has been obtained using mass regularization. In order to check the validity of the method employed, the calculation has been compared against an independent one and against the values obtained using the narrow-width approximation. Furthermore, the total top-quark decay width has been calculated and compared with the existing experimental measurements END

Notstandsalgorithms : Dilemmas in Automated Road Traffic ¤ The digitisation of various areas of life holds new challenges for the law. In particular, automated driving has been the subject of intense and controversial discussions. Coping with dilemmas – which, thanks to a broad media coverage, have also attracted public attention - occupies a special position.This volume analyses extreme situations in which an evasive maneuver will inevitably affect other legally protected interests. A central question is whether these actions can be justified or excused. Numerous alternative proposals on the matter of weighing lives against each other also raise the question if a deviation from settled case law must be allowed.

Boron-oxygen-related recombination centers in crystalline silicon and the effects of dopant-compensation ¤ Compensated silicon, carrier lifetime, boron-oxygen defect. - Compensated silicon, carrier lifetime, boron-oxygen defect

Fracture Energy of Running Cracks in Rock ¤ Seismicity of the upper crust - a topic of great social relevance - is largely controlled by brittle fracture processes. To date, there is no closed description of the energetic conditions for these. Results from energy considerations in laboratory scale seem not to be transferable to in-situ conditions due to too low fracture energies. In the present work, novel methods for geomaterials are used to investigate whether part of this difference results from the fact that crack speeds in the laboratory - compared to natural earthquake events - are usually low. For the first time in rock, the energy dissipation at running cracks is determined up to the maximum fracture speed. In total, a significant increase in the energy level is obtained and valuable insights are gained for the energy balance of dissipative spreading processes in rocks ...

Urban Alternatives - Housing Demand Groups of Younger Age in Erlangen ¤ Germany is getting older and through a renaissance of urban living forms, the demographic composition of urban residential areas is also changing. One is not old by a rigid age boundary based on a characteristic or a disciplinary definition. Rather, one becomes old through the change and decline of competences, performance and reserves connected with increasing morbidity as well as the change of previous social roles. In this context, reactions to changes vary individually. Despite the flowing individual aging processes and aging, it is necessary to define an investigation group, i.e. citizens who have completed their 60th year of life are counted among the elderly. However, it is still necessary to distinguish between the young elderly (60-80 years of life) and the old old (after 80 years of life). The basis for differentiation is the often healthier, more capable physical and mental condition as well as a more active lifestyle of the first group. Furthermore, the multimorbidity grade is relatively lower and the self-competence grade is higher. However, it is not possible to assume a homogeneous group with fixed age boundaries. The widespread, basic image of the single, lonely, immobile and poor person in old age is not correct. The greater part of daily or frequent activities takes place in the house, but a not insignificant part of the activities takes place outside in the living environment. This, however, affects the perception, evaluation and use for everyday life management positively or negatively depending on the characteristics, equipment and personal prerequisites...

Influencing pattern formation and localization through disorder ¤ Lattice-gas simulation; Liesegang pattern; fluctuations; disorder; metal-insulator-transition; Anderson-transition; small magnetic field; complex networks; scale-free network; clustering The goal of this dissertation is to understand how pattern formation and localization can be influenced by the introduction of disorder. Pattern formation is treated using lattice-gas simulations of Liesegang stripe formation. Thermal fluctuations and homogeneous or inhomogeneous nucleation properties of the medium form the disorder parameters. Interestingly, disorder enhances or initiates pattern formation. In addition, it has been shown that a continuous modification of the inhomogeneities of the substrate can be used to obtain equidistant distances of Liesegang stripes on small length scales. Localization is discussed in the context of the Anderson model. Disorder is introduced into the system as a small magnetic field or as topological structural disorder in the form of complex networks. It has been shown that a local topological property, namely clustering, causes a metal-insulator transition.

Commutation Calculation for Permanent Magnet DC Commutator Motors of Small Power ¤ In the present work, a procedure for calculating commutation in permanent magnet DC commutator motors (PM-DC motors) is presented. Furthermore, the fundamentals of current usage and the factors influencing them are discussed. Within the scope of the work, a summary of the most important methods for measuring and evaluating commutation is also provided, as these investigations are still highly relevant for small machine development. The procedures are explained using concrete examples and evaluated in terms of effort and their validity, as well as used for the validation of the new calculation approach. The analysis of known calculation procedures on their suitability and limitations closes this topic. Using the newly developed simulation approach for a complete drive system, current usage can be analyzed in all operating states. The model description includes the influence of the magnetic circuit, control, drive mechanics, and brush-commutator contact system. The creation and parameterization of drive models is discussed, including specific characteristics of PM-DC motors of small power. A focus is on the behavior of the contact system and its representation with all essential influencing factors. Subsequently, practice-relevant questions on commutation behavior are analyzed using drive simulation. Based on the calculation results, aspects for the design and design of PM-DC motors can be derived.

The protection guaranteed by Article 8 ECHR against state interference in personal rights in the internet ¤ The book deals with the topic of the protection guaranteed by Article 8 ECHR against state interference in personal rights in the internet. It addresses the question of whether Article 8 ECHR can effectively protect the personal rights of the individual in the internet from state interference. It is to be taken into account that Article 8 ECHR, unlike Article 8 ECHR, does not contain an explicit reference to data protection. The work shows that Article 8 ECHR still guarantees an independent right to informational self-determination and that personal data are also covered by the scope of this guarantee. It goes into more detail on the interference with the right to respect for private and family life under Article 8 ECHR. In this regard, particular attention is paid to the individual phases of data use. Finally, the justification grounds prescribed by Article 8 (2) ECHR are considered in the sense that special requirements arise for the justification of information-technical interventions in the internet. Introduction -- First Part: The protection goods relevant to personal protection in the internet under Article 8 ECHR -- Second Part: State interference in personal rights in the internet -- Third Part: Justification of interference in personal rights in the internet -- Fourth Part: Summary of the results and conclusion

Motives of the Initial Public Offering on the New Market: Public Financing of Innovations from a Theoretical and Empirical Perspective ¤ In the public, new issues are primarily discussed from a return perspective and thus from the investor's point of view. The question of the motives for the initial public offering is rarely asked, although a closer examination of the motive would also be of great importance for individual investment decisions. In the present work, it is particularly about the question of why innovative growth companies in particular choose public financing and against private placement of shares. -- Initially, the various possible motives for an initial public offering are examined from a theoretical perspective, taking into account the specifics of the innovation process. Subsequently, the theoretical considerations are subjected to an empirical examination in the framework of a comprehensive investigation of the new issuers on the New Market and in other German market segments. -- The discussion with the essential financing theoretical works shows that the advantages of an initial public offering ultimately depend on the broad share dispersion, the information aggregation in the secondary market prices, and the immediacy of the capital allocation relationship. -- The results of the empirical investigation show two mutually exclusive motives for an initial public offering as particularly significant: Obviously, the initial public offering fulfills partially different functions in innovative growth companies than in established companies. On the one hand, there are companies in which the previous controlling shareholders are looking for a way to finance pending investments externally, without having to accept a restriction on the power of disposal over the operational resources. Companies listed on the New Market are generally to be counted among this group. On the other hand, there are (mainly established) companies in which the previous controlling shareholders use the initial public offering as the first stage of a complete disposal of the shares.

Engagement and Remembrance: Left History in Post-1989 Novel Literature ¤ It is said that the winners write history. How, then, is the remembrance of the struggles of the workers' movement after 1989 told? Are stories of decline and a 'left melancholy' dominant, or does a thinking of possibilities unfold in the remembrance of the past, which is also able to re-perspective the future? Sebastian Schweer analyzes engaged German-language memory novels in which the history of the workers' and movement is archived, criticized, reflected, and further spun. Following the question of the relationship between novel form, remembrance, and the status of utopian thinking, he deals with subjects such as squatting, terrorism, the legacy of the GDR, or socialist cybernetics.

Membrane-type acoustic metamaterials for aircraft noise shields ¤ This work investigates the applicability of membrane-type acoustic metamaterials as efficient low-frequency tonal noise reduction means. Analytical models for the calculation of the sound transmission properties of noise shields with membrane-type acoustic metamaterials are developed. These models are then employed in the design of an experimental aircraft noise shield demonstrator, which is characterized on a vibro-acoustic fuselage test structure under realistic mounting and acoustic excitation conditions. END

The Expansion of Public Charging Infrastructure for Electric Vehicles: Perspectives on State Governance for Climate Protection and Mobility Assurance ¤ Die Umstellung des Individualverkehrs auf Batterieelektromobilität ist ein zentraler Baustein für die zum Klimaschutz notwendige Verkehrswende. Ohne ein flächendeckendes Netz öffentlich zugänglicher Ladestationen sind Elektroautos jedoch nicht attraktiv genug. Die mangelnde Verfügbarkeit preisgünstiger Lademöglichkeiten vor allem auf dem Land hemmt die Verbreitung der klimafreundlichen Antriebstechnologie. Es bedarf daher staatlicher Förderung, um den Ladeinfrastrukturausbau zu beschleunigen. Bei der Beurteilung verschiedener politischer Gestaltungsoptionen stellen sich regulierungsrechtliche Fragen. Im Zentrum steht dabei der rechtliche Rahmen für den Umgang mit dem Netzcharakter der Ladeinfrastruktur und ihren daraus folgenden ökonomischen Besonderheiten, insbesondere im Verhältnis von beschleunigtem Infrastrukturaufbau und Wettbewerbssicherung. Climate protection in private transport demands a switch to low-emission drive technologies. Electromobility looks particularly promising – but its success depends on a nationwide network of charging stations. With Germany still having some catching up to do, Charlotte Schings takes a legal look at the various options for state funding to speed up the rollout of charging facilities.

Growth and characterisation of lead iodide single crystals ¤ Abstract: This work deals with the growth and characterization of lead iodide single crystals. The semiconductor material lead iodide (PbI2) is suitable for application as a X-ray or gamma-ray detector at room temperature. It has decisive advantages over other materials such as HgI2, CdTe, Si, GaAs: due to a bandgap energy of 2.32 eV, excellent absorption capacity, and high specific resistance, PbI2 represents a promising alternative for the production of noise-free detectors that do not require additional cooling. However, a particular challenge in the application of PbI2 as a detector material is the growth and preparation of chemically and structurally high-quality single crystals. Against this background, the effectiveness of zone purification of the PbI2 used for growth was spectroscopically confirmed, as well as technological aspects during the further processing of purified PbI2 were investigated. Based on thermal analyses, a correlation between the degree of influence of atmospheric oxygen on the source material and the structural quality of the resulting crystals was found. The use of hydrogen gas as an effective method for removing oxidative impurities was transferred to PbI2 and led to a significant reduction in structural defects such as polycrystalline growth or stress cracks. The growth of PbI2 single crystals was carried out, inter alia, by the Bridgman-Stockbarger method, where the influences of ampule design and preparation were particularly investigated

Integration of Spatial Planning Aspects into Traffic Planning: An Interregional Analysis Based on the Input-Output Account ¤ Spatial planning and traffic planning -- commodity flows of the German national economy -- transport flows of German traffic statistics -- linking commodity flows with transport flows -- transport flow visualization model – TraViMo 2.0. The author provides a contribution to the improvement of federal traffic route planning, particularly under spatial planning aspects, developed using scientific methods. As a result, the steps are shown in detail, how regional data mining with traffic statistics can be carried out using the Business Intelligence software Tableau. By combining the input-output account and traffic connectivity prognosis, new scientific findings are gained and made applicable to practice. With the development of the transport flow visualization model (TraViMo), the author succeeds in developing an instrument in the age of Big Data, which makes large data sets visible, understandable, and usable for the general public. Content • Spatial planning and traffic planning • commodity flows of the German national economy • transport flows of German traffic statistics • linking commodity flows with transport flows • transport flow visualization model – TraViMo 2.0 Target groups • lecturers and students of transportation science and economics • practitioners in the fields of science, management consulting, and professional public The author Dr. Bernd Buthe is a government councilor in the function as project leader at the Federal Institute for Building, Urban and Spatial Research. After studying economics in Münster, he worked in Essen as a management consultant in the transportation sector. Since 2009, he has been active in research and policy consulting.

Titan-Catalyzed Intermolecular Hydroaminoalkylation ¤ Because of the great biological and industrial relevance of amines new pathways for an easy and convenient access to this substance class have been investigated over many years. The metal-catalyzed hydroaminoalkylation of alkenes is a 100% atom-efficient reaction of great interest. In this doctoral thesis it was shown for the first time that titanium-based catalysts can be used for efficient metal-catalyzed hydroaminoalkylations of terminal alkenes. Interestingly, Ti-complexes with very different structures like Ti(NMe2)4, TiBn4 or Ind2TiMe2 showed a high catalytic activity. Besides the hydroaminoalkylation, the hydroamination of alkenes is also an elegant and 100 % atom-efficient pathway to more complex amines. The results presented in this doctoral thesis prove that the Lewis-acids GaCl3 and GaBr3 show a promising catalytical activity for the hydroamination of alkenes with p-toluenesulfonamide. <engl.>

Process and Cost Analysis of Packaging Options for Sterile Supplies in German Hospitals ¤ Kostenanalyse, Hospital, Management, Process analysis, Simulation, Sterile supply, Scenario analysis, Time measurement study Sterile supply through reprocessing of medical devices is often outside the focus of hospital managers as a process remote from the patient, even though this area is both medically and economically essential to the quality of the treatment process. The use of different survey techniques, such as document analysis and time measurement, can contribute to a comprehensive overall view and thus support a decision. This paper investigates the different packaging options of sterile supplies in six hospitals in Germany. With the help of an extensive time measurement study, the time differences in both packaging-related processes and infrastructural processes are first clarified. Furthermore, all relevant cost items are determined, resulting in costs for each packaging option. A distribution adjustment is carried out for both the times and the costs and then a Monte Carlo simulation is performed on this basis. In order to test the stability of the results obtained, a detailed scenario analysis is carried out in which a wide variety of input parameters, such as personnel and material costs, but also handling frequencies, are changed to show under which circumstances the advantageousness of an individual packaging option is given. If, for example, a change in packaging options results in free personnel capacities, these can be used to expand the range of services both in-house and for third parties. The work shows that the choice of packaging option is not the only decisive factor, but ...

Operative Management of Production Enterprises: Development of a Process Model ¤ The management of production enterprises faces the problem that the derivation of strategic plans into operational action possibilities and their implementation often do not lead to the desired success. The goals developed from the strategy process often do not correspond to the action potentials; implementation weaknesses arise. Manfred Bracher focuses the operative management of production enterprises under the aspect of goal-oriented corporate management in the focus of his consideration. He critically questions existing management models and investigates how they can be applied to solve the problem statement. The author develops a process model that he illuminates within a multi-dimensional order system under the aspects of processes, structures, evaluation, and corporate culture. In this, the adaptation and integration of Total Productive Maintenance play a crucial role. He checks the applicability and effectiveness of the model using a case study and derives action recommendations for the management of production enterprises. Problem description -- Management models -- Process model for operative management -- Case study -- Findings and action recommendations -- Summary and outlook.

Noise in the Hospital Operating Room: Performance Enhancement and Error Prevention through Optimized Acoustics ¤ Optimal acoustic conditions and noise-reducing measures provide the basis for concentrated work and promote error prevention. For the operating surgeon, communication deficits and distraction can be concrete consequences of inadequate acoustics. Philipp Knöfler illustrates with measurements in the operating surgeon's ear canal that the recommended noise maximum level at the operating table is clearly exceeded. For the examined operating room, possibilities for reducing the level were developed, which can also be transferred to other operating rooms. However, to ensure an acoustic minimum standard in the realization of operating rooms, simple and manageable guidelines must be implemented in the planning process. The planning task 'quiet operating room' should urgently find its way into practice, so that the working conditions for the staff can be improved and an adequate environment can also be created for the patient. The content Treatment errors due to inadequate acoustics Field study on the topic of noise in the OP Performance reduction due to noise Reverberation times and sound pressure levels in the OP The quiet operating room The target groups Lecturers and students from the fields of architecture, medicine, psychology, environmental sciences, and civil engineering Architects, physicians, and space planners The author Dr. Philipp Knöfler is an architect, lecturer, and scientific employee with a focus on sustainable building and building and room acoustics. Treatment errors due to inadequate acoustics -- Field study on the topic of noise in the OP -- Performance reduction due to noise -- Reverberation times and sound pressure levels in the OP -- The quiet operating room.

Investigations of the Vibration and Noise Behavior of the Crankshaft Drive of an Internal Combustion Engine ¤ Body vibration paths in the internal combustion engine -- measurement of piston oscillations -- measurement value transmission system for real engine operation -- comparison of experimental results with simulation calculations. By combining various measurement technology concepts in the field of body vibration measurement and using detailed signal analysis methods, Daniel Hrdina can present a comprehensive understanding of body vibration transmission over the crankshaft drive of an internal combustion engine. In doing so, he investigates the sensitivity to various parameters in the internal transmission path and in the excitation conditions. As the most influential factor, the author identifies the pressure rise rate – and thus the injection parameters. Based on this, he introduces the concept of the operating point-dependent combustion chamber pressure gradient, which shows potential for optimization under NVH aspects at a passenger car diesel engine with common rail injection. The content Body vibration paths in the internal combustion engine Measurement of piston oscillations Measurement value transmission system for real engine operation Comparison of experimental results with simulation calculations The target groups Researchers, students, and engineers in practice in the field of NVH, engine acoustics and mechanics for internal combustion engines The author Daniel Hrdina was promoted at the Institute for Internal Combustion Engines and Automotive Engineering (IVK) at the University of Stuttgart. He is now a Global Product Expert and Coordinator of the Product Development Portfolio for Truck Piston at a medium-sized automotive supplier in Stuttgart.

Methods of Data Mining Applied to the Flexibility Attributes of Automotive Body Construction for Strategic Investment Planning ¤ The concept of flexibility is always in vogue in the production world, especially in the automotive industry. Increasing derivatives and fluctuations on the sales markets enhance the demand for flexible production facilities.--- The primary problem statement associated with this is that the concept of flexibility is not clearly defined, and accordingly, there is a diffuse general understanding of flexibility. Furthermore, the factors that describe flexibility and the associated investments are mostly unknown. Specifically, for automotive body construction, this paradox was taken up in this work and flexibility was made measurable in the form of investments.--- After analyzing general variant and flexibility management, flexibility can be divided into four areas based on Kaluza's schema. These four areas or flexibility types have general validity and can always be used synonymously for other commonly used designations ...

Influence of General Personality Rights on Statutory Data Protection: An Analysis Using the Example of Virtual Storage ¤ This book deals with virtual storage as an aspect of cloud computing and the General Data Protection Regulation. In accordance with the Federal Constitutional Court's ruling of February 2008 on online searches, the initial investigation is conducted to determine whether the statements made and the highlighted right to ensure the confidentiality and integrity of information technology systems can be transferred and applied to the use of online storage. Subsequently, the statutory framework is examined. In this chapter, Diane Rataj primarily focuses on the General Data Protection Regulation and investigates the influence of the right to ensure the confidentiality and integrity of information technology systems on this framework. The content The Telecommunications Secret and Cloud Technology The Own Sphere of Authority in Times of Permanent Synchronization National Data Protection of Constitutional Rank Virtual Corporate Storage National and European Fundamental Rights Determinations National and European Data Protection The Person Responsible for Data Processing Certification Encryption as a Processing Principle The Target Groups Lecturers and Students from the Departments of Public Law Practitioners of Data Protection and IT Law The Author Diane Rataj is completing her traineeship at the KG Berlin and works in the Law Group of the Research Project „IKT III for Electromobility“ The Telecommunications Secret and Cloud Technology -- The Own Sphere of Authority in Times of Permanent Synchronization -- National Data Protection of Constitutional Rank -- Virtual Corporate Storage -- National and European Fundamental Rights Determinations -- National and European Data Protection -- The Person Responsible for Data Processing -- Certification -- Encryption as a Processing Principle

Decoding magma plumbing and geochemical evolution of active volcanoes of the Central Andes (North Chile) with petrological methods ¤ Lascar, Lastarria, magma plumbing system, andesite, magmatic differentiation, magma mixing, geothermobarometry, pre-eruptive condtions. - Magmatic plumbing system, Andesite, magmatic differentiation, Geothermobarometry, pre-eruptive conditions

Bourgeois Chill : Affect and Colonial Subjectivity ¤ "Bourgeois Chill" refers to a present-day emotional state with which citizens shield themselves from the violence they themselves cause. With colonialism and the philosophy of the Enlightenment in view, Henrike Kohpeiss shows how racist emotional structures develop. For this, the classical, critical texts by Adorno and Horkheimer enter into a dialogue with the field of Black Studies and thinkers like Saidiya Hartman, Fred Moten, and Denise Ferreira da Silva. These two intellectual traditions are connected by radical criticism of the capitalist and colonial establishment of the world. The violence history of European colonialism is thus read as an affect theory of bourgeois subjectivity, its appearance of innocence is taken away

Morphology and crystal orientation of ferroelectric P(VDF-ran-TrFE) nanostructures in porous aluminium oxide ¤ We have fabricated ferroelectric P(VDF-TrFE) nanostructures using ordered nanoporous aluminium oxide. The nanostructures were characterised using DSC, XRD, SEM and TEM. The DSC results show that the melting temperature decreases with increasing confinement, while the transition temperature from the ferro- to the paraelectric phase, TC, remains unchanged. We provide an explanation for the unchanged TC in confinement based on the thermodynamic stability of the different phases. The results of X-ray scattering show that the (110) planes of the crystallites in P(VDF-TrFE) preferentially orient parallel to the substrate surface, with the polar b-axis at an angle of 30° to the pore axis. Furthermore, our results show that the preferred orientation is established in two steps. In the first step - during crystallisation - the parallel orientation of the c-axis to the substrate surface is established. In the second step - during the transition to the ferroelectric phase - the (110) planes orient parallel to the substrate surface. This orientation of the (110) planes is a result of the minimisation of the depolarisation field in the nanostructures. P(VDF-TrFE); Nanostructures; Wetting; Ferroelectric polymer; Confinement; Crystallization; Phase Transition; Porous Alumina; DSC; XRD

Mentoring at the Transition from Studies to Profession: An Empirical Study on Success Factors and Perceived Benefits ¤ Stephan Pflaum examines in a three-year panel study systematically the benefits of mentoring at the transition from studies to profession from the perspective of mentees and mentors. The author presents conditions for good mentoring and successful mentoring programs based on quantitative and qualitative data. The subject of the study is the nationwide largest, faculty- and branch-crossing mentoring program of the Ludwig-Maximilians-University Munich. From the results of the study, recommendations for action are derived for the optimal design of mentoring programs at universities. The content Mentoring in the context of other forms of counseling and support Mentoring from the perspective of the social sciences and pedagogy Empirical findings on the benefits and conditions of successful mentoring Determinants of successful mentoring at the transition from studies to profession The target groups Lecturers and students of pedagogy and social sciences Organizers of university mentoring programs and their participants The author Stephan Pflaum is a pedagogue and sociologist. He leads the faculty- and branch-crossing mentoring program of the Ludwig-Maximilians-University. In addition, he is a trainer and lecturer, inter alia, in the areas of personnel development and counseling in adult education Mentoring in the context of other forms of counseling and support -- Mentoring from the perspective of the social sciences and pedagogy -- Empirical findings on the benefits and conditions of successful mentoring -- Determinants of successful mentoring at the transition from studies to profession

Rationality Deficits in the Actions of Controllers: Forms of Expression and Countermeasures ¤ If one understands controlling as a rationality safeguard of leadership, it has the function to identify and alleviate potential rationality deficits in the actions of managers due to self-interested behavior and cognitive limitations. Essential carriers of this function are controllers. Anne Paefgen examines the following question: Must not also for controllers the assumption apply to act self-interestedly and be cognitively limited? But who then secures the rationality of the controllers themselves or – formulated differently – who controls the controller? From a behavioral scientific perspective, the author analyzes potential rationality deficits in the actions of controllers and traces them back to their possible causes. From the insights gained in this way, she derives reactive and proactive measures to secure the rationality of controllers. Introduction -- Foundations of the work -- Forms of expression of potential rationality deficits in the actions of controllers -- Approaches to a rationality safeguard of controllers -- Final consideration.

Science, Technology Development, and the Varieties of Capitalism: An Analysis of Seed Development in the USA and Germany ¤ Varieties of Knowledge Capitalism -- Intellectual Property Rights -- Science and Technology Development in the Agricultural Sector -- Green Biotechnology. Barbara Brandl illustrates the interconnection of technology development and socio-political settings by means of agricultural innovations. In particular, she highlights how the focus on a one-sided innovation ideal in late capitalist societies poses a long-term risk of significantly limiting the knowledge potential available to solve future problems. The development of seed is particularly significant in terms of sustainability, as the quality and diversification of seed not only affects the quality of food but also makes a decisive contribution to biodiversity and thus to the future of this planet. The content • Varieties of Knowledge Capitalism • Intellectual Property Rights • Science and Technology Development in the Agricultural Sector • Green Biotechnology The target groups • Lecturers and students of sociology • Practitioners in policy consulting, innovation and science policy as well as agricultural policy The author Barbara Brandl is a research assistant at the Chair of Economic Sociology at the University of Trier. Her research focuses on economic sociology, comparative political economy, and technology sociology, particularly digital financial innovations, blockchain, and green biotechnology.

Design, realization, and characterization of optical negative index metamaterials ¤ This work deals with artificial nanostructured optical materials - metamaterials, which possess optical properties that do not occur in natural materials. The metamaterials consist of elementary cells, whose size is smaller than the wavelength of light and can therefore be considered as effective media. The effective optical parameters of the metamaterials are, in analogy to natural materials, determined by the electromagnetic properties of the elementary cells or "meta-atoms" and can be changed by adapted design. The goal of this work was to formulate design principles for metamaterials with a negative refractive index in the optical spectral range and to develop experimental methods for the characterization of their optical properties. The design strategies for double-element metamaterials were developed based on the evaluation of the production method based on electron beam lithography. As a result, a metamaterial in the near-infrared spectral range with a negative refractive index was successfully realized. The possibility of optimizing the optical properties of the metamaterials by breaking the symmetry of the meta-atom geometry was investigated analytically using a multipole model and experimentally. It was shown that asymmetry has a significant impact on the magnetic properties of the meta-atoms and allows the control of the effective magnetic permeability of metamaterials in wide ranges. For the complete and precise determination of the refractive index of metamaterials, an experimental method was developed, which is based on the interferometric determination of the transfer function of an optical metamaterial. For this purpose, a setup for phase measurements in transmission and reflection in the visible and near-infrared spectral range was developed.

Key Actors in Nuclear Waste Governance: Disposal Options and Strategies from a Regional Perspective ¤ Social scientific ‚nuclear waste research‘ -- Individual expectations of waste disposal policy (after 2014) -- Fair and effective citizen participation at potential sites -- Individual evaluation of disposal options. Cord Drögemüller deals with the regional dimension of the nuclear waste conflict in the Federal Republic of Germany. From the perspective of governance and participation research, he examines local problem perceptions. In this context, he shows the expectations of municipal politicians and civil society interest groups for a ‚good‘ waste disposal policy. The author highlights the opportunities and limitations of citizen participation as well as the evaluation of different disposal options. He shows that a reliable and flexible nuclear waste governance is needed, which enables high-quality and demand-oriented participation of citizens with fair negotiation processes. Classical control approaches fall short of meeting the demanding civil society expectations. The content Social scientific ‚nuclear waste research‘ Individual expectations of waste disposal policy (after 2014) Fair and effective citizen participation at potential sites Individual evaluation of disposal options The target groups Lecturers and students of politics and social sciences Actors in the political shaping of the disposal of highly radioactive waste The author Cord Drögemüller is a research assistant at the Research Center for Environmental Policy (FFU) of the Free University of Berlin.

Vergaberecht im Wettbewerb der Systeme : a cross-sectional analysis of procurement law ¤ The open economic constitution of the Basic Law has various effects on the public procurement system. Marc Bungenberg analyses the constitutional, European and international law foundations of increasingly important procurement law. (Source: Publisher's blurb).

The History of Email: Success and Crisis of a Mass Medium ¤ Millions of emails go around the world every day. The more astonishing it is that the origin of this medium seems to have happened almost by the way and has been hardly worked on scientifically so far. This study reconstructs the success story of the email service and shows that technology can only be successful as a network of technical, social, and cultural relationships. If this framework changes without the technology reacting to it, it falls into a fatal crisis, whose effects we are trying to combat today in the form of spam and phishing attacks.

Computer Grafik : Aesthetic Experiments between Two Cultures The Beginnings of Computer Art in the 1960s ¤ "Computer Graphics" is an innovative contribution to the unwritten history of 1960s computer graphics. Against the backdrop of C. P. Snow's "two cultures" discussion, a new form of generative or algorithmic art developed in the Stuttgart School around Max Bense, marking the beginnings of digital computer graphics. Central theoretical and artistic concepts are discussed in the works of Frieder Nake, Georg Nees, A. Michael Noll, and Manfred Mohr. Pioneer achievements, theoretical discussions, and relationships to contemporary art movements are systematically a

Distribution Approximation by Convex Bounds : with Applications to Sums of Lognormally Distributed Random Variables ¤ The goal of the present work was to explore and investigate possibilities for approximating the terminal value of investment plans, as typically offered by banks and insurance companies. Of interest are approximations for the distribution function, quantiles, truncated expectations, and tail values at risk. The modeling of the underlying stock price processes is, as usual, as geometric Brownian motion, so that the terminal value of a stock portfolio plan is structurally a sum of lognormally distributed random variables. The distribution of such a sum is, however, not explicitly given; its simulation is naturally possible, but due to the multitude of investment plans to be managed by a bank or insurance company, impractical. Again and again, one comes across works that point out that the sum of lognormally distributed random variables can be well approximated by a one-dimensional lognormally distributed random variable, usually by one with the same expectation and the same variance. This could mostly be supported only by simulations and numerical calculations. We present here a result that provides a justification for the mentioned approximation: the distribution convergence to a lognormal distribution at vanishing variances/covariances of the summands ...

When Voters Decide: Processes of Decision-Making and the Timing of the Election Decision ¤ This volume deals with the measurement and theoretical interpretation of the timing of the election decision. To this end, a theory of the decision-making process is developed, which produces a synthesis of hitherto disparate research results. Two results are to be highlighted: Firstly, no clear increase in later election decisions can be demonstrated. Secondly, it can be shown that the timing of the election decision results from a complex interplay of voter characteristics, characteristics of the decision situation, and the information environment.

Sequential Investment Decisions under Uncertainty ¤ Real investments are associated with a wide range of different decisions. These decisions are highly interdependent. The initial investment decision must take into account the possibility of being able to make subsequent decisions. This fact becomes particularly relevant when income from investment projects is expected to be received in the distant future, i.e., when there is a long time span between the initial investment decision and the sale of products. In this case, uncertainty about prices, demand, or the behavior of competitors and the possibility of reacting to it play an important role. The author deals with the sequential character of investment decisions under uncertainty. For this purpose, models are developed that are based on options price and game-theoretic findings and can thus include both uncertainty about prices and demand as well as the behavior of competitors in the analysis. From these models, numerous findings can be derived that are of significant importance for the further development of investment theory

Optical Method for Two-Dimensional Measurement of Angles and Angle Changes at Large Measurement Distances ¤ In the present dissertation, a new measurement method and a new measuring device for two-dimensional measurement of angles and angle changes are presented based on a specific task from industrial production. Conventional methods already in use as well as alternative methods based on further physical principles are used and evaluated. A solution based on a so-called vignetting field-blade method is described in its principal structure and function and its suitability is investigated in relation to the task. The theoretical foundations are initially presented in a purely geometric-optical manner and are further subjected to a lighting-technical consideration with natural vignetting. The illumination intensity distribution of the light spot in the image plane, the so-called V-SPOT, is analytically derived in dependence on various influencing factors. Furthermore, intensity and centroid shifts within the V-SPOT are investigated by effects such as geometric-optical influences, radiation characteristics of the object illumination area in dependence on the radiation angle as well as luminance distribution in dependence on the location in the object plane by numerical simulation. Based on these foundations, the theoretical investigations of the possible measurement range, linearity, and physical resolution limit are carried out. The theoretical investigations are compared with experimentally determined measurements and deviations are discussed.

Beyond the quantum limit : a squeezed-light laser in GEO 600 ¤ Interferometric gravitational-wave detector, squeezed light generation and injection, nonclassically enhanced sensitivity, low frequency squeezing. - Gravitationswellendetektor, squeezed light in the audio frequency range, non-classical improvement of the measurement accuracy of laser interferometers

Interaction of amino acids with different ionogenic groups ¤ The subject of this work is the investigation of amorphous silica and mesoporous silicate MCM-41. The focus was on determining the influence of the structure of the silica as a starting material on the properties of the produced material, on the synthesis and on the efficiency of the product in catalytic and adsorption applications. In order to achieve the above-mentioned goal, the modification of amorphous silica and MCM-41 was carried out. For this, the silylation method was chosen. Another important goal of the present work was the investigation of the adsorption of amino acids from aqueous solutions on the starting materials and modified silicates, in order to determine the influence of the structure of the starting material, as well as the built-in functional layer on the adsorption of biologically active molecules. The type of interactions that occur in the system „adsorbate - silicate adsorbent“ were analyzed.

Synthesis of Dihydropyridine Derivatives for Biological Profiling ¤ In the first part of this work, important details of the mechanism of synthesis of crossed dihydropyridines (DHP) were clarified. By breaking down the 4-component reaction into sub-reactions, potential key intermediates were isolated and characterized, as well as implausible reaction pathways were excluded. By inserting the hypothetical intermediate into the crossed DHP synthesis and following the reaction course by in situ NMR, the preferred reaction pathway was identified. To optimize the yield of the crossed DHP synthesis, the influence of reaction parameters pH value, temperature, and solvent as well as Lewis acidic catalysts such as Yb(OTf)3 was investigated. The best results were achieved by the conversion in methanol at 120 °C in the microwave oven over 10 min, the crossed DHP with yields of 60-90% was obtained. In the second part of the work, it was investigated to what extent the inhibitory effect on the Notch signaling pathway depends on the structure of the DHP. Derivatives of the DHP FLI-06 were synthesized, either by substituting the reaction components or by converting the DHP in subsequent reactions. The modifications with the highest biological activity were combined to increase possible interactions with a hypothetical binding pocket. In total, 143 DHP were synthesized and investigated for their biological activity in this work. By separating the enantiomers of the three most active DHP using chiral HPLC, enantioselectivity of the biological activity was demonstrated. An enantioselective synthesis, however, was not successful, corresponding literature reports were not reproducible. The presented DHP served as a 'tool compound' to identify potential intermolecular interactions with a hypothetical binding pocket, which were summarized in a pharmacophore. Based on the findings of the structure-activity relationship, first molecular probes were developed to investigate the localization of DHP in the cell. Several DHP with functionalized side chains were synthesized. They enable coupling with other compounds by click reaction, amidation, and through the presentation of thioethers. Methods for enantiomer separation using chiral HPLC were also developed to be able to distinguish selective colocalization of background signals. It was possible to observe first colocalizations in mitochondria. Their connection with the specific efficacy of DHP must still be further investigated. This work provides a basis for the development of molecular probes that can contribute to the clarification of the role of the target of DHP in the Notch signaling pathway in healthy as well as in diseased cells.

Investigation of the applicability of wetland biomass for producing hydrochar by hydrothermal carbonization and its effectiveness for the adsorption of ammonia ¤ The underlying motivation of this work was the use of widespread but underutilized wetland biomass as reed, typha, juncus and carex to be used as substrates for the hydrothermal carbonation (HTC) to produce a variety of high-value carbonaceous materials and to test their suitability as alternative adsorbents for the removal of ammonia in aqueous solution. The results of this work confirmed that it was possible to transform these wetland biomasses into carbonaceous products with a sufficiently high efficiency for ammonia removal in aqueous solution, which could be designed as a filter.

Criminology in Civil Society: Discourses of Science and the British Public, 1830-1945 ¤ Why do people become criminal? What causes delinquent behavior? Such questions concern experts just as much as the broader public - and both are in greater exchange of ideas than one might initially think. Sabine Freitag approaches places of knowledge production about the causes of crime just as much as civil society spaces where the theses of the experts were discussed

Passages of Pedagogy: Towards a Pedagogical Moment in the Wake of Niklas Luhmann and Gilles Deleuze ¤ This study raises the question of how pedagogy can be thought of as mobile and systematic beyond the petrification in systemic structures. This paradoxical starting constellation can be met with Luhmann's late systems theory, which attempts to push a differentialist turn beyond the classical concept of difference. The hitherto open ends of this project are further developed with Deleuze. In a topological reading - especially from the perspective of a topology of difference - pedagogy can be refigured as an expression system.

Interorganizational Information Systems in the Maritime Supply Chain: An Information Economic Investigation in the Field of Containerized Inland Transport ¤ Holger Pontow demonstrates that interorganizational information systems in the fragmented maritime supply chain hold numerous potential benefits. To be able to evaluate these qualitatively and quantitatively in advance of investment decisions, he uses methods and tools from the fields of business process management (especially business process modeling using BPMN) and decision theory in the core of his investigation. It shows – especially on the basis of the mediated cross-organizational business process understanding – that, in addition to organizations that realize the transport and handling, especially shippers should use suitable systems for communication in order to realize the theoretically possible potential benefits in practice. The content Collection and analysis of business processes and information flows in imports and exports as well as a shipper Collection and analysis of benefit functions for shipowners, terminal operators, rail operators, railway transport companies The target groups Lecturers and students of the fields of (transport-) logistics and business informatics Practitioners in the field of maritime supply chains (especially IT and process managers) as well as providers of portal solutions The author Holger Pontow graduated as a scientific assistant at the field of Corporate Management and Logistics in the Faculty of Law and Economics at the Technical University of Darmstadt.

Virtualization of Embedded Real-Time Systems in Multi-Core Operation for Partitioning Safety-Relevant Vehicle Software ¤ The automotive industry has seen a significant increase in new electrical and electronic vehicle functions over the past few years. This leads to an increase in software volumes in embedded systems. Non-functional requirements such as safety, performance, reliability, and maintainability pose additional challenges for the development of future vehicle systems. To reduce the number of control units, vehicle functions are to be consolidated on common integration control units. System virtualization can be a targeted approach to facilitate software migration to integration control units and meet the required isolation requirements of new security standards at the same time. In this work, the partitioning of safety-relevant vehicle functions on a common hardware platform is focused. Using methods for evaluating social networks, a graph-based approach is presented to assess the partitionability of software networks with safety-relevant components. For the realization of system partitioning, a method for selecting the most suitable kernel architecture is introduced. From selected non-functional properties, potential technical solution concepts are derived within a tree structure and evaluated in an engineering manner. Based on this, a hypervisor for embedded real-time systems of ETAS Ltd. is evaluated. To be able to assess the costs of an additional hypervisor layer, runtime measurements are performed in this framework. Thus, the effects of an additional virtualization layer on vehicle software systems to fulfill selected non-functional properties are shown. The connection of virtualized systems to the communication interfaces of the hypervisor is another focus. Virtual control units continue to exchange information over already implemented communication channels and access common hardware resources. Thus, a concept is introduced to decouple safety-relevant parts of the AUTOSAR Microcontroller Abstraction Layers. The hypervisor itself is extended at relevant points and a reliable communication concept is implemented. A demonstrator setup, to consolidate productive vehicle software on a common hardware platform, finalizes the work. Here, independent software states are paravirtualized. As a summary of the work, the reader receives both a technical overview of the added value and the costs of paravirtualized vehicle platforms, which are integrated on small control units.

Modelling and use of SysML behaviour models for achieving dynamic use cases of technical products in different VR-systems ¤ Digital methods and models enable product designers to evaluate the product early on, so that they can better understand the product's behavior and its interactions with neighboring systems in its later life phases. Virtual Reality (VR) is a technology that can contribute to the early evaluation process by displaying later life situations of a product already in the design phase. However, the application of VR in industry is currently limited due to the high model preparation effort and the limited reusability of existing models. Therefore, this work deals with the development of a method that can facilitate early product evaluation within VR and the use of VR in the product development process. This method deals with the process of developing general behavior descriptions for use in VR, which can also be reused to depict dynamic use cases of a product in different VR systems. The focus is on reducing the entire model preparation effort for VR models and on achieving a high reusability of existing models. The core components of the work consist in the use of Model-Based Systems Engineering (MBSE) to develop general behavior model descriptions, their use in creating different use cases of a product in a VR system, and their reuse in different VR systems. The Systems Modeling Language (SysML) is used to describe the behavior models, the modeling process is systematically described and also summarized in the form of general application guidelines for later use. In addition, a dedicated physics engine is used to perform the physical calculations for virtual objects in VR, which is also integrated with SysML. These SysML behavior models together with the physics engine form a real-time product application simulation in VR. The same SysML behavior models are used for different VR systems to depict real-time simulations and to validate their reuse. Two VR prototypes were developed to demonstrate the effectiveness and use of the presented methods. Finally, one of the prototypes was subjected to an empirical study conducted by experts from science and industry.

Abstract Period Spaces, Projectors, and Traces of Hecke Operators ¤ The subject of the dissertation is the purely algebraic construction of a projector onto abstract period spaces. The abstract period spaces can be viewed as a generalization of the period spaces from the context of classical elliptic modular forms (Manin relations). With the help of the projector, an abstract trace formula of the Hecke operators is then derived, and as an application of this, Zagier's trace formula at level 1 (1990) is reconstructed.

The Neighbourhood Space under Article 8 TEU: Status Quo and Potential of European Neighbourhood Relations ¤ How does the European Union do justice to the special proximity relationship with its neighbouring states? This work approaches the topic of European neighbourhood relations with a normative approach. It analyses what potential Article 8 TEU holds for neighbourhood relations. The look at Article 8 TEU largely dissociates itself from the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) and thus opens up a new access to the political concept of European neighbourhood relations. The norm analysis shows a neighbourhood space that stands out in the system of European external relations particularly through its privilege effect and its independence. In relation to the Association Agreement with Ukraine, the ENP is set in relation to the neighbourhood space as the status quo of European neighbourhood relations. This juxtaposition reveals that the status quo does not exploit the potential of Article 8 TEU.

Regions of Education in Scientific Further Education: Model and Empirical Analysis ¤ In the dissertation, a cross-disciplinary concept of education regions is developed: theoretically and empirically founded. The study on demand-oriented regionalization approaches in scientific further education is based on empirical data and case studies. In the results of the analysis, a new regionalization is confirmed as a counter-movement to internationalization, which is consciously designed in scientific further education. This is also part of economic regional development, as the qualification offers are further developed for the local skilled workers. The author presents the first investigation on this relevant topic of education and higher education practice. His practice-oriented analysis underpins the regionalization trends of scientific higher education further development with a theoretical foundation and creates a model as an orientation for practice.

Klimatic Geographical Contents of Geography Lessons Experienced-Based Understanding: A Didactic Reconstruction of the Trade Wind System ¤ Passatzirkulation, embodied cognition, didactic reconstruction. - Trade wind system, embodied cognition, didactic reconstruction

The spectra of indefinite singular Sturm-Liouville operators ¤ In the present work, the spectral properties of singular Sturm-Liouville differential operators of the form Af=1/r(-(pf')' + qf) with real-valued coefficients p, q, and r are investigated. Here, we consider indefinite weight functions r. Based on knowledge from relative oscillation theory as well as Floquet theory for periodic Sturm-Liouville operators, criteria are established that ensure the stability of the essential spectra under perturbation of the coefficients. Furthermore, the accumulation of eigenvalues in the gaps of the essential spectrum is investigated. We formulate conditions that imply the accumulation of eigenvalues within a gap, or exclude it. Additionally, the non-real spectra of indefinite Sturm-Liouville operators are investigated. Here, bounds of the non-real eigenvalues with respect to their absolute value and imaginary part are determined. The proof of the bounds relies on a careful analysis of the associated eigenfunctions.

Crystallization of a UV-structurable Glass in the System Li2O-Al2O3-SiO2 ¤ UV-structurable glasses expand the material palette of materials used in microsystem technology. Micro-mechanical components, such as grippers, sensors, and micro-drives with high aspect ratios in the micrometer range can be manufactured through the process of photostructuring of glass. In this work, the process flows for the crystallization of a UV-structurable glass in the system Li2O-Al2O3-SiO2 are investigated. The relationships found in this process expand the existing scientific understanding of the complex physical and chemical processes that occur in this specific glass. In accordance with the requirement to set the redox system necessary for UV structuring in the starting glass, the first part of the work briefly addresses the successful production of the glass melted in a small-scale plant. The main part of this work deals with the solution of still open questions about the mechanism of heterogeneous, UV radiation-supported formation of crystal nuclei. Using various experimental methods, the processes during the technological individual steps of illumination, tempering, and etching were investigated. It was largely possible to clarify the effect of silver as a nucleus former and to define the exact illumination and thermal conditions for nucleus formation and crystal growth. In contrast to previously assumed findings, the silver ions are not only located in the droplet-like inhomogeneities of the glass, but are finely dispersed both in the matrix and in the droplets. Only in the droplets can the crystal phase lithium metasilicate grow on the silver clusters formed in the structuring process, since only here the chemical composition is suitable. The conditions found for the production of micro-structured components for nucleus formation and crystal growth are used as a prerequisite for the production of well-etchable crystal aggregates. By applying a multi-stage temperature regime with holding times at nucleus formation and crystal growth temperatures, industrially usable forceps were produced with high reproducibility and yield. Furthermore, the relationships found between illumination energy density, nucleus formation, and crystal growth conditions can be used to deliberately change the mechanical properties of photo-structured glass components. Defined illumination and special thermal post-treatment increased the bending strength of micro-structured components from about 340 to about 540 MPa.

Acting, Thinking, and Understanding : Investigations into the Natural-Scientific-Technical Subject Matter in Elementary School ¤ The starting point of Kornelia Möller's investigation is the controversial discussion among didacticians about the ability of elementary school children to productively deal with matters from nature and technology. The present work is based on multi-year, audiovisually recorded investigations in teaching-like, problem-oriented situations, which are documented and interpreted in this volume. In the interpretation, the previously neglected non-verbal media of confrontation, such as action, gesture, mimicry, and drawing, and their networking in their significance for thinking and interaction processes were analyzed. The author succeeds in proving that elementary school children give up their naive and pre-causal theories in favor of justified, verified, understandable, and communicable statements in a highly action-oriented learning process. This book offers rich material for designing productive, understanding-oriented learning processes in the natural-scientific-technical subject matter.

An element-selective detector for gas chromatography based on a miniaturized capacitively stabilized plasma ¤ The subject of this work is a new atomic emission detector (AED) for gas chromatography (GC), the æ-ESD. In the present work, the design and operating principle of the æ-ESD are presented. The suitability of the detector for element-selective determination of Cl, Br, F, S, and C in the near infrared after optimization of some operating parameters was investigated. Furthermore, possibilities for correcting spectral and chemical interferences were discussed. The characterization of the detector was carried out on the basis of important detector properties such as selectivity and sensitivity.
