A final comparison of the æ-ESD with a commercial AED and an electron trap detector based on investigations of some environmental samples made it possible to assess the performance capability of the new detector. In direct comparison with the commercial AED, both analytical and economic aspects were considered.

Efficient and accurate evaluation of aggregation integrals in population balance equations ¤ Applications of population balance equations can be found in many chemical production processes, e.g, crystallization and precipitation of pharmaceutical materials. In population balance equations the aggregation process is described by source and sink aggregation integrals. The source aggregation integral is usually numerically expensive to evaluate having quadratic complexity. In this thesis we focus on the efficient and accurate evaluation of aggregation integrals, reducing this complexity to almost linear. We also include extensive numerical tests for different setups, leading to (heuristic) strategies for the choice of the discretization parameters.

Education Coaching through Competence Monitoring and Adaptive E-Learning Support: A Case Study of Mathematics Basic Qualification at Universities ¤ Within the scope of this work, a comprehensive system was developed, operated, and evaluated, with which the mathematics entrance skills of students before the start of the first lectures are to be improved and homogenized. The global goal of this work was to develop and verify a transferable concept that enables the prevention of performance problems and reduces the dropout rate. The overall concept follows the approach that a high learning success can be achieved through a precise adjustment of the support measures to the individual mathematics competences of the students. For this purpose, the mathematics competences of the students were recorded in a database, which was used for individual adaptation of the presence and e-learning courses. The approach was divided into a conceptual and implementation phase, which was completed with the system development, and two practice phases with subsequent evaluation. The system was used university-wide for pre-qualification of all students. The formative evaluation of the system showed a high individual fit of the requirements in the pre-courses and a positive assessment of the adaptive measures on personal learning success. The summative evaluation showed a large learning gain of the students through the use of the system. In a t-test of dependent samples, a strong effect (d=1.83) was demonstrated. The average score achieved in the mathematics final test has more than doubled compared to the mathematics entrance test (entrance test: M=13.70; SD=8.82; n=132, final test: M=28.48; SD=7.31; n=132) and the performance differences between the students have leveled out. Thus, the current work provides a valuable knowledge gain for research, development, and practical implementation of qualification measures in the form of integrated blended learning systems in the study entrance phase, which, in the context of the inhomogeneity of the mathematics entrance competences of the students, achieve a high learning success through individual adaptation.
Innovative Plastisizers for Property Modification of Tire Compounds ¤ Rubber, plasticiser, elastomer chemistry, Tg-shift, blend, phase morphology.

Leonhard Euler's Work on Celestial Mechanics ¤ This comprehensive representation of Leonhard Euler's work on celestial mechanics shows how mathematical methods and physical principles developed, established, and evolved into standard procedures through various applications, which are still valid in classical astronomy and physics today. In an introductory chapter, known and newly discovered original sources and publications are described, whose authorship is attributed to Euler. The second chapter introduces the development of the problems of the time and Euler's solution methods in a compact manner. In the third and fourth chapters, Euler's contributions to celestial mechanics of point-like and extended bodies are described in terms of content and chronological development. The extensive appendix consists of overview tables and German translations of individual works by Euler on celestial mechanics. Contents: Introduction -- Problem statements and Euler's solution methods -- Euler's works on celestial mechanics of point-like bodies -- Euler's works on celestial mechanics of extended bodies -- Summary and conclusions -- Appendices and indexes. A Overview of the prize problems of the Paris Academy -- B Overview of Euler's works on celestial mechanics -- C Euler's correspondence on celestial mechanics -- D Description of Euler's treatises from O.II, 26/27 -- E Excerpts from Euler's notebook Ms401 (Diarium mathematicum) -- Illustration index -- Abbreviation index -- Bibliography -- Index.

The Budget Act as a Time Act: On the Significance of Temporal Bonds for Budget and Public Debt Law ¤ The Budget Act is a Time Act. It must be adopted at a specific point in time and is related to and limited to a specific period. Annuality and pre-budgeting of the budget are classical budget principles that have been brought back into focus by current constitutional court decisions on the limits of public debt. Henning Tappe analyzes central questions of budget law. What are the legal consequences of retroactive budget acts and credit authorizations? Can supplementary budgets also be adopted after the end of the budget year and approve the budget execution? What impact does the separation by years required by the Basic Law have on the assignment of revenues and expenditures to a specific budget plan? (Source: Publisher / Internet).

GIS Concept and Contours of an IT Master Plan: Planning and System Development for Information Technology ¤ Geographic Information System (GIS) as an information medium -- Purpose of GIS use and current state -- Core problems and contours of strategic GIS planning -- Implication -- Summary -- Conclusion and Outlook. The development of information technology has experienced continuous diverse application euphoria since the end of the 1990s. This is based on a redundant, superficially integrated, and not systematically conceived IT landscape. In order to secure their competitiveness, administration, industry, and economy are today more than ever dependent on IuK technologies. However, the need to invest in IT infrastructure is often countered by statements from analysts that the majority of IT investments hardly achieve the originally set goals. Ghader Haghwerdi-Poor examines the purpose and goal of high investments in the IT sector within the framework of a ten-year balance analysis. Based on methods of action research, he describes the current state of the use of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) exemplarily. He analyzes the problems and creates the foundation stones of a master plan for the development, implementation, and use of this technology. It can be used not only for the completion of routine tasks of the administration, but also as an instrument of decision-making in cross-sectional tasks through data and information processing.

New Approaches to Preparation and Quantitative Electrochemical Characterization of Catalyst Libraries for Oxygen Reduction ¤ This thesis deals with the combinatorial characterization of catalyst libraries for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in alkaline solution. The catalyst were printed and characterized as libraries onto glassy carbon and Ti. Different modes of the scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) were used. Oxide catalysts were printed onto Ti and investigated with different SECM modes in 3D and 4D setups. A library with a gradient composition was characterized successfully with different 3D modes. Furthermore, this thesis describes the characterization of the activity of gas diffusion electrodes for the ORR using the redox competition mode in combination with a shear force control. Therefore, systems with the same compositions but different overall activities were investigated and compared. Furthermore, the relation between the activity and homogeneity of the catalyst layer was shown.

Computational and Experimental Investigations of Sound Radiation at Vehicle Drives ¤ The present work aims to contribute to the improvement of the acoustic simulation of vehicle drives. Initially, the operating noise of a gearbox is simulated at constant rotational speeds. A method for decoupling the computationally intensive from the rotational speed-dependent part of the simulation is shown. Furthermore, the calculated sounds are auralized at a PC workstation. The results are to be understood as a preliminary study, but the synthetic operating noise sounds authentic. The modeling of component connections significantly influences the results of the body sound calculation within the acoustic simulation. FE models with screw connections and bearings are therefore systematically verified by measurements in a step-by-step and separate manner. After classifying simulation models for screw connections, model variants are derived and implemented at three different gearbox groups with flange connections. The results of the computational modal analysis are extensively compared with measurements in a broad frequency range. Since they exhibit almost single-component quality, a modeling recommendation can be given. For similar groups, the expected result quality and the importance of screw connections are now a priori assessable. The compliance behavior of bearings is described by linearized stiffness matrices. The FE models of two groups are verified at relevant eigenfrequencies with measurements at gearboxes with stationary waves. Uncertainties in bearing modeling and important influences are thus assessable. In total, the investigations on body sound simulation provide a decision-making aid for component connection modeling. At three gearbox housings with differently complex radiation surfaces, extensive investigations of air sound simulation with DBEM, IBEM, Fast-Multipole BEM, and FEM are carried out in a broad frequency range based on body and air sound measurements. By means of measurement-optimized input data, the deviations of the air sound simulation from the measurement are separated. It shows that sound fields can be precisely pre-calculated with various methods. Other aspects for the selection of the simulation method are also extensively discussed, for example, the computing times. The accuracy of the air sound simulation can be represented depending on the complexity of the radiating surfaces. The results of a ribbed gearbox are evaluated for acoustic models with and without ribs, so that the influence of the neglect of these geometric details is recognizable. Furthermore, various possibilities for preventing fictitious resonances in BEM are evaluated. In total, the present work expands the possibilities of acoustic simulation in several areas.

Modelling impacts of climate change on water resources in the Volta Basin, West Africa ¤ The Volta Basin is one of the largest river systems in Africa and covers an area of approximately 400,000 km2 with six West African bordering countries. The semi-arid to sub-humid regions of the Volta catchment belong to the climate-sensitive areas of Africa. The population is largely dependent on rain-fed agriculture and is therefore strongly influenced by the spatial and temporal variability of precipitation and its change due to climate change. Although the average water availability per capita in the catchment area does not indicate a high water stress, there is a large gradient between southern Ghana and northern Burkina Faso. It is to be expected that deforestation, land degradation, and high population growth combined with global climate change will lead to a decrease in available water resources, so that the water demand of the increasing population cannot be met. In the past, there were long droughts in the catchment area, in which rivers and streams dried up, as well as extreme floods in recent years due to very heavy rainfall. It is to be expected that these extremes will intensify...

Strategic Risk Management for Distribution Network Operators in the Liberalized Energy Market: Theory and Practical Implications ¤ The hard competition conditions in the liberalized electricity/gas market lead to insolvencies of energy suppliers (providers), which cause high financial damages to numerous creditors. A great concern is shown by the distribution network operators, whose supplier relationship is based on special energy economic conditions and existing business management approaches to risk-conscious design of the supplier relationship cannot be easily transferred. Kerstin Eiselbrecher develops a strategic risk management model that provides distribution network operators with a practical risk management process with action recommendations for early recognition/evaluation, handling, and monitoring of supplier risk from insolvencies and claims, taking into account the energy economic framework conditions and specifically selected risk factors. Through their central position in the supply chain of energy supply, their actions can also counteract the risk of further market partners connected with the suppliers. Dr. Kerstin Eiselbrecher completed her part-time doctorate under the supervision of Prof. Dr. Iris Hausladen at the Heinz Nixdorf Chair for IT-based Logistics at the HHL Leipzig Graduate School of Management. She has extensive professional experience in the energy supply sector and has presented at conferences on the claims management of distribution network operators. Already during her studies at the Technical University of Munich, Germany, and the University of Canterbury, New Zealand, she focused on energy economic questions. Her scientific focus is on the combination of energy economic and business management elements as well as the connection of theory and practice. Introduction -- Theoretical framework -- Metamodel for strategic risk management for distribution network operators -- Empirical investigation in the practice of distribution network operators -- Model of strategic risk management for application in practice -- Summary of results and outlook.

Aspect-Oriented Data Management in Product Configurators: Requirements, Concepts, and Realization ¤ Since the mid-20th century, the global socio-cultural process of individualization has also expressed itself in changed consumer behavior. In this context, companies are increasingly confronted with the desire for customer-specific products at the price of a mass product equivalent. While production-specific concepts such as modularization and the kit-of-parts principle can achieve an enormous variety of variants, product configurators as supporting IT application systems are necessary to control the complexity associated with this. These are introduced and classified in the first part of this work. Due to the mostly web-based use of product configurators, they must also meet the requirements of globalization. Regional differences regarding language or pricing policy not only affect the user interface but also have an impact on the structure and storage of products. To ensure data independence, a generic and orthogonal integration of those functional aspects referred to as dimensions is also desirable. For this purpose, the paradigm of aspect-oriented data management is formulated in the second part and possibilities for persistence are analyzed. In the third part, a general reference model for aspect-oriented data management is designed on the basis of the relational data model due to its high practical relevance for database systems. In addition, the comparison of suitable access techniques for evaluating the structures in the reference model also takes place. Finally, the practicability of the defined model is demonstrated. For this purpose, a prototypical implementation of the access layer, which is designed as an application library, is first described. Its evaluation by a comprehensive performance test ultimately confirms an efficient runtime behavior.

Swings in Concrete : the Shell Buildings of Ulrich Müther ¤ The engineer Ulrich Müther (1934-2007) created elegantly curved concrete shell constructions, which in the building industry of the GDR represented outstanding exception projects. He set effective counterpoints to the often monotonous large projects of that era. After Müther's buildings had largely fallen into oblivion in the meantime, a re-evaluation of his work has been taking place since the demolition of the Berlin "Ahornblatt" in 2000. In the meantime, the "Landbaumeister of Rügen" is internationally regarded as one of the most important concrete builders of his time. Tanja Seeböck illuminates Müther's position in the historical and international development of concrete shell construction, bridges the present by tracing the different fates of selected buildings and presents the first scientific work catalog. Based on interviews with Müther and numerous witnesses, as well as previously unpublished archival materials, the author analyzes the factors that made Müther a phenomenon among the builders of the GDR and asks why his "bold solitary figures" in the GDR, whose building industry was generally oriented towards maximum standardization, enjoyed such high esteem.

Continuous assessment of software traceability ¤ Traceability of requirements is an important quality feature of software development. For a variety of software development activities, traceability of requirements is a necessary prerequisite. This includes, among other things, the analysis of functional safety, influence analysis, coverage analysis or compliance. For the development of safety-critical software systems, this quality feature is of particular importance. Therefore, this is explicitly prescribed by corresponding guidelines for the development of safety-critical software. Although the relevance of traceability in software projects is generally known, only in a few cases is a systematic planning for achieving this quality feature applied. Often, traceability is implemented only afterwards. As a result, incomplete implementations of traceability often result, which are still used as a basis for major decisions. For this reason, the corresponding implementations should be subjected to a thorough examination, especially in the context of developing safety-critical systems. However, a variety of challenges must be overcome. On the one hand, traceability depends on project-specific goals. In safety-critical systems, often specifications from guidelines must be met. The use of traceability is also very strongly dependent on the respective goals. In this work, an approach to systematic testing of software projects with regard to their traceability of requirements is proposed. A necessary prerequisite for the testing approach is the precise planning and definition of traceability of requirements in a software project. Therefore, a corresponding planning approach is presented in the context of this work. Furthermore, an analytical model for systematic testing of traceability in software projects is presented. This model includes a complete classification of possible error types. In addition, criteria for systematic detection of these errors are proposed. The results of an expert survey confirm the completeness of the analytical test model. Moreover, the proposed approach to systematic testing of traceability of requirements was evaluated in two studies. In this way, the benefit of the approach for the development of safety-critical and non-safety-critical software could be proven.

Variable Compensation in Institutions as Part of Risk Management ¤ The legal processing of the international financial crisis that broke out in 2008 is not yet completed, ten years after the outbreak of the crisis. Part of the legislative measures addressing risk management is the regulation of compensation in banks through national provisions based on CRD IV (§ 25a KWG, InstitutsVergV n.F.). The work examines, on the one hand, whether the regulatory intensity that arose in the background of the initially discussed risk management function of variable compensation is justified. On the other hand, the application and practical implementation of the provisions in compensation agreements are in focus. The supervisory provisions pursue goals that are in conflict with labor law protection mechanisms, so that their compatibility raises relevant questions for practice. The author provides lawyers with suggestions for practical contract design. In addition, he addresses the legislator with suggestions for legislative further development.

Experimental and Theoretical Investigations on the Extension of the Group Contribution Methods UNIFAC and Modified UNIFAC (Dortmund) ¤ This thesis deals with the investigation of the group contribution methods UNIFAC and Modified UNIFAC (Dortund). These models allow to predict phase equilibria and excess properties, even if no experimental information of the examined system is given. For the fitting of UNIFAC group interaction parameters experimental data are necessary. Because experimental mixture data of some substance classes are missing systematic measurements have been carried out in order to extend the data base for phase equilibria. Therefore solid-liquid equilibria using the visual technique, azeotropic points using a wire band column, activity coefficients at infinite dilution using the gas-liquid chromatography and vapor-liquid equilibria using a new computer driven, dynamic apparatus have been measured. These mixture data have been used for the revision and extension of the UNIFAC and Modified UNIFAC (Dortmund) models besides the Dortmund Data Bank.

Development of Biocompatible Superparamagnetic Nanoparticles for In Vivo Diagnostics, Especially in Magnetic Particle Imaging ¤ Magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles have been successfully used as MRI contrast agents in clinical imaging for a considerable amount of time. By optimizing the magnetic properties of the nanoparticles, the diagnostic value of MRI applications can be further increased and the reliability of MR images improved. In addition to improving existing procedures, diagnostic imaging is also driven forward by the development of new procedures, such as Magnetic Particle Imaging. Since the measurement signal is generated by the magnetic nanoparticles themselves, MPI offers a significant advantage in terms of sensitivity while maintaining high temporal and spatial resolution. However, there is currently no commercially available in vivo-compatible MPI tracer, resulting in a pressing need for suitable innovative tracer materials. This motivated the development of biocompatible and superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles for use as in vivo diagnostics, especially in….

Load Management of Private End-Consumers between Energy Market and Smart Grid ¤ The shift from conventional, demand-oriented generation to supply-dependent consumption raises the question of the involvement of private consumers, who played a decisive role in 2011 with a total share of 26% of the demand for electrical energy in Germany. This work examines the flexibility of the load of

Investigations on novel derivatives of the Singlet-Biradical [P(µ-NTer)]2 ¤ In this dissertation, the results of the investigations on the reactivity of the known singlet biradical [P(µ-NTer)]2 are presented and explained. The reactivity towards dienes and diynes, diazomethanes and bromoalkanes was investigated. Also, first reactions were carried out with a Brønsted acid, which has a weakly coordinating anion. The resulting novel compounds were characterized by analytical methods such as NMR, IR and Raman spectroscopy, mass spectrometry and single crystal X-ray structural analysis.

Sugar-modified guanosine analogs as versatile tools for shaping G-quadruplex architectures ¤ Magnetic Resonance, Nucleic Acids, Structure, guanosine analogs, hydrogen bond, quadruplex, sugar pucker G-quadruplexes (G4s) have been in the focus of research in the last decades for their regulatory roles in vivo and for their use in nano- and biotechnology. However, an understanding of the various factors that drive a particular quadruplex fold remains limited, challenging rational therapeutic targeting and design of these tetrahelical structures. In this regard, insights from modified G-quadruplexes may help to deepen our knowledge of G-quadruplex structure. In this dissertation, sugar-modified guanosine analogs are exploited for their altered conformational preferences regarding both glycosidic bond angle and sugar pucker by their incorporation into different syn positions of the G-core of a model G-quadruplex. Induced structural perturbations as characterized by NMR spectroscopy range from a local change in tetrad polarity to a complete refolding into an unusual structure with a V-shaped loop, a unique G4 structural element in the focus of this work. Detailed conformational analysis of the introduced G analogs and high-resolution structures of the modified quadruplexes reveal a complex interplay of glycosidic torsion angle, sugar pucker preferences and local interactions, which may all play a leading role in driving G4 folding.

Vertex-Tracing : Interactive Ray-Tracing through Adaptive Progressive Refinement in Object Space ¤ The present dissertation describes a procedure for the interactive physically exact simulation of specular reflections and specular refractions in virtual environments. Under the term Vertex-Tracing, this work presents an approach that allows hybrid rendering, enabling the supplementation of traditional hardware rendering with global illumination phenomena. - The core of the Vertex-Tracing procedure is an adaptive progressive ray tracing. In contrast to standard ray tracing, the goal is to exploit existing image coherence by only calculating those pixels (samples) that are required for the reconstruction of the final image. The step-by-step approach to the desired final image is achieved by refining (refinement) the geometry of selected polyhedra. These are scene objects that, due to their visual characteristics, are to be subjected to Vertex-Tracing in the form of specular reflections or refractions. The starting point for the calculation of these objects is their object vertices. These form the point of origin of a primary beam shot from the observer and serve as the starting point for further recursive beam tracing in the sense of classical ray tracing. Depending on the need, new vertices are inserted, which leads to a step-by-step refinement of the object geometry. - The reconstruction of the final image is achieved by bilinear interpolation using graphics hardware. Its use not only allows combined rendering with conventional OpenGL objects, but also enables efficient handling of textures in Vertex-Tracing. In this context, a delayed texture lookup is presented. It prevents a complete sampling of textures, which would be particularly time-consuming for high-frequency textures. - In terms of accelerating the procedure, aspects of distributed, parallel computation are investigated and implemented. In the foreground, the distribution of Vertex-Tracing in the computer cluster and the parallelization of the algorithm on shared-memory machines are in the foreground. Both approaches show that, despite the adaptive progressive character of the Vertex-Tracing procedure, a significant speed-up is achievable.

Brücken zwischen Ökologie und Ökonomie : environmental planning and economic knowledge for sustainable regional economic activity ¤ This study was created in the ifo Department of Branch Research and completed in the spring of 2005. The client was the Federal Ministry of Economics and Labour. The subject of the study is the current state and prospects of the New Economy in Germany, as well as a comparison with five other member states of the European Community (France, Great Britain, Italy, the Netherlands and Sweden) with regard to the diffusion and effects of the use of modern information and communication technologies (ICT). From a methodological perspective, the analyses are based on a meso-economic approach, in which four branches were examined as examples: mechanical engineering, vehicle construction, the banking sector and trade. The question is approached in an interdisciplinary manner. Based on the existing scientific literature on the New Economy, a synopsis of previous results is prepared and, in cooperation with Professor Jan-Egbert Sturm, University of Konstanz, the economic theoretical relationships, in particular the most often not explicitly mentioned assumptions, are uncovered. With the help of econometric estimation methods, various models are tested for the relationship between the use of ICT and the increase in labor productivity. These works were carried out by Cambridge Econometrics, a cooperation partner who has a European, sectoral and country-disaggregated data basis. Qualitative investigations, expert discussions and the evaluation of surveys on the use of ICT have guided the branch experts of the ifo Institute and, using the results from the various analyses, a final evaluation has been created for each individual branch. From the aggregation of the branch results, conclusions are drawn for the current state of diffusion of ICT in Germany and their potential effects on productivity and growth.

Social Democracy as Builder: Town Hall Construction in the 1960s and 1970s in the Federal Republic of Germany and Essen ¤ How many and which town halls were demolished and built in the Federal Republic of Germany between 1960 and 1980? And why did the city leaders decide on these building measures - on changes that are often criticized today as 'deviation' or 'nightmarish'? - - This book answers these questions in detail. Based on the knowledge of developments in 82 West German medium and large cities, the author describes a town hall history in which the actors were initially guided by pragmatic, then by ideological, and finally again by pragmatic considerations. - - The book is particularly aimed at the readers of Essen. For the first time, the exemplary Essen town hall history of the 1960s and 1970s is told, which has become one of the greatest myths of the city's history

Oblique graphs ¤ The subject of this work is the investigation of asymmetric structures in graphs. In particular, it is considered to what extent such structures can occur in graphs of arbitrary size. According to a theorem by Wright, almost all graphs are asymmetric. On the other hand, many results of Ramsey theory show that certain regularities or similarities often inevitably occur in growing structures. The concept of asymmetry is extended in such a way that local similarities are also excluded. Graphs with this high degree of asymmetry are called oblique graphs. In the first part of the work, asymmetric structures in polyhedral graphs are investigated. For this graph class, symmetry properties have been studied in the past. In this work, various type definitions for the faces and edges of a polyhedral graph are presented. A polyhedral graph is oblique with respect to such a definition if no two faces or edges have the same type. The main results of this part of the work are theorems that show the finiteness of the set of such oblique graphs. Furthermore, it can be shown in some cases that every sufficiently large polyhedral graph must contain more than z edges or faces of a common type, where z is an arbitrary natural number. In the further course, the finiteness results on oblique polyhedral graphs are transferred to maps on surfaces of higher genus. In the second part of the work, asymmetric structures in general graphs are finally investigated. A simple graph is called edge-oblique if two vertices differ in the sequence of their neighboring vertices. It is shown that there are infinitely many such graphs even under various additional restrictive conditions. In the final section of the work, random graphs are considered. It is shown that with increasing vertex number, the probability of a random graph being edge-oblique converges to 1. This means that almost every graph is edge-oblique if the probability that a certain edge occurs in the random graph moves within certain, given limits.

Development of a Laser Beam Polishing Process for Quartz Glass Surfaces ¤ The goal of laser beam polishing is the fast, uniform, and form-preserving smoothing of the roughness profile of a quartz glass surface. The laser acts in a geometry-independent manner, similar to a fast subaperture tool. Various machined samples are polished using laser radiation, where the process influence parameters, the interactions between laser radiation and quartz glass, and the evaluation of the results in terms of surface quality and influence on stresses or mechanical properties, the investigations and the development of an industrially usable laser beam polishing process are supported. Experimental planning, execution, and evaluation are carried out using statistical methods. The temperature is monitored during polishing with a pyrometer and thermal imaging camera. The application areas of the process include, among others, polishing of 2D and 2½D components, tool insertions (plastic processing), and in parts of optical components.

Interdisciplinary Cooperation in the Creation of Historical 3D Models ¤ BEGIN: Ausgangslage und Zielsetzung -- Begriffe -- Theoretischer Rahmen -- Bibliometrische Analyse -- Qualitative Literaturanalyse -- Fallstudien -- Zusammenführung der Untersuchungsergebnisse -- Grenzen der empirischen Untersuchung und Ausblick -- Literatur -- Anhang. Sander Münster examines in this book, using social science methods, various aspects of interdisciplinary cooperation in 3D modeling projects of historical content. His scope includes the investigation of the scientific landscape, project constellations, and phenomena and strategies in the creation process. The work offers high practical value through concrete and practice-tested recommendations for the conception and implementation of successful 3D modeling projects. The use of information technologies for processing humanities topics is a highly topical research area, and previous analyses focused on technical, methodological, and theoretical aspects of science. Therefore, this systematic investigation of processes and constellations in projects has been lacking so far. The content Bibliometric analysis of themes and actors in the field of historical 3D modeling Qualitative analysis of project constellations in historical 3D modeling Grounded-Theory investigation of phenomena and strategies of interdisciplinary project work The target groups Lecturers and students of history Anwendern digital modeling in the historical and museum area, designers and administrators of projects The author Dr. Sander Münster studied economics, history, and education at TU Dresden and earned his doctorate at the Faculty of Education at the same university in the field of educational technology. END

Exploring the ultrafast excited-state dynamics of transition metal complexes with ab-inito multiple spawning ¤ Since its emergence in the last century, quantum chemistry has become widespread, with a variety of spectra already being calculated routinely. In contrast, modeling ultrafast photochemical processes is still very challenging and limited to small and medium-sized molecules. The steadily increasing computer performance now enables the calculation of large transition metal complexes. However, these pose some challenges for quantum mechanical methods in modeling ultrafast processes due to their high number of electronic states and atoms. Therefore, the goal of this work is to identify methods that can overcome these challenges. For this purpose, the ab-initio multiple spawning (AIMS) method was first selected for the calculation of atomic core dynamics based on a comparison of two promising methods. Subsequently, the time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) was chosen for the description of the electronic structure, as this method allows for a good compromise between accuracy and computational effort. The limitations of the method were also shown using the example of iron pentacarbonyl. With the selected methods, 500 fs of the dynamics of a transition metal complex with more than 100 atoms were simulated, which represents the largest AIMS calculation for a transition metal complex to date. By comparing the results with experimental findings, the simulation was validated, and further insights into the reaction mechanism of the complex were gained. In addition, the dynamics of the excited states of an experimentally hardly investigated transition metal complex were predicted to demonstrate the potential of the selected methods. In summary, it was shown that the combination of AIMS and TDDFT enables an efficient calculation of the dynamics of transition metal complexes.

Reintegration Challenges of Expatriates: An Investigation of the Return Shock after International Staff Deployment ¤ Foundations of reintegration after international staff deployment -- Reintegration as a readjustment process in research literature -- Factors influencing reintegration difficulties and return shock -- Requirements for personnel management to ensure successful reintegration measures -- Empirical investigation of reintegration difficulties and return shock of German expatriates returning home. Kristina Mnich conducts a comprehensive literature review on reintegration difficulties of expatriates and the existence of return shock. In an empirical investigation of German expatriates, the author vividly highlights the relevance and topicality of the reintegration problem and illustrates the consequences of return shock. The content • Foundations of reintegration after international staff deployment • Reintegration as a readjustment process in research literature • Factors influencing reintegration difficulties and return shock • Requirements for personnel management to ensure successful reintegration measures • Empirical investigation of reintegration difficulties and return shock of German expatriates returning home The target groups • Lecturers and students of business sciences with a focus on personnel management and personnel psychology • Personnel managers, executives in personnel affairs The author Kristina Mnich completed the Master's program „International Law and Business“ with a specialization in personnel management and personnel psychology at the Ostfalia University of Applied Sciences at the Faculty of Law (Brunswick European Law School).

Network Relationships in the System of Civil Law ¤ The work deals with the legal classification of networks. For this purpose, the understanding of networks in sociology, economics, politics, and geography is first analyzed. Subsequently, the work deals with the recognition of network relationships in the legal order. The legal assessment begins with the question of whether and to what extent relationships between network actors are subject to contract law. A significant challenge is already the bipolar starting situation in most statutory regulations. Furthermore, a survey of the law of societies, property, unjust enrichment, and tort law is conducted. These latter areas of law are particularly important because network-oriented actions do not necessarily have to be in connection with a contractual relationship. Finally, special forms of action are legally considered, which, from an economic perspective, exhibit a particularly high network orientation.

Electronic Cross-Border Company Formation ¤ Over the question of whether the German legislator should enable a purely electronic formation of capital companies, a heated discussion has been sparked by the EU Commission's proposal for the SUP Directive. The electronic cross-border formation and in it the guarantee of identity are the subject of the present dissertation. The scientific achievement of this work lies on the one hand in the comprehensive capture of the rich argumentation for electronic formation, its systematic focusing and critical penetration; on the other hand and above all, the investigation provides a critical and forward-looking engagement with the electronic identification means, on which the EU Council has essentially based its compromise in the General Orientation to the SUP Directive in this central question. For the EU Commission's

Landscape Development in German and Japanese Middle Mountains - Examples from the Black Forest and the Harima Region ¤ The cultural landscape is shaped by the interplay between natural conditions and socio-cultural influences. The middle mountain cultural landscapes in Germany and Japan leave the impression that there is a certain similarity from several perspectives. This was the starting point of the research. In order to test this impression and to capture similarities and differences between the landscapes, a comparative cultural landscape analysis was carried out. Methodically, the historical landscape analysis and empirical social research were combined. As research areas, the Yach district of the city of Elzach in the middle Black Forest, the municipality of Fröhnd in the southern Black Forest, and the Isarigami district of the municipality of Takacho in the Harima region in western Japan were selected. The goal of the research was to compare cultural landscapes in different (world) regions by analyzing the individual components of the landscape. Through a comparative analysis, similarities and differences between them were captured. Subsequently, the regional typical forms of appearance were to be developed. Written sources, historical maps, as well as specialist maps and aerial photographs were evaluated. The cultural landscape elements mapped during field surveys were entered into a GIS program for evaluation and representation. In addition to the GIS-generated maps, sketches and photos served as documentation. Numerous informal interviews with residents supplemented the reconstruction of historical land use. The reconstruction of the cultural landscape history, which covers the period from settlement to the present day ...

Casual interaction : devices and techniques for low-engagement interaction ¤ Casual interaction, interactive systems, user engagement, control, user interfaces. - Legere Interaktion, interaktive Systeme, Nutzereinsatz, Kontrolle, Benutzerschnittstellen

The Family Enterprise as Socialization Context for Entrepreneur's Children ¤ Simon Caspary investigates how the socialization of descendants from entrepreneurial families is influenced by the existence of a family enterprise. For answering the initial question, a pluralistic approach is chosen, which depicts the mechanisms and influencing factors on the socialization and identity formation of descendants. In addition to a comprehensive overview of the relevant literature, the extensive theoretical processing significantly contributes to advancing the knowledge progress for the socialization context of family enterprises in the scientific discourse. The content The Family Enterprise: Characteristics, Development Stages, Familiness and Enterpriseness, Succession, Socialization Context FU Theoretical Part: Systems Theory, Symbolic Interactionism, Role Theory, Excurs: Integration of Theories The Family Enterprise from a Systems-Theoretical Perspective: Change of Structural Coupling, Socialization of Descendants from Family Enterprises The Target Groups Lecturers and Students of Business Administration with the focus on Family Enterprises and SME Management Family Entrepreneurs, Successors, Mediators, Consultants, and Leading Employees in Family Enterprises The Author Dr. Simon Caspary graduated under the supervision of Prof. Dr. Manfred Lueger at the Institute for Sociology and Empirical Social Research at the Vienna University of Economics and Business.

Homeland. Folk Culture. Architecture : Explorations of Folk-Oriented Building of the Homeland Protection Movement in the Context of Modernity and National Socialism ¤ Around 1900, the Homeland Protection Movement developed an architectural programmatic from the discourse of folk culture, establishing its own, identity-political variant of modernity. Rainer Schmitz examines its emergence and conception by actors of the 1904-founded 'Bundes Heimatschutz' such as Ernst Rudorff, Paul Schultze-Naumburg or Otto March. In the focus of his explorations stands the translation of social phenomena like the 'social question', homeland, folk culture or antisemitism into the building discourse as well as their architecturalization in projects like the national stadiums or the 'German East Colonization'. With this, he contributes, inter alia, to the debate on the construction of collective identities

Achieving Innovation Success through Multi-Stage Knowledge Acquisition : A Conceptual and Empirical Investigation in Technical Industries ¤ The MEWI model developed by Oliver Wiesener brings together market and technology knowledge across market stages in the B-to-B field and thus promotes innovation success. The model contains the MEWI phases of planning, knowledge acquisition, knowledge integration, and knowledge exploitation, as well as methods for practical implementation. By using the empirically tested MEWI factors with regard to innovation success, further positive accents can be set. Innovation success is particularly achieved when a product is accepted in the market and is also technologically realizable. The combination of these two aspects is problematic for B-to-B companies, as markets are multi-staged here and technology and market knowledge are heterogeneous across several market stages. This innovation dilemma can be solved by multi-stage knowledge acquisition (MEWI). The content Model for illustrating MEWI in the B-to-B field Contents and methods of the phases of the MEWI model Empirically tested MEWI factors The target groups Lecturers and students of business administration with focuses on innovation, technology, and knowledge management Persons of the management, technology, knowledge, and innovation management The author Oliver Wiesener was promoted by Univ.-Prof. Dr. Rolf Weiber at the University of Trier. He has extensive experience in technology and innovation management in the international environment. Model for illustrating MEWI in the B-to-B field -- Contents and methods of the phases of the MEWI model -- Empirically tested MEWI factors.

Neighborhood and Fear of Crime: An Empirical Investigation of the Collective Efficacy Approach in Urban Comparison ¤ Jan Starcke examines the role of informal social control within neighborhoods in relation to personal feelings of safety and how trust between residents of a neighborhood arises, drawing on the theory of collective efficacy. For the first time, data sets for two German major cities with different socio-structural conditions are analyzed in comparative perspective: Wuppertal and Stuttgart. In the framework of multilevel analysis, it is found that collective efficacy has a different value for the subjective perception of safety in the investigated cities, which calls into question the generalizability of the approach. The content includes Fear of Crime in the Urban Space Social Capital Theory and Incivilities The Project „Aspects of a Just Distribution of Safety in the City“ (VERSS) Confirmatory Multi-Group Factor Analysis Influencing Factors of Social Cohesion, Informal Social Control, Feelings of Insecurity, Risk Perception, and Protective and Avoidance Behavior The Target Groups Researchers, Lecturers, and Students of Criminology, Sociology, and Security Research Experts in the Field of Criminal Policy The Author Jan Starcke is a research assistant at the Institute of Political Science at the Technical University of Dresden in the SiQua project („Security Analyses and Networking for Urban Quarters in Transition“) Fear of Crime in the Urban Space -- Social Capital Theory and Incivilities -- The Project „Aspects of a Just Distribution of Safety in the City“ (VERSS) -- Confirmatory Multi-Group Factor Analysis -- Influencing Factors of Social Cohesion, Informal Social Control, Feelings of Insecurity, Risk Perception, and Protective and Avoidance Behavior

Implementation of earthworm-assisted constructed wetlands to treat wastewater and possibility of using alternative plants in constructed wetlands ¤ The aim of this research was to add the earthworms into the constructed wetlands, both in Germany and Thailand, in order to investigate whether they could improve the treatment performances. For Germany, earthworm-assisted constructed wetlands exhibited better treatment efficiency than conventional vertical subsurface-flow constructed wetlands and the unplanted constructed wetlands with earthworms. For Thailand, the production of sludge on the surface of wetlands was reduced by 40% with earthworms. Apart from that, alternative plants with high resource recovery potential were proposed. The recommendation table was developed with 13 suitable species. There are more than one most appropriate species in each climatic region.

Product Design of Climate Protection Funds as a Sustainable Investment Product for Private Investors: An Empirical Analysis of Preferences and Product Requirements of German Retail Investors ¤ Market overview of climate protection funds and their preference-based scoring -- Preference measurement using conjoint analysis -- Importance and content of a label for sustainable funds related to climate protection. Thomas Steiauf reveals in this book the preferences of retail investors for climate protection funds. He works out the importance of classical product features of a fund such as risk and return in comparison to sustainable product features and how these features should be designed. Furthermore, the author shows how investor preferences are perceived by product providers and recommendations are given for the improvement of sustainable funds for three clusters of different investor types. Although the achievement of German climate protection goals requires investments from the private sector, sustainable investment funds related to climate protection currently allocate few funds. The content Market overview of climate protection funds and their preference-based scoring Preference measurement using conjoint analysis Importance and content of a label for sustainable funds related to climate protection The target groups Lecturers and students from the fields of finance and marketing Professionals and executives in the fields of asset management, financial product management, fund industry as well as political decision-makers and decision-makers The author Thomas Steiauf was promoted by Prof. Dr. Henry Schäfer at the Chair of General Business Administration and Finance at the University of Stuttgart. His research focuses include Socially Responsible Investments, Investment Funds, Behavioral Finance and the Agency Theory.

Characterization and application of PEG-salt aqueous two-phase systems for liquid-liquid extraction of proteins ¤ Aqueous two-phase systems (ATPS), liquid--liquid extraction, protein partitioning, design of experiments (DoE).

Mathematical Approaches to Solving Multiplication Tables: An Investigation Considering Various Instructional Approaches and the Performance Capabilities of Children ¤ In mathematics education, there is currently a broad consensus regarding the development of the small multiplication table, which corresponds to the contemporary understanding of teaching and learning in mathematics lessons: A comprehension-based development, which provides for the acquisition of unknown multiplication tables using already known multiplication tables and based on insight into operational relationships. The effectiveness of this comprehension-based development has been analyzed in only isolated national and international studies to date. This volume presents an empirical study that captures and examines various mathematical approaches of children to tasks of the small multiplication table in the 3rd school year, and investigates whether and to what extent different instructional approaches in the development affect the use of strategies by children. The investigation of the use of strategies is carried out in addition under consideration of another possible influencing factor, the individual performance capability of a child.

Steerable Antennas for Mobile Satellite Communication based on the Multimode-Monopulse Principle ¤ This work deals with the design and realization of steerable antennas for mobile satellite communication based on reflector antennas. This antenna type plays a central role for ground station antennas that are supposed to provide high data rates even during the movement of the carrier vehicle. Starting from the presentation of existing systems and the requirements for mobile satellite antennas, the construction fundamentals for the dimensioning of Cassegrain antennas are described. For the steering of this antenna type, various technical principles are available, with a special focus on monopulse technologies in this work. This principle allows the estimation of the pointing error of an antenna in relation to the direction from which the received signal comes, for a limited spatial subset of the antenna's radiation diagram. The direction information generated by this is used in a control loop for the mechanical steering of the antenna. Based on the presented concepts, a demonstrator for an external unit of a mobile satellite terminal is described. This demonstrator consists of a custom-made mechanical antenna positioner and a 60 cm Ka-band Cassegrain antenna, which is equipped with a newly designed TM01 multimode monopulse feed system consisting of a waveguide mode converter. The development of the feed chain is shown from a first variant for pure reception operation to a complete dual-band version for transmission and reception functions. In this context, numerical simulation of the structures and post-manufacturing metrological characterization are addressed. Furthermore, the generation of the error vector, which is required for the steering of the antenna, is described. In addition to the waveguide-based coupler, a novel mode coupler for TM01 multimode monopulse is presented in this work, in which transitions from printed coplanar lines to waveguides are used. This method enables the integration of the coupler together with the transmitter-receiver in the same technology, making it possible to build a very compact, lightweight, and cost-effective feed chain.

Bifurcations from codimension-one D4m-equivariant homoclinic cycles ¤ The topic of this work is a detailed description of the dynamics near D4m-symmetric relative homoclinic cycles using Lin's method. The homoclinic cycles have codimension-1, i.e., we observe their generic unfolding within a one-parameter family. They consist of several trajectories that converge to the same hyperbolic equilibrium state for both positive and negative time (homoclinic trajectories) and are all dependent on each other through the symmetry induced by a finite group. We take real leading eigenvalues and homoclinic trajectories that approach the equilibrium state along leading directions. The homoclines are located in flux-invariant subspaces. In particular, for such homoclinic cycles in differential equations with Dk-symmetry (Dk is the symmetry group of a regular k-gon in the plane), where k is a multiple of 4, some of these flux-invariant subspaces are orthogonal to each other. This implies the disappearance of the typically occurring terms of leading exponential convergence order in some of the determination equations obtained from Lin's method. To give a precise description of the non-wandering dynamics of such a homoclinic cycle, i.e., a description of the solutions that remain in the vicinity of the cycle in both the phase and parameter space, further information about the remainder terms in the determination equations is required. In this work, we present an improved representation of the remainder terms in the determination equations and identify two further terms with higher exponential convergence rates. Based on this, we discuss the solvability of the resulting determination equations for homoclinic cycles in R4. There are two cases to distinguish, which depend on the size ratio of the two new terms. In one case, we observe a finite subshift. In the other case, the analysis is more difficult, so that we restrict the investigation to periodic solutions.

Cognitive Science Perspectives on Biblical Vision Narratives: The Transfiguration (Mk 9,2-9) as an Example ¤ Das vorliegende Buch bietet einen umfassenden Beitrag zum Bestreben neuro- und kognitionswissenschaftliche Erkenntnisse in die neutestamentliche Exegese zu integrieren. Für dieses Vorhaben eignen sich veränderte Bewusstseinszustände insbesondere, da sie auf allgemein menschlichen Strukturen des Gehirns beruhen und in sehr vielen Kulturen Teil der religiösen Praxis waren und sind. Anklänge daran finden sich auch in biblischen Visionserzählungen. Die Untersuchung bietet neben einer Einführung in die Philosophie des Geistes und notwendigen naturwissenschaftlichen Grundlagen sowie einer hermeneutischen Reflexion eine breit angelegte Darstellung der antiken Erfahrungen mit veränderten Bewusstseinszuständen anhand ihrer Induktionsrituale. Die gewonnenen Erkenntnisse werden dann auf die Verklärungserzählung angewendet. This book is a comprehensive contribution to the ongoing effort to integrate findings in cognitive science into New Testament studies. Altered states of consciousness are particularly suitable for this attempt as they are a common human property and a widespread religious practice. This study contains an introduction to the basics of philosophy of mind and cognitive studies as well as a hermeneutical reflection. The wide portrayal of ASCs in ancient religious contexts according to the type of induction rituals provides the historic context for the cognitive analysis of the Transfiguration narrative

Journalism and Diversity : Dealing with Cultural Diversity in Journalistic Practice and Consequences for Education and Training ¤ People with a migration background are disproportionately represented in problem contexts in German reporting, according to numerous analyses. To change this, there are various activities such as awards for diversity-sensitive reports or analyses of the media representation of migrants. However, little attention is paid to the sensitization of journalists to cultural diversity, although it was demanded in the National Integration Plan in 2007. Furthermore, the majority of previous activities are based on a representation of homogeneous (national) cultures. Many content analyses investigate the reporting on

Currency Crises: An Empirical Investigation of Contagion Effects and Causality during the Asian Crisis ¤ Since the early 1980s, currency crises have received increasing attention from a scientific perspective. In particular, in retrospect of the Asian crisis (1997/98), both theoretical and empirical approaches have been strengthened to investigate the contagion effects that emerged in this case. The work provides empirical statements on the causes and effects of contagion effects during the Asian crisis. In addition to an analysis of contributions from theoretical crisis research, an in-depth examination of empirical research approaches is first made with regard to the used crisis definition, the investigation method, and the variables examined. At the center of the empirical investigation is a thorough analysis of the contagion effects that occurred during the Asian crisis. It is based on a contagion model, according to which contagion effects are the result of portfolio effects and the herd behavior of poorly informed investors. The empirical investigation of contagion effects is carried out within a two-stage analysis. The first part is formed by a logit regression. It serves to prove the existence of contagion effects and to identify the countries that are severely affected by these effects. In the second part, the sources and transmission paths of contagion effects are examined using dependency analysis. The algorithms used enable statements to be made about dependencies and interdependencies between the examined variables, which can be presented in the form of a causal graph. The findings gained in the analysis steps show that Thailand can be considered as the country of origin of the Asian crisis. With regard to the emergence of crises in Singapore and the Philippines, financial market-based contagion effects can be assigned a leading role.

The Effect of Credibility in Marketing Communication: An Analysis of Short- and Long-Term Effects ¤ Credibility in the context of marketing communication and persuasion research -- Instruments and forms of marketing communication -- Development of persuasion effects over time -- Empirical investigation -- Conclusion. Credible and convincing marketing communication is of great importance for companies. Franziska Küster-Rohde examines the credibility of various design options and checks how these affect a higher effectiveness and persuasiveness of marketing communication. The effect development over time is also considered. The author shows that credibility has generally positive effects, but that this advantage is offset over time and is not sustainable in the long term. The results of her investigation provide valuable indications for a target-oriented design of marketing communication.

Development of an Endoscopic Fiber Probe for Optical Biopsies using Nonlinear Spectroscopy ¤ An early detection and exact diagnosis of diseases such as tumors is essential for optimal treatment and improvement of prognosis for affected individuals. The gold standard for tissue examinations is still histopathology, where painful patient biopsies and complex post-processing of tissue samples are necessary. From tissue removal to diagnosis, valuable time is spent, and in many cases, biopsies must be repeated multiple times until diseased tissue is fully identified and localized. Therefore, new optical technologies have been developed and applied in recent decades to optimize tissue analysis and enable a more patient-friendly treatment. Nonlinear, multimodal in-vivo imaging with CARS (coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering), SHG (second harmonic generation) and TPEF (two-photon excited auto-fluorescence) can offer an attractive solution here, which is non-invasive and enables the detection of microscopic tissue changes in real-time. However, the implementation of nonlinear imaging procedures in an endoscopic design for hard-to-reach tissue sites is still a technological challenge. The present research work presents a fiber-based approach for a multimodal, endoscopic probe, where a multi-core fiber is used to guide the excitation lasers and specially designed GRIN lenses take over the beam formation in the probe head. The probe design is completely without movable parts or the use of electrical power, so that a robust and compact design is achieved. The functionality of the probe is demonstrated with multimodal recordings of thin sections of human skin tissue as well as fresh tissue samples of a pig. Based on the results, it can be shown that multimodal recordings with the presented probe are qualitatively comparable to conventional LSM recordings, and a faster imaging is possible. Thus, the presented probe design has a high potential to be used in future clinical routine examinations.

Physiological characterization and molecular ecological investigation of diverse organisms of the Roseobacter clade isolated from the North Sea ¤ One of the major groups of the marine heterotrophic bacterioplankton is the Roseobacter clade, which is widespread in marine ecosystems. Roseobacters exhibit a remarkably variable physiology and their metabolic activities significantly contribute to processes in the world’s biogeochemical cycles and to the microbial loop of marine food webs. As many roseobacters can easily be cultivated, they became one of the most intensively studied groups of marine bacteria. In this study the Roseobacter community of a water sample from the open southern North Sea was analyzed, which was collected during a bloom of phytoflagellates. Three newly isolated strains were characterized as new species of new genera. For one of the isolates, Planktotalea frisia SH6-1T, the occurrence and abundance in the North Sea was investigated. The results revealed very pronounced seasonal patterns of P. frisia in the German Bight and a possible correlation with phytoplankton. In laboratory experiments with the phytoplankton algae Phaeocystis globosa and Leptocylindrus danicus the bacterial utilization of algal-derived dissolved organic carbon was shown.

Water vapor in the tropical upper troposphere : on the influence of deep convection ¤ Water vapor is one of the most important atmospheric trace gases. Its influence on the climate, chemistry, and energy balance is significant. Of particular interest is the water vapor distribution in the upper troposphere, especially in the tropics. The main water vapor source for the tropical upper troposphere is tropical convection. It counteracts the large-scale sinking, which has its cause both in dynamics and in the radiation balance. It compensates the convective upward movement and transports relatively dry air downward. Little is known about the net effect of these two processes, especially due to a lack of reliable measurements in this region. In this work, the water vapor content and the mechanisms responsible for the water vapor distribution in the upper tropical troposphere are investigated using a large amount of in-situ humidity measurements. The measurements were carried out on commercial airliners within the EU project MOZAIC (Measurements of Ozone and Water Vapor by Airbus In-Service AirCraft; Measurements of ozone and water vapor on Airbus commercial airliners). A climatology of the measured parameters over the tropical Atlantic shows that the humidity is very variable on all temporal and spatial scales. The bimodal distribution of humidity in the tropics differs significantly from the distribution in the subtropics or mid-latitudes ...

Investigations on the Calculation of the Fatigue Strength of Surface-Hardened Diesel Fuel Injectors ¤ Existing methods and guidelines for the calculation of the fatigue strength of surface-hardened diesel fuel injectors do not provide satisfactory results on their own. In various test series, the relevant transfer factors for the present load cases were quantitatively determined and compared with the calculation proposals derived from the published methods and guidelines. Special attention was paid to the surface finish, the mean stress sensitivity, the local hardness, and the absolute notch size. Based on the transfer factors, a calculation method was presented according to the locally elastic concept. The verification of its applicability using 11 independent test series provided satisfactory results, which are only limited by the scope of the experiments. Potentials for increasing the permissible maximum load were found in the surface quality, the introduction of load-induced pressure stresses, and for needle lift-controlled injection systems in the consideration of the actual operating loads.
Three-dimensional finite-element modelling of the influence of erosion and sediment deposition on the slip behaviour of faults ¤ Numerical modelling, landscape evolution, fault slip evolution.

Development of a CAE Tool for the Design of Flight Control and Hydraulic Systems ¤ The practical support of the engineer in the design of flight control and hydraulic systems - including the computer - is the focus of this work. Starting from the data that were established during the aircraft design for a new aircraft project. From this, the requirements for the flight control system are derived: What moment is necessary to move the control surfaces of the aircraft in all flight situations? At what speed must the control surfaces be released? What influence does the required reliability have on the design? With the help of these preliminary considerations, the hydraulic, linear actuators of the flight control can then be dimensioned and integrated into the wings or tailplanes. Furthermore, the connection of the actuators to the energy systems and computers of the aircraft is investigated. With the help of a stationary calculation, the hydraulic system is designed. Finally, it is shown how the design of the aircraft systems can be economically evaluated based on the "Direct Operating Costs".

Post-Merger Integration in European-Japanese Corporate Mergers: Conflict-Oriented Analysis at the Example of Supplier Management ¤ Increasingly, European companies are taking over companies in Japan. The success of such transactions is decided by the phase of post-merger integration. Cultural differences between the acquiring European company and the Japanese target company, however, can jeopardize post-merger integration. This is often not known to European buyers. Carsten Herbes analyzes the integration of the procurement area, as synergies in this area often make a significant financial contribution to the success of the company acquisition. He presents the typical integration measures of the acquirer, e.g. joint procurement and conversion of Japanese-specific supplier relationships to market relationships, against the goals of Japanese stakeholders (employees, management, suppliers) and identifies potential conflicts. He illustrates the existing conflict fields and the problems of dealing with conflicts in the overall context of post-merger integration using case studies and develops solution proposals. Theoretical foundations and analytical framework -- Analysis of individual conflict fields -- Empirical investigation and implications.

Peer Education & Violence Prevention : Theory and Practice presented at the Project Schlag.fertig ¤ The book deals with the topic of violence in adolescence and the peer approach. Detailed theoretical explanations are made about peer involvement, respectively. peer education as a pedagogical method, which is applied in an increasing number of projects. In this context, the peer approach is considered in terms of its practical relevance for participatory work with children and adolescents and especially in terms of its possibilities for violence prevention. The topic of youth violence, which has increasingly come into focus in public and media, is presented and analyzed under consideration of causes and origin and actual occurrence. Characteristics of adolescence, current violence statistics and violence in school are in the focus here. A special focus of the book lies on the connection between peer education and violence prevention. For this purpose, the violence prevention project 'Schlag.fertig' is presented and evaluated. Empirically, the question is addressed whether violence prevention in school can be practiced with the help of peer education. For this purpose, data from school classes are examined that have participated in a 'Schlag.fertig' prevention action. In the 'Schlag.fertig' project, former violent adolescents are trained and develop prevention actions, which they then carry out with school classes. The students of these actions are questioned in writing at three points in time regarding their own (violence) behavior and in terms of the effectiveness of the prevention actions. Both the theoretical foundations and the results of the evaluation are examined in terms of their practical relevance and the possibilities of transfer as well as in terms of critical aspects.

Aspects of Cohesive and Adhesive Properties of PCC ¤ The abbreviation PCC refers here to Polymer modified Cement Concrete, i.e. cement and concrete modified with plastics. This abbreviation has also been internationally established. It denotes materials that, in addition to the mineral binder cement, also contain plastics. Cement and plastics achieve a joint binder effect in the later concrete or mortar. A repeated subject of damage cases is the failure of the bond to other building materials. Since PCC is often applied as a thin protective layer on existing concrete, failure of adhesion will also lead to failure of this protective function earlier or later. Conversely, failure of protection due to cracks in the PCC can also lead to detachment of the coating in the aftermath. The cause of this cohesive failure is usually the selection of incorrect or not matched building material systems or simply processing errors. The goal of this work was to investigate the influence of the cohesive and adhesive properties of PCC on its durability, especially when used as a coating material.

Fabrication of functional thin-film elements on the front surfaces of optical fibers using high-resolution lithographic structuring techniques ¤ This work deals with the development of technologies for lithographic processes for the production of high-frequency diffractive thin-film building elements directly on the front surfaces of optical fibers. For this, optimized lithographic procedures need to be suitably modified for process execution on wafers. This concerns both the production of layers and the adjustable process parameters as well as the process execution. Depending on the materials used and the structure dimensioning, different functionalities of the structured layers can be generated. For illumination, two systems are used. For the production of structures with periods greater than 3 mym, direct writing laser illumination is used at a wavelength of 442 nm. For the generation of high-frequency grids with periods less than 1 mym, DUV interference lithography is used under the use of an excimer laser emitting at a wavelength of 248 nm. At this wavelength, the interferometric structurability of a resist originally specified for electron beam lithography is investigated, which is particularly well suited for the production of structures on the front surfaces of optical fibers due to its properties such as low moisture sensitivity, high long-term stability, good adhesion, and simplified process execution during development. The suitable illumination and other processing parameters for process execution on substrate layers made of different materials are determined for the realization of high-frequency grid structures. The structuring of metallic layers on the front surfaces of optical fibers leads to fiber-based lithography masks, with the help of which efficient and reproducible photolithography on fiber front surfaces is enabled using fiber-to-fiber illumination. Through direct surface structuring of high-frequency grids on quartz glass optical fibers coated with high-refractive-index layers made of As35S65 using excimer laser interference lithography, efficient fiber-coupled grids with high refractive index contrast are generated. Based on such grid structures, wavelength and polarization filters are designed, suitable illumination conditions are determined, and the properties of realized structures are compared with simulation results.

Collecting Things, Creating Knowledge : The History of Natural History Collections in Basel, 1735-1850 ¤ In the transition from the 18th to the 19th century, collecting objects from nature became a scientific practice from a leisure activity of individual private persons. Researchers developed new answers to scientific questions – for example, about the nature of the natural world or the development of living organisms. In natural science museums, this new knowledge could be negotiated and established with a broad public.Flavio Häner traces the history of the natural history collections in Basel, showing how, from this time, not only new scientific disciplines emerged, but a society developed in which questions about nature could no longer be answered by reference to the biblical creation story.

Water vapor, precipitation and evapotranspiration isotopic composition in the tropical atmospheric boundary layer ¤ In the tropical areas, important large-scale climatic phenomena, such as the El-Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO), the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) and the monsoons, occur, which influence the global climate to a large extent. One of the areas of the planet where these perturbations exert their effect with a particular intensity is Indonesia. In this region, where the climate is mostly warm and humid throughout the year, these atmospheric phenomena are responsible for the alternation between periods of drought and periods of very intense rainfall with consequences for the agriculture and the tropical forests. The investigation of the isotopic composition of water vapor, precipitation and evapotranspirative water losses in this region can provide important insights into the mechanisms of these phenomena and thus contribute to the improvement of the forecasting possibilities for the precipitation patterns and the climate changes.

Influence of Fragmentation and Isolation on the Population Biology and Diaspore Bank of Calcareous Grasslands (Mesobrometum erecti) in Southwestern Germany ¤ To investigate the effects of fragmentation and isolation on species of calcareous grasslands, four species were selected, whose fitness was represented by the examination of six parameters. It could be found that the germination rate in all investigated model species significantly increases with increasing population size as well as the seedling density in the field in two species. In all other fitness parameters, only a few significant results were found. The investigations of the present work show that species-specific reactions to changes in relevant parameters such as population size are of great importance for the persistence of a species. The results of the diaspora bank investigations confirm the statements from the literature that the majority of typical calcareous grassland species are unable to build a permanent diaspora bank. This means that species-rich calcareous grasslands are dependent on a permanent diaspora supply from the current vegetation for their persistence.

Heavy Metal and Societal Change: A Social History of a Music Culture in the Long 1980s ¤ Heavy Metal is a social force that can tell us a lot about the historical change of our time. Originally a phenomenon of the working class, the music culture has conquered new social milieus, regions, media, and markets since the 1970s. Heavy Metal has become not only the life content of many fans, but also a profession, a musical and commercial experimentation field, and a social instrument of distinction. For the first time, Marco Swiniartzki takes these developments into account on the basis of a broad foundation of sources. Numerous interviews with musicians provide insight into the 1980s and show: The social history of Heavy Metal and the societal change of this time go hand in hand.

Combined Transport of Rail and Road in Europe: A Comparative Study on the Transformation of Freight Transport Systems ¤ Book description: Truck traffic will double in the next 20 years.
