And will finally reach the limits of its social and ecological acceptability. But the train will also not be able to handle the freight flows alone. For both, combined transport could be a solution. That's why it has become the most important hope for national and European transport policy. Steffen Bukold shows, based on a detailed three-country comparison between Germany, France and the Netherlands, under what conditions combined transport can arise and grow. Methodically, the question is at the center of whether the success or failure of transport systems is determined by technical progress or is also politically shapeable. A central result is: The shift of traffic from the road to the rail is possible - but only with strong political support.

Long-Wavelength Magnons and Phonons and Roton-Like Excitations in Amorphous Solids ¤ Extended inhomogeneities and variations of nearest-neighbor distances are a characteristic commonality of amorphous solids. Essential information about the (magnetic) structure of amorphous solids can be obtained from the static structure factor or the radial distribution function. For long-wavelength magnons and phonons, the inhomogeneities lead to damping and renormalization (reduction) of the stiffness constants or sound velocities. Very long-wavelength magnons and phonons are scattered at the inhomogeneities like point defects and one obtains a magnon- or phonon-Rayleigh scattering. These results follow both from the Green function theory (Matsubara-Kaneyoshi formalism) as well as - for magnons - from a quantum mechanical perturbation calculation. For magnons and phonons with wavelengths shorter than the average extension of the inhomogeneities, a apparent gap energy follows due to the formation of wave packets (magnon-dressed magnon or phonon-dressed phonon). The density of states of long-wavelength magnons and phonons is changed on the one hand by the renormalization of energy and on the other hand by the redistribution of states due to the inhomogeneities as well as by amorphon states. The latter are a new type of (at small energies localized) elementary excitations that arise due to the amorphous structure. The additional contributions to the density of states of low-energy long-wavelength magnons and phonons are interpreted as a contribution to the boson peak. The thermal conductivity and the inverse thermal resistance of magnons and phonons at low temperatures decrease with increasing strength and increasing spatial extension of the inhomogeneities. In amorphous ferromagnets, the contribution of magnons to the thermal conductivity is not negligible. It can even dominate the phonon contribution. Roton-like excitations (magnon-rotons and phonon-rotons) form as wave packets specific excitation branches in amorphous solids, which can be reduced to the first Debye sphere. This reduction is interpreted as a diffuse umklapp process at the first sharp peak of the static structure factor (FSDP). The magnon- and phonon-rotons, represented by wave packets, lead to a finite gap energy in the roton minimum of the dispersion relation. The size of the gap energy is essentially determined by the width of the FSDP. The reduced dispersion relation of phonon-rotons leads to an additional contribution to the specific heat of amorphous solids for temperatures above 1 K. This is interpreted as a super-Debye contribution (excess specific heat), which is characteristic for amorphous solids. The gap energy of the phonon-roton minimum determines the location of the maximum of the super-Debye contribution. - In amorphous solids, long-wavelength magnons and phonons on the one hand and magnon- and phonon-rotons on the other hand have far-reaching commonalities, which are due to the analogous scattering mechanisms for the long-wavelength excitations as well as the wave packet nature of the roton-like excitations.

Laser Cladding of High-Alloy Duplex Steels ¤ In the present work, the development of corrosion-resistant coatings on the low-alloy pressure vessel steel P265GH is described. The functional layers of duplex steel are produced on a low-mixing basis using the laser cladding process. Depending on the process parameters, 1 to 2 mm thick, almost defect-free layers with a porosity of less than 1% are formed. Due to the high energy density and the resulting locally confined melt pool on the substrate surface, it is possible to achieve a melting rate of less than 3% without bonding errors. The parameters of the laser-based coating process were estimated from numerical calculations and transferred to the existing plant. Main influences are the laser power and the feed of the supplied powder mass flow, in addition to the geometrical alignment of the components to each other. For the welding process, iron-based materials with a Cr/Ni equivalent between 1.5 and 3.4, produced by powder metallurgy, are used. This results in austenite fractions between 100 and 20% in the rapidly solidified microstructure. It should be noted that the microstructure is divided into several zones, which, depending on the local heat supply within the applied layer, exhibit different phase ratios and morphologies. Especially nitrogen has a significant influence on the phase formation of duplex steels. An area-resolved analysis of the nitrogen distribution in the weld microstructure shows that nitrogen, in contrast to the substituting alloying elements chromium, nickel, and molybdenum, is almost completely enriched in the austenite despite rapid cooling. However, chromium nitrides form within large ferrite grains during cooling from the melt. Reasons for this are the low solubility of nitrogen in the cubic face-centered lattice and short diffusion lengths. Finally, the development of a canner-based welding process is shown, which can significantly increase the deposition rate. This results in potential for a laser-based coating process in terms of cost savings and resource conservation.

Magnetohydrodynamic duct flow in the presence of a magnetic dipole ¤ Efficient processing of aggressive liquid materials, such as aluminum or copper, often requires knowledge of flow rates and the spatial distribution of the velocity field. It is the declared goal of local Lorentz force anemometry to achieve this. By measuring the Lorentz force, which is induced in the nearby metal by the flow, on a small magnet, however, this force also affects the fluid and distorts the flow profile. The nature of this distortion and whether it changes the measurable force was investigated in the present work using analytical and numerical methods. As a magnetic field, the simplest spatially variable configuration is chosen, a magnetic dipole field. For this, the magnetohydrodynamic equations are investigated in quasistatic approximation, i.e., for small magnetic Reynolds numbers, using direct numerical simulation. Two dimensionless parameters are decisive here: the Hartmann number Ha and the Reynolds number Re. The investigated parameter range exceeds the one achievable in the laboratory experiment, but still provided useful hints for the evaluation of the measurement results. In the present study, the influence parameters for a three-dimensional flow under the influence of an inhomogeneous, local magnetic field were investigated for the first time. The investigations offer interesting perspectives for flow control and, consequently, for flow control.

Surface characterization of indium compounds as functional layers for (opto)electronic and sensoric applications ¤ New developments in the field of thin-film synthesis open up a wide range of new applications for indium compounds in the field of sensorics and (opto)-electronics. Against this background, specific aspects of the properties of indium nitride (InN), indium oxide (In2O3) and indium zinc oxide nitride (ITON) were investigated. Future high-frequency transistors based on InN can expand the technological possibilities, while thin In2O3 films are expected to have a high potential for use in cost-effective, integrated ozone sensors. In addition, the optical transparency in the UV range can be expanded for optoelectronic applications by incorporating nitrogen into Sn-doped indium oxide layers. A principle for the implementation of the materials is the detailed knowledge of the influences of the composition, as well as the structural and electronic properties on important mechanisms of the functionality and stability of components. In this context, the influences of process parameters on the surface properties of thin films were investigated, as well as interactions with reactive molecules were analyzed. Thin InN layers were deposited using plasma-induced molecular beam epitaxy, while further investigations were carried out on In2O3 films deposited by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition and ITON layers produced by magnetron sputtering. For analysis, methods of electron spectroscopy (XPS, UPS, AES, (HR)EELS), electron diffraction (RHEED) and scanning probe microscopy (AFM) were used. Through in-situ analysis of InN(0001) layers, correlations between surface reconstructions and the existence of electron states within the bandgap were first demonstrated, as well as influences of oxidation by O2 were investigated. In addition, the interaction mechanism between ozone and defective In2O3-x layers was analyzed and conclusions were drawn on the principle of reversible O3-induced oxidation and UV-induced reduction, which is based on the adsorption/desorption of O-ions and simultaneous charge transfer. The nitrogen introduced by sputtering in N2 is present in ITON in various chemical bonds and changes the optical and electrical properties, but is thermally unstable and desorbs above 550°C, accompanied by simultaneous surface segregation of Sn. This work demonstrates the benefit of combining layer growth and surface analysis to gain fundamental insights for use in semiconductor components.

Development of new methods and catalysts for the hydroamination and hydroaminoalkylation of alkenes ¤ This work is about the development of new methods and catalysts for hydroamination and hydroaminoalkylation reactions. It could be shown that cheap potassium hydroxide is a suitable catalyst for the addition of various primary and secondary aryl amines or phenylhydrazine to styrenes to produce pharmaceutically interesting ß-arylethylamines. For Ti- and Zr-catalyzed hydroamination and hydroaminoalkylation reactions, 1,1'-diaminoferrocene ligands were synthesized and tested in combination with a precatalyst [e.g. Ti(NMe2)4] for catalytic activity. A promising class of ligands for the synthesis of new titanium-complexes were found to be sulfamide compounds. It could be shown that the combination of a bis-phenyl substituted sulfamide and Ti(NMe2)4 is a good catalytic system for hydroamination and hydroaminoalkylation reactions. <engl.>

Development and Design of Corporate Control in Medium-Sized Construction Companies: Considering Two Empirical Studies in a Temporal Comparison ¤ Introduction -- Controlling as an integrated task of corporate management in medium-sized construction companies -- The construction business accounting as a basis for information for corporate control in medium-sized construction companies -- Corporate control in medium-sized construction companies -- Consideration of the own empirical studies in medium-sized construction companies in a temporal comparison -- Summary. Medium-sized construction companies are most strongly exposed to the structural change in the German construction industry. For the existence security of these companies, corporate control plays a decisive role. Christian Keidel determines the dissemination and development status of corporate control in medium-sized construction companies. He determines a typical appearance and develops a corporate control for medium-sized construction companies based on the value-added-oriented control concept, which provides assistance in adapting to market developments and within the company itself.

Integration of Metal-Organic Resin Paste in Low-Temperature Multilayer Ceramic Systems ¤ This dissertation presents the integration possibilities of resin paste in low-temperature multilayer ceramic technology (Low Temperature Cofired Ceramics, LTCC). Resin pastes consist of metal-organic noble metal compounds (e.g. gold, silver, platinum), dissolved in aromatic oils. These pastes can be applied using cost-effective screen printing like classical thick-film pastes. The sintered layer thickness is only 100 nm to 1 [my]m in this case. By etching, these thin burnt layers can be very finely structured. The structure resolution is mainly limited in the single-digit micrometer range by the roughness and warping of the substrates. The use of a fully printed resin layer as a starting point for a galvanic layer build-up is particularly interesting. In this process, the desired structures are galvanically enhanced after a photolithographic process and the starting layer is then etched. The performance capability of the presented fine structuring technology has been successfully demonstrated for focused high-frequency applications. For reliable integration of fully metallic fine-structured conductor tracks in LTCC modules, a combination of tape-on-substrate technology and pressure-assisted sintering is recommended. By this process, the wet-chemical processes of the resin technology are completely decoupled from the flexible and lightweight structurability of the green foils in the unbaked state. In addition to fine structuring, a solderable and bondable layer sequence based on resin pastes was developed. The suitability of this build-up and connection technology was successfully demonstrated for aerospace applications through qualification studies.
Theory and Design of Self-Organization ¤ Self-organization

Computer Assisted Development and Optimization of a Variable Dielectric Barrier Discharge ¤ In this thesis, the Venturi-DBD concept is thoroughly characterized and an appropriate process control strategy is developed. The Venturi-DBD is an intermediate-pressure dielectric barrier discharge system for the generation of different reactive oxygen and nitrogen species compositions. The chemical processes decisive for the species composition are identified and the complete concept including the process control is implemented in a prototype. Primary fields of application for the concept and the prototype are basic research and engineering in plasma medicine and decontamination.

The Reduction of Land Take by Planning Law: Legal Validity and Realization in the Social System ¤ Land take is a well-known problem in Germany. Since the 1970s, politics has been aware of the effects. Time and again, political goals, such as the Federal Government's sustainability strategy, are presented. In this context, planning law plays a crucial role. The work illustrates for the first time comprehensively and in detail that planning law offers a wide range of options for reducing land take and examines whether it is also sufficiently equipped to prevent extensive land take. The numerous measures for reducing land take are presented using examples and precise definitions, and are ranked in a sequence. For each measure, the relevant regulations are presented and weighted. The work covers both the presentation and setting options in the land-use plans, the planning goals and planning guidelines for the balancing act, the planning substitute regulations as well as the measures of special urban development law. Furthermore, the work examines the effect of the regulations relevant to the measures. In this context, the work analyzes, among other things, land management, administrative resource conservation, and possible cooperations, such as through cooperative urban development law. END

A Reduced Model for the Simulation of Transient Thermal Behavior of a Vehicle Cabin ¤ David Klemm investigates the transient thermal behavior of a vehicle cabin. The author models relevant local parameters using the approach of a linear, time-invariant system and characterizes three load cases through three-dimensional transient CFD simulations. With these parameters, he develops a reduced simulation model based on one-dimensional transmission processes and validates it using three-dimensional CFD simulations. This model requires a factor of 105 reduced computation time in real-time. The content: Fundamentals of linear time-invariant systems (LTI), one-dimensional heat transfer, and numerical finite differences Modeling relevant quantities of the thermal behavior of a vehicle cabin as an LTI system Description of the reduced transient thermal simulation model of a vehicle cabin Validation of the reduced simulation model using three-dimensional CFD simulations for the load cases "Soak", "Heatup", and "Cooldown" Target groups: Lecturers and students of thermodynamics, system modeling, and simulation Developers in industry in the field of vehicle climate control and regulation of vehicle air conditioning systems The author David Klemm has several years of industry experience in the field of flow simulation and design of electronic control units. After research activity at the Institute for Internal Combustion Engines and Vehicles (IVK) of the University of Stuttgart, he is now dealing with simulation in the system development of commercial vehicles Fundamentals of linear time-invariant systems (LTI), one-dimensional heat transfer, and numerical finite differences -- Modeling relevant quantities of the thermal behavior of a vehicle cabin as an LTI system -- Description of the reduced transient thermal simulation model of a vehicle cabin -- Validation of the reduced simulation model using three-dimensional CFD simulations for the load cases "Soak", "Heatup", and "Cooldown"

Transformation Capability Training for Employees in Manual Assembly based on Training Methods from Gymnastics ¤ Transformation capability is a crucial factor for all areas of modern companies (human, technology, and organization) in the face of continuously increasing market dynamics, and therefore receives high attention in research. However, the currently known concepts for improving the transformation capability of companies focus mainly on the areas of technology and organization and do not provide a sufficient systematics and suitable methods for improving transformation capability at the employee level. Against this background, the present work aims to develop a transformation capability training for employees who are active in the organizational unit of manual assembly. To achieve this goal, a series of training modules is developed that target different aspects of transformation capability and application cases in manual assembly. The development of the training modules is based on training methods from gymnastics, which are transferred to application in companies. Prior to this, the plausibility of the transferability from gymnastics to manual assembly executions is checked by comparing both areas on various levels and extracting transferable strategies from gymnastics. The effectiveness of the developed training modules is then exemplified by means of a simulation of assembly. Based on these investigations, a fundamental transferability of training modules from gymnastics to movement executions in assembly is demonstrated. The results indicate an improvement in the execution quality of the defined manual assembly processes. Finally, all training modules are combined into a scalable and comprehensive training concept for employees in manual assembly and equipped with a navigation aid for easy application in companies. This work contributes to the ability to train employees in companies specifically to improve their transformation capability, and thus makes a contribution to the enhancement of the transformation capability of companies as a whole.

Investigations on the Analytics and Diagnostic Utility of Interleukin-1 beta (IL-1ß) and the Soluble Interleukin-2 Receptor alpha (sIL-2Rα) in Dogs ¤ IL-1ß, sIL-2Ra, Dog, dog. - Cytokines are increasingly in the spotlight when it comes to establishing reliable serological markers for the diagnosis of certain disease patterns in dogs. Against this background, two previously little-noticed cytokines in the serum of healthy and diseased dogs were investigated in the present study. The cytokines in question are Interleukin-1 beta (IL-1β) and the soluble Interleukin 2 Receptor alpha (sIL-2Rα), which were determined using a sandwich ELISA. The aim of the investigations was to determine the diagnostic significance of IL-1β in the inflammatory process and of sIL-2Rα in the context of neoplasms and non-malignant internal diseases. The results have already been published (sIL-2Rβ, PRACHAR et al. 2013a) or have been accepted for publication (IL-1β, PRACHAR et al. 2013b). The essential results can be summarized as follows...

Essays on nonlinearities in time series : regime switching, outlying observations, and changes in persistence ¤ Information criteria, nonlinearity, additive outliers, innovative outliers, change in persistence, outlier detection

The Effect of Flexible Compensation Components on the Labor Market Considering Business-Economic Aspects ¤ Flexible Wages as a Contribution to Reducing Unemployment For several years, the Federal Republic has been experiencing a phase of high and persistent unemployment. The high costs and social problems force policymakers, decision-makers, and market actors to take committed measures. Unflexible wages, which do not adapt to the market situation, regional, or qualification-specific characteristics, are considered a major cause of high unemployment. Severe structural flaws also contribute to the increase and consolidation of unemployment figures. This book presents approaches to flexibilization, such as performance, success, or capital participation, and examines the added value of these models from a people's and business economic perspective. In addition, the influences on wage- and structurally conditioned unemployment as well as the compatibility with other concepts for solving this social problem are investigated. There are solutions to the problem of unemployment. Can they be realized in this society?

Computer Criminal Law in Comparative Law - Germany, Austria, Switzerland ¤ BEGIN\nMain description: Daniel Schuh presents the amended (§§ 202a, 303a and b) and newly introduced (§§ 202b and c) provisions of the German Criminal Code, as amended by the 41st Criminal Code Amendment Act, to combat computer crime. After explaining the foundations for the reform (Cybercrime Convention and EU Framework Decision), a comparison is made, using selected examples such as phishing and hacking, with the provisions of our neighboring countries Austria and Switzerland. -- The author concludes that the German norms consistently implement the requirements of the Cybercrime Convention and the EU Framework Decision, effectively combat computer crime, and only require minor adjustments. The regulations in the Austrian and Swiss Criminal Code, on the other hand, reveal gaps in criminal liability. Considering the results, the author ultimately submits proposals for amendments to the German provisions.\nEND

Early Stages of Terpene Metabolism ¤ The biosynthesis of the universal terpene building block isopentenyl pyrophosphate (IPP) can occur via the long-known mevalonate pathway (MVA pathway) or via the methylerythritol phosphate pathway (MEP pathway) that was discovered in recent years. In plants, the MVA pathway appears to be responsible for the biosynthesis of sesquiterpenes and steroids, while the MEP pathway feeds the biosynthesis of monoterpenes. Through incorporation experiments with deuterium-labeled precursors of both pathways, specific inhibition of both pathways, and due to differences in the natural 12C/13C isotope ratios of the resulting terpenes, it could be shown that this classical assignment is not strictly adhered to in terpenes of the induced scent bouquet of the lima bean Paseolus lunatus and that a participation of the MEP pathway can also be observed in the biosynthesis of sesquiterpenes.

Fermenting the Social : Thermal Figures in Social Theory ¤ Elena Beregows study develops a sociology of tempering. It explores societal nature-cultures, thermopolitics, and temporalities through the thermal figures of fire, machine, and the hitherto overlooked fermentation. The latter is at the center of the work and is explored through readings of Marx, Durkheim, Lévi-Strauss, Serres, Latour, and Haraway. The present materialistic discussion of the fermentation metaphor reveals new social theoretical figures of the 'small'. In them, the utopian hopes in the materiality of the social – the new, creative, and unexpected – are just as readable as the 'dark' moments of decay, decomposition, and dissolution.

Suspension Development and Production Technical Integration from Early Product Development Phase ¤ In the present dissertation, a method is described, with which suspension concepts can be evaluated and optimized with regard to their assembly capability as early as the early development phase. The method is based on a detailed analysis of the development process in the automotive industry. It is shown which roles are responsible within the development for the creation of an axle concept that is producible in the framework of industrial series production. The developed method supports these development activities specifically and thus enables an increase in efficiency. The content Basics.- State of the art.- Requirements management for early phases of product development.- Generic solution approach and methodology.- Exemplary implementation at the example of the aggregate assembly. The target groups Vehicle and engine engineers Professors, lecturers and students at universities and universities The author Bastian Leistner worked on the contents of this book between 2016 and 2019 with the Technical University of Chemnitz and in cooperation with the West Saxon University of Applied Sciences Zwickau and the BMW Group Munich. He has been working as a development specialist in the field of vehicle dynamics at the BMW Group since his successfully completed promotion.

Influence of Controlled Charging of Electric Vehicles on Grid Operation under Volatile Wind Power Feed-in ¤ The work summarizes findings on controlled charging of electric vehicles (EVs) under volatile wind power feed-in. Based on the state of the art in controlled EV charging, two operational procedures are shown on the basis of procedures currently under development for the exchange of information between EV and charging point for the negotiation of charging processes. The Wind-2-Vehicle procedure (W2V) is an example of the use of controlled EV charging to realize a regenerative power feed-in demand. The Local Load Management (LLM) is an example of using information from the distribution network to limit the charging power of EVs in time. In a case study, fifty EVs are controlled by a reduced W2V approach. In a second case study, it is shown by time series simulations that controlled and uncontrolled charging can lead to violations of established limits in distribution networks. The application of the developed LLM procedure shows that large and small fleets can be controlled charged with a low reduction of the achievable W2V quality, without further violating operationally established limits.

Minimization of Unwanted Throughput Reductions after Failures and Subsequent Re-Starts of Shelf Service Equipment in Automated High-Bay Warehouses ¤ For the control of the widespread technical warehouse type automated high-bay warehouse (aHRL), warehouse operation strategies are applied, which have a significant influence on the characteristic operating behavior of the warehouse system. Considering increased customer demands in terms of delivery reliability and delivery reliability, extended operating times, and reduced exercise of planned maintenance, the question arises as to what contribution warehouse operation strategies can make if, despite high availability commitments from manufacturers, a shelf service device (RBG) fails in an automated high-bay warehouse. Taking into account Geinitz's investigations on throughput reduction after the end of a RBG failure (1998), it is initially necessary to determine that the operating strategy of cross-distribution is insufficiently evaluated in usual operating situations for these purposes. Detailed considerations of the changes in the inventory of an article during and after a RBG failure enable the development of the concept of the 'point of disturbance', to which the observed throughput behavior of aHRL in simulation experiments in connection with a RBG failure can be traced back. On the basis of so-called 'weak' variants of cross-distribution and the first-in-first-out principle, a new warehouse operation strategy is formulated in the form of several optional measures. The concrete design and application of this new operation strategy must be carried out under consideration of a series of circumstances, which depend on the specific operating situation of the respective aHRL. In individual cases, the adapted variant of this new operation strategy enables the minimization of the negative consequences of a occurred RBG failure.

Digital Transformation of Business Models in SMEs: Theory, Empirics, and Action Recommendations ¤ This book covers both a theoretical and empirical investigation of the digital transformation of business models in SMEs. Tim Botzkowski particularly deals with the original digitalization decision and formulates specific action recommendations for business practice. In addition, a digital governance concept and a structured transformation roadmap are developed. The content Digital Governance Roadmap of the Digital Transformation SME-specific action recommendations The target groups Lecturers and students of business administration with a focus on corporate management, strategic management, business informatics, and computer science Professionals and executives in SMEs in the areas of corporate management, corporate strategy, business informatics, and computer science The author Tim Botzkowski is a research assistant and Ph.D. student at the Chair of Corporate Management and Controlling, member of the European Competence Center for Applied SME Research (EKAM) at the University of Bamberg, and member of the Competence Center for Business Models in the Digital World.

Theory and Politics of the Housing Market: An Analysis of Housing Policy in Germany with Special Consideration of the Economic Theory of Politics ¤ The peculiarities of the economic good of housing lead to frictions regarding the coordination and allocation processes of the housing market. The author checks whether a market failure on the housing market exists, which could be used as an economic justification for state interventions. Subsequently, the housing policy instruments are analyzed in terms of their goal congruence. As suitable criteria, social accuracy and efficiency are brought to the center of the considerations. The housing policy in East Germany is also included in the analysis. -- As a result, an inefficient and socially inaccurate housing policy can be found in Germany since the Second World War. Rather, the state regulations strengthen or create the coordination and allocation disturbances. -- Using the approaches of the New Institutional Economics and the Public-Choice Theory, the tendency towards a short-sighted, discretionary-interventionist housing policy is explained as a result of interactions between the involved actors. Annette Mayer develops solution proposals that are intended to eliminate the dysfunctional incentives and working conditions of politicians, bureaucrats, and interest groups.

Physical and Technological Limitations of SNS-Josephson Contacts for Highly Integrated Low-Temperature Superconducting Switches ¤ This work investigates the physical and technological limitations of novel SNS-Josephson contacts in ramp technology. Based on in-situ shot Nb/HfTi/Nb- and Nb/HfTi/Nb/HfTi/Nb contacts, a fabrication technology has been developed that enables the reproducible production of sub-μm contacts down to contact areas of A = 0.03 μm2. The physical properties of the contacts are investigated: temperature and magnetic field dependence of the critical current Ic, influence of microwave irradiation: Shapiro steps, differential resistance. For the realization of superconducting digital electronic circuits (SDE), the current-carrying capacity of sub-μm Nb wiring is measured and the fringe factor is determined. It is shown that the novel Josephson contacts are suitable for the production of series circuits, which are used in Josephson voltage standards. Furthermore, the feasibility of the novel contacts in superconducting digital logic circuits in Rapid-Single-Flux-Quantum (RSFQ) implementation is verified.

Stochastic satisfiability modulo theories : a symbolic technique for the analysis of probabilistic hybrid systems ¤ This thesis considers symbolic techniques for reachability as well as expected-value analysis of probabilistic hybrid discrete-continuous systems, being based on a probabilistic logic called stochastic satisfiability modulo theories (SSMT). Due to the expressive power of this logic, the step-bounded dynamics of probabilistic hybrid systems can be encoded by SSMT formulae. Aiming at an automatic analysis procedure, a substantial part of the thesis is devoted to algorithms for solving SSMT problems and to algorithmic enhancements improving performance. Applicability of the resulting bounded model checking procedures is demonstrated on a realistic case study from the domain of networked automation systems. To overcome the limitation of step-boundedness, the thesis introduces a generalized concept of Craig interpolation and shows its use in probabilistic model checking of finite-state systems. <engl.>

The SE-Betriebsrat: Application Requirements and Design of Industrial Co-Determination by the SE-Betriebsrat by Agreement and by Law ¤ The core theme of this work are the requirements and contents of industrial co-determination by the SE-Betriebsrat by agreement and by law. In this context, the extent to which the social partners can negotiate a tailored and SE-specific participation agreement through their fundamental agreement autonomy is examined in particular. The limits of this autonomy against the background of the provisions for the SE-Betriebsrat by law have been treated very „stepchildishly“ in the literature so far. The inclusion of exemplary participation agreements from practice rounds off the examination of the theoretically permissible and purposeful agreement options.

International Protection of Privacy from Intelligence Surveillance: Intelligence Surveillance of Telecommunications of Individuals in the Light of the IPpbR and the ECHR ¤ The dissertation examines intelligence surveillance of private telecommunications and its compatibility with the international human right to privacy in Art. 17 ICCPR and in Art. 8 ECHR. These articles provide a comprehensive protection against the most modern forms of surveillance, including mass surveillance. Specific criteria apply to the determinacy of surveillance laws. Surveillance must be approved and controlled by independent authorities and effective remedies must be available. Furthermore, the study investigates to what extent the surveillance state and the host state violate their human rights obligations in cross-border surveillance. The central question is whether the existing definitions of "jurisdiction" are applicable to this extraterritorial scenario. Extraterritorial exercise of jurisdiction can also rely on control over certain human rights relevant objects. According to this approach, telecommunications data are objects relevant to the right of the individual to correspondence and data protection.

Optical Coherence Tomography with Extreme Ultraviolet Radiation ¤ In this dissertation, the concept and realization of laser-based optical coherence tomography in the extreme ultraviolet (XUV) spectral range - briefly XCT - are treated. XCT is a three-dimensional microscopy method that can achieve an axial resolution of a few nanometers. A XCT model for reconstructing the axial sample structure was developed, which includes the interaction between XUV light and the sample to be investigated. The new microscopy method, which has only been demonstrated at synchrotron sources so far, has been implemented with a laser-based XUV source on a laboratory scale. By generating high harmonics of infrared laser radiation, a broadband XUV source with sufficient flux in the silicon transmission window of 30eV - 100eV was realized. A completely revised and adapted XCT microscope was designed and built, so that XCT can now be used routinely. The achieved axial resolution is comparable to the resolution of about 20nm achieved at the synchrotron. Furthermore, a new one-dimensional phase reconstruction algorithm is presented, which is able to uniquely reconstruct the sample structure from the XCT signal, which was not possible so far. Through XCT measurements, a thin layer was found in a sample that was not part of the originally planned sample structure. The existence of this layer and thus the XCT measurement could be confirmed by a measurement with a transmission electron microscope. XCT in its realized form has application fields in the three-dimensional investigation of (multi-layer) coatings, for example, of optical or XUV mirrors, functional axial structures in solar cells or axially structured semiconductors such as graphene-based electronics. Even the imaging of biological laterally homogeneous membranes is conceivable.

The Whole-Nation Bias in Empirical Research: Theory and Empirics at the Example of Democracy Measurement in 18 Federal States ¤ In this book, the Whole-Nation Bias, a highly relevant distortion problem for comparative country research, is subjected to an empirical investigation and an extensive theoretical exploration for the first time. In the theoretical part of the book, a conceptual differentiation of the Whole-Nation Bias is carried out. Furthermore, Felipe Böttcher sketches the occurrence, possible manifestations, and consequences of this distortion problem. The empirical assessment aims to quantitatively represent the magnitude in different state contexts. In an extensive data collection, 6,150 indicator values were calculated for 410 regions in 18 federal states, and thus the quality of democracy was recorded both on the subnational and national levels of these countries. Content Theoretical and empirical exploration of the Whole-Nation Bias Measurement of democracy quality in 18 federal states Revelation of internal state variations Democracy measurement on the subnational level Target groups Lecturers and students of the fields Comparative Political Science, empirical democracy research, and democracy measurement Politicians and politicians, journalists and journalists, think tanks, NGOs The author Felipe Böttcher studied European Studies at the University of Osnabrück and the Universidad de Granada and was finally promoted to Dr. rer. pol. at the University of Lüneburg Theoretical and empirical exploration of the Whole-Nation Bias -- Measurement of democracy quality in 18 federal states -- Revelation of internal state variations -- Democracy measurement on the subnational level

Consideration of Statistical Surface Characteristics in Numerical Simulation of Hydrodynamically Acting Radial Thrust Bearings in the Mixed Friction Regime ¤ The subject of the present scientific work was the investigation of whether a description of the pressure components in the mixed friction regime of a hydrodynamically acting radial thrust bearing is possible by considering experimentally determined statistical surface characteristics. Furthermore, it was checked which surface-determined characteristics are suitable for surface definition in the simulation. Based on the model approach of load distribution in the mixed friction regime, two separate models were created for the respective pressure components.

System Justice and Coherence: Legislative Unity and Diversity through Constitutional and Union Law ¤ Peter Dieterich examines and compares the constitutional postulate of 'system justice' and the union law figure of 'coherence'. In total, the work leads the charged debate about legislative rationality requirements back to their legitimate normative core. -- The analysis of the justifications of a rule of system-just legislation (in particular, the principle of equality, the rule of law, and the principle of proportionality) shows that this only leaves a very narrow scope of application: It stands alone against evident contradictory justifications for infringements of fundamental rights. -- For the union law principle of coherence, two functions can be identified in justifying infringements of fundamental freedoms: As a justification ground, it remains limited to a qualified (primarily tax law) compensation argument, as a justification limit, it forms a legitimate intensification of the suitability test, which largely corresponds to the constitutional system binding.

Effects of Digitalization on Teaching and Learning Processes: Didactic Changes at the Example of the FernUniversität in Hagen ¤ Christina Gloerfeld examines changes caused by digitalization in the complex processes of teaching and learning in the higher education sector. Using an analytical framework model developed by her, the author identifies concrete effects and shows that not only a shift of teaching and learning activities to the digital space takes place, but also a didactic relocation of teaching and learning processes towards cybernetic approaches. In doing so, she works out four development trends – de-bordering, standardization, professionalization, and politicization. However, a transformation of teaching and learning processes from a didactic perspective has not yet been shown. Content Digitalization in Higher Education Teaching and Learning Processes and their Representation in Didactic Models Analytical Framework Model Changes in Teaching and Learning Processes at the FernUniversität in Hagen Development Trends and Theses on the Impact of Digitalization Target Groups Lecturers and students of education science, educational science, media education, empirical educational research, and learning psychology Academic and university didacticians, science managers, university leadership, e-learning teams and responsible persons, teachers The author Dr. Christina Gloerfeld is a research assistant in the field of education theory and media education at the FernUniversität in Hagen and a member of the research focus D2L2 (Digitalization, Diversity, and Lifelong Learning. Consequences for Higher Education) located there. Digitalization in Higher Education -- Teaching and Learning Processes and their Representation in Didactic Models -- Analytical Framework Model -- Changes in Teaching and Learning Processes at the FernUniversität in Hagen -- Development Trends and Theses on the Impact of Digitalization.

Innovation Strategies of Japanese and German Companies: A Comparative Analysis ¤ Introduction -- Case Study Flat-Screen Industry -- Innovation in Japan -- Case Study Automotive Electronics -- Dynamic Determinants of Company Competition Success -- Case Study Mobile Payment -- Success Factors in German and Japanese Companies -- Conclusion. In a global competitive environment, companies must adapt their strategies ever faster to the changing market dynamics in order to achieve competitive success. Raina Schweikle analyzes innovation and implementation strategies of companies in Japan and Germany. Based on empirical case studies in the fields of automotive electronics, flat-screen industry, and mobile payment industry, she identifies essential success-determining factors for Japanese and German companies in innovative key industries.

Amphiphilic carbohydrate-containing compounds for multifunctional nano/macro structures ¤ In living organisms, carbohydrate-containing compounds, such as glycoproteins, glycopeptides, and glycolipids, play key roles in numerous physiological and pathological events via carbohydrate-protein interactions amplified by “glycol-cluster effect”. Inspired by the multifunctional natural glycoconjugates, huge synthetical carbohydrate-containing compounds in the form of polymers and surfactants have been produced and applied in our daily life. In this study, renewable and biodegradable cellulose had been chosen as the biopolymer backbone during the synthesis of carbohydrate-containing polymers. The developed amphiphilic carbohydrate-containing compounds showed a variety of applications, including the formation of nanostructures that can serve as carriers for drugs, genetic material, and other biomolecules. Additionally, the amphiphilic carbohydrate-containing compounds were used to produce macrostructures of interest in biomedicine and materials science. The results of this study demonstrate the great diversity of amphiphilic carbohydrate-containing compounds and their potential applications in various fields.

Full-Day Education and the Concept of Regional Learning 21+: Empirical Study on the Development of Interdisciplinary Educational Offers on the Topic of Globalization ¤ Carolin Duda, research assistant at the University of Vechta, investigated under the leadership of Professor Dr. Martina Flath in her study "Full-Day Education and the Concept of Regional Learning 21+ - Empirical Study on the Development of Interdisciplinary Educational Offers on the Topic of Globalization", how additional, interdisciplinary learning offers in the afternoon influence the learning behavior of students at full-day schools.

Prevalence of Salmonella spp. in primary poultry production and broiler slaughter: Salmonella entry in slaughter poultry during the slaughter process ¤ Salmonella, prevalence, poultry. - Salmonellosis, despite declining numbers since 1992, is one of the most common foodborne illnesses. The entry of Salmonella into the food chain poses a permanent threat to human health. Contamination with Salmonella can occur at various stages of the food chain, making it essential to intervene early on in the food chain and identify and evaluate potential contamination risk points. The aim of the study was to uncover important entry points for Salmonella by determining the prevalence at various stages of the food chain, in order to better respond to critical points with measures. To this end, the entry points of Salmonella were investigated from the stage of the broiler master and possible pathogen sources during rearing were weighed, evaluated, and possibilities for rectification developed. In this study, 10 broiler herds, which were raised on 5 different farms, were examined. The sampling was distributed over two time periods to be able to recognize seasonal influences. The first sampling took place between the months of March 2009 to April 2009, the second investigation took place in the period between July 2009 to September 2009. The sampling of the samples took place at various stages of the food chain. In the examined herds, a total Salmonella prevalence in the herds of 14.29% was determined by Salmonella-positive sock swab samples. The herd prevalence showed a large range of variation, ranging from 0.00% in the herds of two fattening farms to values of 66.66% in the herd of another farm. The cloacal swabs taken in the slaughterhouse showed a total prevalence of 3.52%. In the further course of the food chain, a Salmonella prevalence of 9.50% was found in the brine water dripping from the carcasses. Regarding the increase from the total prevalence of the cloacal swabs from 3.52% to 9.50% in the brine water dripping samples, a significant increase in prevalence is shown. In the further course...

Freiraum or Territory of Authority: Human Right to Access and International Principles as Limits to State Action in the Internet ¤ The author deals with the question of whether and how international limits can already restrict the power of states in the internet today and how they could look like in the future. In particular, he addresses a human right to access the internet. A focus is on the freedom of opinion and information on the level of the United Nations and the Council of Europe, which are examined from the perspective of various dimensions of intervention. For this purpose, an extensive evaluation of existing documents and case law is carried out. Subsequently, the author provides his own proposal for a human right to access the internet de lege ferenda. Due to the qualification of the internet as an international (over-)space, further international limits, which arise in particular from the field of environmental law, the rules of international relations, and humanitarian law, are examined for their transferability.

Market-Based Interest Rate Forecasts with Regime-Switching Models ¤ Due to the individual and macroeconomic relevance of interest rate changes, interest rate forecasts have traditionally been of great interest. Nevertheless, only a few studies can be found in the scientific literature that analyze the forecasting quality of econometric procedures

Interactions between Organization and Social Software in Knowledge Work ¤ Knowledge enables companies to build a long-term competitive advantage. Social software is often used for knowledge work, but its implementation in the company does not always proceed satisfactorily. Simone Kansy therefore examines the influence of the organizational structure on the use of social software in knowledge work and the implications resulting from its use for the organization. The author develops an integrative framework based on aspects of business informatics, organizational theory, and sociology in order to subsequently demonstrate the importance of the organizational structure for the use of social software through a comparative case study analysis.

Deinstitutionalization through organizational change : Self-determination and participation of people with disabilities as a challenge for change processes in organizations ¤ This work addresses the question of how the reforms of residential services of the so-called disability care, which are demanded under the term deinstitutionalization in special education, can be realized through a change of the addressed organizations. The core of the work is an empirical study on the decentralization and regionalization of a large and complex institution. For the theoretical foundation of the study, the special education discourse on the topic of deinstitutionalization is retraced and supplemented and further developed by an institutional sociological perspective of neoinstitutionalism. The qualitative study analyzes the structural and content-related aspects of the change of the large and complex institution in their interaction. The results show the complexity of the change processes, especially with regard to the everyday reality of residents in stationary settings. By linking the empirical results to the deinstitutionalization theory (special education and neoinstitutionalism), key elements of an active strategy of deinstitutionalization are derived. The study understands itself as a system-questioning and active contribution to the development of knowledge on the production of self-determination and participation of people with disabilities. This title is deposited in open access on the document server pedocs of the DIPF. In online sales, it is charged with a service fee for organizational reasons.

Social Policy between Tradition and Modernity: State Regulations at the Intersection of Labor Market Integration and Reproduction in Germany, France, and Spain ¤ The study inquires into the explanatory power of traditions for the divergence of employment-related social policy regulations. Based on a historical analysis of developments and tradition lines, it is shown at the example of Germany, France, and Spain that different cultural traditions have developed here, which have a specific understanding as a consequence. Based on the concept of secondary care arrangements developed in the historical analysis, a categorization of contemporary regulations is carried out. In this process, a theory of different modernization strategies is developed, which provides a basis for further research and, in particular, also beyond the analyzed countries, has explanatory power for the diversity of regulations; it thus offers a point of approach to a culturally sensitive understanding in the field of social policy research

Self-similar Polyhedra ¤ In the present work, in addition to the k-replicating convex and non-convex polygons, k-replicating d-dimensional polyhedra with d ≥ 3 are also studied. So far, very little is known about such polyhedra. E. Hertel has investigated the 8-replicating three-dimensional simplexes [14] and determined a class of 2d-replicating d-dimensional polyhedra [16]. Furthermore, there is a remark by Ch. Bandt that one can obtain 2-replicating polyhedra by product constructions, for example, of two right-angled triangles [1]. A conjecture by McMullen states that for d ≥ 3, every k-replicating d-dimensional polyhedron is combinatorially equivalent to a Cartesian product of simplexes [5, p. 88]. Just as one can construct decompositions of the plane into pairwise congruent polygons using k-replicating polygons, one can construct corresponding decompositions of the d-dimensional Euclidean space using k-replicating d-dimensional polyhedra. Decompositions of the d-dimensional Euclidean space into pairwise congruent polyhedra are the subject of numerous works (e.g. [6], [10]). Another application can be found in applied numerical analysis. If one has a decomposition of a region into k-replicating polyhedra, this decomposition can be refined without changing the shape of the decomposition parts.

STM study of bare and copper covered ceria thin films ¤ The outline of this PhD thesis is concerned with the study of morphologic and electronic characteristics of cerium dioxide (111) thin films on a ruthenium (0001) crystal as a model system for heterogenous catalysis. The focus in this thesis is on oxygen vacancies in the O-Ce-O oxide layers, which control the catalytic activity of the model system and are introduced by annealing the film at highly reducing conditions. Under the same focus is the distribution of the copper nano-particles on the surface of the oxide films. Copper rather prefers to donate charges to Ce ions in the film that consequently transform from Ce^4+ to Ce^3+. Clear evidence for this comes from XPS investigations. The impact of the copper ad-particles on the degree of reduction is strong enough to drive the highest degree of reduction from former 17% to over 50% in the near surface regime. This means the amount of Ce^3+ ions in the film is comparable to that of the bixbyite stoichiometry of ceria (Ce_2O_3). <engl.>

Steuerung Virtueller Communities : Instruments, Mechanisms, Interdependencies ¤ In Virtual Communities, individuals communicate and collaborate with each other over the Internet, where cooperation is mostly voluntary and without financial incentives. Companies use Virtual Communities, among other things, for customer relationship management and knowledge management. In universities, virtual learning networks are intended to increase interaction between students and improve learning outcomes. However, the potential of Virtual Communities is often not fully exploited, as complex motivation structures make systematic member management more difficult. Stefan Stieglitz develops a framework that enables a systematic build-up, operation, and especially the control of Virtual Communities. To this end, he analyzes structures and functional processes in open-source projects and identifies control instruments that he transfers to other types of Virtual Communities. In two case studies, he tests the framework under real conditions in an expert network of a stock exchange and a university learning network. In the final analysis, the author shows the effects of competitive, cooperative, and hierarchical control instruments in Virtual Communities. Institutions, institutional control, and network effects -- Virtual Communities -- Control in open-source projects -- Empirical investigation -- Final consideration.

Bibliotheksflirt : Library as Public Space ¤ Is the flirt between two users meant or the flirt with the library as a public space? The newly published book Bibliotheksflirt: Library as Public Space deals with the question, among other things: Why do people go to the library or what happens in the interpersonal area during a library visit. Are it really just the holdings and information services that people are drawn to in libraries? For far too long, we have only looked at the classical tasks of our institutions - and a wide range of other functions that the library location has, have been almost completely ignored. But is there not more than just an "aura of erudition" and the famous "Pssst" in the air in libraries? For "Bibliotheksflirt - Library as Public Space", extensive conversations were conducted and documented with library users and designers. The result is a mosaic of human motivations that go beyond the classical performance requirements, but also take on the design mandate that goes hand in hand with the characteristic features of these institutions.

Development of a Concept for Modeling and Evaluation of Workflows ¤ Business Reengineering, workflow management, and the use of business standard software applications lead to new requirements for the design of information systems. The development of reference architectures, models, and systems is of great importance here, as such reference instruments can normalize concept systems, delimit and systematize system components. The book deals with the design of computer-supported business processes and organizational structures using workflow management systems. It provides a comprehensive methodological instrument for modeling and evaluating business processes and workflows. The presented concept includes the complete cycle of a business process, starting from the development of business strategy, through business process analysis and restructuring, as well as modeling, to more detailed workflow modeling, simulation, and execution.

Global Conflicts or Global Governance? : Continuity and Change of Global Conflict Lines after the East-West Conflict ¤ Does the end of the East-West conflict also mean the end of system-forming global conflict lines? This question is examined by means of an analysis of six world conferences - from the UNCED 1992 to the Fourth World Women's Conference 1995. The empirical findings of the case studies are contrasted with various popular scenarios of international politics, such as the 'Clash of Cultures'. Since the conflict lines found do not correspond to any of these scenarios, a new model of international conflict dynamics after the end of the East-West conflict is designed. At the center of this model is the simultaneity of development and coordination dilemmas, which should be taken into account in the future discussion of Global Governance just like the analyzed conflict lines.

Characterization and Simulation of Sequentially Processed CIGSSe Solar Cells with Chemically Graded Absorber Layer : Possibilities and Limitations of a One-Dimensional Approach ¤ In this work a one-dimensional (1D) modelbased on the photovoltaic simulator SCAPS-1D has been developed to describe the properties of industrially processed CIGSSe solar cells. In consequence of the large-scale and sequential production sequence, chemical and microstructural inhomogeneities are observed in the device. In order to accurately image these features in the simulation, each functional layer has been characterized separately first. The required dimension reduction was realized subsequently by averaging of the experimental input parameters, determined before. Electrooptical measurements on the investigated solar cells can be predicted quantitatively by the acquired model. An error estimation of the incorporated simplifications and not considered multidimensional effects proves the capability of the 1D approach. Simulative motivated modifications in the solar cell configuration could be implemented in production and led to increased conversion efficiencies. <engl.>

Biobased Plastics with Cellulose Fiber Reinforcement: Relationships between Structure, Adhesion, and Mechanical Properties ¤ composite; cellulose fibre; short fibre-reinforced thermoplastics; mechanical properties; Rayon; polylactide; fibre-matrix adhesion; biobased; bioplastics; interface The present work is concerned in general with short fiber reinforced plastics and in particular with fully bio-based composites consisting of a thermoplastic matrix and a cellulosic reinforcing fiber (Rayon). The aim was to clarify structure-property relationships and identify advantageously acting structures. The composites were prepared by melt mixing and injection molding and characterized for their physical and chemical structure as well as for the corresponding mechanical properties. Starting from the model composite consisting of polylactide (PLA) and Rayon fibers the structural parameters fiber content, fiber diameter, fiber length, fiber toughness, matrix crystallinity, and, in particular, fiber-matrix adhesion were studied. It could be shown that by changing and tailoring the fiber-matrix adhesion the properties of PLA-Rayon composites can be adjusted in a wide range. The principles could be almost completely transferred to further bio-based plastics such as PHB, PBS, PBAT or PA. The present work is concerned in general with short fiber reinforced plastics and in particular with fully bio-based composites consisting of a thermoplastic matrix and a cellulosic reinforcing fiber (Rayon). The aim was to clarify structure-property relationships and identify advantageously acting structures. The composites were prepared by melt mixing and injection molding and characterized for their physical and chemical structure as well as for the corresponding mechanical properties. Starting from the model composite consisting of polylactide (PLA) and Rayon fibers the structural parameters fiber content, fiber diameter, fiber length, fiber toughness, matrix crystallinity, and, in particular, fiber-matrix adhesion were studied. It could be shown that by changing and tailoring the fiber-matrix adhesion the properties of PLA-Rayon composites can be adjusted in a wide range. The principles could be almost completely transferred to further bio-based plastics such as PHB, PBS, PBAT or PA.

Innovative XUV and X-ray plasma spectroscopy to explore warm dense matter ¤ In summary, this work is devoted to the exploration of defined states of warm dense matter. This knowledge is of outstanding importance for laser-fusion research, the study of high-density matter states, as well as a variety of astrophysically relevant questions in plasma research. The present work shows innovative methods for the generation and characterization of warm dense matter. This non-equilibrium state between cold solid and ideal plasma is created by experiments with high energy density. Its properties were studied with high precision. The generation of a defined state of warm dense matter with the help of high-intensity optical short-pulse lasers is challenging. High-energy electrons from a small, hot plasma on the target front surface heat the cold matter through collisional ionization. High spectral and spatial resolutions are necessary to avoid averaging over different plasma states. The author applies advanced X-ray spectroscopy of characteristic emission lines, followed by numerical data processing. The result contains many information, as the line shape is influenced by the plasma parameters and the X-rays are also transparent to solid densities.

Assistance Systems in Industry 4.0: Labour Law and Data Protection Law Issues in an Automated Work Environment ¤ Das Werk widmet sich der Arbeit in der Industrie 4.0, einer Entwicklung, bei der alle realen Prozesse in der Fabrik digital erfassen und so noch stärker automatisiert werden sollen. Für die Beschäftigten bringt dies Chancen, es droht aber auch Dequalifizierung und umfassende Überwachung. Im Arbeitsrecht werden deswegen die rechtliche Bindungskraft der menschengerechten Gestaltung der Arbeit und die Mensch-Maschine-Kollaboration untersucht. Im Datenschutz steht die Frage im Mittelpunkt, inwiefern die effiziente Organisation der Arbeit eine intensive Datenverarbeitung rechtfertigt. Dazu wird in Abgrenzung beider Rechtsgebiete ein neuer Lösungsansatz vorgestellt, abgeleitet aus dem Zusammenspiel deutscher und europäischer Grundrechte. The work is dedicated to work in Industry 4.0, a development in which all real processes in the factory are to be digitally recorded and thus automated even more. This brings opportunities for employees, but also threatens de-skilling and comprehensive monitoring. In labour law, the legal binding force of the humane design of work and human-machine collaboration are therefore being examined. In privacy law the central question is to what extent the efficient organisation of work justifies intensive data processing. To this end, a new approach is presented, which is derived from the interplay of German and European fundamental rights and which differentiates between the two areas of law.

Investigations on ABC and MFS transporters of Streptomyces spp.  ¤ Abstract: ABC (ATP binding cassette) and MFS (major facilitator superfamily) transporters are the two largest families of membrane proteins involved in the import and export of substances across biological membranes. Members of these families have been described for the up-take of a variety, necessary molecules which belong to cell metabolism or for the efflux of toxins and multiple structurally unrelated drugs. In this work ABC and MFS transporters of two Streptomyces spp. have been investigated for their implication in the biosynthesis of two secondary metabolites.Rishirilide B is a type II PKS metabolite produced by Streptomyces bottropensis Goe C4/4 and its gene cluster includes four transporter genes, rslT1-4. An ABC transporter is encoded by rslT1-3 which were predicted to compose an amino acid importer system defined by the substrate binding protein (SBP) RslT1. The multidrug transporter encoded by rslT4 belongs to the MFS and its transcription is controlled by RslR4, a MarR regulator. Inactivation experiments of these transporter genes were performed by Redirect© Technology in the cosmid cos4 which contained rishirilide cluster, for its heterologous expression in Streptomyces albus J1074. Deletion and overexpression experiments of rslT1-3 indicated the capacity of the importer system to affect rishirilide B production. It was therefore suggested that the ABC transporter is responsible for the uptake of a precursor needed for the biosynthesis of rishirilide B. Isobutyryl was proposed as the starter unit for the PKS biosynthesis of rishirilide B and was described to derivate from the valine catabolism. Based on these assumptions, RslT123 was suggested to be involved in the import of this amino acid. Attempts to purify the SBP to prove its substrate specificity failed. Furthermore, deletion and overexpression experiments of the MFS transporter RslT4 and its regulator RslR4 led to the proposal of a regulatory mechanism for the biosynthesis and export of rishirilide B. However, rishirilide B production increased in the ΔrslT4 mutant indicating that another transport mechanism of the host took over the function. The multidrug efflux capacity of RslT4 was determined by MIC and disc diffusion assays.In addition, analysis of the genome sequence of Streptomyces sp. Tü6071 was executed with the help of the bioinformatics platform Galaxy with a focus on transporter genes. S. sp. Tü6071 is responsible for the production of the terpenoids phenalinol ...

The Odeion in the Artemision of Ephesos ¤ In the 125 years of research, the legendary temple of Artemis was always the focus of the archaeological fieldwork, while the once densely built up sacred enclosure remained unexplored. Since 2009 the Austrian Archaeological Institute investigated for the first time a roman building southwest of the Temple, which was up to the present named ‘Tribune’ and whose function could be finally clarified. Due to close typological parallels as well as equipment and furnishing, the building can be identified as roman Odeion of the Early Empire

Acceptance of Ecological Product Alternatives: A Schema-Theoretical Consideration Using Implicit and Experimental Test Procedures ¤ Environmental protection is a topic of high relevance for consumers, but it is not reflected equally in consumer behavior. Katja Rudolph investigates how the acceptance of ecological product alternatives can be increased. She examines how schema congruence in product presentation affects the acceptance of ecological product alternatives and which factors moderate this effect. Based on the results, concrete action implications for the marketing of ecological product alternatives are derived. The content Acceptance of ecological product alternatives as a marketing challenge Ecological product alternatives as ecological innovations Factors influencing the adoption process Cognitive and behavioral scientific consideration as well as schema-theoretical foundations for the acceptance of ecological product alternatives Empirical investigation of the influence of schema congruence on the acceptance of ecological product alternatives The target groups Lecturers and students of business administration with a focus on marketing, consumer behavior, consumer psychology, and sustainability Marketing and sales professionals The author Dr. Katja Rudolph was promoted by Prof. Dr. Manfred Kirchgeorg at the SVI Foundation Chair for Marketing, in particular E-Commerce & Crossmedia Management at the HHL Leipzig Graduate School of Management Acceptance of ecological product alternatives as a marketing challenge -- Ecological product alternatives as ecological innovations -- Factors influencing the adoption process -- Cognitive and behavioral scientific consideration as well as schema-theoretical foundations for the acceptance of ecological product alternatives -- Empirical investigation of the influence of schema congruence on the acceptance of ecological product alternatives

Binuclear CuA formation and the influence of calcium ions on metal cluster maturation in recombinant nitrous oxide reductase from Shewanella denitrificans ¤ Summary: Nitrous oxide has a deleterious effect on our global climate and its level in the atmosphere is on a steady rise. In the stratosphere, various NOx compounds generated from nitrous oxide lead to ozone depletion. The enzyme nitrous oxide reductase (N2OR), found in denitrifying bacteria uniquely reduces nitrous oxide to dinitrogen, but depends on anoxic conditions. Nitrous oxide reductase is a 130 kDa, homodimeric multicopper enzyme that contains the catalytically active tetranuclear CuZ site and the mixed-valent, dinuclear CuA center for electron transfer. In recent years, structures of nitrous oxide reductases from a variety of different bacteria were published.In this thesis, the first crystal structure of Shewanella denitrificans nitrous oxide reductase, heterologously expressed in E.coli, was solved. The apo form of N2OR shows a dimeric structure, that is almost identical to native N2OR structures, but shows flexible regions near the CuA binding site. The structural flexibility enables the copper incorporation into the cluster binding sites of the dimeric protein. Calcium ions play a crucial role in the stabilization of the CuA cluster and the CuA assembly process. We have shown that calcium ions can close the entry point for copper ions at high calcium concentration, whereby the CuA binding site gets stabilized. Under physiological conditions calcium ions have a positive effect on CuA assembly.The process of CuA assembly on SdN2OR was investigated by Stopped-flow spectroscopy by addition of copper ions to the wild-type protein and several variants. These experiments allow the postulation of a assembly mechanism with one intermediate species, namely a type 2 copper site. By studying N2OR variants where the Cys and His ligands are mutated, we propose a complexation of the T2 copper site by the residues Cys613 and His617. The mutation of both active site cysteine residues results also in very low accumulation of the T2 copper site and its reduction, which suggests that electrons can be provided as well by intermolecular disulfide bond formation.The crystal structure of Pseudomonas stutzeri N2OR form I shows a flip of CuA-coordinating residue His583 towards the protein surface during the turnover of N2O. We were able to mimic this open state by substitution of this histidine residue and reconstitution of the CuA site in vitro, which is the basis for further investigations
Resonant Spin Dynamics in Bose-Einstein Condensates ¤ Bose-Einstein condensate, spin dynamic, vacuum fluctuations - Bose-Einstein-Kondensat, Spindynamik, Vakuumfluktuationen.

Reliable and manufacturer-independent medical device interoperability - Contributions to the IEEE 11073 SDC standard family ¤ Medical devices in today's hospitals are almost always isolated systems, which do not transmit information to or interact with external devices. At the most, this is possible within closed company ecosystems. Thus, this work introduces the new IEEE 11073 Service-oriented Device Connectivity (SDC) family of standards, which provides manufacturer-independent interoperability. Three fields of application are considered: safe activation of a device's functionality, dynamic association of a random number of remote-control elements and remote-controllable operations, and distributed alarm systems.

Anion receptors based on hydrogen and halogen bonding ¤ The development of selective anion receptors, which enable the targeted detection and binding as well as the transport of relevant anions, has been one of the most important research areas in supramolecular chemistry for many years. So far, these receptors have been based mainly on the donation of hydrogen bonds, but in recent years, halogen bridge donors have also come into focus. In contrast to the hydrogen bridge, the closely related halogen bridge exhibits higher directionality, a larger covalent bond component, and a stronger interaction with a Lewis base partner, thus enabling the construction of potentially more selective receptors. A significant heterocycle, which enables the simple implementation of halogen bridges in various systems through its modular access, is the halogenated 1,2,3-triazole or the corresponding triazolium salt. This building block allows for strong polarization of the halogen and thus very efficient halogen bridge donation. Within the framework of the dissertation, the great potential of halogen bridge bonds was exploited using particularly efficient and modularly accessible halogenated 1,2,3-triazole and 1,2,3-triazolium building blocks, and was worked on in various sub-projects: 1) Construction of preorganized systems and investigation of the thermodynamic influence in solution. 2) Construction of ion pair receptors and investigation of their cooperative properties in solution. 3) Utilization of the high binding strength and reversibility of halogen bridge bonds for the construction of functional polymeric architectures and their application as self-healing materials

The City Before the Gates : Lüneburg and its Hinterland in the Late Middle Ages ¤ The medieval city did not end at its walls. In multiple respects, the medieval urban space extended beyond its inner area and structured the supposedly empty field beyond the narrower border. This included forests, gardens, and other plots of land in bourgeois and communal ownership, industrial enterprises (brickworks, mills, quarries) and supply facilities (wells) as well as military fortifications (landwehr). Urban governance rights in the hinterland were equally a focus of the city council's policy as were the trade routes necessary for the economic success of a city and its merchants. Niels Petersen reconstructs in detail the hinterland of the Hanseatic and salt city of Lüneburg, which belonged to the largest cities in North Germany in the 15th century, and integrates the results into the city-hinterland research and the newer 'space' discussions. It becomes clear that the urban space - also in Lüneburg - is not abstractly definable, but is practically and symbolically created and perceived as such. Awarded with the Lüneburg History Research Prize and the Third Prize of the Doctoral Forum of the 48th German Historians' Congress.

The New Terrorism : Counter-Terrorism in France in the 1980s ¤ Political and historical framework conditions -- The political system of France -- French experiences with terrorism -- Counter-terrorism in the 1970s -- Counter-terrorism in France in the 1980s -- The left in power -- Terrorism and insecurity -- Mitterrand's new course -- Between intransigence and conflict avoidance -- The return of the conservatives -- The new terrorism : war, consensus, Islam -- Successes of the search and negotiations -- Sources and bibliography -- Register of persons

Quantified vehicles : data, services, ecosystems ¤ Die Digitalisierung hat das Potenzial für Quantified Vehicles aufgezeigt, um Sensordaten über das Fahrzeug selbst und seine Umgebung zu sammeln. Folglich sind (Fahrzeug-)Daten zu einer wichtigen Ressource der Automobilindustrie geworden, da sie auch (datengetriebene) Services ermöglichen. Es bilden sich Ökosysteme von Akteuren, die zusammenarbeiten, um letztlich Services zu generieren. Diese kumulative Dissertation fasst die Beiträge des Autors zusammen und enthält eine Synopsis sowie 14 begutachtete Veröffentlichungen, die zur Beantwortung der drei Forschungsfragen beitragen. Advancing digitalization has shown the potential of so-called Quantified Vehicles for gathering valuable sensor data about the vehicle itself and its environment. Consequently, (vehicle) Data has become an important resource, which can pave the way to (Data-driven) Services. The (Data-driven Service) Ecosystem of actors that collaborate to ultimately generate services, has only shaped up in recent years. This cumulative dissertation summarizes the author's contributions and includes a synopsis as well as 14 peer-reviewed publications, which contribute to answer the three research questions. END

Copper, Lead, and Silver Mining : Central European Metallurgy in the Early Modern Period : A Comparative Representation of Scientific Specialized Literature ¤ Technologietransfer, Montanwissenschaften, Verhüttungstechnik. - Technological transfer, mining and smelting engineering, smelting technology

Probabilistic Lifetime Models for Thermomechanical Fatigue of Solder Joints in CSP Components ¤ Abstract: The goal of the present work was the creation of a reliability model for Chip Scale Package (CSP), by means of which the lifetime of components under changed environmental loads, or newly developed components, can be estimated.
