A prerequisite for this is the determination of basic data for the representation of component reliability with package forms such as µBGA (Micro Ball Grid Array) and QFN (Quad Flat No Lead), as well as with lead-free solders under thermal cyclic loads. In the work, all relevant influencing factors that affect the lifetime of the components are to be found and implemented in a possibly universal reliability model for the different CSP. The investigated package forms include various µBGA and QFN. The focus of the investigations lay in the thermomechanical questions

Personality Research and Internet Use ¤ The work contributes to the understanding of the relationship between personality and internet use. In the theoretical part, personality psychological and media psychological theories and approaches are presented and integrated into various causal models of the relationship between personality and online behavior. The empirical part of the work consists of three independent studies. The first study investigates, based on the five-factor model of personality, whether personality is expressed differently on the computer and in the internet than outside the digital environment. It is shown that the expression of the four properties extraversion, openness to experience, agreeableness, and conscientiousness in the internet is significantly weaker. The expression of the property neuroticism, however, is enhanced in the sense that people on the computer and in the internet are emotionally significantly more stable than outside the digital environment. The second study assumes that narcissistic people have a special preference for online social networking. An online questionnaire study shows, however, that users of social networking sites are not generally more narcissistic than non-users. The assumption that the typical needs of narcissistic people for attention and admiration, self-disclosure and self-presentation, as well as self-esteem can be better satisfied on social networking sites than in face-to-face communication cannot be confirmed. The third study investigates whether the often reported preference of shy people for text-based, computer-mediated communication is also transferable to social networking sites. An online questionnaire study can show that the typical needs of shy people for control, belonging, and self-esteem are actually better satisfied on social networking sites than in face-to-face communication. All three studies equally demonstrate the importance of interactions between personality traits and situational aspects and, in addition, emphasize that computer-mediated communication differs significantly from face-to-face communication in some psychologically relevant aspects.

Speaking with Data : Practices, Expertises, and Visualization Modes in Data Journalism ¤ Data journalists use digital data for their reporting, which they process, visualize, and publish journalistically. Rahel Estermann works on the practice and field level, which expertises, materialities, cultures, and social processes are intertwined in data journalism. Data visualizations emerge as a common vocabulary, which enables speaking with the data in two ways: on the one hand, for the production of knowledge, and on the other hand, for presenting knowledge through data. Thus, the processes of re-hashing epistemological and professional cultures in a datafied society become visible

Open Source Compliance ¤ Viele Unternehmen define under „Open Source Compliance“ rules for dealing with open source software. The present work presents the legal particularities and risks at the example of the GPL and investigates common best practices for the establishment of an open source compliance system.

Vehicle Drives for Electromobility: Total Cost of Ownership, Energy Efficiency, CO2 Emissions, and Customer Benefits ¤ Danny Kreyenberg presents the technological status of alternative drives and investigates the conditions for achieving ambitious cost targets for batteries and fuel cells using a new 2-factor experience curve. Furthermore, he discusses the legal and fiscal policy instruments available to the state to promote alternative drives. The author shows that their complex effect has been little investigated so far, focusing on private users in Germany. He determines their preferences when buying a mid-range passenger car using a conjoint analysis of 408 private customers. After market development and analysis of the incentive instruments, a rapid market upswing in Germany without state support seems impossible. The content Investigation framework and vehicle technologies Cost analyses, life cycle assessment, and customer benefits of alternative drives Model development and evaluation The target groups Lecturers and students in the field of vehicle technology, particularly in the areas of alternative drives, electromobility, and regenerative power generation Politicians, executives, and decision-makers with a focus on electromobility The author Danny Kreyenberg has been dealing with electromobility for years – initially in vehicle development and research and development at a well-known automobile manufacturer, and most recently as project leader of technology evaluation and charging infrastructure projects at the German Aerospace Center in Berlin. Investigation framework and vehicle technologies -- Cost analyses, life cycle assessment, and customer benefits of alternative drives -- Model development and evaluation.

Emotional Experience and Knowledge Acquisition in Computer-Supported Business Education ¤ Matthias Conrad investigates, using the example of a computer-based teaching series in the subject of business, how the emotional experience of learners develops over the course of a series of self-regulated learning sequences using tablet PCs in the classroom and what effect this has on the subject-specific performance of learners. For this purpose, basic mechanisms of emotional, motivational, and cognitive factors in the learning process are presented and the findings on computer-supported learning and teaching are further illuminated. Subsequently, central results of a field study conducted at the Baden-Württemberg business academy are presented. The work concludes with a series of practical implications regarding the learning-promoting integration of computer technologies into teaching practice. The content Emotional Experience and Knowledge Acquisition in Computer-Supported Teaching Research on IKT-based teaching and learning environments Implications for teaching practice The target groups Lecturers and students of economics and education sciences with a focus on business education, business didactics, teaching and learning research, empirical education research, and educational psychology Practitioners from the fields of business didactics and educational science The author Dr. Matthias Conrad earned his doctorate at the University of Konstanz at the Department of Economics at the Faculty of Economics under Prof. Dr. Stephan Schumann in the field of business education. Emotional Experience and Knowledge Acquisition in Computer-Supported Teaching -- Research on IKT-based teaching and learning environments -- Implications for teaching practice.

Atomically resolved studies of quantum excitations and interactions in low-dimensional materials ¤ This work uses a combined STM-AFM, operated at extremely low temperatures and under UHV. In the first part of this work, I investigated the structural and electronic properties of graphene on SiC(0001). The correlation between the bound surface states and the STM images was investigated. In the next part, these surface states were suppressed by Li intercalation of graphene on SiC(0001). The intercalation is discovered by quenching the characteristic superstructure of graphene and further electron doping. The Li atoms are usually placed at the lower surface: SiC buffer layer. In the next part of this study, a further Li intercalation of graphene is performed to saturate both underlying surfaces. Although the predicted superconducting phase was missing, interesting features were found in the inelastic tunnel spectra. In further investigations, single chemical bonds and electrostatic effects in the connection points of the previous samples were evaluated. For this purpose, an AFM is used to form and break a bond between the Au atom, which closes the AFM tip, and a C atom of graphene on SiC(0001) in a controlled manner. In the last part of this dissertation, I investigated the system Fe-Pb(111) using STM. Mainly two different material classes were discovered through their electronic and structural properties. The broad asymmetric gap around the Fermi energy is attributed to the strongly strained first deposited Fe layer, which grows pseudomorphically on the Pb(111) substrate. This material class suppresses the superconducting properties of the substrate. In contrast, the other material group shows metallic properties with YSR bands inside the island region.

System management algorithms for distributed vision networks ¤ Smart Camera Netzwerke, verteilte Algorithmen zur Kameraausrichtung, Interaktion zwischen Nutzern und Kameras. - Smart Camera networks, distributed algorithms for camera alignment, interaction between users and Smart Cameras

C-Arylglycosides and Chalcones: New Paths to Heterocyclic Drugs through Ru- and Pd-Catalyzed Reactions ¤ In the ongoing era of scientific medicine, a broad spectrum of drugs has been compiled for the treatment of various diseases. Nevertheless, organic synthesis chemistry has made it its task to expand this spectrum on new or known ways and for various reasons. On the one hand, the occurrence of certain compounds in nature is often limited, so that synthetic methods increasingly take the place of a less sustainable degradation. On the other hand, the physiological effect or bioavailability of a drug can be increased through derivatization and drug adaptation. In this work, some representatives of the known drug classes C-Arylglycosides and Chalcones were synthesized through the key step of the palladium-catalyzed MATSUDA-HECK reaction. For the case of C-Arylglycosides, unsaturated carbohydrates (glycals) were first represented through a ruthenium-catalyzed cyclization reaction. These were then brought into reaction with differently substituted diazonium salts in the aforementioned palladium-catalyzed coupling reaction. [...]

Participatory governance in the Europe of cross-border regions : cooperation - boundaries - civil society ¤ This policy analysis examines geopolitical and sociocultural bordering practices in Europe’s cross-border regions and their impact on civil society participation and governance in state peripheries. The normative hope of democratisation and the legitimisation of European politics in European Union border regions are connected with a greater degree of cross-border citizen engagement in Euroregional institutions and politics. Using the example of the European Grouping of Territorial Cooperation, this study analyses and compares four cross-border Euroregional case studies: Tyrol–South Tyrol–Trentino, Galicia–North Portugal, SaarMoselle and the planned German–Polish TransOderana EGTC.

Student-Centered Learning in Mathematics Classrooms with Computer Algebra Systems: An Empirical Study of CAS Introduction in Thuringian Schools with Upper Secondary Level ¤ In the school year 2011/2012, the mathematics class for Thuringian students underwent a significant change. With the start of this school year, computer algebra systems (CAS) were compulsorily introduced at all Thuringian schools with upper secondary level. From grade 9 onwards, students now work with these systems in mathematics and natural sciences classes. The aim of the present study is to document the increase in student-centered learning in the classroom, which has been proven in various studies to be motivated by the introduction of CAS, under the specific Thuringian framework conditions. In contrast to previous studies on CAS, the Thuringian specificity lies in the obligation to introduce the systems. The starting point for the theoretical framework of the study is a present-day didactic theory on the use of CAS in the classroom: the triad Task – Technique - Theory. Based on the theoretical framework, three hypotheses are formulated. The hypotheses are empirically tested in the framework of a longitudinal study. The study period covers two years. Both quantitative and qualitative research methods are used. In order to be able to draw a more comprehensive picture of the mathematics class, the perspectives of the students and teachers are taken into account. In addition to the development of new CAS tasks, further essential results of the present study are that Thuringian teachers have recognized the potential of CAS use in mathematics classes in terms of student-centered learning and are becoming increasingly confident in handling the systems. Based on the results, conclusions can be drawn for teacher training in Thuringia. Whether the positive effects of CAS in mathematics classes will be noticeable in the broad sense can only be assessed in the following years. The results of the present study, however, are reassuring.

Wer meiner Gemeinde vierzig Hadithe bewahrt ... ¤ The Forty Hadiths are of great importance for the faith and practice of Muslims from the 9th century to the present day, but have been scientifically neglected until now. For a manageable collection of selected prophetic traditions, the content of the Forty Hadiths is extremely diverse and ranges from child education and religious aspects to jihad. In Part 1, this field of study is completely re-examined on the basis of the collection of over nine hundred collections. In Part 2, the processing of the ideology of jihad is carried out on the basis of prophetic traditions from the time of the Crusades to the present day. A translation of the original texts makes the relevant Hadith material usable for interested parties outside of Islamic studies.

Biological Diversity in Ecobalances : an Integration by Example of Biofuels ¤ Biodiversity, life cycle assessment (LCA), environmental planning, biofuels, biomass, land use, sustainable agriculture, geographic information system

Proper and Purposeful Conduct of the Business Manager in Preparing the Financial Statements: The Duty of Care Requirements of Sections 93(1) of the German Stock Corporation Act and 43(1) of the German Limited Liability Companies Act for the Preparation of the Annual and Consolidated Financial Statements ¤ Considering the planned amendments under the Financial Market Integrity Strengthening Act, the author first analyzes to what degree IFRS and reporting standards under the German Commercial Code grant managers discretion when preparing the annual and consolidated financial statements of a company. She then examines how to exercise such discretion in accordance with § 93 subsection 1 of the German Stock Corporation Act and to what extent accounting decisions are protected by the business judgment rule.

Reactive Wetting Phenomena at the Example of the Si(1)/SiO2(s) Interface ¤ Reaktive Benetzung, Grenzflächen, Siliziumsuboxide, Augerelektronenspektroskopie. - Reactive wetting, interfaces, silicon suboxides, auger electron spectroscopy

Cooperations in Cross-Border European Long-Distance Passenger Rail Transport: European Cartel Law and Competition Economic Application ¤ Despite the market liberalisation of long-distance international passenger rail transport in 2010, competition has hardly developed in that sector until today. Most of the international passenger rail services are still provided by railway alliances between established formerly state-owned railway companies of different European Member States. It is assumed that these railway alliances lead to a collective dominant position and therefore to a significant impediment to effective competition.This study analyzes the existing railway alliances in long-distance international passenger rail transport on the basis of today´s economic and legal frameworks and answers the question of whether the existing alliances are likely to restrict competition and thus fall under the prohibition of cartels or whether they should be exempted from such prohibition due to efficiency gains.

The Liberation of Dwelling: An Architectural Phenomenon of the 1920s and 1930s ¤ When Sigfried Giedion published his small book 'Befreites Wohnen' in 1929, classical modern architecture was at the height of its creative development. What was planned and realized in Europe between 1927 and 1932 revolutionized not only building technology, spatial thinking, and building aesthetics, but also conventional living concepts. Le Corbusier, Theo van Doesburg, Mies van der Rohe, and other avant-garde comrades made fascinating attempts at new building, which were fiercely contested at the time but are now admired for their innovative power and design quality. - The present book deals with the cultural phenomenon of 'liberation'. Through impressive contemporary quotes from numerous publications published on the subject, as well as through illustrative images that reflect the enthusiastic dynamics of architects, artists, and writers of the time, both scientifically, pathetically, and often amusingly, the image of a fundamental component of this period is conveyed. 'Liberation' in general should be achieved through the architectural opening of the traditional house, through the sensual and intellectual sensitization of the occupant. One wanted to create a new architecture and a 'New Man' and built the stilt house, installed the retractable glass wall, or placed a shower on the roof. - - Interesting connections between utopias of life, art theories, and contemporary rationality become visible. The villas and single-family houses of this architectural generation are at the center of the consideration - from well-known examples to a surprising variety of rarely treated or unknown designs.

Elemental Analysis and Multivariate Statistics for the Investigation and Evaluation of the Loading State of Flowing Waters ¤ With the aim of describing and evaluating the distribution of elements in sediments, suspended matter, and filtrates of the Elbe and the development of the burden with inorganic substances in the 1990s, the Elbe was sampled in several campaigns throughout its entire longitudinal profile and analyzed for over 60 elements of the periodic table. By evaluating the data material with two- and multi-way principal component analyses, the elements relevant for anthropogenic and geogenic characterization of the river were selected, as well as typical longitudinal profiles of the relevant elements were summarized. Sampling points with similar element distribution were combined into characteristic Elbe sections using hierarchical cluster analyses. By comparing the average section concentrations, the temporal development of the element burden could be quantified. Using two- and three-way PLS regression models, element contents in one compartment could be predicted from measured concentrations in one or two other compartments.

Field emission scanning probe lithography on molecular resist ¤ The lithographic structure creation in the single-nanometer range represents one of the most critical technological bottlenecks in nanofabrication. As an alternative method to established electron beam lithography (EBL), in this work, illumination with low-energy electrons (<100eV) has been investigated. In this process, a Fowler-Nordheim field emission process is utilized at the apex of a scanning probe to trigger lithographically usable reactions in molecular resist systems. The unique combination of properties: (1) active scanning probes, which allow for direct imaging feedback; (2) the direct application of electrons with energies close to the lithographically relevant excitations, which enable a more efficient and spatially limited exposure process under normal environmental conditions; and (3) molecular (glass) resist systems, e.g. calixarenes, which represent a well-defined monodisperse system with low molecular weight, offers new promising possibilities. Within the scope of this work, a comprehensive picture of the complex interrelated interactions and reactions has been developed for the first time. In this context, the lithographically usable phenomena have been experimentally investigated as a function of exposure parameters, conditions, and resist material, as well as described by models and simulations. As a result of the changed exposure conditions in field emission scanning probe lithography (FE-SPL), it has been shown for the first time that (i) illumination with low-energy electrons in this resist type enables higher sensitivity and resolution, (ii) proximity effects are effectively suppressed, and (iii) new reaction types, e.g. in the form of direct removal of resist material, are triggerable. In this context, both maskless writing in the negative in the form of cross-linking and in the positive 'tone' in the form of an ablative reaction are possible. Furthermore, the overlap of both reaction types shows new self-aligned structure forms. The lithographic structure creation in the range of sub-5nm single lines, 8nm single points, and 7nm hp dense structures has been shown. Aspects regarding applicability, throughput, and structure transfer have been investigated and solved by corresponding strategies.

The Constitutional Protection of Habilitation by Art. 5 Abs. 3 S. 1 GG: Can the Legislature Abolish Habilitation? ¤ The work deals with the question raised by the introduction of the junior professorship about the constitutional protection of habilitation by Art. 5 III 1 GG. The focus is on the objective content of the right of Art. 5 III 1 GG. It is fundamentally discussed whether Art. 5 III 1 GG contains an institutional guarantee of academic self-government and whether the matter of habilitation is to be assigned to the core area of academic self-government. Furthermore, the importance of the value-determining principle norm contained in Art. 5 III 1 GG for the protection of habilitation is examined. In this, a distinction is made between habilitation in its function as a prerequisite for appointment as a professor on the one hand and as a qualification procedure for young scientists on the other hand. (HoF/Text adopted)

Rayleigh-Taylor instability for the two-phase Navier-Stokes equations with surface tension in cylindrical domains ¤ The present thesis is concerned with the dynamic behaviour of two immiscible and incompressible fluids in a cylindrical container, e.g. a capillary, which are separated by a sharp interface. In case that the heavier fluid overlies the lighter fluid one expects that the heavier fluid sacks down into the lighter one. This effect is known as the Rayleigh-Taylor-Instability. The main result yields the existence of a critical surface tension with the following property. In case that the surface tension of the interface between the two fluids is smaller than the critical surface tension, one has Rayleigh-Taylor-Instability. On the contrary, if the interface has a greater surface tension than the critical value, the instability effect does not occur and one has exponential stability of the interface. The last part of this thesis is concerned with the bifurcation of nontrivial equilibria in multiple eigenvalues. The Invariance of the bifurcation equation with respect to rotations and reflections yields the existence of bifurcating subcritical equilibria. Finally it is proven that the bifurcating equilibria are unstable. two-phase flows; Navier-Stokes equations; surface tension; free boundary problem; Rayleigh-Taylor instability; contact angle; maximal regularity; stability; bifurcation; multiple eigenvalue

Platte is not equal to Platte : Cooperation and Competition between the GDR and Poland in the Housing Industry of the 1970s ¤ The study is dedicated to the cooperation between the GDR and the People's Republic of Poland in the industrial housing industry of the 1970s. Using the example of the Polish housing series W-70 ("Warszawa 1970") and the GDR's own WBS 70, successful and unsuccessful aspects of this cooperation between the two socialist states are highlighted. The analysis includes structures, contacts, and areas of action on ministerial, institutional, and individual levels. Was there mutual influence? What role did the West play? Beyond all stereotypical notions of one-dimensional decision-making processes in state socialist systems, a history of European idea transfer and knowledge circulation in post-war modernity is told.

Cloud computing - Challenges to the Legal Framework for Data Protection ¤ Cloud Computing stands for the flexible, dynamic, scalable and demand-oriented offering, use and billing of infrastructure and application components over the Internet »as a service«. The various opportunities and advantages of Cloud Computing, however, meet a legal framework that has not yet conceptually taken into account the special features (global) distributed, multi-tenant capable and virtualized IT infrastructures. The central challenges of Cloud Computing to the legal framework for data protection are discussed on the basis of the BDSG and the developments in the context of the EU data protection reform in a practical and typical field of tension. In focus are the applicable data protection law, the personal reference of data, data and information security as well as commissioned data processing. Since global data streams form the technical backbone of a globalized world economy, a focus is also placed on international data transfers – for reasons of practical relevance especially to the USA on the basis of the »Safe-Harbor-Agreement«.

Auflösung und Ausscheiden einzelner Gesellschafter bei Rechtsanwaltssozietäten : a corporate and professional law investigation ¤ The dissolution of a law firm partnership as well as the withdrawal of individual partners causes significant complications in practice. Not least because law firms are characterized by a special, personal performance and thus also a special asset structure. The author systematizes and analyzes the corporate and professional law issues, from the dissolution of the company and the voluntary or forced withdrawal of individual partners to settlement agreements and anti-competitive measures up to the legal position of partners without capital contribution. De lege ferenda, the upcoming reform of the law firm partnership law and the law to modernize the partnership law are also integrated into the investigation and their effects analyzed. Finally, the author sketches additional draft laws to promote the coherent revision of both matters.

Combustion Processes for the Implementation of Biogas in Medium-Sized Industrial Engines - A 3D-CFD Combustion Process Study on Pre-Chamber, Micro-Pilot, and Direct Ignition ¤ The combustion of biogas in industrial engines poses a particular challenge even at cylinder displacements of only 2 liters. Due to the relatively low laminar flame speed of this special gas, it leads to slow combustion with corresponding disadvantages in engine efficiency and emissions. Within the scope of this work, three combustion processes are considered: direct ignition, ignition enhancement through pre-chamber washing, and micro-pilot ignition. Using 3D-CFD combustion calculations, a spatially resolved and time-dependent insight into these combustion processes in the context of biogas combustion can be given. For this purpose, 0D/1D motor process and charge exchange models were built, which provided the boundary conditions for the 3D-CFD simulations (RANS). The models were validated using measurements on the engine test stand for all three combustion processes. High-pressure indication measurements were available for each of the six cylinders. For the 3D-CFD combustion calculation, the laminar flame speed is required. To work with reliable values for biogas in the operating range of modern pre-chamber gas engines, reaction kinetic calculations were performed. With a specially written script, a high result quality was achieved, along with reliable convergence of the calculations. The validation of these calculations was carried out using literature values. The resulting data basis served as a basis to derive a new correlation for determining the laminar flame speed and to implement it in the 3D-CFD tool. This correlation represents the dependence on temperature, pressure, air-fuel ratio, carbon dioxide content in the biogas, and residual gas content in a very wide operating range. Due to its compact design, it can be used problem-free in other 3D-CFD tools and for predictive engine process calculation in the future. The 3D-CFD results calculated using the new correlation were validated using engine test stand measurements. This makes a comparison of the combustion processes with each other legitimate. In this way, an insight into flame spread and nitric oxide formation is given, as well as locations with high concentrations of unburned fuel are localized. With this, a new depth of information is available for the investigation of the three combustion processes at only 2 liters of cylinder displacement with biogas as a special fuel. Based on these results, a new pre-chamber prototype was manufactured and measured on the engine test stand using pre-chamber pressure indication. This makes it possible to evaluate the predictability of the 3D-CFD calculations.

Robust peer prediction mechanisms ¤ Zusammenfassung: This thesis addresses the challenge of peer prediction, which seeks to elicit private information from rational agents without the requirement that ground truth is eventually revealed. The classical peer prediction method provides a solution to the peer prediction challenge. It compares the reported information of an agent with the reported information of another agent, and computes a payment rule that implements truth revelation in a strategic equilibrium. However, the algorithm computing the payments critically depends on the method's assumption that all agents share the same prior beliefs and that the algorithm ("mechanism") knows these beliefs.In this thesis, I relax this common knowledge assumption. I first design the "Robust Bayesian Truth Serum" (RBTS), which asks agents for two types of reports, the report of the private information it is interested in and a prediction report corresponding to an agent's belief about the private information of other agents. RBTS dispenses with the assumption that the agents' prior beliefs need to be known to compute the payments. It does, however, still rely on the agents sharing the same prior beliefs. My second contribution is the design of subjective-prior peer prediction mechanisms, which further reduce the assumption of common knowledge. As in RBTS, they do not require knowledge of the agents' prior beliefs. Moreover, they allow the agents' prior beliefs to be subjective, i.e. different from one another. My third contribution is the study of effort-incentivizing peer prediction. In many applications of interest, the information that seeks to be elicited first needs to be acquired. When this information acquisition requires costly effort, agents may have an incentive to avoid it and choose to guess instead. Addressing this problem, I suggest payments, where only agents with good enough information have an incentive to participate in the mechanism. Agents not investing effort and agents with low quality, choose to pass, effectively self-selecting according to quality

Success Factors in Small Service Companies: An Analysis Using the Example of the Gastronomy ¤ BEGIN: Theoretical Foundations -- The Gastronomy Industry -- Theoretical Model and Hypothesis Formation -- Empirical Investigation -- Research Results -- Discussion and Evaluation. Due to the ongoing development of the business environment, the permanent adaptability of companies has become a prerequisite for their long-term existence. Especially in industries with less growth potential, companies must develop strategies to achieve competitive advantages. Christine R. Schneider investigates the question of success factors in the gastronomy industry from the perspective of industrial economics theory, resource-based theory, and entrepreneurship theory, with special consideration of the human and social capital of the entrepreneur. Based on a perspective of strategic management and entrepreneurship, the author develops and tests a theoretical model within a quantitative study of St. Gallen gastronomy companies. The author identifies the entrepreneur, a differentiation strategy, and the achievement of virtual rents as critical success factors in small service companies. END

Carbon-based Nanofillers for Olefin Block Copolymer and Multilayer Composites ¤ BEGIN Abstract: One of the goals of this work was to investigate the reinforcement effect of carbon fillers in olefin block copolymers. Initially, the effect of different filler contents of thermally reduced graphite oxide (TRGO), which was reduced at 750 °C, on the property profile was investigated. It was found that in a TRGO 750/OBC composite with a filler content of 2.5 wt%, a reinforcement effect was observed in all mechanical properties (tensile stress at 100% elongation (F100) +10 %, maximum tensile strength (Fmax) +24 %, elongation at break (εmax) +12 %, Shore A hardness +6 %). Further increase of the filler content leads to an increase in F100 and Shore A hardness, but also to a strong decrease in εmax and Fmax. The barrier effect of the composite against oxygen increases steadily with the filler content up to a reduction of 76% at 20 wt%. The reduction per weight fraction of filler is, however, highest at 13% at 2.5 wt% TRGO 750. The significant reduction of εmax at filler contents above 7.5 wt% is, considering the potential application areas of a thermoplastic elastomer like OBC, an exclusion criterion. Therefore, a comparison of carbon fillers of different functionalization and morphology was carried out at a filler content of 2.5 wt%. It was found that functionalized fillers showed greater reinforcement effects than non-functionalized fillers at Fmax, F100, and Shore hardness. The functionalization had no effect on the barrier effect against oxygen. A comparison of the functionalized fillers showed that fillers with a plate-like morphology (pM) showed different reinforcement effects than fillers with a spherical morphology (sM). (Fmax pM: +26 %, sM:+17 %, F100: pM: +15 %, sM: +4 %, εmax: pM: +3%, sM: +15%, Shore hardness: pM: +7%, sM: -6 %, barrier effect: pM: +27 %, sM:+1 %). This can be attributed to a higher aspect ratio and the resulting better bonding to the matrix. Functionalized plate-like fillers showed the greatest reinforcement effect. The second goal of this work was the production of carbon/multilayer composites. Two production methods were investigated. On the one hand, the production of the graphite ...

The Right to Social Protection after the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and its Implementation in Uganda and Ghana ¤ ‚Disability may increase the risk of poverty; poverty may increase the risk of disability’. Die Durchbrechung dieses Kreislaufes stellt für die Staatengemeinschaft eine große Herausforderung dar, insbesondere jedoch für die Länder des globalen Südens. Als jüngstes Menschenrechtsabkommen der Vereinten Nationen konkretisiert die VN Behindertenrechtskonvention auch das Recht auf soziale Sicherung. Diese Studie beschäftigt sich mit der Frage, inwieweit sich aus den konkreten Umsetzungspflichten ein menschenrechtsbasierter Ansatz ableiten lässt, der durch Bedarfsorientierung und Barrierefreiheit geprägt ist. Des Weiteren wird ein Blick auf die Implementierungsbemühungen in Subsahara-Afrika geworfen. Hierbei wird aufgezeigt, wie es in den Beispielländern Uganda und Ghana teilweise gelungen ist, innovative Konzepte zu entwickeln, die die Realitäten des Lebens von Menschen mit Behinderungen vor Ort abbilden und gleichzeitig die Umsetzung völkerrechtlicher Pflichten ermöglichen. ‘Disability may increase the risk of poverty, and poverty may increase the risk of disability.’ Breaking this cycle is a major challenge for the international community, especially the countries of the Global South. As the most recent human rights treaty of the United Nations, the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities also specifies the right to social protection. This study deals with the question of to what extent a human rights-based approach characterised by need orientation and accessibility can be derived from specific state obligations. In addition, it examines the efforts to implement such an approach in Sub-Saharan Africa. In this context, the study shows that it has been possible to both develop innovative concepts that consider the realities of the lives of local people with disabilities in Uganda and Ghana and, at the same time, to ensure the implementation of international human rights law in those two countries.

The Complexity of Political Action: The Liberalism-Communitarianism Debate in the Light of Hannah Arendt's Thought ¤ Introduction-- Chapter I: Political Freedom: From Concept to Experience -- Chapter II: The Political World -- Chapter III: Political Action -- Chapter IV: Political Judgment -- Conclusion -- Bibliography and Abbreviations -- About this Book -- About the Author Starting from the phenomenological results of Hannah Arendt's works and their further development, the Liberalism-Communitarianism debate is expanded and founded in a phenomenological perspective on the situation of the political community. The debate is limited to the direct confrontation of some communitarians with John Rawls' theory of justice. The interdependence of action and political world - a central thought of Hannah Arendt, which guides the investigation - is the field for the recovery of the concrete dimension of political action. The starting point is political freedom, as it appears in everyday experiences and thus becomes experiential. In the course of the presentation, the features of action in the sense of Hannah Arendt are repeatedly confronted with the intentions of non-phenomenological authors, where it becomes clear to what extent they see or miss the phenomena of action and the experientiality of political freedom. The theatrical character of action, the question of being and appearance, and the aesthetics of lying lead to an original description of judgment following Hannah Arendt, which appears in the interdependence of action and political world and in confrontation with Kant's relevant paragraphs from the Critique of Judgment. Continuing Arendt's approaches, the author shows that Hannah Arendt would have attributed a political character to judgment if she had come to the execution of her thoughts on judgment. The examination of the phenomena of action and the various possibilities of judgment reveals previously unseen relationships. It can also be fruitfully used for the formation of political consciousness, which is concretized in the formulation of specific tasks and demands.

Development of new catalysts of group 4 for the hydroamination and hydroamination alkylation of alkenes and alkynes ¤ Within the scope of this work, new ligands for group 4 metal complexes were synthesized, which are used in hydroamination and hydroamination alkylation of alkenes and alkynes. The metal complexes were used in the alken- and alkin-hydroamination. As a ligand class, ß-Enaminone were synthesized. Various crystal structures of these metal complexes could be determined with the help of X-ray structure analysis. After modification of some ß-Enaminone, further ligands could be obtained. A catalyst system was developed, which enables the alkin-hydroamination. In this case, the Zr-catalyst was converted with sulfonamides. Furthermore, the catalytic ability of the complex [Cp2Zr(NMe2)2] was further investigated. In cooperation with the Beckhaus working group, further metal complexes were tested for their activity. <dt.>

Ar@chitekturen in Celluloid : The Cinematic View of Space ¤ When it comes to the topic of architecture and film, one initially associates it with sets or set design, thinks of films like »Metropolis« or »Blade Runner«. This book offers a new perspective: It shows how film designs spaces, evokes emotions, and lets the viewer immerse themselves in an illusionary space. This knowledge is also of great interest for architectural space design. Filmic space concepts such as editing or framing are considered from the perspective of architecture and discussed from a perception-theoretical point of view. Theoretical approaches and exemplary case studies create an intermedial interface that generates a new understanding of the emergence of spatial effects.

Constitutional Evolution in the World Society: Differentiation Problems of Law and Politics in the Age of Global Governance ¤ The theme of global constitutionalism and the problems arising from it in the context of global governance are the focus of this volume. The starting point is the question of whether global law is capable of taking on important tasks of global governance and remaining susceptible to problems of social exclusion, even if there is no political world constitution.

Contested Statehood : Palestine between Occupation, Development, and Political Islam ¤ Helmut Krieger examines the state formation process in the occupied Palestinian territories from a political economy perspective. The Palestinian Authority is analyzed as a strategic terrain where cooperation, conflicts, and struggles between the Israeli occupation power, Western development agencies, and Palestinian organizations are condensed. This reveals how state formation in Palestine is fundamentally contested, dependent, and neoliberal-shaped, and shaped by multiple crisis dynamics. Rather than reiterating the much-vaunted intractability of the Middle East conflict, this book presents a complex account of responsibility for the status quo. The content PLO and Oslo Peace Process Political Islam Neoliberal Development Policies Israeli Occupation Regime Political Economy of State Formation Materialist State Theories The target groups Lecturers and students from the fields of Political Science, International Relations, Sociology, Islamic Studies, International Development, Cultural and Social Anthropology, Peace and Conflict Research, and Economics Practitioners from the fields of Development Cooperation and International Politics The Author Helmut Krieger, sociologist and political scientist, is a scientific project employee and lecturer at the Institute for International Development at the University of Vienna.

The Administration of History: Monument Conservation and the State in Germany 1871 - 1933 ¤ Dealing with the past, shaping the present The remnants of the past do not preserve themselves. Their preservation is the task of monument conservation. But what exactly is monument conservation? What does it do, who is responsible for it? Is it really necessary? Why do we strive to preserve and maintain what has been taken over from the past? Winfried Speitkamp follows how monument conservation has established itself as a public task and a state institution. This happened in the decades between the founding of the Empire and the end of the Weimar Republic. Initially, it was limited to individual, particularly significant monuments, but it had established itself comprehensively by the end. It was then scientifically conducted, bureaucratically organized, and legally legitimized, but it also had to face public criticism. At the beginning of this development, civilizational criticism and the homeland protection movement played an equally important role as urban planning and monument theory. Next, the state's access to monuments and monument conservation will be examined in detail, and then the social conflicts that are inevitably associated with monument conservation will be in the spotlight. A classic conflict area, for example, is the tension between private property and the common good. The investigation includes a lot: intellectual history and administrative history, urban planning, architectural and art history, building law and monument protection laws. All this belongs to monument conservation and its two faces - dealing with the past and shaping the present. Content of the book: Introduction: Monument Conservation and the State. I. Idea and Publicity: Civilizational Criticism and Homeland Idea / Urban Planning and Urban Planning Theory / Monument Theory and Practical Monument Conservation / Associations and Organizations. II. State and Power: Empire and Nation / Countries and Region / Administration and Participation / Profession and Personnel. III. Law and Interest: Building Law and Protection Against Disfigurement / Monument Protection Law and Monument Protection Laws / Church and State / Property and Common Good. Conclusion: The Administration of History. The author Dr. Winfried Speitkamp is a private lecturer for Middle and Newer History at the University of Giessen.

Gas investigations in muddy sediments ¤ The formation of gas in the seafloor, especially in supersaturated concentrations, can lead to a change in the acoustic properties of marine sediments. This phenomenon is also known as the basin effect. The gases can prevent the investigation of sediment layers with flat seismic systems. Therefore, the concentration of methane and its saturation limits were to be investigated. The possibly present bubbles should be analyzed with regard to their size and distribution in the sediment.
Non-classical States in Ultracold Quantum Gases ¤ Bose-Einstein condensation, entanglement, atom interferometry - Bose-Einstein-Kondensation, Verschränkung, Atominterferometrie.

On the complexity of modified instances ¤ This dissertation investigates the complexity of modified instances and to what extent NP-complete problems behave stably under minimal change. We consider for various NP-complete problems whether knowledge of a solution to an instance can provide help in deciding a slightly modified instance. Furthermore, we investigate to what extent modified instances can be decided efficiently if not only a solution of the unmodified instance is given, but more general hints, such as a polynomially long string. This question plays a major role not only everywhere where NP-complete problems need to be solved quickly in dynamic situations, but also provides deeper insights into the general nature of the class of NP-complete problems. Moreover, we consider the problem of reoptimization. That is, we investigate for various optimization problems whether one can find a good solution for modified instances of an optimization problem if an optimal solution of a similar instance is already known.

Mode of Transport Choice in Goods Transport: An Analysis of Regulatory and Price Policy Measures; with 64 Tables ¤ The book explains, based on a broad survey, the decision-making behavior regarding the mode of transport choice in goods transport. Since, due to a strongly increasing transport demand in goods transport, external costs are caused in considerable extent, transport policy must take targeted measures to make this additional demand as environmentally friendly as possible. Therefore, the EU and the federal government strive for the goal of traffic diversion from the road to alternative modes of transport. This work analyzes which determinants the mode of transport choice of shippers depends on, in order to be able to determine the effect of certain regulations subsequently. For example, the impact of the truck toll on the mode of transport choice is examined. To determine the determinants, a discrete decision model is econometrically estimated.

Population and molecular genetic analyses of persistent right aortic arch and primary cataracts in the German Pinscher ¤ German Pinscher, Cataract, Heritability. - The German Pinscher is an ancient dog breed that shares common roots with the Dobermann Pinscher, the Miniature Pinscher, the Affenpinscher, the Miniature Schnauzer, the Standard Schnauzer, and the Giant Schnauzer. The first depictions of the breed can be found in a book from 1884. In the middle of the 20th century, the breed was severely depleted due to the consequences of the two World Wars and had to be completely rebuilt. This task was taken over by Werner Jung, who searched the country for the few remaining, possibly breed-typical Pinschers and crossed them with four particularly large Miniature Pinschers. Most German Pinschers today are descendants of these few dogs. As a result, the modern German Pinscher has a relatively small gene pool, a fact that requires special attention in the context of possible breed-specific diseases. The increasing knowledge of the prevalence and pathogenesis of eye and heart diseases within this breed requires an adjustment and development of breeding guidelines to reduce the occurrence of these likely hereditary diseases as much as possible. Therefore, it is of particular importance to understand the population genetic and molecular genetic backgrounds of persistent right aortic arches and primary cataracts in the German Pinscher to optimize the breeding of dogs with these characteristics and improve the health of the breed. The results of this study will contribute to improving breeding practices in the German Pinscher and securing the health of the breed in the long term.

Identification and functional characterization of idessuis, the immunoglobulin M-degrading enzyme of Streptococcus suis. ¤ Streptococcus suis, IgM, Complement. - Streptococcus (S.) suis is an important invasive, extracellular pathogen of pigs, which mainly causes meningitis, arthritis, and serositis. Furthermore, S. suis is an important zoonotic pathogen that mainly causes meningitis in humans. In Europe, no vaccine against S. suis infections has been licensed so far. S. suis infections occur frequently 6-10 weeks post partum. At this time, piglets usually have high S. suis-specific IgM titers. The present work was initiated by the detection of immunoglobulin M (IgM)-cleavage products in the supernatant of serum-opsonized S. suis. IgM is the first antibody class produced after stimulation with an antigen and represents the main class of natural antibodies. It has important functions including the neutralization of pathogens/toxins, the activation of the classical complement pathway (CP), and the enhancement of humoral immune responses. The present work was designed to investigate the pathogenesis of S. suis infections in piglets during the early adaptive immune response. The objectives consisted of the identification and characterization of the IgM-cleaving factor of S. suis (Chapter 3). After successful identification of IdeSsuis, the immunoglobulin M-cleaving enzyme, the hypothesis was investigated that IdeSsuis is involved in the complement evasion of S. suis (Chapter 4). Finally, the immunogenicity and protective efficacy of a recombinant (r) IdeSsuis vaccine were determined (Chapter 5). Sequence comparisons showed that S. suis has a gene that exhibits large homologies to the IgG-cleaving enzyme of S. pyogenes (IdeS). By functional analysis, it was proven that rIdeSsuis has a specific IgM-proteolytic activity but does not cleave IgG and IgA. Loss and gain of function experiments showed using various isogenic S. suis- and Lactococcus (L.) lactis-mutants that the expression of IdeSsuis is responsible and sufficient for the cleavage of IgM. Furthermore, it was shown that the binding of IgM to the surface of S. suis is modulated by the expression of IdeSsuis. Western Blot analyses proved that IdeSsuis exclusively cleaves porcine IgM, but not the IgM of six other investigated species. By N-terminal Edman sequencing, the cleavage site in the IgM molecule in the N-terminal region of the constant domain 3 (Cμ3) was identified. Since the C1q-binding motif is located in Cμ3 and is separated from the Fab region by the IdeSsuis-mediated IgM cleavage, the hypothesis...

Health Profiling of Food Brand Articles: Measurement, Determinants, and Implications ¤ Through a stronger health profiling, manufacturers and trading companies in the food industry try to secure market shares. Clemens Jüttner measures the perceived health profiling and examines relationships to determinants and success effects analytically and experimentally using a consumer survey on selected food brand articles. He shows that a stronger health profiling can increase the brand value. At the same time, consumers are also willing to pay higher prices for the corresponding food. Health-oriented brand strategies as an option for brand policy in the food sector -- The study design of the present work -- The development of a scale to measure the perceived health profiling of food -- The theory-guided model development for the analysis of determinants and success effects of health profiling of food -- The development of a field experiment to measure the perceived health profiling and the effects on selected brand policy target variables -- The conception of an experimental and analytical investigation to analyze the relationship between health profiling and target variables of brand management -- Consequences resulting from the investigation findings -- Summary and Outlook.

Proof of the Geographical Origin of Pistachios Based on the Isotopic Composition ¤ In the global pistachio trade, falsifications occur repeatedly, as Iranian pistachios are relabeled and sold as more expensive American goods or mixed with American pistachios. This not only deceives the consumer in accordance with §11 of the LFGB, but may also pose a health risk. Iranian and also Turkish pistachios must be examined for their aflatoxin content before import into the EU, as it is often too high, while American pistachios are not subject to a presentation requirement. However, the food monitoring authority currently has no method available to determine the origin of pistachios clearly and check the labeling. In this work, a discriminant model is presented, which, with the help of IRMS measurement technology, provides a clear authenticity determination of pistachios from the three main producing countries Iran, USA, and Turkey.

The Evolution of Song in Acrocephalinae (Hippolais, Acrocephalus and Chloropeta) Including Phylogeny and Morphological, Ecological and Social Factors ¤ The acoustic signaling is a central behavioral trait of Acrocephalinae. Their song shows an enormous diversity with significant interspecific variation. To what extent this song variation is more due to adaptive adjustments to morphological, ecological or social factors or due to the homologous development through phylogeny, is equally little investigated as the complex interaction of these factors. To investigate this question, I dissected the song according to various song characteristics, related these to the mentioned factors and then corrected the result phylogenetically. It shows an unequal influence of the factors on the song characteristics. The most important influence is phylogeny and sexual selection. Through the increased sexual function of the song in migrating Acrocephalinae, these differ in repertoire size and singing place from non-migrating species. The previously assumed relationships between body size and song frequency on the one hand and complexity and social system on the other hand disappear in the phylogenetic correction.

Local Symmetries and Reality: A Philosophical Study of Gauge Theories and Structural Realism ¤ In the debate about scientific realism, structural realism - whose view holds that the real content of scientific theories lies in their mathematically-logical structure - is increasingly gaining importance. The present work examines this thesis in the context of the most significant class of theories in our fundamental physics, the gauge theories, which are characterized by special local symmetry structures. The work offers the reader in its first chapters an introduction to the central themes of symmetries, scientific realism, and gauge theories. In the analyses conducted in the middle part, quantum and gravitational gauge theories are examined in a conceptual sense - especially with regard to the underlying principles - and ontological sense - with a view to the underdetermination of entities and various locality assumptions - in detail. As a result, a support for structural realism emerges, however not in its radical ontological variant, but in the milder epistemological or at most intermediate variant, in which both structures and their carriers exist, with the latter, however, being amorph and thus epistemically unavailable.

Customer Relationship Risk from a Corporate Perspective ¤ On the importance of customer relationship risk in customer value-oriented marketing -- Customer relationships: subject area and theoretical framework -- The risk from a corporate perspective -- Customer relationship risk -- Conclusion. The discussion of the risks of entrepreneurial trade has long taken a central place within business research and corporate practice. Based on value-oriented customer relationship management, Jochen Becker develops a multi-dimensional concept of customer relationship risk. He refers to existing risk concepts in financial economic literature and in controlling, whose applicability to relationship marketing he critically examines. To determine the individual risk dimensions, models are developed that enable implementation in corporate practice.

Environmental Certificates as Economic Control Instruments and Their Effects on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises: A Comparative Investigation of the Controllability of Land Sealing and Water Use in Germany and the USA ¤ The starting point of the treatise is the political requirement of reducing land sealing and water use in Germany. This ecological goal is implemented through the creation of an economic model for controlling land sealing and water use based on environmental certificates. Based on an empirical survey of existing environmental policy controls in the USA and Germany, as well as model-theoretical approaches in the literature, a new economic control model is developed step by step on the basis of tradable environmental certificates. The work is thus internationally and interdisciplinarily located at the interface between ecology, economics, and law. The preventive and follow-up effect of the control model is particularly important for SMEs in the context of land recycling of former business premises and for municipalities in terms of the reduction of commercial land surplus. Against this background, the control model can be seen as a suitable balance between the politically prescribed quantity limitation, the interests of SMEs and municipalities on the one hand, and the preservation of existing assets and preventive behavior on the other hand. It thus represents a contribution to sustainable development for the environmental media soil and water. With the control model for the environmental media soil and water based on environmental certificates, a mature and practical economic control instrument is available for efficient quantity control. Now, only a political decision is necessary regarding its implementation.

Students – Students – Inclusion: Orientations on the way to differential sensitive teacher education? ¤ The implementation of inclusive school education raises questions about the professionalization of prospective teachers – here, above all, the importance of their own school- and education-related orientations is emphasized. At the same time, it is striking in the discussions about inclusion that students themselves are hardly heard. The study takes up these findings by focusing both on the target group of students and that of students and then asks how students in their understanding of inclusion refer to the perspectives of students. The documentary analysis of student orientations shows that students hardly perceive the voices of students as independent positions, but rather use them as a starting point for shaping their own prospective position in school. The results are illuminated from a praxeological perspective on teacher professionalism and provide information on which differential norms are effective and from which students distance themselves. They also draw attention to questions and requirements of inclusive teaching and research.

Graphene - Epitaxial Growth, Characterization, and Non-Classical Electronic Device Concepts ¤ In the present dissertation, the focus points of growth on semi-insulating 6H-SiC, layer- and device characterization based on epitaxial graphene were treated. The layers were investigated using REM, AFM, LEED, XPS and ARPES. By means of REM images, the quality of the layers was correlated with the growth parameters using a new approach. For the determination of the layer thickness using XPS, (a-)symmetric fit functions and their error in determining the thickness were considered. The second focus point deals with the characterization of the produced layers by Raman and FTIR spectroscopy. The influences of strain, Fermi level and layer number on the Raman spectrum of graphene were classified and quantified. Uniaxial could be distinguished from biaxial strain by means of the difference in the G/2D dispersion, the asymmetry of the G-mode is mainly influenced by uniaxial strain, the position of the Fermi level as well as by transfer doping in the presence of adsorbates. Increasing layer number caused a blue shift of the 2D mode with increasing half-width. By means of FTIR, the change of the reststrahlen band of SiC was investigated in dependence on the growth by exciting a surface plasmon polariton in graphene. A method of evaluation was developed to describe the Fano resonance emerging in the division spectrum of the reflectivities. The intensity of the resulting Fano resonance is mainly influenced by the shift of the model oscillators relative to each other. The third focus point deals with the structuring and characterization of completely graphene-based, three-terminal junctions (TTJ) and side-gate transistors (SG-FET). For the measurement of smallest structural widths using REM images, methods for correcting oscillations and determining the width below/just below the resolution limit of the REM were derived. It could be shown that TTJs exhibit a rectification effect with high rectification efficiency. Furthermore, the occurring amplification effects were investigated. The realized SG-FETs show comparable good properties like conventional top-gate transistors at minimizing parasitic influences.
Peptide Masking of Oligonucleotides with Self-Assembling Linkers ¤ This work describes the peptide masking of oligonucleotides with self-assembling linkers for prodrug and release strategies.

The structurally weak areas of the community in the run-up to EC '92: Problem situations, development trends and perspectives; an example of the Objective 1 regions of Spain and Italy ¤ The aim of the work was to make an empirical contribution to the clarification of the question of the spatial effects of the EC internal market. The subject of the investigation were the structurally weak areas of Italy, the Mezzogiorno, which includes the regions of Abruzzo, Molise, Campania, Apulia, Basilicata, Calabria, as well as the two islands of Sardinia and Sicily, and those of Spain with Andalusia, Asturias, Galicia, Castile and León, Castile-La Mancha, Valencia, Murcia, Extremadura and the Canary Islands. In Italy, these areas cover 40% of the total area and approximately 36.6% of the total population. In Spain, the share of the total area is 76.1% and approximately 58% of the population. Special attention was paid to the problem areas of "Direct Investments" and "Infrastructure", as these are the causes of the feared spatially divergent development trends. The investigation comes to the result that through the EC '92 project, spatially divergent development paths experience an additional exacerbation. The policy of the European Communities is too one-sidedly concentrated on the comprehensive deregulation concept of the EC internal market. But for this, a steering and correction mechanism must be established on a political level, in order to counteract the unwanted spatial concentrations and polarizations.

Promoting Attention and Motivation Retention through Digital Game-Based Learning Systems with Specific Suitability for Autism ¤ Institutional education is associated with diverse and specific barriers for autistic learners. This is particularly relevant in the context of inclusion, the relevance of which is not least given by the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. This work discusses numerous learning-relevant peculiarities in the context of autism and shows discrepancies to the institutional teaching concepts that are not always adequately tailored. A central thesis is that the unusually intense attention of autistic individuals for their special interests can be used to facilitate learning with foreign content. Based on this, solution approaches are discussed, which result in a new concept for a digital multi-device-based learning game. A significant challenge in designing game-based learning is the adequate integration of learning content into a captivating narrative context. Using the example of exercises for ...

Präparative and mechanistic studies on titanocatalyzed hydroaminoalkylation of alkenes ¤ Intramolecular hydroaminoalkylation reactions of alkenes were realized selectively without competing hydroamination reactions. Primary and secondary aminoalkenes could be transformed successfully into the corresponding hydroaminoalkylation products with a variety of Ti-catalysts. Secondary aliphatic amines could be successfully used for Ti-catalyzed intermolecular hydroaminoalkylations of alkenes for the first time. In this context, the successful addition of dimethylamine to alkenes deserves particular attention because a corresponding Ti-catalyzed reaction has never been reported before. Because detailed mechanistic data are not available for the hydroaminoalkylation of alkenes, an extensive kinetic investigation of the reaction of a 1-amino-6-heptene was carried out. The data obtained revealed the reaction order, the activation parameters and the rate determining step of the catalytic cycle. <engl.> END

Application of Cryogenic Calorimeters for High-Resolution Precision X-Ray Spectroscopy ¤ Within the scope of this work, the technology of metallic magnetic microcalorimeters, which has been continuously developed over the past few years, was prepared for use as a high-precision spectrometer in atomic physics. These detectors combine the advantages of various conventional energy-dispersive photon detection technologies due to their unique functional principle. They combine the broad spectral acceptance of semiconductor detectors with the high resolution of crystal spectrometers and thus represent an ideal tool for measuring atomic physical interactions with a broad range of photon energies. In order to fully exploit the potential of the detectors, however, the transition from an analog signal analysis established for conventional procedures to a digital signal analysis is required. Therefore, a powerful and comprehensive software package was developed in the course of the work to be able to evaluate the data of several experiments performed. On the one hand, X-ray transitions of barium and iron were observed and identified at the S-EBIT-I. On the other hand, the 1s-Lamb shift of Xe53+ and the 2s-Lamb shift of Xe89+ were successfully measured with microcalorimeter detectors at the internal gas jet target of the ESR storage ring of the GSI. Significant improvements could be achieved both technically and conceptually for the operation and measurement procedure, so that metallic magnetic microcalorimeters are ready for future high-precision experiments in atomic physics.

Investigations on the Protective Influence of Various Feed Additives on Gastrointestinal and Systemic Colonization with Salmonella enterica after Experimental Infection in Broilers ¤ Salmonella, Probiotics, Poultry. - The use of probiotic feed additives is an approach to reduce the entry of Salmonella into the food chain. Salmonella often do not cause clinical symptoms in broilers and infections are therefore often not recognized. Through the consumption of contaminated animal origin food, it leads to Salmonellosis in the consumer, which manifests itself in a sometimes severe enteritis. The aim of the present study was the testing of various feed additives in animal experiments with regard to the reduction of Salmonella colonization of the gut and internal organs of broilers infected with Salmonella enterica. For this purpose, five different probiotics as well as butyric acid-glyceride were tested. All preparations used in this study were previously tested in an in vitro screening procedure for their inhibitory effect against Salmonella. Before and after the chicks were infected with Salmonella at the 13th day of life, samples were taken at intervals for qualitative bacteriological examination. A quantitative bacteriological examination of liver and caecum samples took place on the 19th day of life. From the 18th to the 29th day of life, epithelial-physiological examinations were carried out using the Ussing chamber technique and the ...

Food Standards and Trade Law in the Context of International Regimes: Interaction and Change of the Codex Alimentarius Commission and GATT/WTO ¤ Development of international food standards: procedures, actors, and results -- Negotiation history and contract law of the institutional interlinking of trade and food safety regimes -- Development of secondary norms and processing of regulatory trade conflicts in the WTO -- Design and effects of institutional interlinking in the Codex Alimentarius Commission -- Global governance in the regime complex: effectiveness and legitimacy This book offers a comprehensive, interdisciplinary examination of the interrelations between health consumer protection and cross-border food trade, which have developed over the last 50 years through the interaction of the relevant international institutions (GATT/WTO and Codex Alimentarius). The long-term perspective, analysis of a large number of previously little-noticed documents, and first-hand observations enable a differentiated evaluation of the effectiveness and legitimacy of the resulting 'regime complex'. Content • Development of international food standards: procedures, actors, and results • Negotiation history and contract law of the institutional interlinking of trade and food safety regimes • Development of secondary norms and processing of regulatory trade conflicts in the WTO • Design and effects of institutional interlinking in the Codex Alimentarius Commission • Global governance in the regime complex: effectiveness and legitimacy Target groups • Lecturers and students of law and political science with a focus on trade law, international law, food law, international relations • Professionals and executives from the fields of (trade) diplomacy, food/agricultural trade, international politics, EU external relations The author Dr. Matthias Leonhard Maier is a political and legal scientist (Dr. jur., Dipl.-Pol.) and a member of the European Commission, Directorate-General for Environment

Work against Poverty: Foundations, Historical Genesis, and Empirical Verification of the Poverty Trap Theory ¤ It is repeatedly claimed that social benefit recipients decide against taking up work due to lack of wage incentives and thus remain in poverty permanently (poverty trap theory). Social policy reforms increasingly rely on 'work against poverty' based on these concerns. Ronald Gebauer examines the assumption that work is the key to solving the poverty problem in modern societies in a first step historically-sociologically. In a further step, the theoretical foundations of the poverty trap theory are discussed. But how does the reality content of the poverty trap theory behave now? Most empirical studies show that social benefit receipt is predominantly of short-term nature. Based on these results, a own data evaluation of the Socio-economic Panel (Social Assistance) is presented

On the Validity of the Jarzynski Equation in Quantum Systems ¤ The Jarzynski equation belongs to a series of new theorems of non-equilibrium thermodynamics. It is an equation that contains the second law of thermodynamics, but goes beyond it. It also brings process variables from non-equilibrium processes into a new relationship with equilibrium variables. However, there is still a question about the validity of the equation for the quantum case, especially in small systems. In contrast to classical systems, there is uncertainty here, and there are very contradictory statements that are based on different definitions and quantum-mechanical interpretations of the equation. Simple, understanding-promoting example systems were lacking so far. In this work, two such example systems are now considered and checked, how the results differ from the classical results and which of the special properties of quantum systems have an impact on the result.

Genome Editing in Plants: Legal Framework and Reform Options ¤ The legal regulation lags behind the actual progress in biotechnology. This affects all areas of the biotechnological transformation, especially but the biotechnological procedures of genome editing. The work focuses on genome-edited and other „innovative“ crop plants. It provides suggestions for reforming the EU's genetic engineering legal framework, but not only short- and medium-term, but also long-term, so that also reforms are discussed that currently appear to be not politically realizable. Initially, the scientific and legal starting situation for reforms of European genetic engineering law is presented. Subsequently, the framework conditions for reforms are explained, particularly the interests of those affected and the limits of what is legally permissible in Union and world trade law. Based on this, options for reforms are illuminated, taking into account regulation in non-European countries and proposals from the literature. Finally, a concrete reform of the EU's genetic engineering legal framework is proposed. The author Brigitte Voigt studied law at the University of Passau. Subsequently, she worked there in the project „Genome Editing in Plant Biotechnology“ (FKZ 01GP1615) funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research. She completed her legal clerkship in the district of the Higher Regional Court of Stuttgart. Part 1: Starting situation -- A. Scientific starting situation -- B. Legal starting situation -- Part 2: Regulation factors -- A. Regulation interests – who wants what why? -- B. Legal framework conditions -- Part 3: Regulation options -- A. Basics: „Triggers“ of regulation of innovative plant breeding -- B. Existing models and proposals for regulating innovative plant breeding -- C. Regulation options for the EU -- Part 4: Own regulation proposal -- A. Is there a need for regulation/changes on EU and/or national level regarding genetic engineering law and/or the law of new breeding techniques? -- B. How could a useful regulatory approach look like?.

The Novel in the Sign of Itself: Typology, Analysis, and Historical Studies on the Discourse of Literary Self-Representation in the Spanish Novel of the 15th to 20th Centuries ¤ Dust jacket: This book develops a general model that semiotically describes and discursively reconstructs the literary thematization of aesthetic sign practice (writing, reading, textuality). In analyses of Spanish novels from the 15th to 20th centuries, this discourse appears in the field of tension between media change, poetics, aesthetic subject constructions, and narrative strategies.
Colorings of graphs, digraphs, and hypergraphs ¤ BEGIN \\

The Process of Plasma-Supported Aluminum Sputtering and the Properties of Layers Produced Thereby ¤ This work deals with the investigation of a combination process consisting of aluminum sputtering and additional plasma support for the coating of plastic foil. A hollow cathode arc discharge is used as the plasma source. Due to the interaction of the plasma with the aluminum vapor, aluminum particles are primarily ionized by electron impact and Penning processes. Ionization causes a changed scattering behavior of the Al particles and results in a decrease in the deposition rate. At the same time, the energy input during layer formation increases due to the kinetic and recombination energy of the ions. This energy input causes changes within the growing layer, which affect various layer properties. Due to smaller grain sizes within the plasma-supported deposited layers, their electrical conductivity is reduced. Their optical properties, on the other hand, remain largely unaffected. Depending on the respective permeant, its permeation through the layers is differently affected by the plasma support. While the permeation of water vapor is hardly changed, that of oxygen is reduced by about 50%. Using a simple model of layer growth, this different effect of plasma support on permeation was investigated in more detail. It turned out that different defect sizes are decisive for the different permeants. The number of larger defects through which oxygen can permeate is effectively reduced by the plasma support. The influence on the small defects important for water vapor is, on the other hand, small. For comparison, the properties of the deposited probes were compared to those sputtered. The most important differences concern the electrical and permeation properties. Without plasma support, deposited layers show the highest electrical conductivity. Sputtered layers have similar values to those plasma-supported deposited. The permeation of gases and vapors is at least for thicker layers better prevented by the sputtered layers. For oxygen, thin layers of plasma-supported deposited probes show the lowest permeation.

Lobbyism and Transparency: A Comparative Study of a Complex Relationship ¤ Determinants of lobbyist transparency -- Motives of transparency creation -- Levels of transparency creation -- Regulation of transparency creation -- New perspectives for lobbying and transparency research Although the number of publications on lobbying and transparency has increased significantly, little is known about the connection between the two phenomena. The motives of transparency creation or transparency prevention by lobbyists have remained largely unexplored in scientific discussion, as well as unclear or contradictory concept understandings have made it difficult to compare and connect research results. After an intensive discussion of the definitional foundations, derived knowledge from theory and practice, as well as data from a quantitative survey with qualitative follow-up questioning, show that the connection between lobbying and transparency is much more complex than widely assumed.
