The content Determinants of lobbyist transparency Motives of transparency creation Levels of transparency creation Regulation of transparency creation New perspectives for lobbying and transparency research The target groups Lecturers and students of the subjects of political science, economics, law, sociology Lobbyists and political interest representatives and representatives, political decision-makers and decision-makers, journalists and journalists The author Stefan Schwaneck is a representative for press and public relations at the Verein Deutscher Werkzeugmaschinenfabriken e.V. in Frankfurt am Main and lecturer at the Julius-Maximilians-Universität Würzburg

Modelling primary multisensory mechanisms of spatial perception ¤ In this work, visual, auditory, and multimodal forms of spatial perception and their relevance for the design of technical systems are discussed. The scientific approach adopted here has an interdisciplinary character and considers methodological aspects of neurobiology, psychophysics, and computer science in the context of neuroinformatics and robotics. As a result, new and more comprehensive interpretations of findings on natural perception are possible. On the other hand, deficiencies of existing simulation models and technical applications are named and overcome. The starting point of the investigations is in Chapter 1 the discussion and critical evaluation of established attention models of perception, in which early multisensory brain functions are largely ignored. As a fundamental idea of the following investigations, the thesis is formulated that a conceptual separation between primary attention and higher cognitive abilities both facilitates the assignment of sensory features and neurological mechanisms as well as modeling and simulation. In Chapters 2 and 3, the primary spatial encodings of the central auditory pathway and the visual system are first presented and the specifics of projected and calculated sensory topographies are described. The subsequent modeling of auditory-visual integration mechanisms in Chapter 4 is explicitly not for classification or tracking of objects but for early spatial control of attention, which in the biological model occurs unconsciously and at subcortical level. After discussing the few known model concepts, two own multisensory simulation systems are developed on the basis of artificial neural networks and probabilistic methods. Chapter 5 is devoted to the systematic experimental investigation and optimization of the models and shows how unconscious perception performances and their simulation can be evaluated in reference to qualitative and quantitative findings on multisensory effects in the midbrain. The discussion of the model behavior in real audio-visual scenarios is intended to emphasize that the early control of attention still makes an important contribution to spatial orientation before object recognition.

Social Media as an Instrument of Customer Communication : Comparative Study of Companies in China, Germany, and the USA ¤ Anja Corduan investigates to what extent the communication approaches argued in science for social media can claim general validity and whether these cultural peculiarities are subject to them. In the comparative study, the USA, Germany, and China are analyzed, which have similar values in the variables of internet penetration and bandwidth, but are culturally very different. Based on ten case studies of international large companies such as adidas or Samsung, the communication of the companies on Weibo and Facebook is examined in detail. Finally, concrete and practice-relevant action recommendations are derived. The content • Social Media in companies and current challenges in the intercultural context • Analysis of social media customer communication of companies The target groups • Lecturers and students of the fields of International Marketing, Interactive Marketing, International Communication, Social Media Management • Social Media Managers and Digital Managers from practice The author Dr. Anja Corduan has been active as a management in marketing and online communication in companies worldwide for about 15 years. As a lecturer at various universities in Germany and Hong Kong, she teaches in the fields of Social Media Management, Marketing, Communications Policy, Branding, and Sports Management. She was promoted by Prof. Dr. Ulrike Stopka at the TU Dresden.

The scaenae frons of the Theater of Nysa on the Maeander ¤ Summary: Nysa, one of the most important cities of ancient Caria, lies on the road from Ayd?n (the ancient Tralleis) to Denizli, about 3 km northwest of the present-day town of Sultanhisar. The preserved building remains in the city and the inscriptions as well as the small finds indicate that Nysa was continuously inhabited from the Hellenistic to the Byzantine period. The theater of Nysa probably belonged to the basic equipment of the Hellenistic city and was rebuilt several times in the Roman imperial period. The overall complex consists of the auditorium, the orchestra, the proskenion and the stage building with a three-storeyed scaenae frons

LAMMPSCuda - a new GPU accelerated molecular dynamics simulations package and its application to ion-conducting glasses ¤ Computersimulations are today a fundamental part of research and development. Over the past decades, the boundaries of what can be modeled have been dramatically expanded by the continuous increase in available computing power. Due to the stagnating serial computing power of current processors, future performance gains must be achieved through parallelization. In particular, heterogeneous hardware architectures are becoming increasingly important, as they exhibit inherent advantages in terms of energy efficiency. At present, this area is dominated by systems accelerated by graphics cards. Due to their five- to tenfold energy and cost efficiency, supercomputers based on graphics cards have found rapid dissemination since their introduction in 2008. Meanwhile, three of the five fastest computers in the world derive a significant portion of their computing power from graphics cards. However, new programming approaches are necessary to efficiently utilize such systems. In this work, a new molecular dynamics code called LAMMPScuda is presented. LAMMPScuda uses graphics cards to accelerate simulations of various material classes, including biological systems, semiconductors, metals, inorganic glasses, and polymer systems. Both details of the implementation and extensive performance studies are presented. These show that LAMMPScuda can run efficiently not only on individual PCs but also on large computers with hundreds of graphics cards. In the second part of the work, LAMMPScuda is used to develop a new potential for ion-conducting glasses of the composition xLi2O-yB2O3-zSi2O4-wP2O5. As shown, the new potential, designated as BC-U, not only reproduces structural but also dynamic experimental data of various binary glasses over the entire composition range better than established potentials used for comparison. Furthermore, the so-called mixed network former effect occurs in simulations of borophosphates. With this, the BC-U potential is predestined to be used for the verification of theories of the microscopic causes of this effect.

The Collection of Cardinal Alessandro Farnese : a "studio" for Artists and Scholars ¤ Christina Riebesell: "The Collection of Cardinal Alessandro Farnese". A "studio" for Artists and Scholars. VCH Verlag, Acta Humaniora, Weinheim 1989. 347 pp. with 155 ill., bound, 148,- DM

Wegesysteme ¤ Wegesysteme are abstracted as graphs, so that the topological minors relation is considered as the natural containment relation of graphs. By fixing certain vertices of the topological minor in the large graph, this order relation is specialized, so that existence theorems for weg systems get a simple formulation. Three new and short proofs are given for Menger's theorem on the existence of a certain weg system. One of these proofs provides a new version of the theorem, which includes the prescribability of the start and end vertices of a non-maximal weg system for a maximal weg system, as well as a linear algorithm that can be easily implemented to find this weg system. It is shown that this version has known theorems of the transversal theory, such as Hall's marriage theorem and Ford and Fulkerson's theorem on common transversals, as special cases. Furthermore, the prescribability of the start vertices is shown for Mader's theorem on the number of independent H-paths. The new version of Menger's theorem is also used to justify a procedure by which it can be investigated whether, from certain connectivity assumptions (possibly combined with a given weg system) in a graph, the existence of a sought-after weg system follows. The procedure is constructive. Either it finds a counterexample, i.e. a graph with the given assumptions that does not contain the sought-after weg system, or it provides an algorithm that finds the sought-after weg system linearly in the number of vertices and edges of the given graph. In more detail, when a graph is entered, either a separator is found that proves that the connectivity assumption is not given, or the sought-after weg system is constructed itself. The functionality of the procedure is demonstrated by examples: Two existence theorems for circles through prescribed vertices of a given graph are derived with it.

Crystalline Phases with High Thermal Expansion for Crystallizing High-Temperature Glass Tubes ¤ The motivation for this work was the optimization of the expansion behavior of joining glass ceramics for use in solid electrolyte fuel cells and high-temperature reactors, which require a high thermal expansion from room temperature to 1000 °C. For this purpose, the direction-dependent thermal expansion coefficients (TECs) of various silicate and aluminate phases were investigated using high-temperature X-ray diffraction (HT-XRD) and dilatometry in this temperature range. The more apparatus-intensive and more difficult to evaluate HT-XRD provides the direction-dependent TECs relevant for the evaluation of the thermal expansion of a crystalline phase without the influence of mechanical effects. Both methods showed that barium silicates have the highest TECs in the entire investigated temperature range. Even higher TECs are possible if a sudden increase in thermal expansion occurs, such as in BaZn2Si2O7 at around 300 °C due to a phase transition. Based on this compound, two mixed crystal series with Zn-Mg and Zn-Co substitution were produced. In both mixed crystal series, the temperature of the phase transition increases and the relative volume change decreases with increasing substitution grade. Barium zinc silicate glasses with the same SiO2 content and varying BaO to ZnO ratio were produced. With increasing BaO content, higher TECs can be achieved. Glass powders of different grain fractions were sintered and ceramicized. The glass ceramics show larger and independent of the sintering conditions TECs with increasing BaO content. This can be attributed to the increasing share of BaSi2O5. The presence of BaZn2Si2O7 (increasing with increasing ZnO content) has a negative effect.

Images of Aging and Life Stages in the Adult Education Image Space: A Comparative Analysis Considering Adjacent Image Spaces ¤ In the context of the current widespread concept of 'Lifelong Learning', the human life course becomes the reference point for adult education. The term elevates 'learning' to a central reference point for human life phases in general and the phases of adult age in particular. Franziska Endreß examines the pictorial representation of aging and life stages in image documents that circulate on the internet in connection with the terms adult education, further education, and lifelong learning. A special interest is given to the relationships between metaphors of education and learning and process metaphors of human life. The content Relationship between image, medium, and context Thought image, image, experiential image - Interpictoriality Aging image and life stage iconography Adult education, further education, and lifelong learning in images Images of aging in the contemporary image space of adult education The target groups Lecturers and students of adult education/further education as well as general education and social sciences Practitioners in institutions and organizations of adult education/further education The author Franziska Endreß is a research assistant at the Faculty of Human Sciences at the University of the German Armed Forces Munich, her research focuses on adult education and image science Relationship between image, medium, and context -- Thought image, image, experiential image - Interpictoriality -- Aging image and life stage iconography -- Adult education, further education, and lifelong learning in images -- Images of aging in the contemporary image space of adult education

Criminal Procedure Aspects of the Penal Law Doping Prosecution ¤ BEGIN\nMain description: Jan-Frederik Kolbe deals with the criminal procedure aspects of the penal law doping prosecution. The starting point of the investigation is the prevailing opinion in the literature that the penal law anti-doping norms of the AMG are so-called 'dead law'. This thesis is initially confirmed by means of an empirical investigation conducted by the author involving all public prosecutors' offices in Germany and all justice ministries of the federal states, before the application of the penal law anti-doping provisions of the AMG in the criminal procedure is investigated under orientation at the chronological course of the criminal procedure – and here a focus on the initiation of proceedings. In this way, numerous peculiarities are shown, disputed problems are discussed, and suggestions for the revitalization of this 'dead law' are given.\nEND

International Corruption and Jurisdictional Conflicts: Sanctioning Companies in the Case of Bribery of Foreign Public Officials ¤ Claudia Letzien examines the criminal liability of bribery of foreign public officials and the various sanctions that can be imposed on companies in this context, using the examples of the USA, Germany, and the UK. The author addresses the problem of jurisdictional conflicts that arise when different states try to enforce their sanctions against a company and highlights that these cannot be resolved by the principle of ne bis in idem. She proposes a procedure that can achieve a fair balance of interests in the sanctioning of companies by multiple states in cases of foreign bribery. The content includes: Criminal liability of bribery of foreign public officials in the USA, Germany, and the UK Procedural peculiarities of company sanctions Procedural agreements and extrajudicial proceedings Foundations and limits of national jurisdiction in criminal matters The principles of ne bis in idem and double jeopardy Transfer of criminal jurisdiction to a state and criteria for determining the most suitable legal order The target groups: Lecturers and students of law Legal professionals, compliance officers, speakers, judges, prosecutors The author Claudia Letzien is a prosecutor in Berlin.

School System and Organization: Shape and Problematics of State School Regulation ¤ Introduction and Question - Analytical Perspective and Data Evaluation - Case Determination: Curriculum Work as an Organizational Tool and as an Organization - Curriculum Work in the Federal Republic between 1990 and 1995 - Outlook: Authoritarian Statehood, Leveling, and Field of Tension

How Our Feeling Has Changed : Emotions Discourses in the "BRAVO" ¤ How does a "proper", "normal", or "healthy" handling of emotions look like? Depending on the socio-historical context, the answers to this question are quite different. Manuela Beyer outlines how the concepts of feelings and emotion management have changed since the 1960s in the Federal Republic of Germany. Based on a discourse analysis of the advisory pages of the youth magazine BRAVO, the study shows how societal demands on emotion management have evolved. Beyond theses of increasing liberation or suppression of feelings, it becomes clear which new emotional practices have developed

The implementation of performance-oriented systems ¤ The study at hand examines the strategic perspective of the emerging phenomenon of performance-oriented systems, e.g. car-sharing or cloud computing, in the mobility, IT, energy and chemical industries. In all four industries, firms have likewise implemented a novel system-based offering recently, which is providing the performance of their products for shared use. The existing literature that has already acknowledged the phenomenon is fragmented across different areas of expertise. The emphasis of the contributions resides on the operational level and a consistent strategic innovation management perspective is absent. Thus, the study strives to synthesize the literature into a larger perspective and provide a strategic rationale to explain the phenomenon. The study follows an iterative, interpretative approach based on the methodological foundations of Grounded Theory. The findings are based on semi-structured, qualitative interviews with executives from twenty-seven system examples from four industries, clarifying the motivation for and differences in system development. Items from the substantive concept of dynamic capabilities and the juvenile strategy of superior architectural knowledge are used in a novel approach for interpretation. Based on the compiled data, the study derives ten founding propositions that delineate the strategic characteristics of the case examples, composes a coherent framework and identifies nine initial enabling factors that illustrate the context. The research reveals that novel user preferences towards a higher elasticity of resource deployment have facilitated the system development. The examined firms have integrated downward into the use phase and explicitly met the identified demand in offering the performance of several joint resources to the user instead of selling single complements. The created value is protected through the implementation of a central platform. The governance of the platform secures three types of hidden information; the capacity, the user demand and the efficiency information. The information base in the platform determines the firm's competitive advantage, as the incentive regime of a performance-oriented system is inherently oriented towards resource efficiency. Thus, the implementing firms need to continuously develop process innovations and systematically reduce slack of the system components. The study provides managerial guidance for future system developments, contributes a novel perspective on the phenomenon and qualifies recent conceptual work on superior architectural knowledge.

Insolvency-related Duties of Directors and their Advisors after the Implementation of Directive (EU) 2019/1023 and StaRUG ¤ In pre-insolvency siutations it is important for company directors and their advisors to know the scope of the directors' duties and the point in time at which the duties change. Article 19 of the directive (EU) 2019/1023 contains provisions on the directors' duties when there is a likelihood of insolvency. This doctoral thesis examines to what extent directors' duties in pre-insolvency situation will change as a result of the implementation of Art. 19 RRiL and whether the existing provisions in German law are sufficient for the implementation.

Optical Properties of InN and InN-based Semiconductors ¤ In this work, new ways for the experimental determination of the optical properties of InN and its In-rich alloys with GaN and AlN, as well as the interpretation of the data, are presented. Spectroscopic ellipsometry in the spectral range from mid-infrared (MIR) to near-infrared (NIR) to vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) has proven to be a very powerful tool for investigating the absorption-related properties of these materials. Based on a multi-layer model and including surface roughness and interface layers in the data analysis, one obtains in the first step a reliable dielectric function (DF), which reflects the fundamental optical properties of the material. The interpretation of the spectral behavior represents the second step of the studies, from which one can determine probe-dependent parameters such as the frequencies of coupled phonon-plasmon modes, the splitting between valence and conduction bands at the Fermi wavevector, or the transition energies at Van Hove singularities of the band structure. By correcting these data in view of carrier-induced bandgap renormalization and Burstein-Moss shift as well as distortion, one finally obtains the intrinsic properties of the compounds. Due to an accumulation layer of electrons at the surface, it is necessary to determine the electron concentration in the volume using infrared ellipsometry. The plasma frequency extracted from the MIR data is used for a careful determination of this electron density. Furthermore, the region of the absorption edge in InN is strongly influenced by the presence of high electron concentrations and the non-parabolicity of the conduction band. The NIR data must therefore be self-consistently analyzed (coupled with the MIR results), by calculating the imaginary part of the DF over Fermi's Golden Rule. The method achieves 0.675 eV for the fundamental bandgap of hexagonal InN at room temperature. The value for cubic InN is 80 meV lower and is 0.595 eV. By analyzing the DFs of hexagonal InGaN and InAlN alloys in the same way, one obtains the bowing parameters of the fundamental bandgaps E_A. They amount to b_A = 1.71 eV (InGaN) and b_A = 4.0 eV (InAlN). Another important result is the determination of the DF in the UV-VUV spectral range and its comparison with theoretical calculations. The theoretical results regarding the imaginary part of the DF of InN are only in very good agreement with the experimental data when electron-hole interaction (excitonic effects) is taken into account. The Coulomb correlation leads to a redshift of the absorption peaks and a redistribution of the associated oscillator strengths in contrast to the single-particle DF.

Axiomatik and Empiricism : a historical investigation into the mathematical natural philosophy from Newton to Neumann ¤ Um die klassische Newton'sche Mechanik in ihrer Zeit analysieren und untersuchen zu können, muss man sich besonders mit dem Wandel des Verhältnisses von Axiomatik und Empirie befassen. Dies unternimmt Helmut Pulte hier erstmals in ausführlicher Weise

Development and Characterization of Fluid-Mechanical Flexible Actuators at the Example of a Multifunctional Suction Gripper ¤ Fluid-mechanical flexible actuators (FNA) based on silicone are increasingly used as grippers for various objects. Due to their material-locked design, these actuators enable the integration of multiple functions on a structural level. In particular, FNA are particularly suitable for gripping tasks in clean rooms and the packaging industry in the form of closed suction grippers to reduce hygiene risks. The investigation of such suction grippers is the subject of this work. Within the framework of the work, a general classification for FNA is presented based on various applications, and developed FNA are assigned to this classification. The development of FNA is described in detail at the example of the closed suction gripper. One of the features of the closed suction gripper is that it has a membrane on the object side in contrast to open suction grippers. The membrane allows, in addition to the separation of the medium in the interior of the suction gripper from the ambient medium, also the active, time- and location-specific release of gripped objects. Another feature of the chosen example is its nonlinear spring characteristic. This leads to a motion behavior with snap-through and enables adaptation to various object positions and forms. Through model considerations and experimental investigations of selected geometry and material parameters, the possibilities of influencing the snap-through sizes are shown. The formulation of a general approach for achieving specified FNA values forms a substantial contribution to this work. Furthermore, principal solutions for the implementation of a material-coherent and flexible sensorics for FNA based on silicone are presented. The implementation of the sensorics is described at the example of the suction gripper. The possibility of deriving qualitative statements on the gripping state, object conductivity, and gripping process phases is discussed. The innovative tools, equipment, and processes necessary for the production and testing of the multifunctional suction gripper are described in the framework of the work. Through the overall view of the investigated FNA properties, nonlinear characteristic, adaptability, and sensorization, the work contributes to multifunctional FNA and the approach to their development.

Liability, Attribution, and Proof in Case of Initial and Subsequent Impossibility ¤ BEGIN\nMain description: Daniel Peres deals with problem areas at the interface between material law and civil procedure law, which have not been provided with a satisfactory solution even ten years after the reform of the law of obligations. While as much attention has been paid to the liability elements of impossibility liability as has been paid, there is little literature that explicitly deals with the respective attribution elements and the individual proof requirements. These questions are treated equally as the difficult proof of negative, internal facts (§ 311a para. 2 BGB) or the high requirements for the proof of exoneration in impossibility liability. The solution approach takes into account the limits set by material law and evidence law dogmatics for the modification of proof requirements. It integrates the changes to the regulations on procedural leadership and the partial expansion of the parties' intra-procedural participation obligations in the course of the ZPO reform.\nEND

Transparent Conductive Electrode Structures from Nanomaterials ¤ Nanomaterials, zinc oxide, carbon nanotubes, electrical conductivity, transparency, spray-coating, chemical bath deposition - Nanomaterialien, Zinkoxid, Kohlenstoffnanoröhren, elektrische Leitfähigkeit, Transparenz, Sprühbeschichtung, chemische Badabscheidung.

Hydrophobins : investigation and control of structure formation in amphiphilic fungal proteins ¤ In this thesis the influence of constraints on the formation of supramolecular structures of small amphiphilic fungal proteins called Hydrophobins is studied at the air/water interface and in phospholipid liposomes. Two hydrophobins known to form different primary aggregates at interfaces are subjected to multiple cycles of areal constraint and relief at the air/water interface and the superstructures investigated by atomic force microscopy (AFM) after transfer to mica. The effects on both proteins are compared and contextualized with their known aggregation behaviour. Moreover, their interaction with liposomes is investigated using EPR spectroscopy, revealing fundamental differences between the two proteins that can be explained by their known aggregation tendencies in solutions. It is proposed that specific interactions can be forced to tailor interfacial structures on a micrometer scale. The interactions with liposomes give insight into the role of pre-assembly on interfacial structures and interactions with complex systems.

Synthesis and Characterization of Novel Poly(arylenethinylen) Copolymers ¤ In the last few decades, interest in p-conjugated polymers has steadily increased due to their optical, electrical, and electrochemical properties. As materials for electronic and optical components, increased research has been conducted in academic and industrial research laboratories. In the class of conjugated polymers, Poly(para-phenylenvinylen) (PPV) has established itself alongside Poly-acetylen (PA), Poly(diacetylen) (PDA), Poly(para-phenylen) (PPP), and Poly-(arylenethinylen) (PAE). Furthermore, polymers with linear conjugated p-bonds exhibit interesting effects in electroluminescence, photoluminescence, and nonlinear optics, whose application possibilities are reflected in materials science. These are used in light-emitting diodes (LEDs), polymer lasers, as photoreceptors or as optical switching elements. It is worth noting that this type of polymer can be used in various areas of inorganic semiconductor technology. PPVs and their derivatives possess, in addition to strong photoluminescence (important for electroluminescence (EL)), easy electron polarizability (important for nonlinear optics (NLO)), easy charge carrier generation, and high charge carrier mobility (important for photoreceptor properties and EL) in the electric field, as well as film-forming properties. Due to these properties, PPVs have been and are of great importance in the development of polymer solar cells and as active components in organic polymer LEDs.

Process capability evaluation of quality under consideration of characteristic dependencies: illustrated by an example of a fastening screw ¤ Process capability indices, also known as PFIs, have been an indispensable tool for quality assurance in customer-supplier interactions and accompanying product control in mass production for a long time. These key figures are based on a very simple statistics. They provide information for each design feature about whether the manufacturing process used is capable of producing a part within the required tolerance zones or not. In the case of complete independence of product characteristics from each other, the statements of the well-known PFI formulas are correct. However, the product quality is determined in the majority of cases by the interactions and relationships of its individual parameters. Many constructions set this functionally optimized and cost-saving. Notably, the Maximum Material Condition (MMC) is particularly worth mentioning. It allows the value of the unused tolerance of a feature, for example, the diameter, to be added to other measurements, for example, position, etc. However, such positive properties can not be taken into account by today's statistical quality assurance in the sense of a key figure. This leads to the sad fact that functional parts are still scrapped. Furthermore, superpositions of properties at the parts are known, which can lead to a functional impairment. In this case, the customer receives a non-functional product, although sufficient large PFIs per feature have been proven. The resulting consideration was: to consider the interaction effects in the quality proof by adapting possibly a change in the key figures. By adopting the definition principles of current PFIs, it has been possible to conceive a single index, here referred to as Function Achievement Degree (FAD), for the fulfillment grade of the function of a product part. As an example for the practical examination of the theoretically developed formulas, the commercially available hexagon screw served. On the one hand, this part is still conventionally examined by the teaching methods due to the strong dependence of the parameters such as flank diameter, angle and partial angle. However, due to the lack of depth of statement and the high number of parts to be tested, such a type of examination should be avoided in modern quality assurance in the future. On the other hand, this mass product has a challenging package of form and position tolerances under consideration of the latest standard developments. This makes a more economical production and as a consequence cheaper parts for the customer possible without changing the manufacturing process, without acquiring special measuring instruments, and, what is particularly important, without any functional loss. This potential has been recognized in some sources, but only this work makes it possible to exploit it. The approach presented here is applicable to all common tolerance types in construction and allows not only parameters of a kind, e.g. geometric dimensions, but also all necessary sizes for the functioning of the part to be included in the capability proof.

Representation of Blood Vessels on the Hind Flipper of the European Seal (Phoca vitulina vitulina) and Description and Testing of a Minimally Invasive Blood Sampling Location ¤ Seals, Veins, Blood Sampling. - The location on the hind flipper of the seal (Phoca vitulina vitulina) for blood sampling and its success rate is described differently in the literature. The goal of this work was to re-evaluate the blood vessel course on the hind flipper and, with the help of this knowledge, to describe a suitable location for a vessel puncture on the hind flipper that can be used in medical training without fixation or sedation of the seals. In the present work, the blood vessel course of the hind flipper was investigated in 22 seals and five bearded seals (Halichoerus grypus). In addition to a native macroscopically-anatomical examination, the vessels were depicted with various contrast agents (Xenetix® 350, Barium sulfate and colored latex, as well as a mixture of Barium sulfate, color and latex). Furthermore, CT angiographies were made. The arteries could be enriched with contrast medium up to the skin vessels, whereas only the main vessels could be filled with contrast medium in the veins. The enriched venous vessels ran on the plantar flipper side and mostly in parallel to the bone. At the level of the Ossa tarsi/metatasalia, the plantar plexus could be depicted with various branches and tributaries. In addition, some veno-venous anastomoses were shown. A difference in the course of the veins on the hind flipper between seal and bearded seal could not be observed. CT angiography proved to be the most accurate representation of the vascular topography. Vascular-like structures could be depicted in all seal species using ultrasound, whereas a blood flow using Doppler could only be detected in 44.4% of the seals and 71.4% of the bearded seals. Considering all the knowledge gained, the plantar plexus, which extends over the easily palpable tuber calcanei, could be identified as a suitable location for blood sampling. Subsequently, this location was tested for its practicability. In 58 attempts, a minimum volume of 0.5 ml could be obtained in 29.3%. The method is complication-free, easy to learn, and can be performed in trained animals without coercive measures. This method can therefore be used when only very small blood volumes (e.g. blood count) are required. By applying venous stasis (n=26), a minimum blood volume of 3 ml could be obtained in 23.1%, whereas this was only possible in 15.6% of the cases without stasis (n= 32). We therefore recommend venous stasis as well as the use of a Vacutainers system for easier handling. The described location could also be successfully used in bearded seals.

Complete Sale of Municipal Housing to International Investors: Governance-Analytical Consideration of the Consequences for Urban Development and Housing Market Processes ¤ The work deals with the internationalization of the housing market in Germany. In this context, the question is pursued of how communication and cooperation on the housing market and in the framework of urban development processes change after the complete sale of municipal housing. Based on case studies in Kiel, Osnabrück, and Wilhelmshaven, municipal and housing economic action strategies and interaction orientations of local actors are related to each other. Even if the knowledge gained with the help of an Urban Governance approach shows large differences in municipal design claims, a principal loss of control after the sale is verifiable. Above all, financially oriented investors and their low investment interest lead to a persistently decreasing design capacity at the neighborhood level.
Absentia in praesentia? : on the presentation and mediation of digital media in physical space ¤ This excellent master's thesis by Janin Taubert,

Visualizations of the Political: Homophobia and Queer Protest Culture in Poland since 1980 ¤ Homophobic hate in Poland is propagated through posters, pictograms, graffiti and other image types of nationalist, right-wing and Catholic fundamentalist movements. Through the internet and street protests, these homophobic images are disseminated in the digital and urban space. As a result, they have a fundamental impact on Poland's visual culture. Julia Austermann researches these Polish text and image collections before and after 1989, which provide information on homophobia and its visibility and combating. At the center are the analysis of the production of these images, their handling and the associated emotionalization techniques. But also the queer interventions against homophobia are examined.

Transnational Law Creation : Elements of a Normative Theory of Lex Financiaria ¤ The markets for over-the-counter (OTC) traded financial derivatives have had significant negative impacts due to the increase in food prices, the influence on the fiscal situation of states, and the buildup of systemic risks. Democratization of these markets is therefore one of the most important tasks of global law. The International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA) shapes the legal infrastructure of these markets as a private institution. Johan Horst examines the legal practice of ISDA and shows that the ISDA regime has developed its own forms of legislative activity, enforcement of law, and adjudication. Due to the massive impacts of ISDA's activities, a normative reconnection is needed through the establishment of transnational responsibility obligations, which can be dogmatically anchored in the horizontal effect of human rights, prohibitions on the indirect effect of transnational contract networks, and a decentralized politicization of transnational law.

Innovative Lighting for Novel Imaging and Lithography Systems ¤ In this work, innovative lighting systems in the fields of microscopy and lithography are investigated. LEDs and LED arrays are used as light sources of the lighting systems in two optical systems, namely Fourier Ptychography and the Lau effect. The coherence properties of the lighting are theoretically analyzed and experimentally verified to affect the two optical applications. The use of spatially coherent lighting using an LED array in Fourier Ptychography enables the resolution to be increased. In practice, a coherent 4f imaging system is built, in which two different lighting concepts are introduced. Both the planar and spherical arrangement of the lighting provide spatially coherent light with each LED. Depending on the position of the LEDs, various lighting angles are realized. The LEDs are sequentially turned on and off, so that some low-resolution intensity images are taken. To reconstruct a high-resolution intensity image using the information of the low-resolution intensity images, two iterative phase recovery algorithms are checked. The reconstruction process corresponds to a broadened transfer function or synthetic numerical aperture. A high-resolution intensity image can be reconstructed using the kFP algorithm or the EPRY-FPM algorithm, but its quality is affected by the faulty optical system. The influence of the wave aberrations of the lighting system and the removal of this influence are discussed. A reduction of these wave aberrations is achieved by introducing a spherical arrangement of the LED array lighting. The use of spatially coherent lighting in the experimental setup for the Lau effect leads to diffraction orders of the grid in the observation plane. Only with spatially incoherent lighting, which is realized with a single LED or an LED array, do periodic triangular Lau strips arise. From the experiment, it is found that the LED array achieves approximately 7 times the optical performance of a single LED. This leads to increased intensities of the Lau strips and reduces the exposure time in the exposure process of the lithography. Depending on the grid parameters, the intensities and periods of the Lau strips vary around the observation plane. By using the Lau strips in optical lithography, three-dimensional structures are realized on both planar and curved surfaces.

Theory of Sustainability: Legal, Ethical, and Political Approaches - An Example of Climate Change, Resource Scarcity, and Global Trade ¤ Sustainability demands durable and globally sustainable forms of life. Politics and law have been little successful in resource and climate protection so far. The transdisciplinary habilitation thesis analyzes and integrates legal, political, social, economic, and ethical discourses and challenges them critically. It develops a foundation including a problematization of the growth thinking and the widespread vague sustainability concepts. Furthermore, the work provides an analysis of the causes of non-sustainability in politics, companies, and individuals as well as possible transformation processes. Furthermore, the author develops a legal and ethical justice, human rights, and institution theory of sustainability. In addition to a cost-benefit / weighing theory and an analysis of

Shanghai XXL : Everyday Life and Identity Formation in the Field of Extreme Urbanization ¤ Reform, opening up, and rapid globalization are causing an extreme dynamic of development in Chinese metropolises. At the forefront is - as a model example - the dynamic space of Shanghai: Here, economic, urban planning, cultural, and social change converge in a unique intensity worldwide. This study combines, in a theoretical approach specifically developed for these new phenomena, the multifaceted, interconnected dimensions of urban change with the micro-perspective of the young population on their own living world. Thus, a comprehensive access to the space of the future is enabled.

Contributions to the Automation of Early Design Phases of Distributed Systems ¤ With the rapidly increasing speed of electronic components, systems with increased complexity, networking, and heterogeneity can be developed. This has the consequence that development can only be carried out by teams of specialists. At the same time, development must take place in parallel to enable early product introduction as quickly as possible. In the traditional design process, the design is therefore recorded in the form of a written specification of the overall system and then divided among several teams. This occurs in the early design phases, which are characterized by a high degree of uncertainty about the product. When developing subsystems, assumptions and decisions must be made without being able to assess the impact on the overall system. Coupling effects are largely ignored. Many critical, especially coupling-induced errors, can be discovered at the end of the development process. In addition, optimization of the overall system is not possible, as no overall system model is available. The traditional design process therefore has a high development risk. With the Mission Level Design design approach, instead of a written specification, an executable specification of the overall system is developed after the concept design. This is validated and optimized against the overall system requirements. Subsequently, the specification of the coupled overall system is passed on to several teams for the development of subsystems, which are then integrated again into a single overall system. Integration problems are thus already solved in the early design phases, resulting in a significant reduction in development time and risk. To increase the specification quality and speed in the development of overall system models, standardized methods for describing and evaluating distributed systems, as well as for automated mapping of functions to architecture are developed within the scope of the work. This enables architecture optimization of the overall system already in the early design phases. In addition, methods for transferring the abstract design to implementations are developed.

Bayes filters with improved measurements for visual object tracking ¤ Visual object tracking uses cameras to track target objects in the environment, which has many applications nowadays, such as intelligent surveillance, medical care, intelligent transportation and human-machine interaction. However, it is still a challenging task because of background noises, occlusions, illumination changes and fast motion. The goal of this dissertation is to improve measurements in Bayesian filtering frameworks for visual object tracking as follows: First, we combine multiple visual cues to improve the measurement for lane tracking. The lane is modeled by a linear-parabolic shape, which is a trade-off between accuracy of the fit and robustness with respect to image artifacts. In contrast to previous methods for linear-parabolic lane tracking, we use not only the color and edge information, but also the gradient orientation as visual cues. The lane tracking becomes a statistical reference problem when these local visual cues are available. The probabilistic distribution of lane parameters are estimated from the visual cues by multiple kernel density estimation, which is proved to be very robust to the image noise. Furthermore we use this probabilistic distribution function as the measurement model of the partitioned particle filter to update lane parameters. The experiments show that our novel lane tracking framework has its strength in a new combination and improvement of various advanced methods ...

Conciliar Organization: Structures, Processes, Persons, and Relationships ¤ Objective and research question -- Inventory of the state of research on internal corporate communication -- Justification of the suitability of the basic theory and research method -- Basic theoretical foundations -- Description of the Conciliar Organization -- Consideration of optimality and efficiency criteria -- Personal economic conclusions -- Summary of results and outlook. Relational social capital affects the competitive position of companies just as much as financial and tangible capital, making communication a key function for companies. As a communication-oriented organizational form, Inéz Labucay presents the Conciliar Organization. Using the categories of structures, processes, persons, and relationships, she designs a high-performance grid and shows personal economic, organizational, and leadership-related points of connection for implementation in business practice.

The Effect of System Support on Political Participation: A Comparative Analysis of Western Democracies ¤ How does the support of the political system by society members affect their political participation? So far, the research literature has assumed that individuals with a well-developed support for the political system tend to use written political participation forms, while individuals with a low level of support tend to use unwritten political participation forms. Dominik Allenspach represents the thesis that the effects are u-shaped. This means that both individuals with a well-developed and those with a low level of support for the political system use written and unwritten political participation forms, while individuals who are indifferent to the political system do not participate politically. The author has checked the presence of these effects for various Western democracies. The results show that the effects of the support of the political system on the various political participation forms are primarily u-shaped, but in some cases also inversely u-shaped.

Experimental and Numerical Investigation of Flow in Pumps with Small Specific Speed Considering the Roughness Influence ¤ In industrial pumps with small specific speed, significant deviations from reality occur in flow simulations. As essential reasons, the faulty modeling of wall boundary layers with the logarithmic wall law and the neglect of the effect of hydraulically rough walls are identified in this work. An improved method is developed and validated using measurements (including wall shear stress). The flow field of a test pump is analyzed and essential phenomena as well as loss sources are worked out.

Decision-Oriented Environmental Cost Management: Concept for Active Environmental Cost Design in Corporate Environmental Management ¤ A Introduction -- 1 Subject and Objective of the Investigation -- 2 Methodology -- 3 Need for Environmental Cost Management -- B Research Objects of the Work: Circular Economy and Environmental Management -- 1 Circular Economy Consideration of the Company as a Starting Situation for Environmental Management and Environmental Cost Management -- 2 Corporate Environmental Management within the Framework of the Circular Economy -- C Decision-Supporting Environmental Cost Management in Corporate Environmental Management -- 1 Foundations of Corporate Environmental Cost Management -- 2 Optimization Model for Designing Environmental Costs -- 3 Model-Based Derivation of a Decision-Supporting Environmental Cost Management Concept -- 4 Environmental Cost Management as a Decision-Supporting Instrumentarium -- D Conclusion and Outlook -- Appendix 1: Formulation of the Numerical Example in GAMS -- Appendix 2: Results of the Numerical Example -- Glossary -- Symbol Index -- Bibliography -- Legislation This dissertation is dedicated to decision-oriented environmental cost management and presents a new concept that supports the active design of environmental costs. It provides a 'toolbox' that delivers relevant information for various decision-making and evaluation purposes. The presented optimization model builds on existing information structures in companies and enables companies to precisely assess the consequences of their decisions. The model includes the integration of environmental levies, emissions trading, the possibility of recycling and the reuse of resources, emissions limits, and limiting environmental damage, which covers almost all relevant aspects for production planning that include corporate environmental impacts. The work provides a comprehensive overview of environmental cost management issues and is therefore of equal interest to both scientists and practitioners.

Risk Management and Risk Control for Young Companies in Growth Industries: Conceptualization of a Theory-Guided Framework for Practice-Induced Corporate Governance ¤ Young technology companies have to overcome 'market entry barriers' in two respects. On the one hand, they must build a certain level of awareness of their company among the target group and in the environment within a short period of time. On the other hand, they must demonstrate the performance capability of their product to their customers. Their competitive advantages and strengths result from innovative products or technological head starts. In the context of success factor research, a multitude of empirical studies have established the causes of the competitive advantages and strengths of young technology companies, while the causes of failures, i.e. the investigation of risk factors, play a subordinate role. Innovative company foundations with above-average growth rates in future-oriented technology industries include not only opportunities but also significant risks with regard to the future development of this company type. The present book deals with this problem, developing a practice-oriented risk control tailored to the specific characteristics of young technology companies. - First, a content-related definition and classification of risk control for young technology companies is carried out. It is highlighted that risk management serves as a function of corporate governance and risk control as its methodical support. - Based on an analysis of the initial situation of young technology companies, the focus is on the implementation of a risk management system. A procedure model for the introduction of a risk management system is developed and an evaluation approach for the instrumental design is worked out. The goal of this evaluation approach is the selection of instruments from the comprehensive business instrumentarium under the aspect of practical use within the risk management process. In addition to the establishment of an integrated risk management process, particularly the functional, instrumental, and institutional design in the individual process phases, the book deals with components of a risk management system, such as the risk management handbook and the risk report system. Finally, essential changes to the concept are addressed due to the consolidation of the risk management process for continuous improvement of risk management. - The book is aimed at lecturers and students of business administration with a focus on controlling, risk management, and corporate governance. It is suitable for executives of young technology companies as well as for auditors and management consultants who care for these companies.

Modeling and Generation of Combinable User Interface Variants and Their Joint Use in Service Ecosystems ¤ Digitalization enables us to interact with partners (e.g. companies, institutions) in an IT-supported environment and perform tasks that were previously done manually. A goal of digitalization is to combine services from different professional domains into processes and make them accessible to many user groups in a needs-oriented manner. To this end, providers offer technical services that can be integrated into different applications. Digitalization poses new challenges to application development. One aspect is the needs-oriented binding of users to services. To interact with human users and services, user interfaces are needed that are tailored to their needs. For this, variants for specific user groups (professional variants) and varying environments (technical variants) are required. Increasingly, these must be able to be combined with services from other providers in order to cross-domain processes to ...

The Obligation to Close the Airspace over Conflict Zones: An Examination of Sovereign Responsibility in the Wake of the Downed Flight MH17 over Eastern Ukraine ¤ The downing of flight MH17 in 2014 raised the question of whether states are obligated to close their airspace above conflict zones. Relying on the concept of sovereignty as a responsibility, Matina Jozi demonstrates that the obligation to close the airspace can be deduced from public international law and applies her results to the specific case of eastern Ukraine. The table of contents includes Introduction, Part 1: The Occasion of the Investigation, Part 2: Dogmatic Foundations, Part 3: Concretization of General Protective Responsibility, Part 4: Derivation of the Obligation from Other Sources of Law, and Part 5: Violation of the Obligation. The final consideration shows that the downing of flight MH17 has highlighted the dangers of overflying conflict zones and that an efficient protection of civil aviation in certain cases can only be achieved by a duty of the conflict state to close the airspace affected by the conflict.

Strain field and strain engineering in semiconductor nanostructures: coherent X-ray diffraction imaging and analytical studies ¤ Abstract: In specific magneto-optical, electronic materials, such as Ga1-xMnxAs, the electronic and magnetic properties are set by the concentration of the charge carrier determining component, here by Mn. However, changes in the chemical composition also lead to a change in the order of the system. A good way to approach this problem is the use of external electrostatic fields to obtain a doping effect without changing the composition. This approach not only allows the development of new components but can also be used to investigate quantum phenomena, as the ground state in such systems can be controlled. Epitaxial nanostructures are suitable candidates, as they allow the required quantum confinement. An elastic lattice strain due to a lattice mismatch can be used to influence the observed quantum effects. Ga1-xMnxAs is currently of great interest for spintronic components. Due to its strong magnetic anisotropy, the spin polarization can be reversed by a magnetic field or by electrical triggers. However, the anisotropy also causes an asymmetric charge carrier distribution. Ga1-xMnxAs therefore has a complex, anisotropic representation surface for the magnetic energy and thus a variety of easily magnetizable axes

Interactions between Organization and Costs of Municipal Building Management ¤ For the management of buildings, various costs arise depending on the type of use. The study shows - based on statewide data from Mecklenburg-Vorpommern - a significant correlation between the organization of building management and the resulting costs. Between July 2006 and March 2007, all municipalities in MV with more than 10,000 inhabitants were examined. Municipalities with an organization close to the developed optimal model have only about half the costs per square meter compared to municipalities with a poor organization.

Apartments for workers : social housing, segregation, and stigmatization in urban Brazil ¤ Social inequalities are part of most aspects of daily life and have persistently characterised life in Latin American cities. As such, in Brazil and other countries on the South American subcontinent, unequal housing conditions became a visible expression of social inequality during the twentieth century. Since public and academic debates on unequal housing largely focus on impoverished shanty towns and upper-class gated communities, focusing on the history of social housing challenges and reconfigures conventional scholarship.This study explores the complex relationships between housing policies, socio-spatial segregation and the stigmatisation of residents in the Conjunto IAPI in Belo Horizonte. It utilises a range of sources from the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s, while interviews conducted with residents in the housing complex complement the analysis.

Electron Scattering Methods for Structural Analysis of Epitaxial Silicon Carbide Layers ¤ BEGIN The goal of this work is to investigate the application possibilities of various electron scattering methods for the crystal structure analysis of ultrathin layers using silicon carbide as an example. The focus was on the implementation and application of effective simulation procedures. For this purpose, new programs for simulating photoelectron scattering, backscattered electron diffraction, and dynamic effects in electron channeling patterns were developed, which are based on different theoretical approaches. The similarities between photoelectron scattering and electron channeling patterns are used to present a simulation algorithm for photoelectron scattering at crystal surfaces, which has made it possible to perform calculations of complete photoelectron scattering patterns in the context of dynamic Kikuchi band theory. This allows the equivalence of the cluster approach and the Kikuchi band approach to be shown in both directions at complete diffraction patterns. Together with the analyzed backscattering effects of electrons in LEED and RHEED experiments, this contributes to a unified view of electron scattering effects and the models that serve to describe them. END

A Contribution to Humidity Compensation of Precision Measuring Instruments ¤ A development direction for reducing the measurement uncertainty of precision measuring instruments is the minimization of the cross-sensitivities of the measuring instruments to disturbing influences. These include all influences acting on a measuring instrument other than the actual measured quantity. A crucial role is played by the three climatic quantities temperature, humidity, and air pressure. The state of the art is that a large part of today's precision measuring instruments are equipped with a comprehensive suppression of disturbing influences. However, the field of reducing humidity dependence still offers considerable potential for further reducing measurement uncertainty. The present work presents a systematic approach to achieving a humidity-independent measuring instrument. Starting from the causes of humidity dependence, methods for reducing humidity dependence are derived. These methods can be divided into two categories: 1. Minimization of the humidity transport responsible for humidity dependence. 2. Compensation of humidity dependence based on mathematical methods. The humidity transport can be almost completely prevented by maintaining a constant relative humidity in the measuring instrument, e.g. by means of humidity buffering. Furthermore, the penetration of moisture into components can be reduced by constructive measures such as encapsulation, sealing, and sealing. Among a variety of variants for modeling the behavior of systems, so-called polynomial models are particularly well-suited for mathematical humidity compensation. With these models, it is possible to describe both the static and dynamic humidity dependence simultaneously. Essential influence on the quality of mathematical compensation is exerted by the model structure as well as the representation variant of humidity (relative humidity, absolute humidity, vapor pressure, dew point temperature, and similar). Experimental investigations are required to determine the humidity dependence of precision measuring instruments. Since there are interactions between temperature and humidity dependence, the time courses of air temperature and humidity must be orthogonal. Only under this condition can statistically secure statements be made about temperature and humidity dependence from the experiments.

American Right and Environmental Protection: A History of Radicalization ¤ In January 1970, Republican Richard Nixon signed the National Environmental Policy Act, thereby institutionalizing modern environmental policy in the USA. Over the next two decades, federal and state governments implemented extensive measures to protect nature. At the same time, a societal counter-movement emerged: Anti-Environmentalism. Protests against parks, drinking water standards, and renewable energy are now a fixed part of the conservative agenda. Ella Müller traces the historical genesis of this phenomenon. She shows how resistance to individual measures could become a reactionary political project, driven by the fight against liberal America. Based on a broad range of sources and with great narrative power, she reconstructs the history of radicalization: from the 1960s to the Reagan Revolution and the culture wars of the present. This book thus provides significant insights into the development history of the American Right.

A flexible wing modeling and physical mass estimation system for early aircraft design stages ¤ A multidisciplinary tool chain for wing mass estimation for early design stages is presented. Beside the wing primary structure, the structural FE model includes flaps and tracks, ailerons, landing gears and engine pylons. The chain includes the structural analysis and sizing capability and models for aerodynamic, fuel, landing gear and engine loads. The chain is calibrated against two reference aircraft. The calibration shows the high accuracy of the extended physical modeling.

The Furnishing of Smaller Houses in Pompeii (Insula IX 5) : Decor Decisions and Their Effect (62-79 AD) ¤ The book examines the interplay of ancient and new decor elements on Insula IX 5 in Pompeii during the final phase of the city between AD 62-79 . This is the first time that an attempt has been made to grasp the construction and equipment phases of the houses. However, the décor is not only classified chronologically, but analyzed both in terms of the décor decisions made for it and the effect of the décor

Payment Willingness for Value-Added-Services in Freight Transport: Illustrated by Road Freight Transport in Germany ¤ Within the scope of this work, the demand for Value-Added-Services for transport services in road freight transport within Germany is modelled on the basis of a cost minimization calculation by companies and a method is developed to quantify a construct derived from the modelled demand similar to the payment willingness. The author develops a complex traffic demand model based on discrete choice analysis that allows for explicit consideration of qualitative variables such as Value-Added-Services. The model is then tested by means of an internet-based survey of German shippers and forwarders who are potential demanders of Value-Added-Services and first empirical results on the payment willingness for Value-Added-Services are determined.

Völkerrechtliche Jurisdiktionsgrundlagen für den Datenschutz im Netz ¤ Stefan Herrmann examines the permissibility and limitation of cross-border data protection regulation issues on the internet from an international law perspective and demonstrates how regulatory conflicts can be dealt with.

Accounting for Economic Ownership in IFRS Reporting: A Comparative Analysis of Illustrative Rules for Selected Legal Institutes ¤ The current IASB Work Plan includes projects such as the re-conceptualization of the recognition of financial assets, leasing accounting, and the framework. Currently, there is a coexistence of different accounting solutions for the subjective assignment of assets, which is problematic both for specific accounting transactions and from a conceptual perspective. A uniform, transaction-based concept is lacking. Sigrun Scharenberg develops a transaction-based and appropriate systematics that enables system-conform and consistent accounting. The focus is on situations where formal legal ownership and economic content diverge, such as Factoring, Asset-backed Securities, Security Assignment, Leasing. The current accounting solutions for this are analyzed and critically evaluated using a uniformly defined risk-chance structure. Existing inconsistencies are also detailed. The final comparative analysis culminates in an aggregated solution concept. Introduction -- The IASB in the process of internationalization of accounting -- Methodological foundations and their application to IFRS accounting -- The system of IFRS accounting -- Transaction-based solution concepts for the subjective assignment of assets in the balance sheet -- Selected legal institutes in Germany and their accounting in IFRS accounting -- Derivation of a transaction-based illustration rule for IFRS accounting -- Summary and Outlook.

Calcium signal generation and transient receptor potential channel homologues in the fungal pathogen Colletotrichum graminicola : [cumulative Dissertation] ¤ Colletotrichum graminicola; calcium signaling; TRP channels; Hyphal tip growth; Aequorin luminometry; Yellow cameleon imaging; calcium channels; filamentous fungi The Object of this thesis was the hemibiotrophic filamentous fungus Colletotrichum graminicola, a pathogen of maize. The first part focuses on the relevance of Ca2+ signals for hyphal growth. Ca2+ signals precede hyphal growth re-initiation, a correlation of Ca2+ spike rate and growth was not found. The second part deals with TRPF-Channel homologues. The gene sequences of the four C. graminicola TRPF-Channel homologues (CgTRPFs) were elucidated by RACE PCR. Trans-membrane topology of all four CgTRPFs was similar to the yeast TRPY1 Ca2+ channel. CgTRPFs were expressed in axenic culture and in plant. CgTRPFs1-3 locate to small vesicular structures while CgTRPF4 resides in the vacuolar membrane. Deletion strains were generated and tested for differences vs. WT in sporulation, growth on different carbon sources, low Ca2+, osmotic stress, Ca2+ signal generation and pathogenicity. In summary no differences were found. This PhD thesis investigated the hemibiotrophic, maize-pathogenic, filamentous fungus Colletotrichum graminicola. Part One focused on the relevance of Ca2+ signals for hyphal growth: Ca2+ signals precede hyphal growth re-initiation, a correlation of Ca2+ spike rate and growth was not found. Part Two analyzed TRPF-channel homologues (CgTRPFs). Four CgTRPFs were found and their sequence elucidated. The transmembrane topology of CgTRPFs is similar to that of the yeast Ca2+ channel TRPY1. The mRNA of CgTRPFs was expressed in axenic culture and in planta. CgTRPF1-3 localize to small vesicular structures, CgTRPF4 was found in the vacuolar membrane. Deletion strains were generated and tested for differences to WT in: sporulation, growth on different carbon sources and with low Ca2+ concentration, osmotic stress, Ca2+ signal generation and pathogenicity. No differences were found. Colletotrichum graminicola; calcium signaling; TRP channels; Hyphal tip growth; Aequorin luminometry; Yellow cameleon imaging; calcium channels; filamentous fungi

Sources of uncertainty in precautionary risk assessment of mobile and potentially mobile trace elements in the soil groundwater pathway ¤ Soil-groundwater pathway, trace elements, uncertainty. - Soil-groundwater pathway, trace elements, uncertainty
Simulation Study on the Determination of Degradation of High-Reliability Metallization Systems ¤ Reliability, design of semiconductor devices

Search for Supersymmetry in single-lepton final states with the ATLAS detector and Improved background model for the search of new physics ¤ Abstract: This dissertation presents the author's contribution to the search for supersymmetric particles in final states with exactly one high-energy lepton, caused by proton-proton collisions at the ATLAS experiment of the Large Hadron Collider. Furthermore, a new method for improving background models in a search for new physics is presented

System identification of computer networks with random service ¤ System identification, performance evaluation, network calculus, TCP, WLAN, random systems, available bandwidth estimation, computer networks, effective service curve. - System identification, performance evaluation, network calculus, TCP, WLAN, random systems, available bandwidth estimation, computer networks, effective service curve.

The pecuniary loss in the embezzlement. The possibility of compensating asset outflows through illegally obtained profits. An examination in the light of recent developments in jurisdiction ¤ In a globalized, competition-oriented market environment, companies are constantly finding 'more creative' ways to increase profits, which the judiciary must evaluate from a criminal law perspective. Often, bribes are paid from the company's cash register to obtain lucrative contracts. -- Due to its abstract formulation, illegal economic activity is usually subsumed under § 266 StGB. The central question here is whether the company suffers a loss within the meaning of § 266 StGB as a result of the illegal diversion or use, or whether this enables lucrative business transactions and thus increases profits. The judiciary is inconsistent in this regard and tends to the former view. This work shows that illegally obtained profits must also be included in the balance and that the judiciary must pay greater attention to the purely economic assessment of asset inflows – also from a constitutional law perspective. / 'The pecuniary loss in the embezzlement. The possibility of compensating asset outflows through illegally obtained profits. An examination in the light of recent developments in jurisdiction': In cases of corporate embezzlement, when an employee uses company funds to obtain lucrative contracts through bribery, a central question is whether the company suffers a loss within the meaning of Section 266 StGB as a result of the bribery or whether its assets are ultimately increased by obtaining the contract. This work shows that illegally obtained profits must be included in the assessment of the economic loss and that the compensation of asset outflows must be assessed purely economically.

Twitter in German Academic Libraries ¤ Die Zahl der Internet- sowie Twitternutzer in Deutschland steigt stetig an. Der Microblogging-Dienst, Twitter, kann den Bibliotheken eine Unterstützung bei der Verbreitung von Informationen und der Vernetzung mit den Nutzern schaffen. Um den Ist-Zustand der twitternden Bibliotheken in Deutschland festzustellen, wurden 125 deutsche Hochschulbibliotheken durch eine Onlinebefragung zu der Nutzung des Dienstes befragt. Die Befragung zeigt, dass die twitternde Bibliotheken den Dienst besonders für die externe Nutzung wie z.B. Öffentlichkeitsarbeit einsetzen. Weiterhin präsentieren die Ergebnisse der Online-Befragung die Chancen und Herausforderungen des Dienstes an den Bibliotheken. The number of internet and twitter users has continuously increased in Germany. Twitter, as a microblogging service, can be used to distribute information and to shape a network to a user. 125 German academic libraries were surveyed to determine the present number of academic libraries that use Twitter. This survey demonstrates that Twitter was mainly used for external use (e.g. public relation, network to library user). Moreover, using the results this study summarises the possible chances and challenges of Twitter in academic libraries.

A temperature-dependent thermodynamic model for the H+ - NH+4 - Na+ - SO2-4 - NO-3 - Cl- - H2O system ¤ Atmospheric aerosol particles play a significant role in various questions of air purification. A substantial part of their mass is formed by inorganic components such as sulfate, ammonium, and nitrate, which are supplemented in the marine planetary boundary layer, inter alia, by sodium and chloride. The effect of an aerosol is dependent on the phase state of the particles, their water content, and the partitioning of volatile components between the gas and particle phase. A thermodynamic model is used to determine these properties...

CRIC: Context-based Recommendation of Unstructured Texts in Real-time Environments: A Procedure for Determining the Semantic Proximity of Text Objects Based on a Heuristic Asymmetric Distance Measure ¤ The idea of automatically linking content-related texts to each other is not new. The solution approach presented in this work pursues two main goals: working automatically based on unstructured texts and supporting a high number of simultaneous accesses. It differs from other procedures essentially by determining the semantic distance between the texts based on an asymmetric pre-calculated distance matrix. The relationships between unstructured text objects are established using a heuristic algorithm independent of the national language for feature selection. The resulting 'word cloud' is then used as a query parameter for the selection of suitable texts. Content-related texts are recommended to the user for the text currently displayed. The processing speed of the procedure was analyzed in the form of the time complexity of the algorithms. In addition, extensive practice tests were carried out on the website of an industrial magazine over a period of 12 months to test the efficiency of the procedure in terms of the quality of the recommendations. The results show that the presented approach is almost on par with the manually created recommendations of professional editors.

Process Management in Indirect Areas: Empirical Investigation and Recommendations for Action ¤ Functional dimensions of process management in indirect areas -- Empirical investigation of indirect areas -- Recommendations for action. Christian Hilmer examines the question of whether uncovered deficits in existing concepts of management theory can be remedied or at least mitigated by integrating existing and new knowledge of process management. The focus of the investigation lies on the analytically and empirically derived derivation of specific recommendations for action for the management of indirect processes. The presented research results provide a theoretically and empirically founded concept for process management in indirect areas. The instruments and methods of process management used are presented and scientifically evaluated in the context of their influencing factors. The author translates the challenges derived from these findings into practice-oriented recommendations for action. The content • Functional dimensions of process management in indirect areas • Empirical investigation of indirect areas • Recommendations for action The target groups • Lecturers and students of business sciences with a focus on corporate management, organization, and process management • Professionals and executives in companies in the areas of process management and organization The author Christian Hilmer was promoted by Univ.-Prof. Dr. Dr. habil. Wolfgang Becker at the Chair of Business Administration, in particular Corporate Management and Controlling at the Otto-Friedrich University of Bamberg and is active as a management consultant and lecturer.

Zeolitic Filters and Membranes in Gas Sensing ¤ Metal oxide gas sensors are widely used today in large quantities to detect flammable and toxic gases in various industrial and everyday life applications. However, the gas-sensitive metal oxide layers used in the sensors are almost exclusively sensitive to multiple gases, resulting in false readings and even false alarms. The reason for this is similar interactions of different gases with the metal oxide surface. In the present dissertation, the use of zeolitic filters and membranes is used to reduce the cross-sensitivity of commercial methane gas sensors to ethanol. These sensors, which are based on sensitive tin dioxide layers, are mainly used in gas warning systems (mining, industry, household). Zeolites (e.g. ZSM-5, Zeolite-A) exhibit excellent catalytic properties and high thermal and chemical stability. They are therefore particularly suitable for use as active filters in front of the gas-sensitive layers of gas sensors. Crystalline zeolite powders are obtained in the work as end products of a series of hydrothermal syntheses. Subsequently, the crystals were partially modified by ion exchange. However, it is technologically more sensible to use zeolite membranes supported on carriers for the use of zeolites as filter material in gas sensors. By a new variant of the in-situ synthesis of zeolite layers on porous carriers made of aluminum oxide and titanium dioxide substrates, the membranes were defect-free produced and also further modified by ion exchange. Zeolite powders and membranes were structurally characterized in numerous investigations. Their catalytic properties were comprehensively tested and documented by means of the conversion of ethanol on acidic zeolites. The suitability of the generated zeolitic membranes for the separation of gas species was confirmed by permeation measurements. The modified zeolites and zeolitic membranes proved themselves in sensor investigations as active filters for the selective detection of methane in various methane-ethanol gas mixtures.

Intellectual property related generic defense strategies in the European pharmaceutical market : implications of the EU Commission's sector inquiry from an IP, competition law and economic perspective ¤ Das Buch wertet die Untersuchung des Arzneimittelsektors der Europäischen Kommission aus. Im Mittelpunkt dieser Untersuchung stehen die Praktiken der Pharmaunternehmen, den Wettbewerb durch Generika und die Entwicklung konkurrierender Originalpräparate zu verhindern bzw. zu erschweren.
