Die interdisziplinäre Arbeit gibt den Entscheidungsträgern der Pharmaindustrie wertvolle Hinweise welche Auswirkungen die Untersuchung hat

Two-Level Optimization with Discrete Lower and Continuous Upper Level ¤ In the dissertation, tasks of two-level optimization with discrete lower and continuous upper level are considered. The structure of these tasks is analyzed and optimality conditions are given. This is done both for the optimistic and pessimistic solution approach as well as for a solution approach via selection functions. Subsequently, the theoretical results are applied to three different task classes.

The Era of Datafication: Media Innovation as a Change of Media Typologies ¤ Introduction -- Media and mediated communication -- Innovation -- Media innovation as change -- The four media typologies -- Quinary media -- Conclusion -- Bibliography. In an era of algorithmic decisions, where precise predictions and personalized recommendations are calculated by data-driven devices, human daily life is no longer only mediated, dematerialized, or digitally transformed, but has been undergoing a datafication process for several years. New technologies such as Big Data analyses, the use of smart objects and services, or artificial intelligence are driving the development of increasingly powerful media. At the same time, these media have grown into hunters and collectors of data. Kira Krüger first extends the established theories of the classification of media typologies established by Harry Pross and expanded by Manfred Faßler, and complements them extensively. Because society has long arrived in the era of datafication, which is shaped by a new media typology, namely the so-called quinary media. The author Kira Krüger has been promoted in media studies at Humboldt University of Berlin with a focus on innovations as a change of media and communication, particularly considering digital transformation and datafication. Professionally, she works as a consultant in innovation consulting for future-oriented projects that want to change the economy and society in the long term.

Redistribution Effects of the German Healthcare System: A Microsimulation Study ¤ The German healthcare system is undergoing a transformation. This transformation is primarily evident in the public and scientifically guided discussion on the reorganization of the healthcare system's financing, which is dominated by the concepts of statutory health insurance and the lump sum. The financial changes resulting from these concepts for private households, health insurance funds, and other institutions remain largely unquantified. The methodology developed in this work for the analysis of effects and redistribution enables the evaluation of these changes from an individual, institutional, and macroeconomic perspective. For the evaluation, a computer-based microsimulation model of the German tax and social security system is specified, the

A contribution to understanding the recently enhanced coastal siltation in the German Wadden Sea ¤ The impact of human activity on the world's unique coastal system, the Wadden Sea, has permanently changed the coastline and morphology of this system over the last centuries. Stakeholders and harbor operators in the coastal area have been complaining about steadily increasing sedimentation for decades. The task of this dissertation was (1) to find evidence of increasing sedimentation in the period from 1996 to 2016 and (2) to investigate possible cause-and-effect relationships. A topography analysis initially confirmed this by the increase in average mudflat height and sediment volume in the mudflat area. These morphological changes had an impact on the properties of the tide, particularly through decreasing flow velocities, longer slack water duration, and decreasing flood dominance. A reduction in tidal flat volume and higher, broader mudflats likely reduced the energy of waves and tide, which favored sedimentation. The Wadden Sea on the Northwestern European Shelf is world's largest channel-shoal system that comprises broad coherent intertidal flats, islands, shoals, and several estuaries. Coastal management has shaped the Wadden Sea's coastline and its estuaries for centuries which is why navigational channel dredging and coastline maintenance have become routine coastal engineering tasks. Since the 2010s, German coastal stakeholders reported further enhanced coastal siltation. My research objectives were (1) to identify whether there was quantifiable evidence of enhanced coastal siltation and (2) to find the driving processes behind this development. An analysis of bathymetry data confirmed that intertidal flats accreted and that lateral expansion and subtidal deepening occurred. Balanced subtidal and intertidal sediment budgets suggested a redistribution of local subtidal sediments to intertidal flats. In addition, surface sediment data indicated a gradually increasing mudflat coverage over time. Based on this information, numerical modeling and observational data were used to quantify changes in tidal and non-tidal forcing: I found near-constant wind-wave and storm surge conditions which indicated that event-driven phenomena were an unlikely driver. Spatial tidal analysis and observational data revealed amplitude and phase shifts of principle and shallow water tidal constituents which reflected in increased tidal amplitude, and reduced flood dominance. Furthermore, diminishing flood flow velocity and increased slack duration were noted. These phenomena were related to increased relative intertidal storage and to subtidal deepening from bathymetry evolution. Hence, the reduction in channel volume and the intertidal accretion likely decreased tidal and wave energy on the tidal flats and enabled the deposition of more fines. Longer flood and ebb slack duration should add to this effect. The import of sand into the coastal zone was likely reduced as flood dominance diminished at the entire study site.

Improving attitudes towards geometric proof through a suggested story-based dynamic geometry approach ¤ In this work, an approach is presented and explored, in which students are presented with geometric problems through a daily story using dynamic geometry software. This is intended to enable them to recognize the importance of geometry for everyday life, to experience the process of formulating geometric statements and hypotheses together, and to perceive geometric proofs as something that goes beyond the mere confirmation of the correctness of geometric theorems. They begin with the real situation and are guided through seven steps to geometric proofs. The content of the teaching material is structured in a tiered manner, with each unit being a prerequisite for the next, either geometric-structurally or embedded in the story.

Organisation-related Participation in Criminal Law: The Statutory Behavior of Organizational Crimes and the Phenomenon of Terrorism Financing ¤ Main description: In the present work, the provisions of §§ 84, 85 StGB, § 20 Abs. 1 Nr. 1 to 4 VereinsG, and §§ 129, 129a StGB are presented as a unified complex of organizational crimes. The focus of this consideration is on the specifically organization-related participation. By this view, the organization is reduced to an environment in which the participatory behavior takes place. With this perspective, Natalia Eroshkina turns against the group-dynamic explanatory approach of organizational crimes. In particular, the work presents the organizational criminal law in connection with the constitutional limits of the freedom of association according to Art. 9 Abs. 2 GG and shows the attribution structure of participation in an association and its manifestation in the system of organization-specific participatory roles. Finally, the protection of legal interests by organizational criminal law is critically questioned. This criticism demands a revision of the protective directions of organizational crimes and the development of the delict structure in the background of the question of how organization-related participatory behavior can impair legal interests in a real cumulative attack. To exemplify the elaborated differences of organizational crimes in relation to further forms of punishable joint action and to single perpetrator offenses, the author links to the phenomenon of terrorism financing.

Determinants of Mode Choice ¤ Transport, transport policy, road construction, public transport, Deutsche Bundesbahn are keywords that are constantly present in our media and attract a lot of public attention. This is not surprising due to the 'everyman' quality of transport. Almost everyone participates in the transport phenomenon and experiences the positive mobility effects, but also the negative ones in the form of congestion or environmental impact. In addition, transport is an input for most production processes. This central social position of transport requires an economic consideration. In Part A, the author deals with the related questions. The focus of the work is on passenger transport, especially on public transport. -- To secure sufficient mobility as a prerequisite for economic and social exchange relationships, public transport and its promotion are an important building block in a comprehensive package of measures. If public transport is to meet the mobility needs of transport users to a greater extent, it must be strengthened in competition with the car. Only then is there a compulsion to minimize costs on the one hand and to create an attractive offer on the other. An expansion of market share through an appropriate product policy is only possible by taking into account corresponding customer preferences. -- The central task for the transport companies is therefore to understand transport users as customers and to align their strategy and organization accordingly. To do this, corresponding information must be obtained. With the help of statistical methods, it is possible to measure the utility creation of specific transport medium characteristics and provide action guidelines for acting in the market. In Part B of the work, relevant methods of applied demand research are presented and their special problem-solving capacity discussed. With the selected special procedure of conjoint analysis, new, innovative public transport concepts can be evaluated in terms of their market opportunities. This also includes finding specific user benefits from the customer's point of view that are only available to public transport or can be made available and can be 'played off' against the car. -- The empirical Part C contains an acceptance study for a new concept between public transport and motorized individual transport (MIV). It can be shown that with corresponding ...
Unpaid Work and Urban Development : Productivity, Resistance, and Effectiveness of the Everyday ¤ Urban development, unpaid work, the commons, customary rights

Alliances for Housing in the Quarter: A Format for Integrated and Cooperative Quarter Development ¤ Alliances for Housing are considered on the federal, state, and local policy level as new governance forms to develop solutions for current housing policy challenges and at the same time to integrate private economic and civil society engagement in the process. Svenja Grzesiok examines the question of what significance this new form of governance can take in quarter development. She analyzes the manifestation and potential of such alliances in the context of integrated quarter development and illuminates the goals, strategies, and action logics of the actors in the field of housing. Based on three case studies, the effects on integrated quarter development are investigated. Content Quarter-related governance Integrated and cooperative quarter development Format-oriented planning Case studies: Cologne-Kalk, Essen-Altendorf, and Dortmund-Westerfilde Quarter-crossing analysis of the model projects Target groups Lecturers and students of the departments of Geography, Sociology, Political Science, Housing Economics, Real Estate Economics Responsible persons in urban planning, quarter development, spatial planning, housing economics, municipal administration, and politics The author Svenja Grzesiok is a representative for urban planning, urban culture, city, and quarter development at the Association of Housing and Real Estate Economy Rhineland Westphalia e.V. Previously, she was at the Ruhr University Bochum as a scientific assistant at the Geographical Institute in the department of Urban and Metropolitan Studies. Quarter-related governance -- Integrated and cooperative quarter development -- Format-oriented planning -- Case studies: Cologne-Kalk, Essen-Altendorf, and Dortmund-Westerfilde -- Quarter-crossing analysis of the model projects.

Location-based Advertising in the Context of Big Data: Determinants of Consumer Acceptance ¤ Big Data and customer acceptance in the field of tension -- Determinants of customer acceptance of LBA and their impact on privacy concerns as a central research gap -- Acceptance factors of location-based advertising -- Empirical analysis of the effect of the determinants of acceptance of LBA. Claudius Warwitz shows that privacy concerns play a minor role in the decision to use location-based advertising (LBA) for consumers. On the other hand, brand attachment and trust in the LBA provider and the advertised brand are crucial for consumers to accept and use location-based advertising. As further important determinants, the author identifies brand authenticity, brand image, as well as usefulness, entertainment value, attitude, and personal relevance. In the course of the investigation, 1,237 smartphone users were surveyed regarding their LBA usage behavior for 14 brands. The content Big Data and customer acceptance in the field of tension Determinants of customer acceptance of LBA and their impact on privacy concerns as a central research gap Acceptance factors of location-based advertising Empirical analysis of the effect of the determinants of acceptance of LBA The target groups Lecturers and students of business administration with a focus on marketing, online and mobile marketing as well as advertising practitioners active in the areas of location-based advertising and mobile marketing The author Dr. Claudius Warwitz was promoted by Univ.-Prof. Dr. Christoph Burmann at the Chair for Innovative Brand Management (LiM) at the University of Bremen.

Investigation of the innate immune response of equine macrophages to bacterial lipopolysaccharide ¤ Endotoxemia, lipopolysaccharide, macrophages. - Endotoxemia, caused by gastrointestinal disturbances, is one of the most common causes of death in horses. Initiators are Gram-negative bacteria and their membrane components, particularly the immunologically active endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide, LPS). LPS is able to overcome the impaired intestinal mucosa and enter the blood circulation. The recognition of LPS by mononuclear phagocytes causes their activation, which leads to the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines as the essential triggers of sepsis and shock. The receptor complex for the recognition of bacterial...

Titan Catalysts for Intermolecular Hydroaminoalkylation of 1,3-Dienes ¤ In this work, it could be shown that a titanium-catalyzed hydroaminoalkylation of conjugated double bonds in 1,3-diene systems is possible to both branched and linear products. For this reaction at the terminal double bond of the diene systems, several catalysts could be identified as active, for example, aminopyridinato- and formamidinato-based titanium complexes and the already known catalyst Bis(indenyl)dimethyltitan from the hydroaminoalkylation of styrene. The branched products formed in the hydroaminoalkylation of 1,3-dienes with N-methylaniline could be converted in a subsequent iodine hydrogen catalyzed intramolecular hydroamination to the 1,2-disubstituted 4-methylpyrrolidines. Two diastereomers could be gained, whose ratio could be controlled by the reaction time. It could also be demonstrated that an intramolecular, hydrogen iodide catalyzed hydroamination procedure can be used to transform the branched hydroaminoalkylation products of 1,3-dienes with N-methylaniline into 1,2-disubstituted 4-methylpyrrolidines. It was possible to gain access to two diastereoisomers which were formed either as kinetic (cis) or thermodynamic (trans) products. The formation of the cis and trans products could therefore be controlled via reaction time.

4-Iminomethylpyridine : novel Azomethines and metalated 4-Iminomethylene-4H-pyridin-1-ides : reactions with Heterocumulenes and other electrophiles ¤ Novel Ca-imino-functionalized 4-alkylpyridines exhibit increased acidity of the benzyl position (Ca) compared to simple 4-alkyl derivatives such as 4-i-propyl- or 4-benzylpyridine. Deprotonation is achieved with various bases (e.g. n-BuLi, MgEt2, KHMDS, NaH) and results in the strongly mesomerically stabilized 4H-pyridin-1-ide anions. Crystal structure analyses of three metal 4H-pyridin-1-ides demonstrate a preferred coordination of the metal at the pyridine nitrogen N1. Upon reaction of lithium 4H-pyridin-1-ide LiP with various electrophiles such as heterocumulenes X=C=Y, esters, epoxides or aldehydes, addition occurs exclusively at the Ca atom. The primary adducts of CS2, PhNCO and PhNCS with LiP undergo cyclization-oxidation in the presence of a proton source and an oxidizing agent, resulting in the formation of various five-membered heterocycles (thiazoles, imidazolones, imidazolthiones). Reaction of LiP with CO2 yields the open-chain lithium pyridin-4-yliminomethylcarboxylates, which are capable of reversible CO2 fixation due to the very labile CO2 binding and can be characterized as CO2 storage materials. The results of extensive DFT studies at the B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p) level include the E/Z isomerism of azomethine 3 and anions, various coordination modes of the lithium ion at the 4H-pyridin-1-ide anion, the adducts of LiP with CO2 and the mechanism of CS2 addition to LiP.

Aegis or Achilles heel : the dilemma of homology in biopatents in the wake of Novozymes ¤ Biopatents frequently disclose sequences of polypeptides and nucleic acids in the written description. The claims often cover a homology range surrounding the disclosed sequence to get a broader protection. However, homology claims face a hurdle that they may lack support by the written description. The Supreme Court of China ruled that homology claims lack support, but a further limitation by species of origin satisfies this requirement. This study explains that homology per se should have formed the essence of such disputes. Homology dictates the skilled person’s confidence on the functionality of unknown sequences, and is involved in multiple patentability requirements. Thus, the assessment of support is not an isolated matter. Disparity of different requirements creates an unclaimable gap, and constitutes a discrimination to biotechnology. An appropriate test for the support requirement is thus furnished to confer a scope of protection commensurating to the technical contribution. Biopatents frequently disclose sequences of polypeptides and nucleic acids in the written description. The claims often cover a homology range surrounding the disclosed sequence to get a broader protection. However, homology claims face a hurdle that they may lack support by the written description. The Supreme Court of China ruled that homology claims lack support, but a further limitation by species of origin satisfies this requirement. This study explains that homology per se should have formed the essence of such disputes. Homology dictates the skilled person’s confidence on the functionality of unknown sequences, and is involved in multiple patentability requirements. Thus, the assessment of support is not an isolated matter. Disparity of different requirements creates an unclaimable gap, and constitutes a discrimination to biotechnology. An appropriate test for the support requirement is thus furnished to confer a scope of protection commensurating to the technical contribution.

LINDA : Performance Management in Networks with Service Quality Adaptation - An Example of an Ethernet Middleware ¤ This work presents a solution proposal for the realization of service quality in Ethernet networks. The central element herefor is a software system consisting of a middleware, which regulates communication in the network according to the specifications. This approach was conceived theoretically as well as practically programmed. The implementation of the solution served as a basis for the performance evaluation of the presented approach. In addition to the evaluation of the characteristic behavior of the middleware under various requirements, studies and alternatives are presented, which show how the system can be adapted in terms of the requirements that arise in larger networks. The presented solution approach offers an alternative to existing service quality functions, which are implemented via communication protocols and Ethernet hardware. The advantage of the middleware lies in the fact that it works independently of the functions of the network, so that no special specifications need to be made for the communication infrastructure. Since the realization of service quality is implemented solely through the software of the middleware, all degrees of freedom are given to adapt the service quality concept freely to individual needs.

Estimation of forest structure parameters in Mexico by integration of remote sensing and forest inventory data ¤ This work provides insights into the current possibilities and limitations of using remote sensing data for mapping forest structure at local, regional, and national levels in Mexico. In particular, the effects of multisensor and multitemporal remote sensing data on the mapping accuracy of forest structure parameters (i.e., above-ground biomass (AGB) and vegetation height) were investigated. Furthermore, the influence of quality, quantity, and spatial distribution of reference data on the modeling accuracy was investigated. To answer these questions, optical and L-band Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) remote sensing data were integrated with national forest inventory data and airborne Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) data using various modeling scenarios.

Nanotribological Investigations of Ultrathin Water Films on Hydrophobic and Hydrophilic Silicon Surfaces ¤ Water has a significant impact on the friction of moving parts in micro- and nanotechnology. The dependence of friction on the water environment and surface chemistry can be investigated using atomic force microscopy at single-point contacts. In model experiments, nanotribological properties - friction, adhesion, and long-term stability - were investigated as a function of water vapor pressure. Measurements were performed on hydrophobic, hydrogen-terminated silicon and hydrophilic and hydrophobic silicon oxide. An oxidized silicon tip was used as a probe. The friction force was characterized as a function of normal force and sliding velocity. The water vapor pressure was reduced by pumping the vacuum chamber from atmospheric pressure to 1E-8 mbar and increased by introducing water vapor into the vacuum chamber from 1E-10 to 1E-5 mbar. The water film thickness was determined separately using dynamic force spectroscopy as a function of distance. This method is based on the analysis of the amplitude and normal force component during the approach of a vertically oscillating cantilever to the probe. The friction of hydrophobic silicon and hydrophobic silicon oxide is independent of water vapor pressure. There is no water present on the surfaces. Both surfaces change to hydrophilic silicon oxide under tribological stress in a water-containing environment, resulting in a change in friction. Hydrophilic silicon oxide showed a strong dependence of friction and adhesion on water vapor pressure. During the reduction of water vapor pressure starting from atmospheric pressure, the water film thickness (from 2.6 to 0.7 nm to no measurable water), friction (from 500 to 200 to 20 nN, given for a normal force of 60 nN), and surface energy (from 556 to 434 to 21 mJ/mø) decreased stepwise over 3 regions. The velocity characteristic also changed over 3 regions. The increase in water vapor pressure is up to 1E-8 mbar associated with the reduction of friction (from 15 to 14 nN) and surface energy (from 68 to 20 mJ/mø). For pressures higher than 1E-8 mbar, friction (from 14 to 16 nJ) and surface energy (from 20 to 154 mJ/mø) increase with water vapor pressure. These properties can be correlated with the different states of water adsorption on silicon oxide. The minimum values for friction and adhesion coincide at the increase and reduction of water vapor pressure. The different time scales for water adsorption and desorption cause hysteresis for adhesion and friction during changes in water vapor pressure.

Visual Communication Research: Media Images as a Challenge for Communication and Media Science ¤ We live in a visual media culture, a 'visual culture', in which we are constantly confronted with 'images' of various kinds: advertising tries to seduce us with perfectly staged images, press photos make us eyewitnesses to distant wars and catastrophes, and politicians strive to present themselves in a camera-friendly manner. But we also capture all important events photographically in our daily lives, in order to remember them and share them with others. But how can images be deciphered? And how is the communicative 'power of images' to be explained? Katharina Lobinger defines the approach of 'Visual Communication Research' in distinction to other image sciences. In this context, the central research fields are worked out: images in journalism, in advertising, public relations, political communication, and in mediated everyday communication. In a meta-analysis, the author examines the development, establishment, and research activities of 'Visual Communication Research' over the past 20 years and shows which methods were used to produce the findings in previous research. Dr. Katharina Lobinger is a research associate at the Center for Media, Communication, and Information Research (ZeMKI) of the University of Bremen.

Investigations on the Technofunctionality of Egg Yolk Fractions in Fine Baked Goods Using Biscuit and Shortbread as Examples ¤ Egg yolk fractions, cake structure, rheology. - In fine baked goods, such as biscuit and shortbread, the egg is the most important structuring ingredient. It is valued, in addition to taste and nutritional value, primarily due to its three outstanding technofunctional properties: thermal gelation, foam-forming ability, and excellent emulsifying properties, where the egg also plays a decisive role. Egg can now be cost-effectively and on an industrial scale separated into three main fractions: low-density lipoproteins (LDL), granula, and livetine, and freeze-dried using a special process. In this way, the technofunctional properties can be fully retained and utilized. The present work aimed to develop the technofunctional properties of newly developed freeze-dried egg yolk fractions (LDL, granula, livetine) in order to use them specifically in fine baked goods (biscuit/shortbread). Furthermore, the complex relationships in thermally induced gelation of ....

Integration of a Neuro-Sensor into a Measurement System as well as Investigations on Unit Separation ¤ At the University of Rostock, a novel CMOS (Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor) sensor chip was used in the framework of a dissertation for the extracellular analysis of electrically active biological cells. This chip, in addition to a MEA (Multi-electrode array), has further FET (Field Effect Transistor)-based sensors for the capture of different cell parameters. In addition to the commissioning of this sensor, external hardware for data acquisition and algorithms for signal processing were designed and implemented. The goal was the creation of a Cell Monitor System (CMS) for the semi-automated use of the silicon-based sensor chip.

Industrial Nature Relations: Politically-Cultural Orientations of Trade Union Actors in Social-Ecological Transformation Processes ¤ Front Cover -- Table of Contents -- Acknowledgement -- Abbreviations -- Foreword: Work, Environment, and the Good Life -- 1 Perspectives on Trade Unions in the Social-Ecological Field -- 2 Ecology and Work: Strengthening Connecting Policies -- 3 Research Status -- 3.1 Environmental Sociology &amp -- Societal Nature Relations -- 3.2 Production and Lifestyle -- 3.3 Work and Ecology -- 3.4 Trade Unions, Ecology, and Quality of Life -- 4 Societal Nature Relations, Culture, and Politics -- 4.1 Work, Nature Domination, Culture -- 4.1.1 Nature and Work: Historical-Materialist Approaches -- 4.1.2 Environmental Knowledge and Nature Domination: Societal Nature Relations -- 4.1.3 Reality and Construction of Nature: Cultural-Theoretical Approaches -- 4.1.4 Understandings of Nature and Societal Change -- 4.1.5 Materiality and Meaning in Societal Nature Relations -- 4.2 The Connection between Production and Lifestyle -- 4.2.1 Economy and Culture: From 'Base and Superstructure' to 'Production and Lifestyle' -- 4.2.2 Meaning of Life Conduct and Distinction through Life Styles -- 4.2.3 Production and Reproduction -- 4.3 Cultural Approaches to Political Power -- 4.3.1 The Political Power of Norms - Moral Economy and Political Culture -- 4.3.2 Cultural Domination and Societal Transformation -- 4.3.3 Societal Nature Relations in the Struggle for Cultural and Political Power -- 4.4 Trade Unions in the Light of Societal-Theoretical Approaches -- 5 Political Culture of Trade Union Actors in the Social-Ecological Field -- 5.1 Trade Union Understandings: Social Partnership and Conflict Orientation -- 5.2 Fordist Value Configuration: Economic Miracle, Welfare Model, and Class Compromise -- 5.3 Post-Fordist Nature Relations: Ecological Modernization of Destructive Relations?

Automated Modeling of Forest Landscapes for Virtual Worlds and Mobile Robots ¤ Remote sensing data such as aerial images, terrain and surface models are now globally available and have found their place in our daily lives. On the other hand, landscape models for simulations and presentations in Virtual Reality are still often laboriously generated by hand in many cases. Arnold Bücken shows a way to derive forest landscapes on a large scale from remote sensing data in an automated procedure. The result are detailed forest models with geographically located, attributed individual trees that are suitable for a variety of simulation tasks and at the same time offer a highly detailed cartographic recording of the forest, for example for localization tasks of robotic systems. The content Efficient and realistic segmentation of individual trees from remote sensing data Attribution of trees with visualization-relevant parameters Application of forest models in simulation and localization in the closed stand The target groups Lecturers and students from the departments of Virtual Reality, Mobile Robotics, Geodata Processing and Remote Sensing Practitioners from the field of simulation and modeling The author Arnold Bücken has as group leader at the Institute for Human-Machine Interaction of the RWTH Aachen long-standing experience in the field of virtual reality and is particularly interested in the use of remote sensing data in the field of simulation as well as in applications of mobile robotics. State of the art -- Data basis -- Procedure for generating forest landscapes -- Collection of individual tree data -- Visualization -- Discussion -- Applications.-Summary.

Medien(sub)culture : Stories - Discourses - Designs ¤ The scientific analysis of the media society is often normatively shaped. Accordingly, predictable and unsatisfying are their findings and interpretations. The study by Christoph Jacke seeks ways out of this dead end by presenting innovative readings of the three prominent theoretical strands Critical Theory (Frankfurt School and successors), Cultural Studies, and sociocultural constructivism. From them, a media culture observation grid with the levels Main and Sub is prepared. The results of this new method show up in the final focusing of the central actors in the media and pop culture, the stars.

Between Biopower and Life Power: Biopolitical Thinking in Michel Foucault and Ernst Jünger ¤ Are there parallels between Michel Foucault's and Ernst Jünger's political thinking? At first glance, this seems unlikely. However, Nasser Ahmed reveals the same type of biopolitical thinking in Foucault's 'The History of Sexuality, Volume 1' and Jünger's 'The Worker' and shows how close the two approaches are. Between biopower on the one hand and life power on the other, he illuminates a space that has remained invisible in previous political categorizations: Foucault and Jünger stand as biopolitical thinkers on the same side of a fundamental division of political thinking, which understands the political less as a function of communication, but rather as a function of struggle.

Customer Service through User Information: Technical Documentation as Secondary Service in Marketing ¤ The service policy of providers of explainable investment and consumption goods includes the product-accompanying secondary service of user information, i.e., the task of providing customers/users with all the information required for complete product use. Although user information - also known as technical documentation - is a mandatory customer service with significant sales policy opportunities, this instrument is often considered the

Properties of polarized electromagnets and their dimensioning based on a design algorithm with an optimization procedure ¤ In the present work, the fundamentals and design possibilities for polarized electromagnets are investigated. First, the basic structures of polarized electromagnets are presented, suitable calculation procedures are described, and the most important properties of permanent magnet materials are presented. Further, the characteristic properties of polarized electromagnets are described and compared with neutral electromagnets. The principal approach to simulating dynamic processes of polarized electromagnets is shown. Finally, various possibilities for the dimensioning of polarized electromagnets are systematically presented. In this, a new general design procedure for the dimensioning of the main dimensions is introduced. With an extended and generally valid design algorithm compared to neutral electromagnets, the design part is completed. The presented examples serve to validate the used calculation and optimization procedures as well as the developed algorithms.

Innovation Paths: Evolution and Institutionalization of Complex Technology ¤ The innovation path model presented by Uli Meyer opens up a new perspective on the development of complex technology. It integrates insights from sociological neo-institutionalism and social evolution theories to explain how innovation paths emerge and which mechanisms stabilize and strengthen them. The presented perspective takes into account that technology is increasingly produced in stable networks of many organizations and no longer by individual organizations or inventors. Innovation paths are expressions and drivers of the increasingly routinized and entrenched search for the new. The model is developed using the example of the establishment of electronic systems in the automotive industry, particularly driver assistance systems. Content A sociological perspective on technology development and the underlying processes Innovation paths describe how concrete forms of complex technology development institutionalize and certain technological development dynamics become entrenched Driver assistance systems Electronic development in the automotive industry Target groups Researchers, lecturers, and students of sociology, particularly technology and organization sociology and innovation research Social scientists The author Dr. Uli Meyer works at the DFG Graduate College "Innovation Society Today", Institute of Sociology, Technical University of Berlin. . A sociological perspective on technology development and the underlying processes -- Innovation paths describe how concrete forms of complex technology development institutionalize and certain technological development dynamics become entrenched -- Driver assistance systems -- Electronic development in the automotive industry. .

The Cathedral of Notre-Dame in Rouen: Investigations into the Architecture of Normandy in the Early and High Gothic Period ¤ The Cathedral of Rouen, coronation site and burial place of the Norman dukes as well as the metropolitan church of Normandy, belongs to the great Gothic church buildings of the beginning of the 13th century in France. However, the long struggle between the French and English crowns for control over Normandy, which culminated in their military conquest by Philip II Augustus in 1214, leaves its mark on the building history of the cathedral just as much as the inner-city power struggle between the clergy and the emerging bourgeoisie of Rouen. A fluctuating building process with multiple replanning leads to individual solutions, in which the tense confrontation between Norman building tradition and the influences of the High Gothic of Île-de-France is manifested at the same time. - - Based on archaeological and archival investigations, the complex building history of the cathedral is reconstructed. The various building phases with their respective architectural characteristics and style features are shown to be embedded in the artistic environment of Normandy in a dense network of reciprocal relationships with other major construction sites. Questions about the responsible master builders, patrons, and founders as well as the liturgical use are added. The Cathedral of Rouen proves to be a multifaceted mirror of a traditional art landscape in times of historical upheaval

Convexity properties of moment maps of real forms acting on Kählerian manifolds ¤ Let X be a compact connected Kähler manifold with a holomorphic action of a complex reductive Lie group, such that the action of the maximal compact subgroup U is Hamiltonian, i.e., there exists a moment map for this action. In the present work, we consider projections of this moment map onto subspaces associated to compatible real subgroups G of the above complex Lie group. In particular, we are interested in convexity properties of the image of this new map. A main result is a convexity theorem in the integral projective case for any closed G-stable irreducible semialgebraic subsets of the projective space. As special cases, we obtain classical convexity theorems of Guillemin-Sternberg and Mumford, as well as convexity assertions for complex flag manifolds.

Analysis of Telemetry Signals and Radar Return Signals for Reconstruction of Orbital Perturbations of Interplanetary Spacecraft, exemplified by the simulated descent dynamics of the Huygens Probe ¤ The Cassini/Huygens Mission is a joint venture between NASA and ESA, aiming to explore the Saturn system. The present work was carried out within the framework of the Doppler Wind Experiment. The goal of the work was to develop a method for determining the equilibrium position and amplitude of the pendulum movement of the Huygens probe during the descent on the Saturn moon Titan. The available data are the Doppler frequency shift and the reception power of the telemetry signal. In addition, there is the return signal of the radar altimeter. With the information of the telemetry signal, a deterministic approach and a stochastic approach were developed to determine the parameters of the pendulum movement, depending on whether the measurement data provide sufficient information about the movement, or whether a periodicity of the movement is present. With the return signal of the radar altimeter, an interactive procedure was developed in addition to this purpose.

Symmetrization procedures for the isoperimetric problem in symmetric spaces of noncompact type ¤ In the present work, a new symmetrization procedure for the isoperimetric problem in symmetric spaces of noncompact type is developed. This is a generalization of the Steiner symmetrization in the Euclidean space. Unlike in the classical case, the symmetrized region is obtained by solving a nonlinear partial differential equation. Finally, possible applications of the procedure to the isoperimetric problem are discussed.

Biologically inspired microtechnological tools for microassembly and minimal-invasive surgery ¤ BEGIN \"Natur findet die Form". Die konstruktiven Eigenschaften und Funktionsprinzipien der Lebewesen wurden in Millionen Jahren Evolution durch Spezialisierung erworben. Bionik verbindet so die Biologie mit der Technik und gibt als Methode der Umsetzung von Funktionsprinzipien biologischer Systeme dem Konstrukteur eine von der Evolution begründete Logik in die Hand. - In der Mikrosystemtechnik ist eine Vielfalt von Mikrokomponenten entwickelt worden. In der Kombination verschiedener Mikroteile zu einem hybriden System besteht das nächste Forschungsziel. Das Manipulieren dieser Mikrokomponenten ist eine der Schlüsseltechnologien für die weitere Systemintegration. Die Einbeziehung bionischer Entwurfskriterien in die Greifer- und Manipulationstechnik stellt anwendungsorientierte Erweiterungen der Greifer-Grundstruktur nach dem Vorbild biologischer Systeme bereit. - Mundwerkzeuge von Wirbellosen bieten in ihrer modellhaften Abstraktion Anregungen für die Konstruktion des Greifmechanismus und der Greifer-Wirkflächengestaltung. Sie sind - unter Maßgabe der Spezifik der Mikrodimension - störungstolerant und nachgiebig. In der Mikrosystemtechnik werden die monolithischen Getriebe durch nachgiebige Mechanismen realisiert. - Glastechnologie mit fotoempfindlichem Glas, FOTURAN, wurde gewählt für die Fertigung des Greifers. Ein Mikrogreifer mit linearer Kraft-Auslenkung-Kennlinie wurde hergestellt. - Ein strömungsunterstütztes Ätzverfahren wurde entwickelt, mit dem tiefe Strukturen mit einer Wandneigung von ca. 1ʿ in 2mm Glas realisiert wurden. Auf der Basis der 2mm-Glastechnologie wurden Greifer mit Piezostapel-Aktuatoren entwickelt. Der Einsatz der Finite-Elemente-Methode (FEM) ermöglichte die Optimierung der Gestaltung von mikrostrukturierten Festkörpergelenken für die Realisierung einer großen Auslenkung mit möglichst reduzierter mechanischer Spannung. Ein Greifweg von 2(400æm konnte von den beiden Greifarmen realisiert werden. - Nach dem Prinzip der Flügelkopplung einer Wanze (Graphosoma spec.) wird Silikon-Elastomer eingesetzt, um die Funktionsteile durch ein elastisches Gelenk zu verbinden. Damit wird der Bewegungsbereich der Funktionsteile, unter Verminderung der Bruchgefahr, wesentlich größer. - Mit

Thanks for Your Entry in the Logbook : Literary Mass Communication in the Social Web ¤ Summary: This work examines various variants of literary mass communication in the Social Web. After an introductory chapter, which also explains the technical conditions of online communication, the peculiarities of mass communication on various platforms of the Social Web are highlighted. In the main part of the dissertation, the author presents various projects of literary mass communication, including literature on Twitter, serialized novels on Facebook, literature and secondary literary communication on literature platforms, as well as literary communication on blogs and much more. In this context, the special production conditions are highlighted, the texts are subjected to an analysis, and the distribution and subsequent communication via social channels are addressed. In a concluding chapter, the specific appeal of participating in literary online mass communication in the Social Web is worked out. The work understands itself as a broad analysis of a previously little-noticed field of literary communication

The Knowledge Problem in Asylum Law: Between Material Control Deficits and Europeanization ¤ When making an asylum decision, the legal practitioner is faced with the task of determining social and political circumstances abroad. These are questions that cannot be answered by a mere interpretation of legal texts, but require the generation and processing of factual knowledge. Due to the material control concept of German administrative law, this presents a (knowledge) problem for German asylum law dogmatics. The presentation of the shortcomings of established dogmatics, taking into account the Europeanization of migration law, is just as much a topic of this book as the proposal of a re-conceptualization for a partial solution to the asylum law knowledge problem.

Inter-kingdom communication in the marine environment : bacterial modulation of growth, sexual reproduction and biofilm formation of marine microalgae ¤ Microalgae, and particularly diatoms, play a fundamental ecological role and have a wide range of industrial and technological applications. In recent years, research in chemical ecology and biotechnology has focused on molecular mechanisms that regulate the interaction between algae and bacteria. This dissertation investigates the bacterial modulation of sexual reproduction and growth of the pennate model diatom Seminavis robusta. By combining metabolomics and transcriptomics approaches, as well as physiological bioassays and targeted analyses, we discovered novel interactions between algae and bacteria. The bacteria associated with the S. robusta mating type – (MT-) have different influences on the sexual reproduction of diatoms. Bacteria have a special influence on the amino acid metabolism of S. robusta and trigger an oxidative stress reaction in diatoms. Furthermore, they influence the growth and metabolism of another microalga, Nannochloropsis sp., but do not induce biofilm production in bioreactors. These findings are important to understand the outstanding importance of algae-bacteria communication from the perspective of algal cultivation and production. This could promote the use of microbial communities with increased productivity in bioreactors. To better discover signal molecules transmitted through water, we finally developed a new, non-destructive method for the extraction of primary and secondary metabolites from algal surfaces. The results of this dissertation show new insights in the relatively young field of microalgae-bacteria interactions, by applying and linking various approaches (omics techniques, physiological bioassays, innovative analytical procedures) in a broad interdisciplinary approach.
The role of microRNA-155 in innate immunity and immunopathology ¤ Abstract: In the last 10 years, microRNA (miR) research has

Investigation of the Membrane Potential of Smooth Muscle Cells of the Abomasal Musculature and its Influence by Ketone Bodies, Calcium and Potassium ¤ Abomasal displacement, membrane potential, smooth musculature. - Abomasal displacement (AD) of cattle is a widespread disease of the gastrointestinal tract in high-performance dairy herds, whose pathogenesis is not fully clarified. Ketosis, hypocalcemia, and hypokalemia are often associated with reduced abomasal motility, without being able to name possible causal relationships. The goal of this work was to provide a contribution to the clarification of the pathogenesis of AD. To this end, the fluctuations in the membrane potential, so-called slow waves, were first characterized by microelectrode technique as the basis of contraction of smooth muscle cells in the abomasum of various ruminants, in order to investigate in the further course of the work a possible influence of slow waves by different calcium concentrations, β-hydroxybutyrate (BHB) as ketone bodies and barium as potassium channel blocker. In the final part, the results of the intracellular recordings were also checked on the level of contraction activity by in vitro motility measurements. For the microelectrode measurements as well as for the in vitro motility measurements, muscle samples of the circular muscle layer of the abomasal wall were prepared and incubated in buffer solutions. For the microelectrode measurements, a total of 23 bulls were tested. The time course of membrane potential fluctuations was measured in solutions with 1.2 mmol/l CaCl2 as well as with 2.4 mmol/l CaCl2. In addition, the effect of 5 mmol/l BHB (under hypo- and normocalcemic conditions) and 2 mmol/l barium chloride (under hypocalcemic conditions) was tested. The samples of the total 13 slaughter animals were only measured in buffer solutions with 1.2 mmol/l CaCl2 in the time course, under the influence of 5 mmol/l BHB and with 2 mmol/l barium chloride. Also from goats, samples of the abomasal wall were available. These were divided into two groups: 4 goats had been fed under normocalcemic conditions and were considered as a control group, which was only measured with buffer solution and 2.4 mmol/l CaCl2, while the second group, 5 goats, were exposed to a restrictive calcium supply...

Multicomponent 3D-printing for core-shell capsule composites and supramolecular polymers ¤ 3D print, Fused deposition modeling, Polymers, Supramolecular, Capsule, Click, Copper, Mechanophore, Polyisobutylene, Encapsulation The critical manufacturing process is the simultaneous build up of capsule shell and liquid core filling in a layer by layer approach for micrometer sized capsules. As a proof of concept “click”-reaction systems, based on liquid trivalent resin monomers, are manufactured. PCL composites with nano- and micro-fillers are combined with reactive liquids. The 3D-printed core-shell capsule composite can be used for post-printing reactions. With a similar approach, stress‐sensing materials, based on high- and low molecular weight mechanophores are manufactured. Another concept for 3D-printing multi-material composites is based on hydrogen-bonded supramolecular polymers. The printability is relies on reversible thermal- and shear-induced dissociation of the supramolecular interactions, which generates stable and self-supported structures after 3D-printing. The supramolecular PIB polymers showed a rubber like behavior and were able to form self-supported 3D-printed objects at room temperature.

Reverse-conductive IGBT with nearly gate-emitter voltage independent diode characteristic ¤ In this dissertation, a novel Trench RC-IGBT concept, called RC-GID-IGBT, is proposed. This new RC-IGBT structure allows operation with a conventional IGBT gate drive and has reverse recovery charge in diode operating mode as low as a state-of-the-art freewheeling diodes. This is achieved by introducing dedicated areas for the diode operation as well as an auxiliary schottky emitter into the IGBT chip without generating negative electrical effects on the IGBT mode. As a result, the novel RC-GID-IGBT can take full advantage of the thermal benefit.

Targeted Micro- and Nano-Integration of DNA and DNA-Superstructures in Micro-Structured Chip Layouts ¤ In this work, techniques for the targeted integration of DNA molecules were presented and optimized. This enables the use of DNA as a scaffold molecule for nanoscale, electrical components. Subsequent metallic functionalization is necessary. DNA-based nano-construction (bottom-up) was performed using self-assembly. This allows for precise, guided integration of DNA into existing top-down microstructures, as well as subsequent functionalization (biomolecular). The use of assembled DNA superstructures (G-wires) as a biomolecular building block could also be shown in addition to long DNA molecules. Through precise correlative characterization of the integrated structures during and after the integration steps, optimization and establishment could be achieved up to the integration of DNA single molecules using dielectrophoresis. The integration of lambda-DNA was transferred from the layer silicate glimmer onto glass and silicon substrates. On unstructured substrates, stretching was performed using the method of drying droplets. Different surface properties have an impact on the stretching behavior of DNA molecules. Further decisive factors are the droplet size and the DNA concentration. The optimum lies at a DNA concentration of 6 ng/mL and a droplet volume of 0.5 ?L. On microstructured substrates, the efficiency of electrode bridging with DNA strands depends decisively on the DNA concentration and the preferred direction during drying. Single-molecule bridges can be realized at low DNA concentrations.

Investigation of Planting Variants and Filter Zone Perfusion of Small Ponds ¤ Abstract: The present work investigates the interactions of various planting and perfusion variants of swimming pool filters with the water quality of the free water and the filling water demand as well as the aesthetics and vitality of the planting, in order to find solution approaches for the following problems in the operation of private swimming pools: - unwanted growth of filamentous algae due to a too high total phosphorus content. - lack of vitality and damage patterns in the usual planting of swimming pool filters, caused by nitrogen deficiency. - The processed research goals are: 1. Reduction of algal growth in the swimming pool by plant mixtures with low transpiration, which reduces the required filling water volume and the associated phosphorus input. 2. Reduction of filamentous algae development by influencing the water hardness through sphagnum planting 3. Development of a vital, functional and aesthetically appealing planting. - The data used in the work were collected in a test facility consisting of 24 swimming pool models with free water and planted filter area. The planting variants "no planting", "calciferous moor", "high moor" and "conventional" were tested in combination with the perfusion variants "no perfusion", "from top to bottom" and "from bottom to top" using visual assessments, investigations of relevant water parameters and determination of filling water volume and algal dry mass. - From the results of the work, the following recommendations are derived: - By planting with peinomorphic growth form moor plants, the filling water demand and the associated phosphorus input can be reduced. - By planting the filter surface with suitable sphagnum species, the hardness of the pool water can be reduced and a lower filamentous algae occurrence can be achieved. - Plant mixtures from oligotrophic plant species of calciferous moors form a vital, sustainable and optically appealing target vegetation for nutrient-poor swimming pools.

Integration of Electric Drives in Mobile Agricultural Machinery ¤ Introduction -- Integration of drives in mobile agricultural machinery -- Drive systems in mobile agricultural machinery -- Decision-making aids for evaluating drive chains -- Research and developments on electric drives in agricultural machinery -- Development study of the integration of functions for the drum drive -- Test stand investigations for determining the characteristic curves.-Labor experiments for functional testing in the material flow -- Summary -- Outlook. In the present book, the integration of functions is explained and implemented using the example of an electric drive in mobile agricultural machinery. So far, the integration of functions has not been carried out in mobile agricultural machinery. The drive types mechanics, hydraulics, and electricity were compared and evaluated with each other according to various evaluation criteria. The state of the art of electric drives in agricultural machinery was comprehensively and completely researched and described from the first use in the 19th century to the present day. With introduced and calculated complexity costs, the complexity of an electric drive chain can be estimated in the concept phase compared to the usual mechanical drive chain. The functionally integrated electric drive was compared with the state of the art and with data taken in the field in the test stand and laboratory. The advantages of the integration of electric drives are described as better power density and power-to-weight ratio. The higher construction effort and the currently high material costs for electric drives are disadvantageous. The author Dr.-Ing. Wolfgang Aumer studied electrical engineering and information technology with a focus on methods of automation technology. He was a scientific employee at the Chair of Agricultural Systems Technology at the Technical University of Dresden.

The Sarrabus-Gerrei Ore Province (SE-Sardinia/Italy) and its Geological Framework ¤ Table of Contents: The first part of the work presents the geological framework of the Sarrabus-Gerrei Ore Province. The actual focus, however, lies in the investigation of the facies dependencies of the mineralizations in the Silurian black shales and in the description of their complex tectono-metamorphic development during the Variscan orogeny.

Materia prima : On the Semantics of the Concept in Natural Science Manuscripts of the 16th Century ¤ Materia prima as physical principle of existence -- Materia prima as pre-physical principle of existence -- Mataria prima as metaphysical principle of existence Katharina Dück devotes this book to the extensive doctrine of the concept „Materia prima“ in the field of tension between theory and repeatable practice in German-language alchemical-natural science manuscripts of the 16th century. She contributes new aspects to the debate on materialism in the Early Modern Period. Texts of so-called master thinkers as well as testimonies of those who have been little considered so far are examined. Special attention is paid to the Corpus Paracelsicum and the Paracelsian current. Three raster-like outlined basic patterns, to which the „Materia prima“-conceptions are assigned, are presented in detail and the continuities and transformations of existing matter concepts are found. The content Materia prima as physical principle of existence Materia prima as pre-physical principle of existence Mataria prima as metaphysical principle of existence The target groups Lecturers and students of philosophy, German studies, medical history, and the history of early modern chemistry and medicine Medical doctors and chemists with historical interest The author The author is a science philosopher and linguist in the department of central research at the Leibniz Institute for German Language in Mannheim

On the Regulation and Function of Polyamine Biosynthesis in Cultured Rat Hepatocytes ¤ This work presents protein synthesis as the primary point of attack of polyamine action. The results are discussed in the context of the vitalizing and differentiation-promoting effect of glucocorticoids on hepatocyte primary cultures.

The influence of ceramic particles on texture formation during hot rolling of magnesium wrought alloys ¤ The influence of ceramic particles on texture formation during hot rolling of magnesium wrought alloys has been investigated. The starting material for deformation has been produced by casting. For this purpose basic experiments concerning the fabrication of particle modified alloys in gravity die casting were necessary. Agglomeration of particles proved to be a central problem. AZ31 based alloys have been selected for an application oriented rolling procedure. The desired weakening of the texture of the sheet material could not be accomplished. This is because the deformation degree obtained in the passes of a conventional nonisothermal rolling process is too low to activate mechanisms like particle stimulated nucleation. Furthermore the content and morphology of the ceramic particles could be identified as critical parameters for texture weakening. The findings of this work expand the state of knowledge concerning the influence of particles on recrystallization of magnesium wrought alloys and allows for a more purposeful development of alloys with improved texture formation. END

Cost-effective and comparable monitoring components : an interdisciplinary approach based on remote sensing, landscape structure assessment and social research for Bach Ma National Park, Vietnam ¤ Monitoring, Vietnam, Landscape structure, Empirical social research, National park, Protected area, Landsat, Landscape monitoring, Landscape structure analysis, Bach Ma National Park, interdisciplinary, RapidEye, Landscape Monitoring, Landscape Metrics, Social research, Remote sensing, Protected area management All human activities have transformed one-third to one-half of the Earth's land surface. There is a strong correlation of human well-being with ecosystem function, including poverty alleviation programs as well as enhancements of the health sector. To assess and evaluate the progress and outcome of initiatives stringent periodic observation is necessary. The presented approach combines the strengths of remote sensing and GIS analysis with social research applications. The Bach Ma National Park as an area under investigation was designated as protected area in 1991 and extended in 2008. The national park is uninhabited, but in the surrounding buffer zones approximately 62,000 to 79,000 people live in rural areas and in mostly impoverished conditions. The comprehensive nature conservation efforts of the Vietnamese Government during the last two decades has led to growing forest coverage of both plantation and natural forests. Nevertheless, the decreasing biodiversity and ongoing illegal logging and hunting activities in the national park are seen as major threats to conservation initiatives in the future. The remote sensing component consists of an analysis of a time series of Landsat images with seven steps ranging from 1973 to 2010. The resulting land cover analysis had 13 different classes. The accuracy assessment revealed an overall accuracy ranging from 84 to 90%. The basis for the second monitoring component was the Landsat images. A total of 25 different ...

Computer Graphics : On the History and Production Aesthetics of Synthetic Images ¤ There are numerous procedures for generating digital images. However, this diversity makes it difficult to distinguish digital photographs, AI, or CGI images from one another. Carolin Scheler presents a fundamentally new approach to aesthetically analyzing digital image products using the example of 3D computer graphics. Starting from the production process, she describes computer graphics as an independent expression procedure and works out an inherent ideological conception of realism in computer-generated images. It becomes clear: In computer graphics software development, a specific world feeling is always inscribed - with effects on the relationship between image and reality.

Quality of the Auditor's Examination: Influence of the Mandate Duration on the Accounting Policy of the Client ¤ The question of how a statutory limitation of the mandate duration of the auditor contributes to an increase in the quality of the examination has been the subject of a controversial discussion for more than 30 years. The debate on such external rotation of auditors was triggered by numerous accounting scandals in recent years, which have led to doubts about the quality of the audit. Daniela Wiemann analyzes for the first time in an empirical study the influence of the mandate duration of the auditor on the examination quality for Germany. To measure the examination quality, she examines the accounting policy in the audited consolidated financial statements of the companies listed in the CDAX.

The Constitutionalization of International Law from a Systems-Theoretical Perspective ¤ The book deals with the question of the constitutionalization of international law and illuminates this from a systems-theoretical perspective. The work first intensively deals with the systems theory of Niklas Luhmann and then analyzes both prevailing constitutionalization and fragmentation tendencies. In detail, the approach of the so-called Societal Constitutionalism is addressed and the main thesis of the representatives of this approach is critically evaluated. Finally, the work illuminates the constitutionalization of international law under systems-theoretical aspects and investigates to what extent an autonomous or even autopoietic law and politics system exists on an international level and whether these two systems are connected by a kind of structural coupling analogous to the national state level. In essence, the work affirms the existence of a structural coupling and thus also a constitutionalization at least in a weakened form Introduction -- 1. Theoretical Foundations - Systems Theory of Niklas Luhmann -- 2. Constitutionalization in International Law -- 3. Fragmentation -- 4. Pluralistic Conceptions of Global Order -- 5. Societal Constitutionalism -- 6. Constitutionalization from a Systems-Theoretical Perspective -- Conclusion

Ecological Consumer Information: Foundations, Methods, and Effectiveness Opportunities ¤ Increasing environmental problems are the burden that the past has transferred to the new millennium. It remains questionable what ecological role the demander should have and with what means an environmentally friendly consumer behavior can be promoted. Economic foundations on the costs and benefits of ecological action on the one hand, socio-psychological interdependencies and psychology of consumer behavior on the other hand form the scientific poles of the present investigation. Effective behavior corrections are linked to the convictions of the individual consumer regarding the results of his actions, the expectations of others as well as the individually to be mastered barriers. The empirical results show where the promising focal points of ecological consumer information lie. It is about an information that is oriented towards the needs of consumers, which answers application-related questions in detail in quick access, accentuates positive achievements instead of failures and refrains from general moralizing. This information is not only demanded by the state and consumer and environmental associations, but also by the companies in a pressing manner

Behavioral Changes and Organizational-Technical Optimizations - A Strong Team for Energy Savings: Experiences and Insights from Psychological Studies on Energy Consumption Behavior at Universities ¤ Summary: In times of looming climate change, rising energy prices, and tight budgets, exploring all possibilities for the most efficient use of energy is a fundamental social and economic obligation. Universities play a special role in this regard due to various factors. As numerous initiatives show, the political and social goal of sustainable development has also found its way into universities. In particular, measures to reduce energy consumption can help universities maintain or even expand their financial leeway, which is becoming increasingly narrow due to rising consumption and prices for energy, despite a fixed budget and a high proportion of fixed costs. While technically oriented measures such as renovations or an energy-optimized building operation are associated with significant potential, they may encounter obstacles in financial, structural, organizational, or technical areas. In addition to these potential, others are often available that can be accessed with minimal investment measures and changes in user behavior. The exploration of user needs, goals, and actions in relation to their respective spatial, social, and cultural environment and corresponding possibilities for voluntary energy-saving measures are genuine psychological tasks.

Biomechanical Analysis of the Level Locomotion of Ancylometes Bogotensis (Keyserling, 1877) (Chelicerata, Arachnida, Lycosoidea) ¤ Spider legs are characterized by their bow-shaped configuration and are unique in the animal kingdom due to their hydraulic stretching mechanism. So far, it has been assumed for spiders that there is a stereotypical, speed-independent gait pattern and that the hydraulic mechanism plays an essential role in power generation. The global kinematics and individual leg-ground reaction forces of the continuous and accelerated, level locomotion of the South American running spider Ancylometes bogotensis were investigated. In this process, three gait patterns could be distinguished on the basis of discontinuous speed dependencies of various kinematic parameters. The directions of the ground reaction force vectors show that the hydraulic mechanism does not significantly contribute to the generation of ground reaction forces in either continuous or accelerated locomotion.

Planning method for integration and expansion of renewable energy sources with special attention to security supply in distribution system ¤ The current structure of the power grid and the power markets promote the introduction of new energy producers and products. Due to the variability of prices for fossil fuels on the world market, which already takes into account their impending increasing scarcity, the implementation of policies to control the reduction of CO2 emissions and a more efficient use of energy must be incorporated into new grid expansion projects. They force new forms of expansion of the power grid without impairing their economic growth to be sought. This expresses a challenge, to maintain this growth and the changes in the vision of the security of the electricity supply, which is based on the current transmission and distribution networks, the uncertainties of competition on the power market and the effects of decentralized energy generation. The increase in resources of decentralized generation is increasingly observed worldwide and depends on the costs of technologies, market design, and subsidies. Therefore, it is necessary to find alternatives that develop a sustainable strategic plan for the expansion of the power grid. Currently, efforts are being made in the development of planning models with income from decentralized energy generation, renewable energy, market connection, and the power of electrical system planning, which are being undertaken. In this dissertation, a general planning model for the expansion of the power grid is proposed. This model should enable the expansion of the electrical installation and coordinate the proposed solutions. The proposed model combines a temporal and spatial load prognosis module, which optimizes the distribution of the load into the network, the proposal of new power plant projects and their branches, the planning of transmission and distribution networks, and the classification of proposed projects. The optimization model combines classical methods with the exploratory development of other mathematical tools. The model is applied to a real system and shows its potential use for an analysis of the introduction of new consumers. The direct effects on each variable included in the analysis are mainly due to the introduction of new components such as energy efficiency tariffs and the classification of projects.

Self-assembly, rheological properties and self-healing studies of supramolecular polymers in the bulk state ¤ Thymine/Triazine hydrogen bonding; supramolecular dynamic polymer network; supramolecular block copolymer; telechelic polymer; Self-assembly; self-healing property; disordered micelles; SAXS; rheology; unspecific hydrogen bonding In this thesis, we studied three different supramolecular polymer systems with small angle X-ray scattering and rheology to investigate the structure formation and the mechanical properties of supramolecular hydrogen bonding groups functionalized polymers in the bulk state. Several nanostructures were found in the supramolecular polymer systems. For the hydrogen bonding functional nonpolar polyisobutylene samples, micellar nano-aggregates were formed, driven by the demixing between the hydrogen bonding groups and the main chain. Unspecific hydrogen bonding was also found, which can act as another driving force. For the supramolecular block copolymer, the main driving force is the demixing between two polymer blocks and the specific hydrogen bonding was found to be very effective. Self-healing properties were studied with dynamic rheological measurements and it was found to contain a process which is related to terminal relaxation and a slow perfectioning process

Dynamic partial self-reconfiguration : quick modeling, simulation, and synthesis ¤ In this work, OSSS+R is presented as an approach to simplify the design of dynamically partially reconfigurable systems with FPGAs. Modeling is done object-oriented and uses both polymorphic elements and the concept of virtual hardware. The focus is on simple modeling and changeability rather than maximizing degrees of freedom in expression. The models can be simulated using a C/C++ library and SystemC. A synthesis on RTL level is described and in part demonstrated by implementation in a tool called „Fossy“. The generated models match cycle-accurately in their time behavior with the OSSS+R description. To evaluate the approach, the presented design flow was applied to a model in C/C++ up to execution on an FPGA prototyping platform. <dt.>

Journalistic Source Protection in German and European Law ¤ Who is today as a journalist entitled to claim source protection? In view of the technological development in the field of media and an increasing number of attacks on media freedom, this question has gained new relevance in recent times. From this perspective, the author compares the legal situation of source protection, i.e. the protected trust relationship between an informant and a journalist, in German law, in the system of the European Convention on Human Rights, in the law of the European Union, and in US-American law, and always focuses on the journalist. Thus, the work should be of particular interest to legal scholars and journalists.

Characterization of MOS Transistors before and after Gate Oxide Breakdown ¤ The continuous scaling of integrated circuits in the last decades has led to gate oxide thicknesses below 2nm in MOS transistors of state of the art technologies. Breakdown of such thin oxides becomes intrinsically more likely, and the 1 billion transistor chip is already within reach. Therefore, the probability of having at least one oxide breakdown within the projected circuit lifetime of 10 years seems quite high. In this work, the characteristics of MOS transistors before and after gate oxide breakdown are studied. Different categories of breakdown are identified and models for the dc characteristics as well as the noise (random telegraph signals) after breakdown are developed. The models are implemented to analyze the effect of breakdown on different analog and digital circuits. It is shown that, according to the application and breakdown type, circuits may be functional after breakdown of a transistor. With the presented approach it is possible to point out critical transistors in the circuit and analyze the impact of breakdown during the design stage.

Physical Hydrogels on Polyurethane Basis ¤ Physical hydrogels are currently gaining interest as cell substrates, as viscoelasticity or stress relaxation is a significant parameter in mechanotransduction that has been previously neglected. In this work, multifunctional polyurethanes were designed that form physical hydrogels through a novel gelation mechanism. In water, the anionic polyurethanes spontaneously form aggregates, which are held in solution by electrostatic repulsion. A rapid gelation can be achieved from here through charge shielding, whereby aggregation proceeds and a network is formed. This can be achieved by adding various acids or salts, so that both acidic (pH 4-5) and pH-neutral hydrogels can be obtained. While conventional hydrogels on a polyurethane basis are typically produced using toxic isocyanate-containing prepolymers, the described physical gelation mechanism is suitable for in situ applications in sensitive environments. Both hardness and stress relaxation of the hydrogels can be set independently over a broad range. Furthermore, the hydrogels are characterized by excellent stress regeneration.

Strategic Planning of a Circular Economy System for Photovoltaic Modules: Data-Based Forecast and Development of a Comprehensive System Understanding ¤ The author develops the necessary information, particularly the expected occurrence, in order to plan the recycling of materials bound in photovoltaic modules in a cycle. This results in a comprehensive understanding of the system, which enables the conception of a circular economy system for photovoltaic modules on a strategic level. With this, valuable resources, which are bound in large quantities due to the widespread distribution of photovoltaic systems, can be returned to utilization. The content • Technological and economic framework conditions • Forecast of installed performance • Occurrence for the utilization of pending material quantities • Modeling of the circular economy system • Implications for the optimal design of the circular economy system The target groups • Lecturers and students of economics and engineering, economics and applied natural sciences • Experts and management staff from the field of photovoltaics and waste management The author Dr.-Ing. Martin Dirr is a scientific assistant at the Chair for Production & Supply Chain Management at the University of Augsburg. In addition to classical questions of operations management in the field of production and logistics, he deals with aspects of sustainability, particularly in the field of resource-strategic concepts for future-proof energy systems. Technological and economic framework conditions -- Forecast of installed performance -- Occurrence for the utilization of pending material quantities -- Modeling of the circular economy system -- Implications for the optimal design of the circular economy system.

The Migration Behavior of Employees in the Media Industry: An Empirical Investigation of the Residential and Workplace Choice, Satisfaction, and Relocation Decision of Talents in German Metropolises ¤ From the introduction: Cities are in an „interurban war for talent“. Therefore, it is important for cities that pursue a person-oriented approach to know how to win this fight. They must have knowledge about which location factors and to what extent the location factors attract talented people and keep them at their current residential and workplace. I will answer this question in my dissertation project, where the focus of the work is on talents from the media industry. The main goal of the work is the analysis of the migration behavior of employees in the media industry. This includes the identification of the factors that determine the residential and workplace choice, overall satisfaction, and relocation decision. Since employees of the culture and creative industry in Germany in general and those of the media industry in particular concentrate in the large cities, employees from the four metropolises with more than one million inhabitants are considered in this study. That is, those who live and work in Berlin, Hamburg, Munich, and Cologne. The theoretical contribution of this work lies in the testing of existing theories on the residential and workplace choice of talents. In particular, the explanatory contribution of the theory of the Creative Class to the migration behavior of media professionals in German metropolises is tested.
