Furthermore, relevant location factors from migration research are to be analyzed and the differences in the relevance of individual factors between the four media metropolises are to be uncovered. The practical contribution of the work lies in generating new knowledge on the migration behavior of talents from the media industry. On the basis of the identified influencing factors, it will be possible to derive recommendations for policy and urban marketing. This will enable the German metropolises to position themselves as attractive residential and workplace locations for employees in the media industry.

Biography and Educational Culture: Portrayals of Individuals by Pliny the Younger, Gellius, and Sueton ¤ What significance did biographical information hold in the educational culture of the 2nd century AD, and which literary forms were chosen for the presentation of individuals? Under this double guiding question, Dennis Pausch investigates portrayals of individuals in the letters of the younger Pliny, the miscellaneous work of Aulus Gellius, and the imperial biographies of Sueton from a genre-transcending perspective. Sales arguments: - of interest to both literary scholars and ancient historians - new insights through genre-transcending interpretive approach - important results on cultural communication in the Roman imperial era

Function of the Transcription Factor CbfA in Dictyostelium discoideum ¤ The CbfA mutant JH.D showed a failure of multicellular development. Expression of CbfA in a low-copy situation caused a healing of the phenotype, which is why this system could be used to gain clues about the functions of individual CbfA domains by expressing mutated CbfA proteins. It turned out that the catalytic activity of the JmjC domain was not essential for the mediation of multicellular development by CbfA. The exchange of a conserved histidine in CbfA for alanine in the first zinc finger motif or the deletion of both zinc fingers resulted in a loss of function of the CbfA protein. Complementation of the CbfA suppression strain with CbfA, which had mutations in the AT-hook region, led to the restoration of aggregation. However, this resulted in premature termination of multicellular development.

Studies of intestinal barrier functions of common carp, Cyprinus carpio, under feeding modulation and pathogen challenge ¤ Intestinal barrier, Common carp, Pathogen. - The epithelium that lines the mucosal surface in the intestine of animals performs important barrier functions, including the selective uptake of nutrients and the transport of ions and water, as well as the protection of the mucosa and the tissues beneath the mucosa from luminal antigens, toxins, or pathogenic invaders. To improve fish production and fish health in aquaculture, a more comprehensive knowledge of these different functions in the intestine of fish is necessary. In aquaculture, particularly the provision of fish with highly digestible, nutritious, and affordable feed, the protection of fish from infectious diseases, or the treatment of infectious diseases are challenges that have significantly burdened fish production, including that of the common carp, for a long time. The present work investigated...

Climate Change in the Context of the Climate System: Cognitive Development Processes Regarding the Climate Concept in the Context of the Linking of School and Out-of-School Learning ¤ This dissertation explored, within a design-based research framework, the medium-term impact of linking school and out-of-school learning (OLE) on a systemic understanding of climate change among 7th grade students. A method mix was used for this purpose. While a written test suggested a significant improvement in systemic understanding, a qualitative content analysis revealed both a heterogeneous and discontinuous development. The results indicate that ideas about dynamic processes in the climate system were mostly developed by the analogue and digital models used in class. With regard to OLE, motivational factors and memorable personal experiences emerged as essential for the cognitive development process. However, for students with lower performance development, no general positive effects of extracurricular learning could be proven.

Architecture of a Knowledge-Based Threat and Risk Analysis of IT Systems with Automated Selection and Integration of Security Mechanisms ¤ The security of application systems of companies is increasingly becoming a decisive factor for the continued existence of companies. This results from the availability requirements for systems and data that are needed for the business processes of companies, and from external requirements such as the data protection act. In order to be able to evaluate an application system with regard to security, risks are identified with the help of threat and risk analysis. The so-identified risks must be reacted to by suitable modification of the application system. In the consistent implementation of the analysis and later security measures, the analyst is only insufficiently and in part supported by the existing procedures. The present work deals with a comprehensive procedure model for the threat and risk analysis of application systems and their security through the integration of security mechanisms. In this procedure model, possible security mechanisms are determined based on the results of the analysis conducted, taking into account the risk emergence, and their effects on risk emergence and the costs incurred are presented. Based on this information, the system operator is supported in selecting a security alternative. Thus, the results of this work enable a regular threat and risk analysis and contribute to the development of secure and the security of existing application systems.

Image-based Inline Monitoring of Cultivation Processes with an Optimized In-situ Microscopy System ¤ In-situ Microscopy, Image Processing, S. cerevisiae, Euglena gracilis, Microcarrier, Insect Cells, Animal Cells

Spaces of Change : Innovations and their Transfer in the Field of Education and Upbringing ¤ How and in what way is the transfer of innovation in the field of education and upbringing influenced? Inka Bormann addresses the question of how something hybrid like innovation can be theoretically and conceptually precisely captured and empirically determined. In doing so, she takes a knowledge-analytical perspective and designs a model of discursive innovation, which she unfolds and discusses against the background of educational governance research. The author thus makes a contribution to the systematization and theoretical foundation of educational innovation research as well as to the investigation of governance in the field of education and upbringing. Inka Bormann, Dr. phil. habil, is a scientific university assistant at the Department of Education and Psychology at the Free University of Berlin.

Development of novel catalysts for the photocatalytic hydrogen formation ¤ For the future conversion of sunlight into chemical energy, step-by-step intramolecular working systems for artificial photosynthesis were built. In this process, a number of new ligands and resulting charge-transfer chromophores (Ru(bpy)3-like) and catalytically active complexes (Pt, Pd) were produced. These were combined into heteronuclear diads, which consist of covalently linked functional subunits. In particular, the chromophore and catalytic center were bridged in such a way that their individual properties remained, but their individual functions functioned as a supramolecular photocatalyst in combination. Thus, it becomes possible under light irradiation to reduce protons to hydrogen at these catalysts. For this purpose, oligodentate ligands were produced and used as bridging units, which can coordinate the active metal centers via bipyridines and N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHC). A number of such heterobimetallic complexes, whose starting compounds as well as suitable reference compounds were produced, characterized and compared with each other. In addition to structural, photophysical, and electrochemical analyses, successful catalysis experiments with the generated photocatalysts for light-driven hydrogen production from water were also carried out. Similarly, representative control experiments and additional analyses using dynamic light scattering were performed to gain a deeper understanding of the processes during the catalysis. By comparing the properties of the produced catalysts with selected reference compounds, further statements about the structure-property relationships of the systems could also be derived.

Data-Based State Monitoring in Passenger Vehicles with Application to a Three-Way Catalyst ¤ Feature generation for dynamic operating states -- Two-class Support Vector Machine-based fault detection -- One-class Support Vector Machine-based fault detection -- Support Vector Machine-based state monitoring. Chris Louen develops a data-based state monitoring of dynamic operating states for passenger vehicles, which can be realized in today's control units. It is applied to the example of the three-way catalyst by means of catalyst removal after a push operation and its effectiveness is proven at a simulation and real vehicle data. The presented state monitoring is characterized by a low demand for training data and computing power in the control unit. The content Feature generation for dynamic operating states Two-class Support Vector Machine-based fault detection One-class Support Vector Machine-based fault detection Support Vector Machine-based state monitoring The target groups Lecturers and students of control engineering and automotive engineering Practitioners in the field of vehicle diagnosis (development and application engineers) The author Chris Louen is an academic advisor in the field of automation technology and complex systems at the University of Duisburg-Essen and works, among other things, on data-based procedures for state monitoring and fault prognosis.

EPR Spectroscopic Investigation of the Solvation of Amphiphilic Substances in Aqueous Medium ¤ In the present work, the phase separation behavior of responsive poly(phosphoester)s (PPEs) with identical side group structure but different copolymer composition, as well as the solvation process of nitroxide spin probes in aqueous medium was investigated in detail using EPR spectroscopy. From a methodological point of view, this work impressively demonstrates the enormous potential of EPR spectroscopy, which shows remarkably high sensitivity and precision even with comparatively simple CW measurement technique. Moreover, this work also illustrates how much the solvation of amphiphilic substances in an aqueous medium can differ and thus shows in an impressive way the unbelievable adaptability of water with respect to its solvation behavior and emphasizes its unique character. In the present work, the following points were also discussed: electron paramagnetic resonance, EPR spectroscopy, poly(phosphoester)s, nitroxide spin probes, solvation, water, amphiphilicity END

Quality Intelligence : IT-based Decision Support for Preventive Quality Assurance in the Early Phases of the Vehicle Development Process ¤ Introduction -- Business and technical fundamentals -- Case Study on the exploration of preventive concept assurance – methodology and findings -- Development of a professional concept for decision support of preventive concept assurance -- Prototypical realization and evaluation -- Abstraction, appreciation and research needs. Due to the high dynamics and complexity in the context of vehicle creation, product quality is a major challenge for the long-term competitiveness of automobile manufacturers. Product quality is particularly influenced by decisions made in the early phases of automotive development. Studies show that the availability of relevant quality-related information can make a significant contribution to decision-making in this context. The goal of the research work is therefore to develop an IT-based approach to decision support in favor of preventive assurance of product concepts in the early phases of the automotive product development process. The solution path of the present work includes an exploration of preventive assurance of product concepts in the early vehicle development phases. Based on the findings of the investigation, a professional concept for decision support is developed as the main component of the work. The conceptual focal points are then implemented prototypically using real data and evaluated in the framework of several workshops with professional users. The author Sven Herzberg was promoted by Prof. Dr. Hans-Georg Kemper at the Chair for ABWL and Business Informatics 1 of the Institute of Business Administration at the University of Stuttgart.

Plastic Deformation Behavior of Undercooled Aluminum Alloys in the Al-Mg-Si System ¤ This work contributes to closing existing knowledge gaps on the effect of major alloying elements in Al-Mg-Si hot-extrusion alloys on their strength and flow behavior. For this purpose, a methodology was developed that enables mechanical material testing at defined, metastable material states under varying forming conditions. To better assess the influence of major alloying elements, experimental investigations were carried out on binary model alloys (Al-Mg, Al-Si) with systematic variation of the alloy contents and on a ternary Al-Mg-Si alloy.

Polymer Solar Cells: Morphology-Property Correlation ¤ The objective of this dissertation is to clarify questions of morphology development and targeted morphology control of the active layers of polymer

Convergence of Value-Oriented Indicators and IFRS Financial Reporting Information ¤ Alexander Bantz investigates whether information from IFRS financial reporting is suitable for designing value-oriented indicators in general and specifically for fair value accounting. He shows possibilities and limitations of value-oriented indicators based on fair value and refutes essential criticism points in convergence considerations. To this end, he analyzes whether convergence potential can be recognized in terms of the accounting purposes pursued with value-oriented indicators and information from IFRS financial reporting and the associated requirements. Furthermore, the convergence potential of fair value accounting is examined under special consideration of the regulations of IFRS 13 in terms of behavioral control in investment decisions through various scenarios. Content • Fair Value Accounting • Value-Oriented Indicators • Suitability of Fair Value Accounting under IFRS 13 for Value-Oriented Investment Control • Implications for the Design of Convergent Value-Oriented Indicators Target Groups • Lecturers and students of business administration, especially controlling and accounting • Practitioners in financial and management accounting The author Alexander Bantz is a research assistant at the Chair of Controlling of Univ.-Prof. Dr. Louis Velthuis at Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz Fair Value Accounting -- Value-Oriented Indicators -- Suitability of Fair Value Accounting under IFRS 13 for Value-Oriented Investment Control -- Implications for the Design of Convergent Value-Oriented Indicators

Optimization of the Use of Unmanned Aerial Systems using Mathematical Optimization Methods ¤ In this work, a model has been developed, which includes new aspects regarding the planning of trajectories of drones using mathematical optimization. In particular, the linearization of circles and spheres using the Glineur method could be successfully implemented and tested. It could be shown that a trajectory under temporal and spatial boundary conditions could be plausibly solved using the given formulas. Furthermore, it was illustrated that such problems can also be solved with simple hardware and software. Only with increasing complexity and side conditions, the system reaches its limits.
The Human Factor in Risk Management of Public Infrastructure Projects in Kenya ¤ Faktor Mensch, Risikosteuerung, öffentliche Bauvorhaben. - Human element, risk management, public infrastructure

Design and characterization of highly-efficient GaN-HEMTs for power applications ¤ BEGIN
Abstract: The excellent physical properties of the semiconductor Gallium nitride (GaN) and the AlGaN/GaN heterostructures based on it are particularly suitable for processing power electronic components. The high breakdown field of GaN in combination with the high electrical conductivity of a polarization-induced two-dimensional electron gas enables the development of transistors with high blocking voltage, small on-resistance, and small switching charges. While material properties and technologies are continuously improved, progress should also be made in device design.
This work aims to make the enormous potential of this technology usable by new approaches in the design and characterization of highly efficient GaN transistors.
To this end, „High-Electron-Mobility Transistors” (HEMTs) are investigated in their operating states and their behavior in relation to their device structure is analyzed. This results in new approaches for the design of these power components, which are presented here.
A focus is on the area-efficient design of very low-ohmic GaN components. Based on an analytical model, construction methods for the development of highly efficient GaN-HEMTs are derived. In addition to the design of interdigital comb structures, new layouts for very large-area components are presented. The layouts are inspired by natural flow systems, such as a fractal comb structure or a cloverleaf structure.
In many power electronic applications, the reverse conduction state is also relevant. Since GaN-HEMTs do not contain intrinsic „body diodes”, the behavior differs significantly from conventional power transistors. This work investigates the reverse conduction behavior of a conventional HEMT structure and presents a new, improved HEMT structure with integrated freewheeling diode.
END

Quantification of the Effects of Road Traffic on Particulate and Nitrogen Oxide Emissions ¤ Against the background of frequent exceedance of emission limits for particulate matter and nitrogen dioxide, restrictive measures for urban road traffic, which is considered a main contributor to the burden of these pollutants, are often planned and implemented. This work deals with the effects of traffic control measures, which can influence traffic flow, traffic demand, and traffic composition. However, quantifying the emission-related effects of the aforementioned traffic parameters is difficult: current models often show deviations from measured values in the order of 20 to 40 percent due to complex cause-and-effect relationships, but also due to inaccurate and/or strongly aggregated input data. With a predicted reduction potential of individual traffic control measures in the single-digit to low two-digit percentage range, an optimal selection and design of measures through dynamic, environment-dependent traffic control appears to be only limitedly possible. Within the research project AMONES - Application and Analysis of Model-Based Network Control Procedures in Urban Street Networks, the complex of topics was examined in more detail ...

Growth and Characterization of InSb-Nanowire Structures ¤ III-V semiconductors; nanowires; Vapor-Liquid-Solid (VLS); Vapor-Solid-Solid (VSS); epitaxial growth; Chemical Beam Epitaxy (CBE); electron microscopy; heterostructures This work is concerned with the growth of InSb nanowires using Chemical Beam Epitaxy (CBE). Utilizing a self-developed growth system, the growth behavior of the InSb nanowires is first determined, followed by the examination of the cultivated structures with respect to their morphology, structural composition, and physical properties. The synthesized nanowires were characterized using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), and X-ray Diffraction (XRD). Essential results of the investigations are: i) The planar defect density within the nanowires can be influenced by the growth temperature. ii) The change of the mass flow ratio of the precursor materials suppresses parasitic layer growth, as well as radial growth of the nanowires. iii) By using suitable growth parameters, radial InSb-GaSb-heterostructures were generated and characterized. iv) Both individual nanowires and large-area ordered nanowire fields were contacted and electrically measured using lithographic processes.

Neuronal regeneration in the olfactory system of locusts ¤ Neuronal regeneration in invertebrates is extensively studied. For this work, I have chosen Locusta migratoria as a model organism to describe the neuronal regeneration of the olfactory system on a morphological and functional level. After deafferentation of the antennal nerve (AN), the size changes in the antennal lobes (AL) are observed. Within 4 days after crushing (dpc: days post crush), the AL of adult locusts and larvae from the 5th larval stage (L5) reach their minimum size and grow again afterwards. By marking the AN with Neurobiotin, it can be shown that this is caused by Wallerian degeneration. Within 24 hours after deafferentation, the distal parts of the olfactory receptor neurons (ORN) disappear completely. Then, the ORN grow out towards the AL and form synapses with local interneurons and projection neurons (PN). The glomeruli belonging to an ORN are usually circularly arranged. This pattern is not restored after regeneration, instead, the ORN form synapses with random glomeruli. There is a weak correlation between the origin of the ORN in the antenna and the position of the corresponding synapses in the AL, where the ORN from the oldest annuli mainly innervate the 50% - 70% area of the AL neuropil. The fluorescence intensity of the Fasciclin I marking is used to quantify the time frame of ORN regeneration in the AL of adult animals and L5. The AL of treated and untreated adult animals are no longer distinguishable after 10 dpc. Since the L5 had completed their last molt after 8 days, the experiments were terminated at that time, however, the AL of treated animals at that time already looked very similar to those of untreated animals. The analysis of immunofluorescence in the lateral area of the AL shows a significant decrease in L5 with a minimum value after 2 dpc, followed by an increase back to the control level within 7 dpc. In adult animals, the immunofluorescence reaches its minimum after 4 dpc and the control level after 7 dpc. In the medial area of the AL, the immunofluorescence reaches its minimum in adult animals and L5 after 4 dpc. In adult animals, the control level is reached after 10 dpc, in L5 already after 7 dpc. The PN of the AL begin to respond to odor stimuli within 4-7 dpc. Young adult locusts, whose AN was crushed in the L5 stage, reach the control level faster. The response types (excitatory, inhibitory, composite response) usually occur in a fixed ratio to each other. This ratio is disturbed at the beginning of regeneration, but is restored within 21 dpc. First local field potentials (LFPs) can already be measured in the mushroom body (MB) after 4 dpc and after 7 dpc, the odor-induced oscillations are also restored. The olfactory system of the locust regenerates quickly, precisely, and reaches a functional grade similar to the normal state within 21 days after treatment. Whether the ability to identify and distinguish odors is fully restored remains to be proven by behavioral experiments.

New Titan Catalysts for Hydroamination and Hydroaminoalkylation Reactions for the Generation of Pharmaceutically Relevant Structure Motifs ¤ The use of a mono(aminopyridinato) titanium catalyst for the hydroaminoalkylation of styrene with N-methylaniline provided the branched and the linear product in a ratio of 90:10. Additionally, it was possible to use the mono(aminopyridinato) titanium catalyst in the intermolecular as well as intramolecular hydroamination of alkynes and alkenes with great success. The synthesis of corresponding mono(amidate) titanium complexes was executed as well. Moreover, a variety of amidines and guanidines were synthesized and used as ligand precursors in titanium-catalyzed hydroamination and hydroaminoalkylation reactions. A mono(formamidinato) titanium catalyst was then utilized for the implementation of allylamines, allylsilanes and vinylsilanes as substrates. The combination of this reaction with the Buchwald-Hartwig amination to an elegant one-pot procedure finally led to pharmaceutically relevant structure motifs. END

Development of an Engineering Model for the Evaluation of the Out-of-Plane Load-Carrying Capacity of Unreinforced Masonry Walls Subjected to Earthquake Loading ¤ Masonry must withstand loads perpendicular to the plane (out-of-plane), e.g. due to earthquakes, in addition to vertical and horizontal loads in the plane. The out-of-plane behavior of unreinforced masonry walls depends on the used stone-mortar combination and is very complex due to strong nonlinearity. Current assessment procedures in German standards are not explicitly developed for out-of-plane behavior and contain significant conservativities in part. Detailed investigations on typical masonry types in Germany do not exist so far.In the framework of the present work, the out-of-plane behavior of singly spanned unreinforced masonry walls was investigated analytically and experimentally. The goal was the development of a model for the description of the out-of-plane vibration behavior of masonry walls.The existing procedures for determining the out-of-plane load-carrying capacity from literature and standards were analyzed. By comparing with nonlinear, numerical simulations, the essential influencing factors were identified. In subsequent shake table tests with insulating brick masonry and porous concrete masonry, these factors were experimentally verified.As a crucial parameter, the vertical stiffness at the wall head due to the underlying frame, supports or ceilings has emerged. Since these cannot be considered in previous procedures, an engineering model was derived that takes this parameter into account. In subsequent tests, the developed model was verified and further investigations on vibration and damping behavior were carried out. In final sensitivity and correlation analyses, the relationship between earthquake parameters and wall displacement was investigated. On this basis, a design model for the considered masonry walls was proposed.

The Best of Two Divergent Work Worlds: An Analysis of Individual Career Trajectories and Concepts of People in a Dual Career under the Inclusion of the Self-Determination Theory ¤ An indicator of the change in individual careers is the increasing number of people who engage in more than one professional activity. This phenomenon is addressed by the present work through the examination of narrative interviews of dual career individuals. The focus is on the analysis of research questions, why individuals voluntarily engage in two occupations simultaneously and how they conceive their career. The results show that the career concept of self-determined dual career is related to the satisfaction of work-related needs and can enable the optimization of these needs. These findings partially support the concepts of the new career idea and reflect the three psychological basic needs of autonomy, relatedness, and competence of the Self-Determination Theory (SDT). The integration of this motivation theory into the present analysis also confirms a fruitful and enlightening interdisciplinary connection between SDT and career research. Furthermore, the widespread understanding of career as a sequential sequence of professional experiences is expanded by the dimension of simultaneity and is discussed accordingly.

Electronic Press and Citizen Journalism: Press Law Rights and Obligations of Word Media on the Internet ¤ The numerous publication options of the Internet enable every Internet user to engage in citizen journalism occasionally and randomly, but also regularly. The work inquires into how this is to be legally classified. Initially, the conventional press concept and its historical development are comprehensively examined to see in which ways offers of electronic press can be included in the scope of press freedom. Subsequently, a new press concept is developed, combining old and new criteria in order to better meet the technical development. Finally, existing press law rights and obligations of the printed press are analyzed in detail to see in which ways they can be transferred to the electronic press. In addition, the press law peculiarities of the electronic press are presented, which have no equivalent in the printed press, as they are purely internet-specific.

Economic Analysis of Automated Management of Unstructured Data in Information Lifecycle Management ¤ The goal of Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) is the classification and cost-effective management of information. Information frequently accessed in a company can be separated from information with lower access frequencies and made available and managed on the most suitable storage medium according to corporate requirements. Rapid data growth, high storage, administration, and operating costs, as well as numerous legal requirements are the essential reasons for the emergence of ILM. To analyze the cost-benefit ratio that arises from the implementation and application of ILM, a procedure for the economic analysis of unstructured data management in ILM is constructed, implemented, demonstrated, and evaluated in this work. Classification, migration, and cost functions are implemented to simulate and evaluate the creation of costs and cost-saving potentials for different usage levels of information. It is investigated how the automated classification and management of varying amounts of data with varying access frequencies and usage levels affect the economic efficiency of ILM. In addition to internal corporate storage media, the management of data in Cloud Computing is included in the considerations. The present work provides a literature analysis of the concepts ILM and Cloud Computing as well as a scientific contribution to discuss both legal, functional, and technical requirements for ILM and Cloud Computing. The work ends with a summary and a critical evaluation of the results. A look ahead provides hints and suggestions for improvement regarding the economic analysis of unstructured data in Information Lifecycle Management.

Informationspraxen in der Bildungsforschung : ethnographic information research on research environments, apparatuses, and research data in interaction ¤ How are data used in educational research or, put differently, how are data turned into research data with corresponding assertiveness for the relevant research question and thus into relevant information in research practice? To address this question, information practices in five different educational research projects are ethnographically investigated, described, and contrasted. This shows how these research projects are enabled to pursue their respective research questions through the production, use, and re-configuration of apparatuses, materials, and data in interaction with an object of investigation. In this work, therefore, less emphasis is placed – as is often the case in information science – on the end product of scientific work, the scientific publication, as the focus of knowledge interest. Instead, information practices, especially interactions in the production and use of research data in their contexts, are assigned a primary position in research interest, without, however, neglecting publications. Publications are considered here – just like other entities – as part of the interaction context to be investigated, through which educational research takes place.

New Experimental Designs on Natural Substances in Chemistry Lessons: Chemistry with Fungi ¤ Jan-Markus Teuscher presents his dissertation with a curriculum development work, which, using the extremely interesting fungi from a chemical perspective, has developed a wide range of and attractive new experimental possibilities for chemistry lessons to promote interest and motivation of students in this subject. The introductory chapters include a brief overview of the biological-mycological basics, a more comprehensive summary of knowledge on the chemistry of fungi, as well as a summarizing and evaluating overview of the already published works on the complex of fungi in biology and chemistry lessons. The experiments described in detail in the main part of the work were tested by students and students. The experiment sets were compiled in a richly illustrated guide for teachers and students, the material book, and can be used immediately in chemistry lessons and in interdisciplinary projects.

Cityscape in Transition : Publicity and Cologne Buildings 1763 - 1814 ¤ Revolution and secularization triggered around 1800 one of the greatest loss waves in architectural history. At the same time, the view on historical buildings changed in the transition from the Enlightenment to Romanticism. The real upheaval and the new perspective are treated as an example of Cologne, a city with rich architecture and a multifaceted public. - - As the public discussion on the protection of endangered buildings and their inventories contributed, so did the discussion of church and urban buildings provide important spaces for political criticism. The present study describes the discussion about historical buildings as an example of Cologne. In the Middle Ages and at the beginning of modern times, the largest city in Germany, a trade center and a church metropolis, Cologne had a unique architectural inventory. As a press city, seat of a university - and station of European educational travelers, Cologne was also a hub of national and international communication. Comparisons with Paris, Mainz and other cities complement the investigation. The study also crosses, which rarely happens, the caesuras 1789/1799 and compares the Enlightenment era, the revolutionary decade and the Napoleonic era. - - Facets-rich and differentiated insights through the combination of urban, intellectual and art historical analyses

Strengthened for the Teaching Profession : Mental Health through the Promotion of Profession-Specific Competences ; Development and Evaluation of a Strength-Focused Intervention Program for Teacher Trainees ¤ In a quasi-experimental longitudinal study with 380 teacher trainees, the intervention program

Indigenous Resistance : the Resistance of the Bolivian TIPNIS Movement ¤ Blurb: Latin America is home to numerous protest movements of its indigenous population. One of the most emblematic cases is the social movement against a prestige project of the Morales government: the construction of a road in the indigenous territory and national park Isiboro Sécure (TIPNIS) in the Bolivian Amazon region. From the perspectives of the heterogeneous protest actors, Maximilian Held reconstructs this resistance in its complex forms. In doing so, he highlights how problems of weakened indigenous self-government, socio-ecological threats, deficits of the neo-extractive development model, and inadequate legal implementation are interconnected.

Trends of Urban Open Space Development in Politics and Administration ¤ From the introduction: The focus of this study lies in the field of urban green space departments, which have been hardly made into a research subject from the side of landscape planning so far. It is mainly about the level of awareness of the actors, who significantly design and implement municipal open space planning in the city council and in the city administration. In particular, the question should be pursued, which perspectives and opportunities arise from the awareness level of the actors for the urban green administrations.

Static and Dynamic Oligopoly Models : A Contribution to Decision Theory in Oligopol Situations ¤ All considerations in this work are business-oriented, thus being carried out from the point of view of the enterprise. Therefore, the central point of interest is the question of what price a company must set in an oligopol situation, taking into account the given data constellation, in order to behave in accordance with its objectives.

Atomistic simulation of dealloying-made microstructures ¤ This thesis explores the evolution of these microstructural features: residual silver, characteristic length scale, and topological connectivity in nanoporous gold (NPG). Kinetic Monte Carlo was used to simulate the dealloying and coarsening processes. Molecular Dynamics was used to simulate the shrinkage process of NPG structures. It is found that the dealloying occurs in two stages. In the primary dealloying, silver clusters are embedded in the ligaments; in the secondary dealloying, the number of silver clusters is reduced. The silver cluster size retains constant during the whole dealloying and scales with the initial ligament size established in the primary dealloying. The finding of coarsening law provides a conclusive confirmation for scattered experimental results. This thesis points out that the solid fraction plays a significant role in the evolution of the nanoporous network’s connectivity during the dealloying, coarsening and shrinkage processes.

School Autonomy as an Element of New Governance: Recontextualizations between Pedagogical and Structural Perspectives ¤ Nicole Miceli describes the individual recontextualization processes of school actors and shows the contrasts in dealing with the reform conditions of the

Written Location Determinations in Arithmetic Instruction: An Investigation Based on Content-Related Competencies ¤ For several years, there has been a demand to adjust mathematics instruction to individual competencies and deficits of students. In order to implement this demand in the reality of instruction, it must be concretized in a subject- and content-related manner. Julia Voßmeier takes up the concept of so-called location determinations and investigates how the knowledge gained through written location determinations about individual learning status can be used by both teachers and students in the classroom and for further learning process. Based on an investigation with 600 students from school years 2 to 4 as well as their teachers, she shows that the potential of location determinations has been recognized, but not always fully exploited.

Bypassing of path-blocking proteins on microtubules in kinesin-mediated cargo transport ¤ Kinesins are microtubule-associated motor proteins that convert the chemical energy of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) into movement energy to support intracellular transport processes. It is generally accepted that kinesin movement along a single protofilament is the thermodynamically preferred transport mechanism. Kinesin-mediated transport in the intracellular matrix is subject to complex mechanisms, in which a variety of associated cell components or other proteins can interact with the motor proteins and limit their binding to the microtubule surface. Ultimately, this can lead to the cessation of transport processes. The present dissertation describes the transport of kinesin-complexed gold spheres along immobilized microtubules, whose surface has irreversibly bound blocking proteins that compete with the transporter protein for binding sites. To exactly block the binding site of the transporting kinesin on the microtubule, kinesin constructs of different lengths were chosen as obstacles. In the presence of protein blockades, it was observed that the kinesin did not move continuously like in the corresponding control experiments, but that phases of active transport alternated with rest phases. In general, transport was continued after rest pauses, without the kinesin detaching from the microtubule. This behavior suggests that the transporting kinesin is able to bypass irreversibly bound obstacles in the presence of ...

Mindfulness as Cultural Practice: On the Self-World Models of a Popular Phenomenon ¤ Mindfulness has gained an astonishing popularity over the last 50 years - driven by blooming promises and accompanied by blanket criticism. Jacob Schmidt's analysis of various approaches - such as Jon Kabat-Zinn's developed Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) - shows, however, that mindfulness practices model quite different self- and world relations. These do not only go back to Buddhist meditation practices, but can be reconstructed as complex entanglements with the culture of modernity and the acceleration society. This presents the first comprehensive and systematic sociological study of the popular phenomenon of mindfulness. Frontmatter -- Content -- Preface -- 1 Introduction: Mindfulness as a self-world model of successful life -- 2 Research status -- 3 Sociological anchoring: Cultural self-world models -- 4 Methodological notes -- 5 Introduction: History and systematization -- 6 Mindfulness I: The dissecting-distant self-world model -- 7 Mindfulness II: The interested-caring self-world model -- 8 Mindfulness III: The capable-functionalistic self-world model -- 9 Interim conclusion: Three models, two continuations -- 10 Introduction: Mindfulness in the context of modernity -- 11 Mindfulness as a radicalized form of Buddhist modernism -- 12 'like a research scientist': Scientific mindfulness? -- 13 The actualization of the Romantic -- 14 Interim conclusion: Hybrid mindfulness, or: Popularity through ambiguity -- 15 Introduction: Obsession with the present -- 16 Social acceleration and the transformation of 'here and now' -- 17 The ambivalence of late modern present experience -- 18 Actualizations of late modern temporality -- 19 Interim conclusion: Mindful acceleration or subversive mindfulness? -- 20 Conclusion: An alternative to the inevitability? -- Bibliography

On the Influence of Context-Dependent Quality Parameters on the Perception of Externalization and Sound Event Location ¤ This work encompasses my research activities in the field of spatial hearing. It addresses the question of which effects various contextual influences have on the formation of an auditory illusion. These effects are quantitatively measured. The perception of externalization, sound event location, etc. is investigated using a binaural synthesis system. The goal is to describe and make measurable the contextual influences of divergence, personalization, and visual features. My own investigations clearly show that for the occurrence of a so-called perfect auditory illusion, a sufficient technical realization of the correct ear signals is not sufficient. Rather, fulfillment of the intrinsic expectation of the listener is necessary. The process of quality formation can be described by a comparison and evaluation process. Here, the quality features derived from the stimuli received by the senses are compared with the derived features of an internal, individual reference. This process is decisive for the formation of a sound event. Using quality-assessing surveys (listening tests), this sound event can be made measurable and describable as an image. The results of my work show that a divergence of acoustic space parameters between a binaurally synthesized scene and the listening room leads to a significant reduction in the externalization of sound events. A convergence of acoustic space parameters increases the perceived externalization. The visibility of, for example, loudspeaker dummies in the listening room increases overall externalization. The so-called divergence effect of space cannot be resolved in this way. Personalization of a binaural synthesis system shows a reduction in localization errors and an increase in externalization. The hypothesis is set up and investigated as to whether localization errors and externalization correlate. It will be shown that a personalized binaural synthesis cannot resolve the divergence effect of space. The investigations on the divergence effect of space serve as a basis for the development of methods that change various time- and energy-based acoustic features of the used room impulse responses. The goal is to adapt individual acoustic space parameters of the synthesis to the room acoustics of the listening room to produce a plausible auditory illusion.

Models for mexican temperate forests : a sustainable management approach ¤ In Mexico there is a need for technologies that link forest stand dynamics with silviculture systems. Providing these technologies could enhance forest management, not only by making forests more profitable, but by adapting them to climate change. Lately, there has been a debate on forest management for carbon and climate change benefits. Recent studies claim that letting forest grow without management is better for carbon sequestration and storage. However, other researchers argue that harvesting is a better management strategy because of the substitution effects of using wood products in reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Furthermore, the use of wood products could reduce emissions of greenhouse gases. The results of these studies are, however, controversial and further research is required to better understand the impacts of forest management on climate change. This work aims to contribute to the solution of this question and evaluate the results of the studies to give recommendations for sustainable forest management in Mexico. The work consists of three parts: In the first part, the results of the studies are evaluated and the impacts of forest management on climate change are discussed. In the second part, the results of the studies are evaluated and the impacts of forest management on carbon sequestration and storage are discussed. In the third part, the results of the studies are evaluated and the impacts of forest management on greenhouse gas emissions are discussed. This work aims to contribute to the solution of the question of how forest management in Mexico can be sustainably designed to minimize the impacts of climate change.

Angle-sensitive MRI for non-invasive analysis of loaded cartilage structure ¤ Osteoarthritis is caused by degenerative changes in the joint cartilage. In late stages of the disease, arthrotic changes are almost always irreversible. Only targeted therapeutic measures against early osteoarthritis can halt this progressive pathological development. However, there are currently no established non-invasive methods for early osteoarthritis diagnosis in joint cartilage. Conventional clinical magnetic resonance tomography (MRI) can represent soft tissue non-invasively, but due to technical limitations, it is hardly suitable for detecting early arthrotic changes. An extended method - angle-sensitive MRI (AS-MRI) - is based on the orientation dependence of T2 relaxation in MR imaging and offers the possibility of obtaining information about the collagen matrix structure of joint cartilage using an analytical model. Since osteoarthritis affects the organized ultrastructure of joint cartilage, its biomechanical properties and the deformation behavior of the collagen matrix also change under continuous physiological loading. If these barely perceptible changes are recognized, early osteoarthritis stages could be detected. Therefore, the studies on pressure-induced deformation of cartilage structure in this work are based on AS-MRI. For this purpose, untreated cartilage samples from sheep knees were taken and examined under pressure loading in a high-resolution 7T MRI. In the experiments, a procedure modification was made, which was characterized by pressure distribution on the entire sample surface with the help of quickly hardening acrylic resin. This not only allowed the elastic mechanical properties of the tissue to be obtained, but also the pressure-induced inclination of collagen fibers to be quantitatively recorded. These data served the detailed observation of matrix deformation, including the phenomenon of wave formation in fiber form under pressure loading. The gained knowledge was used for the AS-MRI analysis of signal intensity with the aim of evaluating the possibilities of this method for clinical practice. This analysis showed a good agreement of the modeled intensities with the experimentally read data. The result offers good prospects for solving an inverse problem: The pressure-induced matrix deformation could be clarified alone by considering the signal intensity in an MRI loading test. However, this requires further studies, especially basic studies on native and loaded cartilage in vivo.

Design, Synthesis and Properties of Pyrene-Fused Azaacenes and Their Applications in Organic Electronics ¤ Abstract: This thesis is mainly based on synthesis of pyrene-fused azaacenes. Based on the synthesis and properties of obtained azaacenes, the thesis has been divided into five sections as follow. 1) Small molecules for organic electronics: This chapter contains brief introduction of organic electronic devices such as Organic Field Effect Transistors (OFETs), Organic Light Emitting Diodes (OLEDs) and Orgainc Photovoltaics (OPVs). As well as the role of small molecules i.e. acenes in the organic electronic has been briefly explained. 2) Design, synthesis and properties of pyrene fused azaacenes: The objective of this project was to develop a new method for the synthesis of ultralong and discrete pyrene-fused azaacenes to overcome all the aspects related to their synthesis and solubility. Such novel methodology is based on the synthesis of a series of charged and uncharged building blocks with solubilising groups that can be assembled in a cyclic proccess to yield pyrene-fused azaacenes, facilitating their synthesis and enhancing their semiconducting properties, solubility and processability. Due to the lack of solubility azaacenes only upto seven fused aromatic rings i. e. “heptacene” was synthesized and characterized. 3) Design, synthesis and properties of versatile 2,7-substituted pyrene fused azaacenes as low LUMO materials for OPV: In this project new synthetic route has been developed following which it was possible to synthesize pyrene fused azaacenes with variety of substitutions on the 2,7 position of pyrene. Following the route synthesis of pyrene fused “hexacenes” and “octacenes” was carried out and their electrochemical and photophysical properties were studied. This route was further utilized for synthesis of low LUMO material, designed with simple cyclocondensation protocol. In order to lower the LUMO, diamines with electron withdrawing groups were used. Obtained low LUMO material has been utilized for organic photovoltaic device. 4) Synthesis and properties of “twisted” pyrene fused azaacenes: In this project synthesis of twistacenes has been carried out using easy synthetic protocol. The synthetic scheme was based on cyclocondensation of substituted o-phenylenediamine with 2,7-substituted pyrene tetraketone. The respective substitutions on damine and tetraketone moieties was carried out by Sonogashira coupling that provided rigidity as well as the substitutents were posed away from core that avoided electronic int ...

Communication Networks and Inventor Productivity : An Empirical Analysis of the German Tissue Engineering Industry ¤ In knowledge-intensive industries, inventions are considered a crucial source of future competitiveness. In this context, the communication networks of inventors play a central role in the invention process today. Maria Heibel examines the relationship between communication networks and inventor productivity. Based on a quantitative empirical analysis, detailed knowledge is gained about the importance of communication networks in the invention process as well as about the two-way causality between networking and inventor productivity.

Building Knowledge Structures: Investigations into Coherence Formation in Knowledge Acquisition with Texts ¤ A comprehensive overview of the current state of research on understanding texts and learning with texts.

Mobile Daily Life in the Context of Changing Gender Relations ¤ For a period of over 30 years, Kathrin Konrad charts the essential trends in the daily mobility of men and women, assigns these trends to the change of norms and gender relations, and closes a research gap in the field of gender and mobility through her comprehensive consideration of traffic behavior and its framework conditions. The quantitative study takes into account the social diversity of society and the spatial context as a framework for daily mobility in gender relations through complex regression models. Both daily mobility itself and its framework conditions change significantly for men and women over the observation period – partly to a very different extent depending on the social and spatial environment. While many behavioral differences between men and women disappear over time in some population groups, some differences in certain dimensions of daily mobility and in individual groups are still persistent.

Appreciative Self-Organization: Work Ability- and Recognition-Based Self-Organization in Project Work ¤ Organizational and individual requirements of self-organization -- Formal and informal recognition in organizations -- Interactions of the analyzed dimensions recognition and work ability -- Opportunities and challenges of agile and transnational project work -- Case studies from the IT and automotive industries Stefan Sauer develops a general sociological analysis concept for self-organized work and applies it exemplarily in two empirical cases from the automotive industry and the IT sector. The analysis concept shows possibilities, prerequisites, and limitations of self-organization based on work ability and recognition in the interplay of structural, interactionist, and subjectifying levels. Key factors are the individual work ability of employees and its structural and interactive recognition as prerequisites for successful self-organization. The content Organizational and individual requirements of self-organization Formal and informal recognition in organizations Interactions of the analyzed dimensions recognition and work ability Opportunities and challenges of agile and transnational project work Case studies from the IT and automotive industries The target groups Lecturers and students in the fields of social sciences and economics Practitioners in the field of project management, human relations, research and development The author Dr. Stefan Sauer is sociologist at the Institute for Social Scientific Research e.V. - ISF Munich. His current research focuses are self-organization, agility, recognition, learning in the work process, sustainability action, and qualitative methodology

Influence of Formulation and Process on Adhesion Behavior in Multi-Component Injection Moulding of Thermoplastic Elastomer Composite Parts - Example PA6.6 - HNBR ¤ The combined use of two or more materials in one composite part is nowadays necessary for the product development of polymer parts in order to get an integration of function and design. Furthermore, a growing cost pressure enforces a reduction of production steps, e.g. realized by multi-component injection moulding. Especially the automotive engineering turns his attention for the integration of sealing and damping functions as well as for weight reduction to composite parts made of a hard thermoplastic and a soft rubber material. To ensure an everlasting operation of such composite parts, a strong adhesion between these components is necessary. This thesis deals precisely with the direct material bonding of thermoplastics and peroxide cross-linked rubbers. Using the combination PA6.6 and HNBR, the influence of rubber compound ingredients and process parameters on the adhesion strength is determined and evaluated based on analytical results. Additionally, by using basic rubber compounds and simplifying boundary conditions conclusions on the bonding mechanisms can be drawn. Multi-Component Injection Moulding; 2K; Rubber; Thermoplastic; Adhesion Strength; Composite; Bonding Mechanism; Interdiffusion; Co-vulcanization; Interface END

Searching for runaway stars in twelve Galactic supernova remnants ¤ Runaway stars move faster than typical field stars. They can either be released through dynamic interactions in dense stellar systems or through supernovae in multiple star systems. In this work, young runaway stars are to be identified that are located within the remnants of core-collapse supernovae. A connection to a runaway star yields the exact time and place of the supernova as well as the parameters of the previous binary system. This also yields insights into the kinematics of a supernova and the expansion of a supernova remnant. Previous works have mainly dealt with massive runaway stars, as these are always young (less than about 32 million years, maximum age of the progenitor star), and easier to find. We are looking for low-mass runaway stars, however, in order to limit their share of all runaway stars. With Gaia data, runaway candidates were identified in twelve nearby supernova remnants. With the VLT and the Subaru telescope, spectra of 39 candidates were taken to search, for example, for the lithium absorption line at 671 nm, which can be used as an indicator of a low age for stars of spectral classes F, G, K, and M. Lithium was found in the spectra of eleven stars, but no candidate could be confirmed as a runaway star from a core-collapse supernova. We show the spectral analysis with measurements of radial velocity, atmospheric parameters, and lithium content. Using the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram and the lithium test, we estimate the age of the observed stars. Then we present a selection of promising runaway candidates from Gaia data, discuss our results for the individual supernova remnants, and limit the number of released runaway stars compared to model calculations.

Potentials and limits of genomics-assisted wheat breeding ¤ Wheat yield needs to be doubled to feed 9 billion people by 2050. The goal of this thesis was to study the potential and limits of marker-assisted and genomic selection for enhancing yield, as well as resistances to Fusarium head blight and Septoriatritici blotch. The association mapping study in combination with different validation strategies revealed that all three traits were complex approximating the infinitesimal model. The complex genetic architecture limits the use of marker-assisted selection. In contrast, genomic selection allows predicting precisely all three examined traits. Contrasting different genomic selection models suggested that epistasis contributed to the phenotypic variation. Relatedness drives the prediction accuracy of genomic selection. Applying the reliability criterion facilitates to exploit relatedness very efficient by estimating the prediction accuracy of individual genotypes. Weizen; Genomik-basierte Züchtung; genomische Selektion; genomweite Assoziationsstudie; Epistasie; Verlässlichkeitskriterium

Model-Based Operation Strategy for PEM Fuel Cell Systems ¤ Modeling -- Interaction analysis of operating relevant parameters -- Development methodology of the operation strategy -- Proof of function and evaluation of the methodology. Sergei Hahn develops a procedure by which model-based operation strategies for PEM fuel cell systems can be developed. The operation strategy affects the performance distribution between battery and fuel cell system on the one hand and the operating conditions within the fuel cell system on the other hand. By using model-based procedures, it is possible to optimize both the efficiency and the lifespan of the fuel cell system in operation. The content Modeling Interaction analysis of operating relevant parameters Development methodology of the operation strategy Proof of function and evaluation of the methodology The target groups Lecturers and students from the field of fuel cell and control engineering Engineers from this field working in industry The author Sergei Hahn has been promoted at the Institute for Vehicle Technology Stuttgart (IFS) of the University of Stuttgart in the field of vehicle mechatronics. At present, he works as a development engineer for fuel cell systems at a German automotive supplier.

Highly Qualified Immigration : The Blue Card Directive 2009/50/EC and its Implementation in Germany ¤ Germany and also the other EU member states are confronted with a growing shortage of highly qualified individuals. Traditional immigration countries like the USA, Canada or Australia introduced significantly more flexible admission requirements for highly qualified individuals in the past. In order to make the EU more attractive for highly qualified individuals from third countries and thus ensure competitiveness and economic growth, the same conditions should be created at EU level through the Blue Card Directive to facilitate the immigration of highly qualified workers. The author provides a careful legal analysis of the Blue Card Directive and the German implementation law (Law on the Implementation of the Highly Qualified Workers Directive of the European Union). The work has a high practical value, as it thoroughly deals with the interpretation and compatibility questions of the Blue Card Directive and the German implementation law.

Development and Application of Sparse Coding Methods for the Analysis of Arm Movement Trajectories ¤ One of many modalities for conveying information in human-machine interaction is gesture. With the help of dynamic gestures, both concepts and emotions can be communicated. In this work, the temporal course of the position of a limb during the execution of the gesture, known as the movement trajectory, is considered. In order for a machine to perceive gestures, the trajectories must be captured using sensors and then interpreted through corresponding data processing. A multi-stage pattern recognition process is used in this case. One step in this process is feature extraction, which presents the captured signal in a compact form. This work is devoted to an investigation of the application of sparse coding in feature extraction for movement trajectories. Sparse coding can represent a data set through a limited number of representative, recurring features. These features are learned from training data in a learning phase and detected in an unknown signal in the recognition phase. This concept has the advantage over conventional methods for feature extraction in temporal signals that the features are optimally adapted to the data and thus describe the characteristic properties of the training data. In this work, the procedure is optimized for application to movement trajectories. It is investigated under which conditions sparse coding is applicable to movement trajectories and how the captured data must be preprocessed. Furthermore, the effects of the procedure on subsequent processing steps in the pattern recognition process, such as classification and generation of movement trajectories, are considered. The performance of the procedure in the use of gesture recognition is demonstrated in experiments using a dataset created within the scope of this work. To investigate the generalizability of the procedure to other application domains, it is applied to benchmark datasets from the areas of activity recognition and handwriting recognition. Furthermore, a real-time implementation of the procedure is presented in a demonstrator application.

Insulin Sensitivity and Insulin Response after Long-Term Supplementation of Conjugated Linoleic Acids in Lactating Dairy Cows ¤ Insulin resistance, CLA, cows. - Conjugated linoleic acids (CLA), used in dairy cows as feed supplements, have been suspected to lead to insulin resistance in studies on rodents and humans. It is assumed that a reduction in insulin sensitivity in dairy cows plays a significant role in the pathogenesis of metabolic disorders such as increased lipomobilization, ketosis, and liver fat accumulation. The hyperinsulinemic euglycemic glucose clamp (HEC) is the gold standard for demonstrating insulin resistance. It allows the distinction between reduced insulin sensitivity and reduced insulin response when consecutive, increasing insulin infusion concentrations are used. However, the HEC is only suitable for studies with small sample sizes due to its high cost and labor requirements. Therefore, various alternative indices, such as the Homeostasis model assessment (HOMA) and the Quantitative insulin sensitivity check index (QUICKI) in various modifications, have been developed in human medicine for simple determination of insulin sensitivity. These indices are based on the plasma concentrations of insulin, glucose, non-esterified fatty acids (NEFA), beta-hydroxybutyrate (BHB), and glycerol in fasting subjects. Considering the differences between the regulatory mechanisms for maintaining glucose homeostasis in humans and ruminants, the direct transfer of these indices to dairy cows is not possible. Therefore, it is necessary to determine insulin sensitivity in dairy cows with specific methods. This work aims to investigate insulin sensitivity and insulin response after long-term supplementation of conjugated linoleic acids in lactating dairy cows. The results of this work are intended to show the effects of CLA on insulin sensitivity and insulin response in dairy cows and discuss the possible consequences for the health of these animals.

The German Military Interventions in Afghanistan: Political Decision-Making Process with Escalation Dynamics ¤ This book deals with the German military interventions in Afghanistan and examines the political decision-making processes behind these interventions. It mainly asks how a escalation of German engagement could have occurred, which factors were decisive for this and how the relationship between politics and the military is determined in political decisions. This book deals with the German military interventions in Afghanistan and examines the political decision-making processes behind these interventions. It mainly asks how a escalation of German engagement could have occurred, which factors were decisive for this and how the relationship between politics and the military is determined in political decisions. Ulf von Krause is an economist, military economist, and political scientist. As a former Lieutenant General of the German Armed Forces, he was last involved in the preparation of German overseas interventions in a leading position.

OFDM-based MIMO Channel Measurements with Various Antennas ¤ This work deals with the measurement and evaluation of the channels of modern multiple-antenna wireless systems (English: multiple input multiple output, abbreviated MIMO). In this context, MIMO transmissions are carried out inside an aircraft and in a typical office environment. Based on some channel parameters, the influence of the aircraft cabin on MIMO wireless transmission is evaluated in comparison to the office environment. The channel is determined in the frequency range using pilot sequences and the Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing method (OFDM). The used MIMO system is presented in detail. Then, the used algorithms are addressed and techniques for reducing the crest factor in MIMO-OFDM systems are investigated. Furthermore, the results of the channel measurements are presented and discussed. The work ends with a brief summary of the results.

Characterization of the Transcription Factor CcpN from Bacillus subtilis ¤ Catabolite repression, the ability to shut off non-essential alternative metabolic pathways in the presence of a preferred nutrient source, is an important property of numerous bacteria. In Bacillus subtilis, this task is taken over by the transcription factor CcpN, which can repress the transcription of the genes gapB, pckA, and sr1. In the framework of this work, the recently identified transcription factor was thoroughly investigated. It could be shown that CcpN occupies two operators at each of the three mentioned promoters and cooperatively binds to them. Furthermore, ATP and acidic pH were identified as activators and ADP as a repressor of CcpN activity using in vitro transcription experiments and CD spectroscopy. Additionally, the molecular mechanism of repression by CcpN at the three mentioned promoters was elucidated. It was shown that CcpN can bind to all promoters together with the RNA polymerase and also allows the formation of an open complex. Finally, CcpN was identified as a new, previously unknown target of CcpN and it was shown that CcpN can act as an activator there. In summary, the mode of action of CcpN was presented in detail using a comprehensive model and thus an important contribution to the understanding of catabolite repression in Bacillus subtilis was made.

Science-Based Urban Development : An Investigation at the Example of the City of Mainz ¤ Against the backdrop of the increasing importance of knowledge resources for sustainable urban development, Marie-Theres Moritz shows the effects of the title win City of Science 2011 on the further development of the science city Mainz. The starting point of the evaluation are, inter alia, concepts of science-based urban development as well as the announcement City of Science of the Donors' Association and the concept of the city of Mainz for further development as a science city. The author gives central action recommendations that may also be guiding for other science cities. The content Concepts of science-based urban development Knowledge production and innovation processes in networks Evaluation of the overall project Mainz – City of Science 2011 Effects of the title win as well as action tasks for the further development of the science city Mainz The target groups Lecturers and students of geography with a focus on regional and urban planning as well as urban marketing and sociology Interested in human/social geography, urban geography, urban research, urban planning, urban marketing The author Marie-Theres Moritz is managing director of the Gutenberg College (GLK) of the Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz (JGU). Her research focuses are in the field of science and urban development.

Legal Assurance of a High Level of Protection for Nanomaterials in REACH: Deficiency Analysis and Design Options ¤ Requirements of international law, European primary law, and the substance law of the European Union (REACH and CLP) demand a high level of protection for human health and the environment. Nanomaterials pose special challenges to this protective mandate, because their risk management is hindered by a structural uncertainty. The work first examines the question of whether the substance law sets sufficient incentives so that manufacturers and importers of nanomaterials can ensure the normatively pursued high level of protection. [...] (Source: Publisher) Quoted regulations, inter alia: Regulation (EC) No 1272/2008; Directive 2010/75/EU; Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006; Directive 98/24/EG; Directive 85/374/EWG; Directive 2001/95/EG;

Chance statt Show - Citizen Participation with Virtual Reality & Co. : Acceptance and Effect of the Visualization of Building Projects ¤ With classical plan documents or montage images, ordinary citizens can hardly assess the benefits and effects of building projects. Today, realistic and freely experienced 3D models enable spectacular applications, in which the viewer is completely immersed in the plans as if they were already realized. Arne Spieker formulates requirements for the use in citizen participation in building projects and examines the acceptance and effect of different visualization technologies among citizens. He shows that real-time simulations and virtual reality have great potential across groups, if instead of fancy image worlds, credibility and information content are in the foreground. (Publisher's text)

Sequence Stratigraphy and Facies of the Lower and Middle Bunter Sandstone in the Eastern Part of the Germanic Basin (Germany, Poland) : with 9 Tables ¤ Also includes exposures at Schönburg, Leißling, Nebra, Großwangen, Baalberge and drillings at Burg, Hakel, Halle, Farsleben, Roßleben and Wegeleben

Characterization of Influencing Factors on SERS Spectra of Low-Molecular Substances and Medical Relevant Applications of the LOC-SERS System ¤ The combination of surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) and a microfluidic lab-on-a-chip (LOC) system is a promising analytical approach for medical diagnostics. The SERS spectra contain molecular-specific information and enable the detection of molecular systems in the submicromolar range. The LOC-SERS method allows for a high throughput of single samples with low sample volume. Furthermore, the implementation of modules for sample pretreatment is feasible with low technical effort. Within this work, the various possibilities of the microfluidic SERS system are to be shown. By using the LOC-SERS system, the determination of exact measurement conditions and high reproducibility is ensured. In a basic study, the influences on SERS spectra are investigated in this work. Pyridine and monosubstituted pyridine derivatives are used as analytes. It is shown that the inclusion of quantum chemical methods is essential for accurate band assignment. It is demonstrated that quantitative analyses can be performed using LOC-SERS datasets in complex media. The antimetabolite Methotrexate (MTX) is semi-quantitatively detected in aqueous solution and artificial blood plasma, and different concentrations of MTX in real blood plasma can be clearly distinguished. Furthermore, pathogens are identified using chemometric methods based on the SERS spectra of marker molecules. The focus of the work is on the detection of low-molecular substances in complex media, such as blood plasma and bacterial suspension, as well as the identification of pathogenic mycobacteria.

Quality goal oriented architectural design and traceability for evolvable software systems ¤ Software systems are today confronted with frequent changes due to changing business processes or technologies, for example. The software and especially its architecture must enable these changes for permanent usability. During software evolution, changes can lead to a deterioration of the architecture, architecture erosion. This hinders or prevents further changes due to inconsistency or lack of program understanding. To prevent erosion, quality goals such as evolvability, performance, or usability as well as the traceability of architectural design decisions must be considered. This is often neglected. Existing design methods only insufficiently support the transition from quality goals to suitable architectural solutions due to a gap between methods of requirements engineering and architectural design. This is particularly true for evolvability and the traceability of design decisions through explicit model dependencies. This work presents a new concept, called Goal Solution Scheme, which maps quality goals over architectural principles to solution instruments through explicit dependencies. It thus helps to select architectural solutions corresponding to their influence on quality goals. The schema is specifically discussed with regard to evolvability and is embedded in a goal-oriented approach that improves and integrates established methods and concepts of requirements engineering and architectural design. This is supplemented by a traceability concept that combines a rule-based approach with techniques of information retrieval. This enables the semi-automatic creation of traceability links with specific link types and attributes for a rich semantics as well as high accuracy and hit rate. The realizability of the approach is shown in a case study of a software for mobile service robots. The EMFTrace tool was implemented as an extensible platform based on Eclipse technology to show the applicability of the concepts. It integrates design models from external CASE tools using XML technology in a common model repository, applies rules for link creation, and provides validation functions for rules and links.

Higher Education Didactics of Future Research ¤ With a foreword by Prof. Dr. Gerhard de Haan Victor Tiberius teaches and researches as a postdoc in the field of strategic management at the University of Potsdam. Future research explores possible and probable futures, evaluates desirable and undesirable future scenarios, and discusses options for shaping the future. Since the 1960s, corresponding study programs have existed worldwide. The didactic engagement with university teaching in the field of future research is still at the beginning. Victor Tiberius analyzes the existing study offers worldwide, evaluates interviews with lecturers, and develops his own didactic concept (learning goals, contents, methods, media, and control of learner success) for the study of future research. The book is aimed at future researchers in research, teaching, and practice as well as at higher education didacticians.

Surface-Controlled Mineralization of Calcium Phosphate ¤ In the present work, it could be shown that the two used amphiphiles with cholesterol as hydrophobic block, are good templates for the mineralization of calcium phosphate at the water/air interface. By means of infrared reflection-absorption spectroscopy (IRRAS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDXS), electron diffraction (SAED) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), the successful mineralization of calcium phosphate for both amphiphiles at the water/air interface could be proven. It could also be shown that the phase behavior of the two amphiphiles and the crystal phases formed during the mineralization of calcium phosphate are not identical. Both amphiphiles thus exert a different influence on the course of mineralization. At CHOL-HEM, both after 3 h and after 5 h, octacalcium phosphate (OCP) could be proven as the only crystal phase by means of XPS, SAED, HRTEM and EDXS …

Spielerisch selbstbestimmt : rechtskonforme Einwilligungserklärungen in Zeiten ubiquitärer Digitalisierung ¤ Auch nach den Vorgaben der DSGVO ist die Einwilligungserklärung das zentrale Ausübungsinstrument datenschutzrechtlicher Selbstbestimmung. Allerdings wird das Versprechen einer freiwilligen, selbstbestimmten und allem voran informierten Einwilligung im Kontext der voranschreitenden Vernetzung und Verdatung der Gesellschaft vermehrt kritisch beäugt. Gerade aber mit Blick auf die zunehmende Ökonomisierung personenbezogener Daten sollten die Vorgaben des Datenschutzrechts nicht als Antagonist der datengetriebenen Wirtschaft identifiziert werden, sondern vielmehr als Innovationsmotor bei der Ausgestaltung kreativer Einwilligungsprozesse. Vor diesem Hintergrund analysiert die vorliegende Arbeit die nunmehr geltenden grund- und datenschutzrechtlichen Anforderungen an die Einwilligungserklärung und untersucht erste Lösungsansätze zur Gewährleistung einer effektiven, digitalisierten Selbstbestimmung. / »Playfully Self-Determined. Legally Compliant Declarations of Consent in Times of Ubiquitous Digitization« -- Consent is increasingly called into question in the context of digitization. Rather, it should be questioned whether the digitized declaration of consent can contribute to the realization of the constitutionally based data disposition.
